简介

Intro

Lec 1 简介

Lec 1 Introduction

教授：欢迎再次来到 18.01。今天我们开始学习第一单元，这是一个极富想象力的标题。它的主题是差异化。

Professor: So, again welcome to 18.01. We’re getting started today with what we’re calling Unit One, a highly imaginative title. And it’s differentiation.

那么，首先让我简单介绍一下接下来几周的内容。今天的主要话题是导数是什么。我们将从几个不同的角度来探讨这个问题，第一个角度是几何解释。今天我们将花大部分时间来讨论这个话题。然后，我们还将讨论导数的物理解释。

So, let me first tell you, briefly, what’s in store in the next couple of weeks. The main topic today is what is a derivative. And, we’re going to look at this from several different points of view, and the first one is the geometric interpretation. That’s what we’ll spend most of today on. And then, we’ll also talk about a physical interpretation of what a derivative is.

然后还有一点，我想这也许就是为什么微积分如此基础，为什么我们总是在大多数科学和工程学院从它开始，这是因为导数对所有测量都很重要。所以这几乎意味着每个地方。这意味着在科学、工程、经济学、政治学等。民意调查、许多商业应用，几乎所有领域。

And then there’s going to be something else which I guess is maybe the reason why Calculus is so fundamental, and why we always start with it in most science and engineering schools, which is the importance of derivatives, of this, to all measurements. So that means pretty much every place. That means in science, in engineering, in economics, in political science, etc. Polling, lots of commercial applications, just about everything.

现在，这就是我们要开始的内容，然后我们在本单元中要做的另一件事是，我们将解释如何区分任何事物。所以，如何区分任何函数。这有点难以理解，但让我举个例子。

Now, that’s what we’ll be getting started with, and then there’s another thing that we’re gonna do in this unit, which is we’re going to explain how to differentiate anything. So, how to differentiate any function you know. And that’s kind of a tall order, but let me just give you an example.

如果你想求导数，我们今天将会看到一些复杂函数的导数符号，例如 e ^ x arctan x。我们将在本单元结束时解决这个问题。好吗？任何你能想到的，任何你能写下来的东西，我们都可以对其进行区分。好的，这就是我们要做的，今天，正如我所说，我们将把大部分时间花在这个几何解释上。

If you want to take the derivative this we’ll see today is the notation for the derivative of something of some messy function like e ^ x arctan x. We’ll work this out by the end of this unit. All right? Anything you can think of, anything you can write down, we can differentiate it. All right, so that’s what we’re gonna do, and today, as I said, we’re gonna spend most of our time on this geometric interpretation.

那么我们就从这里开始吧。

So let’s begin with that.

几何问题

Geometric Problem

现在我们来看一下导数的几何解释。我们要做的就是求某个函数图像在某个点的切线，也就是 (x_0, y_0)。这就是我们在这里要解决的问题。好了，这就是我们的问题，现在让我向你展示解决方案。那么，让我们绘制函数图像。这是它的图像。

So here we go with the geometric interpretation of derivatives. And, what we’re going to do is just ask the geometric problem of finding the tangent line to some graph of some function at some point. Which is to say (x_0, y_0). So that’s the problem that we’re addressing here. Alright, so here’s our problem, and now let me show you the solution. So, well, let’s graph the function. Here’s its graph.

这是某个点。好吧，也许我应该把它画得稍微低一点。所以这是点 P。也许它在点 x_0 的上方。顺便说一下，x_0 应该是 x_0。那是 x 轴上的某个固定位置。现在，为了完成这个伟大的壮举，我将使用另一种颜色的粉笔。红色怎么样？好的。所以它在这里。这是切线，嗯，不是很直。足够接近了。

Here’s some point. All right, maybe I should draw it just a bit lower. So here’s a point P. Maybe it’s above the point x_0. x_0, by the way, this was supposed to be an x_0. That was some fixed place on the x axis. And now, in order to perform this mighty feat, I will use another color of chalk. How about red? OK. So here it is. There’s the tangent line, well, not quite straight. Close enough.

好吧？我做到了。这就是几何问题。我实现了我想要做的事情，这是一个很有趣的问题，但不幸的是我无法在这堂课上为你解答，那就是，我是怎么做到的？也就是说，我是如何从物理上知道如何画出这条切线的？但这就是几何问题。我们将其形象化。我们可以在大脑的某个地方弄清楚。它会发生。

All right? I did it. That’s the geometric problem. I achieved what I wanted to do, and it’s kind of an interesting question, which unfortunately I can’t solve for you in this class, which is, how did I do that? That is, how physically did I manage to know what to do to draw this tangent line? But that’s what geometric problems are like. We visualize it. We can figure it out somewhere in our brains. It happens.

我们现在的任务是找出如何进行分析，让机器也能像我画这条切线一样好地完成它。那么，我们在高中学到了什么是切线？

And the task that we have now is to figure out how to do it analytically, to do it in a way that a machine could just as well as I did in drawing this tangent line. So, what did we learn in high school about what a tangent line is?

嗯，切线有一个方程，任何通过一点的直线都有方程 y y_0 等于 m，即斜率乘以 x x_0。所以这是那条线的方程，现在我们需要两条信息来计算这条线是什么。第一条是点。那就是那个点 P。

Well, a tangent line has an equation, and any line through a point has the equation y y_0 is equal to m, the slope, times x x_0. So here’s the equation for that line, and now there are two pieces of information that we’re going to need to work out what the line is. The first one is the point. That’s that point P there.

为了指定 P，给定 x，我们需要知道 y 的水平，当然就是 f(x_0)。这不是微积分问题，但无论如何，这是该过程中非常重要的一部分。所以这是我们需要知道的第一件事。我们需要知道的第二件事是斜率。这就是这个数字 m。在微积分中，我们为它起了另一个名字。

And to specify P, given x, we need to know the level of y, which is of course just f(x_0). That’s not a calculus problem, but anyway that’s a very important part of the process. So that’s the first thing we need to know. And the second thing we need to know is the slope. And that’s this number m. And in calculus we have another name for it.

我们称它为 f 是 x_0 的素数。即 f 的导数。这就是微积分部分。这是棘手的部分，也是我们现在要讨论的部分。

We call it f prime of x_0. Namely, the derivative of f. So that’s the calculus part. That’s the tricky part, and that’s the part that we have to discuss now.

切线

Tangent Lines

因此，为了在这里明确说明，我将做出一个定义，即 f '(x_0)，即 f 在 x_0 处的导数，是 y = f(x) 在点处的切线的斜率，我们就把它称为 P 吧。好吗？

So just to make that explicit here, I’m going to make a definition, which is that f ’(x_0),which is known as the derivative, of f, at x_0, is the slope of the tangent line to y = f(x) at the point, let’s just call it P. All right?

就是这样，但我仍然没有取得任何进展，无法更好地弄清楚如何画出这条线。所以我必须说一些更具体的东西，因为我希望能够弄清楚这些数字是什么。我必须弄清楚这个数字 m 是多少。

So, that’s what it is, but still I haven’t made any progress in figuring out any better how I drew that line. So I have to say something that’s more concrete, because I want to be able to cook up what these numbers are. I have to figure out what this number m is.

对此的一种思考方式，让我试一试，我当然会认为在某种非微积分部分中，我知道通过某个点的直线是什么。所以我知道这个方程。

And one way of thinking about that, let me just try this, so I certainly am taking for granted that in sort of non calculus part that I know what a line through a point is. So I know this equation.

但另一种可能性可能是，这条线，我怎么知道呢，不幸的是，我没有把它画得很直，但它就在那里，我怎么知道这条橙线不是切线，而另一条线是切线？嗯，其实不是那么明显，但我要稍微描述一下。事实并非如此。这个东西在其他地方相交，也就是这个点 Q。

But another possibility might be, this line here, how do I know well, unfortunately, I didn’t draw it quite straight, but there it is how do I know that this orange line is not a tangent line, but this other line is a tangent line? Well, it’s actually not so obvious, but I’m gonna describe it a little bit. It’s not really the fact. this thing crosses at some other place, which is this point Q.

但事实上，事物在两处相交并不重要，因为直线可以弯曲，曲线也可以弯曲，而且可以来回相交多次。这不是切线的区别所在。所以我必须以某种方式掌握这一点，我首先要用语言来做到这一点。

But it’s not really the fact that the thing crosses at two place, because the line could be wiggly, the curve could be wiggly, and it could cross back and forth a number of times. That’s not what distinguishes the tangent line. So I’m gonna have to somehow grasp this, and I’ll first do it in language.

其思想如下：如果你取这条橙色线，也就是割线，并认为 Q 点离 P 点越来越近，那么这条线的斜率就会越来越接近红线的斜率。如果我们把它画得足够近，那么它就是正确的线。

And it’s the following idea: it’s that if you take this orange line, which is called a secant line, and you think of the point Q as getting closer and closer to P, then the slope of that line will get closer and closer to the slope of the red line. And if we draw it close enough, then that’s gonna be the correct line.

所以当我画出第一条线时，我脑子里确实在想这件事。这就是我首先要表达的方式。现在，切线等于所谓的割线 PQ 的极限，因为 Q 趋向于 P。在这里，我们认为 P 是固定的，Q 是可变的。好吗？

So that’s really what I did, sort of in my brain when I drew that first line. And so that’s the way I’m going to articulate it first. Now, so the tangent line is equal to the limit of so called secant lines PQ, as Q tends to P. And here we’re thinking of P as being fixed and Q as variable. All right?

再次强调，这仍然是几何讨论，但现在我们将能够将符号和公式用于此计算。我们将能够在任何示例中推导出公式。让我们开始吧。首先，我将再次写出这些点 P 和 Q。因此，我们可能将 P 放在这里，将 Q 放在这里。我正在考虑穿过它们的这条线。我猜它是橙色的，所以我们将其保留为橙色。

Again, this is still the geometric discussion, but now we’re gonna be able to put symbols and formulas to this computation. And we’ll be able to work out formulas in any example. So let’s do that. So first of all, I’m gonna write out these points P and Q again. So maybe we’ll put P here and Q here. And I’m thinking of this line through them. I guess it was orange, so we’ll leave it as orange.

好的。

All right.

坡

Slope

现在我要计算它的斜率。因此，我们将分两步逐步完成。这些步骤将向我们介绍微积分（包括多元微积分）中使用的基本符号。因此，使用的第一个符号是，您想象这是下面的 x 轴，这是 x_0，即点 P 正下方的位置。我们在这里移动一段水平距离，用 delta x 表示。

And now I want to compute its slope. So this, gradually, we’ll do this in two steps. And these steps will introduce us to the basic notations which are used throughout calculus, including multi variable calculus, across the board. So the first notation that’s used is you imagine here’s the x axis underneath, and here’s the x_0, the location directly below the point P. And we’re traveling here a horizontal distance which is denoted by delta x.

这就是所谓的 delta x。我们也可以称它为 x 的变化。这是我们要测量的一件事，以便得到这条线 PQ 的斜率。另一件事是高度。这就是这里的距离，我们将其表示为 delta f，即 f 的变化。然后，斜率就是比率，delta f / delta x。所以这是割线的斜率。

So that’s delta x, so called. And we could also call it the change in x. So that’s one thing we want to measure in order to get the slope of this line PQ. And the other thing is this height. So that’s this distance here, which we denote delta f, which is the change in f. And then, the slope is just the ratio, delta f / delta x. So this is the slope of the secant.

我刚才在这里描述的这个极限不仅适用于整条线本身，也特别适用于它的斜率。我们这样写，就是当 delta x 趋于 0 时的极限。这就是我们的斜率。所以这是切线的斜率。好的。

And the process I just described over here with this limit applies not just to the whole line itself, but also in particular to its slope. And the way we write that is the limit as delta x goes to 0. And that’s going to be our slope. So this is the slope of the tangent line. OK.

现在，这仍然有点笼统，我想在这里制定一个更实用的形式，一个更好的公式。为了做到这一点，我将在这里更明确地写出 delta f，即分子。f 的变化，所以请记住点 P 是点 (x_0, f(x_0))。好的，这就是我们得到的点公式。

Now, This is still a little general, and I want to work out a more usable form here, a better formula for this. And in order to do that, I’m gonna write delta f, the numerator more explicitly here. The change in f, so remember that the point P is the point (x_0, f(x_0)). All right, that’s what we got for the formula for the point.

为了计算这些距离，特别是这里的垂直距离，我还必须得到 Q 的公式。所以如果这个水平距离是 delta x，那么这个位置就是 x_0 + delta x。所以这个点上方的点有一个公式，即 x_0 加 delta x，f，这是一个完整的 x_0 加 delta x。好的，这就是点 Q 的公式。

And in order to compute these distances and in particular the vertical distance here, I’m gonna have to get a formula for Q as well. So if this horizontal distance is delta x, then this location is x_0 + delta x. And so the point above that point has a formula, which is x_0 plus delta x, f of and this is a mouthful x_0 plus delta x. All right, so there’s the formula for the point Q.

这是点 P 的公式。现在我可以为导数写出一个不同的公式，如下所示：所以这个 f'(x_0)，它与 ​​m 相同，将是当 delta x 趋于 0 时 f 变化的极限，那么 f 的变化就是这里上限点的 f 值，即 x_0 + delta x，减去它在下限点 P 的值，即 f(x_0)，除以 delta x。

Here’s the formula for the point P. And now I can write a different formula for the derivative, which is the following: so this f’(x_0),which is the same as m, is going to be the limit as delta x goes to 0 of the change in f, well the change in f is the value of f at the upper point here, which is x_0 + delta x, and minus its value at the lower point P, which is f(x_0), divided by delta x.

好的，这就是公式。我要把它放在一个小框里，因为这是迄今为止最重要的公式，我们用它来推导几乎所有其他的东西。这就是我们能够计算这些数字的方法。让我们举个例子。

All right, so this is the formula. I’m going to put this in a little box, because this is by far the most important formula today, which we use to derive pretty much everything else. And this is the way that we’re going to be able to compute these numbers. So let’s do an example.

例子

Example

这个例子，我们称之为例子一。我们取函数 f(x)，也就是 1/x

This example, we’ll call this example one. We’ll take the function f(x),which is 1/x

这个方程足够复杂，所以答案很有趣，也足够简单，我们可以很快计算出导数。那么我们在这里要做什么呢？我们要做的就是把这个公式代入这个函数中。这就是我们要做的，从视觉上看，我们要完成的是以某种方式取双曲线，在双曲线上取一个点，然后找出一条切线。

That’s sufficiently complicated to have an interesting answer, and sufficiently straightforward that we can compute the derivative fairly quickly. So what is it that we’re gonna do here? All we’re going to do is we’re going to plug in this formula here for that function. That’s all we’re going to do, and visually what we’re accomplishing is somehow to take the hyperbola, and take a point on the hyperbola, and figure out some tangent line.

这就是我们这样做的目的。所以我们是在几何上实现这一点，但我们将以代数方式实现。因此，首先，我们考虑这个差值 delta f / delta x 并写出它的公式。所以我必须有一个位置。所以我将再次将其置于这个点 x_0 之上，这是一般点。我们将进行一般计算。

That’s what we’re accomplishing when we do that. So we’re accomplishing this geometrically but we’ll be doing it algebraically. So first, we consider this difference delta f / delta x and write out its formula. So I have to have a place. So I’m gonna make it again above this point x_0, which is the general point. We’ll make the general calculation.

因此，当我们向右移动 f(x) 时，顶部的 f 值就是这个，所以我只是从这里读出，从这里读出。公式中，我得到的第一个值是 1 / (x_0 + delta x)。这是左边的项。减去 1 / x_0，这是右边的项。然后我必须用 delta x 除以它。好的，这是我们的表达式。顺便说一下，它有一个名字。

So the value of f at the top, when we move to the right by f(x), so I just read off from this, read off from here. The formula, the first thing I get here is 1 / (x_0 + delta x). That’s the left hand term. Minus 1 / x_0, that’s the right hand term. And then I have to divide that by delta x. OK, so here’s our expression. And by the way this has a name.

这个东西叫做差商。它相当复杂，因为分子总是有差。而分母实际上是一个差，因为它是右边的值和左边的值之间的差。

This thing is called a difference quotient. It’s pretty complicated, because there’s always a difference in the numerator. And in disguise, the denominator is a difference, because it’s the difference between the value on the right side and the value on the left side here.

代数

Algebra

好的，现在我们要用一些代数来简化它。让我们看一下。这等于，让我们继续下一个级别。

OK, so now we’re going to simplify it by some algebra. So let’s just take a look. So this is equal to, let’s continue on the next level here.

这等于 1 / delta x 乘以 1。我要做的就是将它放在一个公分母上。因此，公分母是 (x_0 + delta x) * x_0。因此，在第一个表达式的分子中，我有 x_0，在第二个表达式中，我有 x_0 + delta x。因此，这与我之前在分子中得到的相同，即分解出这个分母。

This is equal to 1 / delta x times. All I’m going to do is put it over a common denominator. So the common denominator is (x_0 + delta x) * x_0. And so in the numerator for the first expressions I have x_0, and for the second expression I have x_0 + delta x. So this is the same thing as I had in the numerator before, factoring out this denominator.

这里我将分子放入更合适的形式。现在有两个基本的消去。第一个是 x_0 和 x_0 消去，所以我们有这个。然后第二步是这两个表达式消去，分子和分母。现在我们有了一个可以利用的消去。所以我们把它写在这里。

And here I put that numerator into this more amenable form. And now there are two basic cancellations. The first one is that x_0 and x_0 cancel, so we have this. And then the second step is that these two expressions cancel, the numerator and the denominator. Now we have a cancellation that we can make use of. So we’ll write that under here.

这等于 1/x_0 加上 delta x 乘以 x_0。最后一步是当 delta x 趋向于 0 时取极限，现在我们可以这样做了。以前我们做不到。为什么？因为分子和分母得出的结果是 0/0。但现在我已经进行了这个取消，我可以求极限了。

And this is equals 1 over x_0 plus delta x times x_0. And then the very last step is to take the limit as delta x tends to 0, and now we can do it. Before we couldn’t do it. Why? Because the numerator and the denominator gave us 0 / 0. But now that I’ve made this cancellation, I can pass to the limit.

所发生的一切就是我将这个 delta x 设置为 0，然后得到 1/x_0^2。这就是答案。好的，换句话说，我在这里展示的是 f'(x_0) = 1/x_0^2。现在，让我们稍微看一下图表，检查一下它的合理性，好吗？这里发生的事情是，首先它是负数。它小于 0，这是一件好事。

And all that happens is I set this delta x to 0, and I get 1/x_0^2. So that’s the answer. All right, so in other words what I’ve shown let me put it up here is that f’(x_0) = 1/x_0^2. Now, let’s look at the graph just a little bit to check this for plausibility, all right? What’s happening here is, first of all it’s negative. It’s less than 0, which is a good thing.

你看，斜率是负的。这是你能做的最简单的检查。我想指出的第二件事是，当 x 趋向无穷大时，当我们向右移动得越远，斜率就越小。所以当 x_0 趋向无穷大时，斜率就越小。

You see that slope there is negative. That’s the simplest check that you could make. And the second thing that I would just like to point out is that as x goes to infinity, that as we go farther to the right, it gets less and less steep. So as x_0 goes to infinity, less and less steep.

所以这里也是一致的，当 x_0 非常大时，这个数字的幅度会越来越小，尽管它总是负数。它总是向下倾斜。好吧，我已经填满了板子。所以也许我应该停下来问一两个问题。是吗？学生：教授：所以问题是再次解释这个限制过程。所以这里的公式基本上是我们有两个数字。

So that’s also consistent here, when x_0 is very large, this is a smaller and smaller number in magnitude, although it’s always negative. It’s always sloping down. All right, so I’ve managed to fill the boards. So maybe I should stop for a question or two. Yes? Student: Professor: So the question is to explain again this limiting process. So the formula here is we have basically two numbers.

换句话说，为什么当 delta x 趋向于 0 时，这个表达式等于 1 / x_0^2 ？让我通过为 x_0 插入一个数字来说明这一点，以使其更明确。好吧，例如，让我在这里为 x_0 插入数字 3。那么它就是 1/3 加上 delta x 乘以 3。这就是我们得到的情况。

So in other words, why is it that this expression, when delta x tends to 0, is equal to 1 / x_0^2 ? Let me illustrate it by sticking in a number for x_0 to make it more explicit. All right, so for instance, let me stick in here for x_0 the number 3. Then it’s 1 over 3 plus delta x times 3. That’s the situation that we’ve got.

现在的问题是，当这个数字越来越小，直到接近 0 时会发生什么？实际上，我们可以做的就是在那里代入 0，然后得到分母为 3 加 0 乘以 3，分子为 1。因此，它趋向于 1/9（除以 3^2）。这就是我在这里用这个额外的数字表达的意思。还有其他问题吗？是的。

And now the question is what happens as this number gets smaller and smaller and smaller, and gets to be practically 0? Well, literally what we can do is just plug in 0 there, and you get 3 plus 0 times 3 in the denominator. 1 in the numerator. So this tends to 1/9 (over 3^2). And that’s what I’m saying in general with this extra number here. Other questions? Yes.

学生：教授：那么问题是这一步和这一步之间发生了什么，对吧？解释一下这一步。好吧，这有两个部分。第一个是这个 delta x，它位于分母中，我把它分解到了前面。所以括号里的内容应该与另一个表达式的分子中的内容相同。

Student: Professor: So the question is what happened between this step and this step, right? Explain this step here. Alright, so there were two parts to that. The first is this delta x which is sitting in the denominator, I factored all the way out front. And so what’s in the parentheses is supposed to be the same as what’s in the numerator of this other expression.

然后，在这样做的同时，我把那个表达式，也就是两个分数的差，用一个共同的分母来表示。所以在这里的分母中，你可以看到两个分数分母的乘积。然后我算出了分子应该是多少，实际上没有。还有其他问题吗？好的。

And then, at the same time as doing that, I put that expression, which is the difference of two fractions, I expressed it with a common denominator. So in the denominator here, you see the product of the denominators of the two fractions. And then I just figured out what the numerator had to be without really. Other questions? OK.

微积分变得困难

Calculus Made Hard

因此我认为，总体而言，微积分名声不好，但实际上它比大多数东西都简单。

So I claim that on the whole, calculus gets a bad rap, that it’s actually easier than most things.

但人们认为微积分更难。所以我真的有责任在这里告诉你们微积分变得更难的故事。所以我们必须让事情变得更难，因为这是我们的工作。这实际上是大多数人在微积分中所做的，也是微积分名声不好的原因。所以秘诀在于，当人们问微积分问题时，他们通常会结合上下文来问。

But there’s a perception that it’s harder. And so I really have a duty to give you the calculus made harder story here. So we have to make things harder, because that’s our job. And this is actually what most people do in calculus, and it’s the reason why calculus has a bad reputation. So the secret is that when people ask problems in calculus, they generally ask them in context.

还有许多其他事情要做。所以问题中的小部分，也就是微积分，其实相当常规，必须单独解决。但其余部分，都依赖于你从小学到高中在这个阶段学到的数学知识。所以这就是复杂性。所以现在我们要做一些稍微难一点的微积分。

And there are many, many other things going on. And so the little piece of the problem which is calculus is actually fairly routine and has to be isolated and gotten through. But all the rest of it, relies on everything else you learned in mathematics up to this stage, from grade school through high school. So that’s the complication. So now we’re going to do a little bit of calculus made hard.

文字问题

Word Problem

通过讨论一个文字问题。

By talking about a word problem.

我们只能提出一种应用题，因为我们讨论的都是几何观点。到目前为止，这些是我们可以提出的唯一应用题。所以我们要做的就是提出这样的问题。求出由轴和 y = 1/x 的切线围成的三角形的面积。好的，这是一道几何题。让我画一张图。

We only have one sort of word problem that we can pose, because all we’ve talked about is this geometry point of view. So far those are the only kinds of word problems we can pose. So what we’re gonna do is just pose such a problem. So find the areas of triangles, enclosed by the axes and the tangent to y = 1/x. OK, so that’s a geometry problem. And let me draw a picture of it.

它实际上与示例一中的图片相同。我们只考虑第一象限。这是我们的形状。好吧，它是双曲线。这也许是我们的一条切线，它像这样进来。然后我们试图找到这里的这个区域。好的，这就是我们的问题。那么为什么它与微积分有关？

It’s practically the same as the picture for example one. We only consider the first quadrant. Here’s our shape. All right, it’s the hyperbola. And here’s maybe one of our tangent lines, which is coming in like this. And then we’re trying to find this area here. Right, so there’s our problem. So why does it have to do with calculus?

这和微积分有关，因为其中有一条切线，所以我们需要做一些微积分来回答这个问题。但正如你所看到的，微积分是最简单的部分。所以让我们开始解决这个问题吧。首先，我要标记一些东西。当然，要记住的一件重要的事情是曲线是 y = 1/x。这是完全合理的。

It has to do with calculus because there’s a tangent line in it, so we’re gonna need to do some calculus to answer this question. But as you’ll see, the calculus is the easy part. So let’s get started with this problem. First of all, I’m gonna label a few things. And one important thing to remember of course, is that the curve is y = 1/x. That’s perfectly reasonable to do.

此外，我们还要计算三角形的面积，你可以问问自己，从什么角度来计算？好吧，我们必须选择一个点并给它命名。因为我们需要一个数字，所以我们要做的不仅仅是几何。我们必须像以前一样做一些分析。

And also, we’re gonna calculate the areas of the triangles, and you could ask yourself, in terms of what? Well, we’re gonna have to pick a point and give it a name. And since we need a number, we’re gonna have to do more than geometry. We’re gonna have to do some of this analysis just as we’ve done before.

所以我要选择一个点，与我们之前所做的标记一致，我要将其称为 (x_0, y_0)。所以这几乎是成功的一半，有符号，x 和 y 表示变量，x_0 和 y_0 表示特定点。现在，一旦你看到你有这些标签，我希望执行以下操作是合理的。

So I’m gonna pick a point and, consistent with the labeling we’ve done before, I’m gonna to call it (x_0, y_0). So that’s almost half the battle, having notations, x and y for the variables, and x_0 and y_0, for the specific point. Now, once you see that you have these labelings, I hope it’s reasonable to do the following.

首先，这是点 x_0，这里是点 y_0。这是我们在图形中常用到的。为了计算出这个三角形的面积，很明显我们应该找到底边，也就是我们应该找到这里的这个位置。我们应该找到高边，所以我们需要在那里找到那个值。让我们开始吧。

So first of all, this is the point x_0, and over here is the point y_0. That’s something that we’re used to in graphs. And in order to figure out the area of this triangle, it’s pretty clear that we should find the base, which is that we should find this location here. And we should find the height, so we need to find that value there. Let’s go ahead and do it.

那么我们该怎么做呢？好吧，让我们来看看。那么我们需要做什么呢？我声称只有一个微积分步骤，我将在这里为这条切线画一个星号。我必须了解切线是什么。一旦我弄清楚了切线是什么，剩下的问题就不再是微积分了。我们需要的只是那个斜率。

So how are we going to do this? Well, so let’s just take a look. So what is it that we need to do? I claim that there’s only one calculus step, and I’m gonna put a star here for this tangent line. I have to understand what the tangent line is. Once I’ve figured out what the tangent line is, the rest of the problem is no longer calculus. It’s just that slope that we need.

那么切线公式是什么呢？把它写在这里。它将等于 y y_0，这是我们已经计算过的魔法数字。它在那边的盒子里。它是 1/x_0^2 ( x x_0)。所以这是这个问题中唯一的微积分。但现在我们还没有完成。我们必须完成它。我们必须找出所有这些剩余的量，这样我们才能算出面积。

So what’s the formula for the tangent line? Put that over here. it’s going to be y y_0 is equal to, and here’s the magic number, we already calculated it. It’s in the box over there. It’s 1/x_0^2 ( x x_0). So this is the only bit of calculus in this problem. But now we’re not done. We have to finish it. We have to figure out all the rest of these quantities so we can figure out the area.

好的。那么我们该怎么做呢？好吧，要找到这个点，它有一个名字。我们要找到所谓的 x 截距。这是我们要做的第一件事。因此，要做到这一点，我们需要做的是找到这条水平线与那条对角线的交点。x 截距的方程是 y = 0。所以我们代入 y = 0，这就是这条水平线，然后我们找到这个点。

All right. So how do we do that? Well, to find this point, this has a name. We’re gonna find the so called x intercept. That’s the first thing we’re going to do. So to do that, what we need to do is to find where this horizontal line meets that diagonal line. And the equation for the x intercept is y = 0. So we plug in y = 0, that’s this horizontal line, and we find this point.

那么让我们把它代入星号中。我们得到 0 减，哦，还有一件事我们需要知道。我们知道 y0 是 f(x_0)，f(x) 是 1/x，所以这个是 1/x_0。这等于 1/x_0^2。这是 x，这是 x_0。好吧，为了找到这个 x 值，我必须将一个方程代入另一个方程。这样就简单了一点。

So let’s do that into star. We get 0 minus, oh one other thing we need to know. We know that y0 is f(x_0),and f(x) is 1/x,so this thing is 1/x_0. And that’s equal to 1/x_0^2. And here’s x, and here’s x_0. All right, so in order to find this x value, I have to plug in one equation into the other. So this simplifies a bit.

这是 x/x_0^2。这是加上 1/x_0，因为 x_0 和 x0^2 稍微抵消了。因此，如果我将其放在另一边，我得到 x / x_0^2 等于 2 / x_0。如果我再乘以 x_0^2，那么这就是它的含义，如果我乘以 x_0^2，我得到 x = 2x_0。好的，所以我声称我们刚刚计算的这个点是 2x_0。现在，我快完成了。

This is x/x_0^2. And this is plus 1/x_0 because the x_0 and x0^2 cancel somewhat. And so if I put this on the other side, I get x / x_0^2 is equal to 2 / x_0. And if I then multiply through so that’s what this implies and if I multiply through by x_0^2 I get x = 2x_0. OK, so I claim that this point we’ve just calculated, it’s 2x_0. Now, I’m almost done.

对称

Symmetry

我需要得到另一个。我需要把这个放在这儿。现在我要用一个非常大的捷径来做到这一点。所以 y 截距的捷径是使用对称性。好吧，我声称我可以盯着这个，我可以看看那个，我知道 y 截距的公式。它等于 2y_0。好的。这就是那个。

I need to get the other one. I need to get this one up here. Now I’m gonna use a very big shortcut to do that. So the shortcut to the y intercept is to use symmetry. All right, I claim I can stare at this and I can look at that, and I know the formula for the y intercept. It’s equal to 2y_0. All right. That’s what that one is.

所以这个是 2y_0。我知道这个的原因如下：这是这种情况的对称性，它不是完全直接的。它是一种围绕对角线的镜像对称。它涉及 (x, y) 与 (y, x) 的交换；因此交换 x 和 y 的角色。

So this one is 2y_0. And the reason I know this is the following: so here’s the symmetry of the situation, which is not completely direct. It’s a kind of mirror symmetry around the diagonal. It involves the exchange of (x, y) with (y, x); so trading the roles of x and y.

因此，我使用的对称性是，任何涉及 x 和 y 的公式，如果我将所有 x 交换为 y，将所有 y 交换为 x，那么我就会得到一个相反的正确公式。因此，如果我看到 ay 的每个地方都将其改为 x，看到 x 的每个地方都将其改为 ay，那么就会发生转换。

So the symmetry that I’m using is that any formula I get that involves x’s and y’s, if I trade all the x’s and replace them by y’s and trade all the y’s and replace them by x’s, then I’ll have a correct formula on the other way. So if everywhere I see a y I make it an x, and everywhere I see an x I make it a y, the switch will take place.

那么为什么会这样呢？这只是这个方程的一个偶然。这是因为，所以对称性得到了解释。这个方程是 y = 1/x。但如果我乘以 x，这与 xy = 1 是一样的，这与 x = 1/y 是一样的。所以这里 x 和 y 被反转了。

So why is that? That’s just an accident of this equation. That’s because, so the symmetry explained. is that the equation is y = 1/x. But that’s the same thing as xy = 1, if I multiply through by x, which is the same thing as x = 1/y. So here’s where the x and the y get reversed.

好的，现在如果你不相信这个解释，你也可以通过将 x = 0 代入星形方程来获得 y 截距。好吗？我们代入 y = 0 并得到了 x 值。你可以用另一种方式类似地做同样的事情。好的，我几乎完成了几何问题，现在让我们完成它。好吧，让我等一秒钟再完成它。

OK now if you don’t trust this explanation, you can also get the y intercept by plugging x = 0 into the equation star. OK? We plugged y = 0 in and we got the x value. And you can do the same thing analogously the other way. All right so I’m almost done with the geometry problem, and let’s finish it off now. Well, let me hold off for one second before I finish it off.

单变量微积分

One Variable Calculus

我想说的是再说一点。我认为这是微积分中最难的部分。微积分最难的部分是我们称之为单变量微积分，但我们很乐意一次处理四个或五个变量，或任何数量的变量。在这个问题中，我有一个 x、ay、一个 x_0 和一个 y_0。这已经是四个不同的东西，它们之间有各种关系。

What I’d like to say is just make one more tiny remark. And this is the hardest part of calculus in my opinion. So the hardest part of calculus is that we call it one variable calculus, but we’re perfectly happy to deal with four variables at a time or five, or any number. In this problem, I had an x, a y, an x_0 and a y_0. That’s already four different things that have various relationships between them.

当然，我们对它们进行的运算是代数运算，当我们进行导数运算时，我们只考虑所谓的单变量微积分。但实际上可能存在数百万个变量。这就是让事情变得复杂的原因，你必须习惯这一点。

Of course the manipulations we do with them are algebraic, and when we’re doing the derivatives we just consider what’s known as one variable calculus. But really there are millions of variable floating around potentially. So that’s what makes things complicated, and that’s something that you have to get used to.

现在，还有更微妙的事情，我认为许多教授或使用这门学科的人都没有意识到这一点，因为他们已经进入了这门语言，并且对它非常熟悉，以至于他们甚至没有注意到这种混淆。我们处理这些变量的方式有些故意马虎。原因很简单。这里已经有四个变量了。

Now there’s something else which is more subtle, and that I think many people who teach the subject or use the subject aren’t aware, because they’ve already entered into the language and they’re so comfortable with it that they don’t even notice this confusion. There’s something deliberately sloppy about the way we deal with these variables. The reason is very simple. There are already four variables here.

我不想为变量创建六个或八个名称。但实际上在这个问题中大约有八个。我只是把它们从你身边溜走了。那么为什么呢？请注意，我第一次得到 y_0 的公式时，就是这个点。所以我在这里插入的 y_0 的公式来自曲线方程。

I don’t wanna create six names for variables or eight names for variables. But really in this problem there were about eight. I just slipped them by you. So why is that? Well notice that the first time that I got a formula for y_0 here, it was this point. And so the formula for y_0, which I plugged in right here, was from the equation of the curve.

Y_0 = 1 / x_0。第二次做的时候，我没有用 y = 1/x。我在这里用了这个等式，所以这不是 y = 1/x。这样做是错误的。如果你对这些公式一头雾水，而且没有注意它们在图表上的位置，那么很容易犯这个错误。

Y_0 = 1 / x_0. The second time I did it, I did not use y = 1/x. I used this equation here, so this is not y = 1/x. That’s the wrong thing to do. It’s an easy mistake to make if the formulas are all a blur to you and you’re not paying attention to where they are on the diagram.

你看，那里的 x 截距计算涉及这条水平线与这条对角线的交点，而 y = 0 代表这条线。所以，不严谨的地方在于 y 代表了两个不同的东西。我们经常这样做，因为不这样做会更加复杂。对我们来说，在计算过程中，允许自己灵活地改变这个字母所扮演的角色要方便得多。

You see that x intercept calculation there involved where this horizontal line met this diagonal line, and y = 0 represented this line here. So the sloppiness is that y means two different things. And we do this constantly because it’s way, way more complicated not to do it. It’s much more convenient for us to allow ourselves the flexibility to change the role that this letter plays in the middle of a computation.

同样，如果我后来用这种更直接的方法，对于 y 截距，我会将 x 设置为 0。那将是一条垂直线，即 x = 0。但我这样做时并没有改变字母 x，因为那对我们来说是一种浪费。所以这是发生的主要混淆之一。

And similarly, later on, if I had done this by this more straightforward method, for the y intercept, I would have set x equal to 0. That would have been this vertical line, which is x = 0. But I didn’t change the letter x when I did that, because that would be a waste for us. So this is one of the main confusions that happens.

如果你能保持头脑清醒，情况就会好很多，正如我所说，这是其中的一个复杂之处。好吧，现在让我们解决这个问题。让我最后得到这个面积。所以，实际上我就在这里把它解决掉。三角形的面积是，嗯，它是底乘以高。底是 2x_0，高是 2y_0，再乘以它的一半。

If you can keep yourself straight, you’re a lot better off, and as I say this is one of the complexities. All right, so now let’s finish off the problem. Let me finally get this area here. So, actually I’ll just finish it off right here. So the area of the triangle is, well it’s the base times the height. The base is 2x_0, the height is 2y_0, and a half of that.

所以它是 1/2 (2x_0) * (2y_0)，也就是 2x_0 y_0，瞧瞧，就是 2。所以这个例子中有趣的事情是 x_0 和 y_0 是什么实际上并不重要。我们每次都得到相同的答案。这只是函数 1 / x 的一个意外。它恰好是具有该属性的函数。好吧，我们今天还有一些事情，一些严肃的事情。那么让我继续。

So it’s 1/2 (2x_0) * (2y_0),which is 2x_0 y_0, which is, lo and behold, 2. So the amusing thing in this case is that it actually didn’t matter what x_0 and y_0 are. We get the same answer every time. That’s just an accident of the function 1 / x. It happens to be the function with that property. All right, so we have some more business today, some serious business. So let me continue.

符号

Notations

首先，我想再给大家介绍几个符号。这些只是人们用来表示导数的其他符号。第一个符号如下：我们已经写过 y = f(x)。因此，当我们写 delta y 时，其含义与 delta f 相同。这是一种典型的符号。之前我们将导数写为 f prime，因此这是牛顿对导数的符号。

So, first of all, I want to give you a few more notations. And these are just other notations that people use to refer to derivatives. And the first one is the following: we already wrote y = f(x). And so when we write delta y, that means the same thing as delta f. That’s a typical notation. And previously we wrote f prime for the derivative, so this is Newton’s notation for the derivative.

但还有其他符号。其中一种是 df/dx，另一种是 dy/dx，意思完全一样。有时我们让函数向下滑动，这样就变成了 f 的 d/dx 和 y 的 d/dx。所以这些都是用于导数的符号，它们是由莱布尼茨首创的。这些符号可以互换使用，有时实际上可以一起使用。它们都非常有用。

But there are other notations. And one of them is df/dx, and another one is dy/dx, meaning exactly the same thing. And sometimes we let the function slip down below so that becomes d/dx of f and d/dx of y. So these are all notations that are used for the derivative, and these were initiated by Leibniz. And these notations are used interchangeably, sometimes practically together. They both turn out to be extremely useful.

这忽略了注意到这个东西忽略了底层基点 x_0。这是麻烦之一。它没有给你所有的信息。但有很多这样的情况，人们会遗漏一些重要信息，你必须从上下文中补充。所以这是另外几个符号。所以今天我还有一个计算要给你。我对函数 1 / x 的导数进行了计算。

This one omits notice that this thing omits the underlying base point, x_0. That’s one of the nuisances. It doesn’t give you all the information. But there are lots of situations like that where people leave out some of the important information, and you have to fill it in from context. So that’s another couple of notations. So now I have one more calculation for you today. I carried out this calculation of the derivative of the function 1 / x.

我想处理一些其他的幂。那就让我们这样做吧。因此，示例 2 将是函数 f(x) = x^n。n = 1,2.3；这些中的一个。现在，我们试图找出的是 x^n 对 x 的导数，在我们的新符号中，它等于什么。因此，我们将再次形成这个表达式，delta f / delta x。我们将进行一些代数简化。

I wanna take care of some other powers. So let’s do that. So Example 2 is going to be the function f(x) = x^n. n = 1,2.3; one of these guys. And now what we’re trying to figure out is the derivative with respect to x of x^n in our new notation, what this is equal to. So again, we’re going to form this expression, delta f / delta x. And we’re going to make some algebraic simplification.

因此，我们代入 delta f 的值是 ((x delta x)^nx^n)/delta x。现在，让我先把这个代入进去，然后我会把它抹掉。之前，我在这里写了 x_0，在那里写了 x_0。但现在我要把它去掉，因为在这个特定的计算中，它很麻烦。我没有 x 浮动，这意味着与 x_0 不同的东西。我只是不想继续写所有这些符号。

So what we plug in for delta f is ((x delta x)^n x^n)/delta x. Now before, let me just stick this in then I’m gonna erase it. Before, I wrote x_0 here and x_0 there. But now I’m going to get rid of it, because in this particular calculation, it’s a nuisance. I don’t have an x floating around, which means something different from the x_0. And I just don’t wanna have to keep on writing all those symbols.

这浪费了黑板能量。能量总量是有限的，我已经填满了这么多黑板，所以能量有限。另外，我正在努力节省粉笔。无论如何，没有 0。所以把 x 看作是固定的。在这种情况下，delta x 移动，而 x 在这个计算中是固定的。

It’s a waste of blackboard energy. There’s a total amount of energy, and I’ve already filled up so many blackboards that, there’s just a limited amount. Plus, I’m trying to conserve chalk. Anyway, no 0’s. So think of x as fixed. In this case, delta x moves and x is fixed in this calculation.

好了，现在，为了简化这一点，为了从代数上理解发生了什么，我需要了解和的 n 次方是什么。这是一个著名的公式。我们只需要一点点，称为二项式定理。

All right now, in order to simplify this, in order to understand algebraically what’s going on, I need to understand what the nth power of a sum is. And that’s a famous formula. We only need a little tiny bit of it, called the binomial theorem.

二项式定理

Binomial Theorem

因此，您课本中的二项式定理在附录中进行了解释，它表示，如果将两个数相加并进行 n 次方，那么结果当然是 (x + delta x) 乘以自身 n 次。因此，第一个项是 x^n，即所有 n 个因子都加入其中。然后，您就可以得到 delta x 这个因子和所有其余 x。

So, the binomial theorem which is in your text and explained in an appendix, says that if you take the sum of two guys and you take them to the nth power, that of course is (x + delta x) multiplied by itself n times. And so the first term is x^n, that’s when all of the n factors come in. And then, you could have this factor of delta x and all the rest x’s.

因此至少有一个形式为 (x^(n 1)) 乘以 delta x 的项。这种情况会发生多少次？嗯，当有一个因子从这里开始，从下一个因子开始，依此类推，依此类推。总共有 n 次可能发生这种情况。现在最棒的是，仅凭这一点，其余所有项都是垃圾，我们不必担心。

So at least one term of the form (x^(n 1)) times delta x. And how many times does that happen? Well, it happens when there’s a factor from here, from the next factor, and so on, and so on, and so on. There’s a total of n possible times that happens. And now the great thing is that, with this alone, all the rest of the terms are junk that we won’t have to worry about.

更具体地说，对垃圾有一个非常谨慎的符号。垃圾就是所谓的 (delta x)^2 的大 O。这意味着这些是有序项，因此具有 (delta x)^2、(delta x)^3 或更高。好吧，就是这样。非常令人兴奋的高阶项。好的，这是我们需要做的唯一代数运算，现在我们只需要将它们组合在一起即可得到结果。

So to be more specific, there’s a very careful notation for the junk. The junk is what’s called big O of (delta x)^2. What that means is that these are terms of order, so with (delta x)^2, (delta x)^3 or higher. All right, that’s how. Very exciting, higher order terms. OK, so this is the only algebra that we need to do, and now we just need to combine it together to get our result.

所以，现在我要进行我们需要的取消。我们开始吧。我们有 delta f / delta x，记住是 1 / delta x 乘以这个，也就是这个乘以，现在这是 x^n 加上 nx^(n 1) delta x 加上这个垃圾项，减去 x^n。这就是我们根据之前的计算得出的结果。现在，我要进行主要的取消，也就是这个。好的。

So, now I’m going to just carry out the cancellations that we need. So here we go. We have delta f / delta x, which remember was 1 / delta x times this, which is this times, now this is x^n plus nx^(n 1) delta x plus this junk term, minus x^n. So that’s what we have so far based on our previous calculations. Now, I’m going to do the main cancellation, which is this. All right.

所以，这是 1/delta x 乘以 nx^(n 1) delta x 加上这里的这个项。现在我可以用 delta x 除以它。所以我得到 nx^(n 1) 加上，现在它是 O(delta x)。delta x 至少有一个因子，而不是两个因子，因为我必须取消其中一个。现在我可以取极限。在极限中，这个项将为 0。这就是我最初称它为垃圾的原因，因为它消失了。

So, that’s 1/delta x times nx^(n 1) delta x plus this term here. And now I can divide in by delta x. So I get nx^(n 1) plus, now it’s O(delta x). There’s at least one factor of delta x not two factors of delta x, because I have to cancel one of them. And now I can just take the limit. In the limit this term is gonna be 0. That’s why I called it junk originally, because it disappears.

在数学中，垃圾是会消失的东西。因此，当 delta x 趋向于 0 时，nx^(n 1)。所以我向你展示的是 x 的 d/dx 减去 n。抱歉，n，等于 nx^(n 1)。所以现在这对你来说非常重要，无论从哪个方面来说，它都非常重要，我想告诉你一件事，它非常重要。

And in math, junk is something that goes away. So this tends to, as delta x goes to 0, nx^(n 1). And so what I’ve shown you is that d/dx of x to the n minus. sorry, n, is equal to nx^(n 1). So now this is gonna be super important to you right on your problem set in every possible way, and I want to tell you one thing, one way in which it’s very important.

一种方法是立即将其扩展。因此，这个东西可以扩展到多项式。我们从这个计算中得到很多东西。也就是说，如果我取某个东西的 d/dx，例如 (x^3 + 5x^10)，它将等于 3x^2，这是将此规则应用于 x^3。然后在这里，我将得到 5*10，即 50x^9。这就是我们从中得到的东西，下次我们将利用它做更多的事情。问题。是的。

One way that extends it immediately. So this thing extends to polynomials. We get quite a lot out of this one calculation. Namely, if I take d/dx of something like (x^3 + 5x^10) that’s gonna be equal to 3x^2, that’s applying this rule to x^3. And then here, I’ll get 5*10 so 50x^9. So this is the type of thing that we get out of it, and we’re gonna make more hay with that next time. Question. Yes.

我关掉了。是吗？学生：教授：。问题是二项式定理只有当 delta x 趋于 0 时才有效。不，二项式定理是一个通用公式，它还明确指定了垃圾是什么。它非常详细。但我们只需要这一部分。我们不关心所有这些疯狂的术语是什么。现在对于我们的目的来说，它是垃圾，因为我们不需要比前两个术语更多的内容。是的，因为 delta x 趋于 0。好的，下次见。

I turned myself off. Yes? Student: Professor:. The question was the binomial theorem only works when delta x goes to 0. No, the binomial theorem is a general formula which also specifies exactly what the junk is. It’s very much more detailed. But we only needed this part. We didn’t care what all these crazy terms were. It’s junk for our purposes now, because we don’t happen to need any more than those first two terms. Yes, because delta x goes to 0. OK, see you next time.

Lec 2 | MIT 18.01 单变量微积分，2007 年秋季

Lec 2 | MIT 18.01 Single Variable Calculus, Fall 2007

16 年前 (2009 年 1 月 17 日) — 52:47 https://youtube.com/watch?v=ryLdyDrBfvI

16 years ago (Jan 17, 2009) — 52:47 https://youtube.com/watch?v=ryLdyDrBfvI

以下内容根据 Creative Commons 许可提供。您的支持将帮助 MIT OpenCourseWare 继续免费提供高质量的教育资源。要捐款或查看数百门 MIT 课程的其他材料，请访问 MIT OpenCourseWare，网址为 ocw.mit.edu。好的，我想在第二讲开始时提醒大家我们上次讲过的内容。上次，我们将导数定义为切线的斜率。

The following content is provided under a Creative Commons license. Your support will help MIT OpenCourseWare continue to offer high quality educational resources for free. To make a donation or to view additional materials from hundreds of MIT courses visit MIT OpenCourseWare at ocw.mit.edu. Okay so I’d like to begin the second lecture by reminding you what we did last time. So last time, we defined the derivative as the slope of a tangent line.

这就是我们的几何观点，我们还做了一些计算。我们算出 1 / x 的导数是 1 / x^2。我们还计算了 x 的 n 次方导数，其中 n = 1,2 等，结果是 x，对不起，是 nx^(n 1)。

So that was our geometric point of view and we also did a couple of computations. We worked out that the derivative of 1 / x was 1 / x^2. And we also computed the derivative of x to the nth power for n = 1,2, etc., and that turned out to be x, I’m sorry, nx^(n 1).

这就是我们上次讲的内容，今天我想从其他角度来结束对导数的讨论。这非常重要，几乎是我在课堂上要讲的最重要的内容。但是当你重新开始并在现实世界中使用微积分时，你必须再次思考这个问题。所以我们再次讨论什么是导数，这只是上次的延续。

So that’s what we did last time, and today I want to finish up with other points of view on what a derivative is. So this is extremely important, it’s almost the most important thing I’ll be saying in the class. But you’ll have to think about it again when you start over and start using calculus in the real world. So again we’re talking about what is a derivative and this is just a continuation of last time.

正如我上次所说，我们讨论了几何解释，今天我们要讨论的是变化率作为导数的一种解释。所以记得我们画了函数图，y = f(x)，我们跟踪了 x 的变化，这里是 y 的变化，假设。

So, as I said last time, we talked about geometric interpretations, and today what we’re gonna talk about is rate of change as an interpretation of the derivative. So remember we drew graphs of functions, y = f(x) and we kept track of the change in x and here the change in y, let’s say.

然后从这个新角度来看，变化率，跟踪 x 的变化率和 y 的变化率，我们感兴趣的是相对变化率，即 delta y / delta x，这有另一种解释。这是平均变化。

And then from this new point of view a rate of change, keeping track of the rate of change of x and the rate of change of y, it’s the relative rate of change we’re interested in, and that’s delta y / delta x and that has another interpretation. This is the average change.

通常我们会这样想，如果 x 测量的是时间，那么平均值就是速率，平均值是时间间隔 delta x。然后极限值表示为 dy/dx，所以这个是平均变化率，这个是瞬时变化率。好的，这就是我现在想讨论的观点，我给你举几个例子。

Usually we would think of that, if x were measuring time and so the average and that’s when this becomes a rate, and the average is over the time interval delta x. And then the limiting value is denoted dy/dx and so this one is the average rate of change and this one is the instantaneous rate. Okay, so that’s the point of view that I’d like to discuss now and give you just a couple of examples.

那么，让我们看看。首先，也许这里有一些物理学的例子。q 通常是电荷的名称，然后 dq/dt 就是所谓的电流。所以这是一个物理例子。第二个例子，可能是最明显的例子，我们可以用字母 s 表示距离，然后变化率就是我们所说的速度。

So, let’s see. Well, first of all, maybe some examples from physics here. So q is usually the name for a charge, and then dq/dt is what’s known as current. So that’s one physical example. A second example, which is probably the most tangible one, is we could denote the letter s by distance and then the rate of change is what we call speed.

以上就是两个典型的例子，我只想更详细地说明第二个例子，因为我认为对瞬时速度的概念有某种内在的理解很重要。我使用这个建筑的例子来做到这一点。

So those are the two typical examples and I just want to illustrate the second example in a little bit more detail because I think it’s important to have some visceral sense of this notion of instantaneous speed. And I get to use the example of this very building to do that.

您可能知道，也可能不知道，万圣节期间，这座建筑或这座建筑顶部会举行一个活动，称为“南瓜掉落”。让我们用南瓜掉落来说明变化率的概念。那么，这座建筑会发生什么呢？

Probably you know, or maybe you don’t, that on Halloween there’s an event that takes place in this building or really from the top of this building which is called the pumpkin drop. So let’s illustrates this idea of rate of change with the pumpkin drop. So what happens is, this building.

好吧，让我们看看这是那栋建筑，这是那个点，那是建筑这边美丽的草地，然后这里有一些人和一些非常小的物体，当你靠近它们时它们并不那么小，它们被扔到那边。它们掉下来了。你知道麻省理工学院的一切或麻省理工学院的很多东西都是物理实验。这就是南瓜掉落。

Well let’s see here’s the building, and here’s the dot, that’s the beautiful grass out on this side of the building, and then there’s some people up here and very small objects, well they’re not that small when you’re close to them, that get dumped over the side there. And they fall down. You know everything at MIT or a lot of things at MIT are physics experiments. That’s the pumpkin drop.

粗略地说，这栋建筑大约有 300 英尺高，我们在这里的第一层可用。因此，我们将使用 80 米而不是 300 英尺，只是为了方便起见，因为这样数字会更简洁。因此，我们得到了从时间 0 开始的高度，即 80 米，然后重力加速度会给出 h 的公式，这就是高度。

So roughly speaking, the building is about 300 feet high, we’re down here on the first usable floor. And so we’re going to use instead of 300 feet, just for convenience purposes we’ll use 80 meters because that makes the numbers come out simply. So we have the height which starts out at 80 meters at time 0 and then the acceleration due to gravity gives you this formula for h, this is the height.

因此，在时间 t = 0 时，我们在顶部，h 为 80 米，这里的单位是米。在时间 t = 4 时，您会注意到，5 * 4^2 为 80。我选择这些数字很方便，这样我们就在底部。好的，这里的平均变化概念，因此这里的平均变化或平均速度，也许我们将其称为平均速度，因为那是。

So at time t = 0, we’re up at the top, h is 80 meters, the units here are meters. And at time t = 4 you notice, 5 * 4^2 is 80. I picked these numbers conveniently so that we’re down at the bottom. Okay, so this notion of average change here, so the average change, or the average speed here, maybe we’ll call it the average speed, since that’s.

在南瓜掉落的这段时间内，h 的变化量除以 t 的变化量。从哪里开始呢？从 80 开始，对吧？最后是 0。所以实际上我们必须倒着来。我们必须取 0 80，因为第一个值是最终位置，第二个值是初始位置。

Over this time that it takes for the pumpkin to drop is going to be the change in h divided by the change in t. Which starts out at, what does it start out as? It starts out as 80, right? And it ends at 0. So actually we have to do it backwards. We have to take 0 80 because the first value is the final position and the second value is the initial position.

除以 40；乘以 4 秒减去 0 秒。当然是每秒 20 米。所以这个人的平均速度是每秒 20 米。那么我为什么选择这个例子呢？因为，当然，平均值虽然很有趣，但对于真正参加活动的人来说并不是真正关心的。

And that’s divided by 4 0; times 4 seconds minus times 0 seconds. And so that of course is 20 meters per second. So the average speed of this guy is 20 meters a second. Now, so why did I pick this example? Because, of course, the average, although interesting, is not really what anybody cares about who actually goes to the event.

我们真正关心的是当它撞击路面时的瞬时速度，因此可以在底部计算出来。那么瞬时速度是多少？这就是导数，或者为了与我到目前为止使用的符号保持一致，那就是 h 的 d/dt。好吗？所以这就是 h 的 d/dt。现在请记住，我们有这些东西的公式。我们现在可以对这个函数进行微分。我们昨天已经这样做了。

All we really care about is the instantaneous speed when it hits the pavement and so that’s can be calculated at the bottom. So what’s the instantaneous speed? That’s the derivative, or maybe to be consistent with the notation I’ve been using so far, that’s d/dt of h. All right? So that’s d/dt of h. Now remember we have formulas for these things. We can differentiate this function now. We did that yesterday.

所以我们要取变化率，如果你看一下，就会发现它只是 80 的变化率为 0，减去 5t^2 的变化率，也就是减去 10t。所以这是利用了 80 的 d/dt 等于 0 而 t^2 的 d/dt 等于 2t 的事实。特殊情况。好吧，我在这里作弊了，但有一个特殊情况很明显。我没有在这里提到它。

So we’re gonna take the rate of change and if you take a look at it, it’s just the rate of change of 80 is 0, minus the rate change for this 5t^2, that’s minus 10t. So that’s using the fact that d/dt of 80 is equal to 0 and d/dt of t^2 is equal to 2t. The special case. Well I’m cheating here, but there’s a special case that’s obvious. I didn’t throw it in over here.

n = 2 的情况是第二种情况。但 n = 0 的情况也成立。因为那是常数。常数的导数是 0。然后因子 n 是 0，这是一致的。实际上，如果你看一下上面的公式，你会发现它是 n = 1 的情况。所以我们很快就会得到一个更大的幂模式。好吧，无论如何。

The case n = 2 is that second case there. But the case n = 0 also works. Because that’s constants. The derivative of a constant is 0. And then the factor n there’s 0 and that’s consistent. And actually if you look at the formula above it you’ll see that it’s the case of n = 1. So we’ll get a larger pattern soon enough with the powers. Okay anyway.

回到这里，我们得到了变化率，这就是它。在底部，在撞击点，我们有 t = 4，因此 h'（导数）等于每秒 40 米。所以是这里平均速度的两倍，如果你需要转换它，那就是大约每小时 90 英里。

Back over here we have our rate of change and this is what it is. And at the bottom, at that point of impact, we have t = 4 and so h’which is the derivative, is equal to 40 meters per second. So twice as fast as the average speed here, and if you need to convert that, that’s about 90 miles an hour.

这就是为什么警察会在万圣节午夜到场以确保你们的安全，也是为什么你们来的时候必须做好事后清理的准备。所以无论如何，这就是发生的事情，时速是 90 英里。实际上，建筑物会更高一些，有空气阻力，我相信你可以对这个例子进行更彻底的研究。

Which is why the police are there at midnight on Halloween to make sure you’re all safe and also why when you come you have to be prepared to clean up afterwards. So anyway that’s what happens, it’s 90 miles an hour. It’s actually the buildings a little taller, there’s air resistance and I’m sure you can do a much more thorough study of this example.

好吧，现在我想再举几个例子，因为时间和这类参数和变量并不是微积分中唯一重要的因素。如果只涉及这种物理，那么这门学科就会比现在更加专业。所以我想给你们举几个不涉及时间变量的例子。

All right so now I want to give you a couple of more examples because time and these kinds of parameters and variables are not the only ones that are important for calculus. If it were only this kind of physics that was involved, then this would be a much more specialized subject than it is. And so I want to give you a couple of examples that don’t involve time as a variable.

我要给出的第三个例子是。字母 T 通常表示温度，然后 dT/dx 就是所谓的温度梯度。我们在预测天气时非常关心这一点，因为正是这种温差导致气流并导致事物发生变化。然后还有另一个贯穿科学和工程的主题，我将在测量灵敏度的标题下讨论它。

So the third example I’ll give here is. The letter T often denotes temperature, and then dT/dx would be what is known as the temperature gradient. Which we really care about a lot when we’re predicting the weather because it’s that temperature difference that causes air flows and causes things to change. And then there’s another theme which is throughout the sciences and engineering which I’m going to talk about under the heading of sensitivity of measurements.

让我来解释一下。我不想过多地解释，因为我这样做只是为了向你介绍你的问题集上的想法，这是这种情况的第一个例子。所以在问题集一中，你有一个基于 GPS 简化模型的例子，有点像平面地球模型。在这种情况下，如果地球是平的，它只是一条水平线，就像这样。

So let me explain this. I don’t want to belabor it because I just am doing this in order to introduce you to the ideas on your problem set which are the first case of this. So on problem set one you have an example which is based on a simplified model of GPS, sort of the Flat Earth Model. And in that situation, well, if the Earth is flat it’s just a horizontal line like this.

然后你有一颗卫星，它就在这里，最好是在地球上方，卫星或系统确切地知道卫星正下方的点在哪里。所以这个点被视为已知点。我坐在这里，拿着我的小 GPS 设备，我想知道我在哪里。

And then you have a satellite, which is over here, preferably above the earth, and the satellite or the system knows exactly where the point directly below the satellite is. So this point is treated as known. And I’m sitting here with my little GPS device and I want to know where I am.

我定位自己位置的方法是通过无线电信号与卫星通信，然后测量距离，也就是 h。然后系统会计算水平距离，也就是 L。换句话说，测量的是 h，通过无线电、无线电波和时钟或各种时钟测量。然后从 h 推导出 L。

And the way I locate where I am is I communicate with this satellite by radio signals and I can measure this distance here which is called h. And then system will compute this horizontal distance which is L. So in other words what is measured, so h measured by radios, radio waves and a clock, or various clocks. And then L is deduced from h.

在所有这些系统中，关键在于你无法准确知道 h。h 中存在误差，这将表示 delta h。存在一定程度的不确定性。GPS 中的主要不确定性来自电离层。但有很多各种各样的修正。而且如果你在建筑物内，测量它就会很困难。但这是一个极其重要的问题，我稍后会解释。

And what’s critical in all of these systems is that you don’t know h exactly. There’s an error in h which will denote delta h. There’s some degree of uncertainty. The main uncertainty in GPS is from the ionosphere. But there are lots of corrections that are made of all kinds. And also if you’re inside a building it’s a problem to measure it. But it’s an extremely important issue, as I’ll explain in a second.

因此，我们的想法是，通过考虑 delta L/delta h 这个比率来估计 delta L，这个比率将大致等于 L 相对于 h 的导数。所以这是件容易的事，因为它当然是微积分。微积分是最简单的部分，它使我们能够推断出一些关于这里附近的现实世界的东西。

So the idea is we then get at delta L is estimated by considering this ratio delta L/delta h which is going to be approximately the same as the derivative of L with respect to h. So this is the thing that’s easy because of course it’s calculus. Calculus is the easy part and that allows us to deduce something about the real world that’s close by over here.

所以你应该非常关心这一点的原因是它一直用于飞机着陆。所以你确实应该关心他们是否真的知道你的飞机在几英尺甚至更近的位置以及它的高度等等。好的。这就是对导数的一般介绍。

So the reason why you should care about this quite a bit is that it’s used all the time to land airplanes. So you really do care that they actually know to within a few feet or even closer where your plane is and how high up it is and so forth. All right. So that’s it for the general introduction of what a derivative is.

我相信你们会在课程中在很多不同的情况下习惯这一点。现在我们必须回到一些严格的细节。好吧，大家对我们目前所得到的结果满意吗？是吗？学生：你是如何得到高度方程的？教授：啊，好问题。问题是我是如何得到这个高度方程的？

I’m sure you’ll be getting used to this in a lot of different contexts throughout the course. And now we have to get back down to some rigorous details. Okay, everybody happy with what we’ve got so far? Yeah? Student: How did you get the equation for height? Professor: Ah good question. The question was how did I get this equation for height?

我编造了它，因为这是你在 8.01 课上学到的物理学公式，事实上，它与这个事实有关，如果你再微分一次，你会得到加速度，重力加速度是 10 米/秒。这恰好是它的二阶导数。但无论如何，我只是从你的物理课上突然想到的。

I just made it up because it’s the formula from physics that you will learn when you take 8.01 and, in fact, it has to do with the fact that this is the speed if you differentiate another time you get acceleration and acceleration due to gravity is 10 meters per second. Which happens to be the second derivative of this. But anyway I just pulled it out of a hat from your physics class.

所以你可以说看 8.01 好吧，还有其他问题吗？好吧，我们现在继续。现在我必须更系统地讲解极限。现在让我们开始吧。现在我想谈谈极限和连续性。这是推导所有其他公式的热身，我将需要所有这些公式来区分每个函数。

So you can just say see 8.01 All right, other questions? All right, so let’s go on now. Now I have to be a little bit more systematic about limits. So let’s do that now. So now what I’d like to talk about is limits and continuity. And this is a warm up for deriving all the rest of the formulas, all the rest of the formulas that I’m going to need to differentiate every function you know.

记住，这是我们的目标，我们只剩下大约一周的时间，所以我们最好开始行动。首先，我将称之为轻松限制。那么，什么是轻松限制？

Remember, that’s our goal and we only have about a week left so we’d better get started. So first of all there is what I will call easy limits. So what’s an easy limit?

一个简单的极限是类似于当 x 变为 4 的 x 加 3 除以 x^2 + 1 时的极限。对于这种极限，我只需代入 x = 4 即可求出，因此我得到的结果是 4 + 3 除以 4^2 + 1。结果就是 7 / 17。这就是简单的极限。所以这些就是简单的极限。

An easy limit is something like the limit as x goes to 4 of x plus 3 over x^2 + 1. And with this kind of limit all I have to do to evaluate it is to plug in x = 4 because, so what I get here is 4 + 3 divided by 4^2 + 1. And that’s just 7 / 17. And that’s the end of it. So those are the easy limits.

第二种极限，嗯，这不是唯一的第二种极限，但我只想指出这一点，这一点非常重要：导数总是比这更难。在这里你不能什么都不做。那么，为什么呢？嗯，当你求导数时，你要求当 x 趋向于 x_0 时 f(x) 的极限，好吧，我们会把它全部写出来。这是导数的公式。

The second kind of limit well so this isn’t the only second kind of limit but I just want to point this out, it’s very important is that: derivatives are always harder than this. You can’t get away with nothing here. So, why is that? Well, when you take a derivative, you’re taking the limit as x goes to x_0 of f(x), well we’ll write it all out in all its glory. Here’s the formula for the derivative.

现在请注意，如果你代入 x = x:0，结果总是 0 / 0。所以它基本上永远行不通。所以我们总是需要一些取消来理解极限。现在为了让我自己更容易解释极限是怎么回事，我需要再引入一个符号。

Now notice that if you plug in x = x:0, always gives 0 / 0. So it just basically never works. So we always are going to need some cancellation to make sense out of the limit. Now in order to make things a little easier for myself to explain what’s going on with limits I need to introduce just one more piece of notation.

我在这里要介绍的是所谓的左极限和右极限。如果我取 x 趋向于 x_0 的极限，并在此加上某个函数的加号，这就是所谓的右极限。我可以直观地显示它。那么这是什么意思呢？

What I’m gonna introduce here is what’s known as a left hand and a right limit. If I take the limit as x tends to x_0 with a plus sign here of some function, this is what’s known as the right hand limit. And I can display it visually. So what does this mean?

它实际上意味着 x 趋向于 x_0，只不过还有一个与加号有关的限制，即我们从 x_0 的正侧开始。这意味着 x 大于 x_0。我说的是右手，所以这里应该有一个连字符，右手极限，因为在数轴上，如果 x_0 在这边，那么 x 就在右边。对吧？这就是右手极限。

It means practically the same thing as x tends to x_0 except there is one more restriction which has to do with this plus sign, which is we’re going from the plus side of x_0. That means x is bigger than x_0. And I say right hand, so there should be a hyphen here, right hand limit because on the number line, if x_0 is over here the x is to the right. All right? So that’s the right hand limit.

然后这是棋盘的左侧，我会在棋盘的右侧放置左极限，只是为了让事情变得混乱。所以这里有一个减号。我只是有点诵读困难，我希望你不是。所以我可能弄错了。所以这是左极限，我会画出来。

And then this being the left side of the board, I’ll put on the right side of the board the left limit, just to make things confusing. So that one has the minus sign here. I’m just a little dyslexic and I hope you’re not. So I may have gotten that wrong. So this is the left hand limit, and I’ll draw it.

所以当然这只是意味着 x 指向 x_0，但 x 在 x_0 的左边。同样，在数轴上，这里是 x_0，x 在它的另一边。好的，这两个符号将帮助我们澄清很多事情。有这额外的极限描述比只考虑两边的极限要方便得多。

So of course that just means x goes to x_0 but x is to the left of x_0 And again, on the number line, here’s the x_0 and the x is on the other side of it. Okay, so those two notations are going to help us to clarify a bunch of things. It’s much more convenient to have this extra bit of description of limits than to just consider limits from both sides.

好的，我想举个例子。同时也举个例子来说明如何思考这类问题。所以我将采用一个具有两个不同定义的函数。假设当 x > 0 时，它是 x + 1；当 x < 0 时，它是 x + 2。所以也许可以在那里加上逗号。所以当 x > 0 时，它是 x + 1。现在我可以画出这个图了。

Okay so I want to give an example of this. And also an example of how you’re going to think about these sorts of problems. So I’ll take a function which has two different definitions. Say it’s x + 1, when x > 0 and x + 2, when x < 0. So maybe put commas there. So when x > 0, it’s x + 1. Now I can draw a picture of this.

它会有点小，因为我要试着把它放在这里，但也许我会把轴放在下面。所以在高度 1 处，我在右侧有一个斜率为 1 的东西，所以它像这样向上。好吗？然后在 0 的左侧，我有一个斜率为 1 的东西，但它在 2 处与轴相交，所以它在这里。

It’s gonna be kind of a little small because I’m gonna try to fit it down in here, but maybe I’ll put the axis down below. So at height 1, I have to the right something of slope 1 so it goes up like this. All right? And then to the left of 0 I have something which has slope 1, but it hits the axis at 2 so it’s up here.

所以我这里有一个奇怪的天线图形，这是我的图表。也许我应该用另一种颜色来描绘它。然后，如果我计算这两个极限，我看到的是，当 x 从 f(x) 的上方趋向 0 时的极限，这与这里公式 x + 1 的 x 趋向 0 时的极限相同。结果是 1。如果我取极限，那就是左边的极限。对不起，我告诉过你我有诵读困难症。这是右边的，所以是右手边的极限。我们开始吧。

So I had this sort of strange antenna figure here, which is my graph. Maybe I should draw these in another color to depict that. And then if I calculate these two limits here, what I see is that the limit as x goes to 0 from above of f(x), that’s the same as the limit as x goes to 0 of the formula here, x + 1. Which turns out to be 1. And if I take the limit, so that’s the left hand limit. Sorry, I told you I was dyslexic. This is the right, so it’s that right hand. Here we go.

所以现在我从左边开始，它又是 f(x)，但是现在因为我在那边，所以我需要代入另一个公式，x + 2，这将给我们 2。现在，请注意左边和右边的极限，这是一个微小的微妙之处，几乎是我现在需要你真正注意的唯一事情，就是我们不需要 x = 0 值。

So now I’m going from the left, and it’s f(x) again, but now because I’m on that side the thing I need to plug is the other formula, x + 2, and that’s gonna give us 2. Now, notice that the left and right limits, and this is one little tiny subtlety and it’s almost the only thing that I need you to really pay attention to a little bit right now, is that this, we did not need x = 0 value.

事实上我甚至从未告诉过你这里的 f(0) 是什么。如果我们把它放进去，我们就可以把它放进去。好吧，假设我们把它放在这一边。让我们把它放在这一边。这意味着这个点在里面，这个点在外面。所以这是一个典型的符号：这个小的开口圆和这个闭合的点，当你包括它时。

In fact I never even told you what f(0) was here. If we stick it in we could stick it in. Okay let’s say we stick it in on this side. Let’s make it be that it’s on this side. So that means that this point is in and this point is out. So that’s a typical notation: this little open circle and this closed dot for when you include the.

因此，在这种情况下，f(x) 的值恰好与其右极限相同，即这里的值为 1，而不是 2。好的，这是第一种例子。有问题吗？好的，现在我们的下一个任务是介绍连续性的定义。这是这里的另一个主题。所以我们要定义。

So in that case the value of f(x) happens to be the same as its right hand limit, namely the value is 1 here and not 2. Okay, so that’s the first kind of example. Questions? Okay, so now our next job is to introduce the definition of continuity. So that was the other topic here. So we’re going to define.

所以 f 在 x_0 处连续意味着当 x 趋向于 x_0 时，f(x) 的极限等于 f(x_0) 对吗？所以我花了这么多时间关注左边和右边等等，并集中注意力，是因为我想让你注意一下这个定义的内容是什么。

So f is continuous at x_0 means that the limit of f(x) as x tends to x_0 is equal to f(x_0) Right? So the reason why I spend all this time paying attention to the left and the right and so on and so forth and focusing is that I want you to pay attention for one moment to what the content of this definition is.

它说的是：在 x_0 处连续有各种成分。所以第一个是这个极限存在。这意味着左边和右边都有一个真实的极限值。而且它们也必须相同。好吧，这就是这里发生的事情。第二个属性是 f(x_0) 是定义的。

What it’s saying is the following: continuous at x_0 has various ingredients here. So the first one is that this limit exists. And what that means is that there’s an honest limiting value both from the left and right. And they also have to be the same. All right, so that’s what’s going on here. And the second property is that f(x_0) is defined.

所以我不能处于这样的情况：我甚至还没有指定 f(x_0) 是什么，它们就相等了。好吧，情况就是这样。现在让我再次强调极限定义的一个棘手部分。这一边，左边是完全独立的，通过一个不涉及右边的过程来求值。它们是分开的。这一点是，为了求值，你总是要避开极限点。

So I can’t be in one of these situations where I haven’t even specified what f(x_0) is and they’re equal. Okay, so that’s the situation. Now again let me emphasize a tricky part of the definition of a limit. This side, the left hand side is completely independent, is evaluated by a procedure which does not involve the right hand side. These are separate things. This one is, to evaluate it, you always avoid the limit point.

如果你喜欢悖论，那么这就是问题所在：如果你代入 x_0，你会得到与在极限中移动相同的答案，这是真的吗？这就是我们在这里考虑的问题。我们必须做出这种区分才能说这是两个，否则这只是同义反复。它没有任何意义。

So that’s if you like a paradox, because it’s exactly the question: is it true that if you plug in x_0 you get the same answer as if you move in the limit? That’s the issue that we’re considering here. We have to make that distinction in order to say that these are two, otherwise this is just tautological. It doesn’t have any meaning.

但事实上它确实有意义，因为一件事是参考所有其他点单独评估的，而另一件事是在所讨论的点上评估的。事实上，这些东西正是简单的极限。这正是我们在这里谈论的。它们是你可以通过这种方式评估的东西。所以我们必须做出区分。

But in fact it does have a meaning because one thing is evaluated separately with reference to all the other points and the other is evaluated right at the point in question. And indeed what these things are, are exactly the easy limits. That’s exactly what we’re talking about here. They’re the ones you can evaluate this way. So we have to make the distinction.

而其他函数则是我们无法用这种方式求值的函数。所以这些函数很好，这就是我们关心它们的原因，也是我们为它们制定完整定义的原因。好吗？那么接下来呢？好吧，我需要带你参观一下，非常简短的参观一下，看看所谓的不连续函数。也就是其他所有不连续的东西。

And these other ones are gonna be the ones which we can’t evaluate that way. So these are the nice ones and that’s why we care about them, why we have a whole definition associated with them. All right? So now what’s next? Well, I need to give you a little tour, very brief tour, of the zoo of what are known as discontinuous functions. So sort of everything else that’s not continuous.

那么，第一个例子，让我把它写下来。它是跳跃不连续性。那么跳跃不连续性是什么呢？其实我们已经见过了。跳跃不连续性就是我们刚才的例子。这是当左侧和右侧的极限存在但不相等时。好的，就像例子中的那样。对吧？

So, the first example here, let me just write it down here. It’s jump discontinuities. So what would a jump discontinuity be? Well we’ve actually already seen it. The jump discontinuity is the example that we had right there. This is when the limit from the left and right exist, but are not equal. Okay, so that’s as in the example. Right?

在这个例子中，两个极限，其中一个是 1，另一个是 2。所以这是一个跳跃不连续性。这种东西是否连续的问题可能看起来有点技术性，但确实人们对此非常担心。

In this example, the two limits, one of them was 1 and of them was 2. So that’s a jump discontinuity. And this kind of issue, of whether something is continuous or not, may seem a little bit technical but it is true that people have worried about it a lot.

鲍勃·默顿 (Bob Merton) 是麻省理工学院的教授，他当时的研究成果为他赢得了诺贝尔经济学奖。他对这个问题很感兴趣：在某个模型中，各种股票价格是从左向右连续的还是从右向左连续的。在开发我们的对冲基金现在一直使用的定价模型时，这是一个非常严肃的问题。所以左和右的含义可能完全不同。

Bob Merton, who was a professor at MIT when he did his work for the Nobel prize in economics, was interested in this very issue of whether stock prices of various kinds are continuous from the left or right in a certain model. And that was a very serious issue in developing the model that priced things that our hedge funds use all the time now. So left and right can really mean something very different.

在这种情况下，左边是过去，右边是未来，而事物是从左边连续还是从右边连续，这有很大的不同。对，点是在这里、这里、中间某处还是其他地方，这是真的吗？这是一个严重的问题。所以我要给你们举的下一个例子有点微妙。这就是所谓的可移除不连续性。

In this case left is the past and right is the future and it makes a big difference whether things are continuous from the left or continuous from the right. Right, is it true that the point is here, here, somewhere in the middle, somewhere else. That’s a serious issue. So the next example that I want to give you is a little bit more subtle. It’s what’s known as a removable discontinuity.

所以这意味着左边和右边的极限是相等的。所以，一个这样的图景是，你有一个函数，它像这样运行，可能有一个洞，谁知道这个函数是未定义的，还是在这里定义的，然后它就继续运行。对吧？所以这两个极限是相同的。

And so what this means is that the limit from left and right are equal. So a picture of that would be, you have a function which is coming along like this and there’s a hole maybe where, who knows either the function is undefined or maybe it’s defined up here, and then it just continues on. All right? So the two limits are the same.

然后当然需要重新定义函数，以便我们消除这个漏洞。这就是为什么它被称为可移除不连续性。现在让我给你举一个例子，或者实际上是几个例子。这些是相当重要的例子，几分钟后你就会用到它们。

And then of course the function is begging to be redefined so that we remove that hole. And that’s why it’s called a removable discontinuity. Now let me give you an example of this, or actually a couple of examples. So these are quite important examples which you will be working with in a few minutes.

因此，第一个是函数 g(x)，即 sin x / x，第二个是函数 h(x)，即 1 cos x 除以 x。因此，我们在 g(0) 处遇到一个问题，g(0) 未定义。另一方面，事实证明该函数具有所谓的可移除奇点。即，当 x 趋于 0 时，sin x / x 的极限确实存在。

So the first is the function g(x), which is sin x / x, and the second will be the function h(x), which is 1 cos x over x. So we have a problem at g(0), g(0) is undefined. On the other hand it turns out this function has what’s called a removable singularity. Namely the limit as x goes to 0 of sin x / x does exist.

事实上它等于 1。所以这是一个非常重要的极限，我们将在本课结束或下一课开始时计算出来。同样，1 cos x 除以 x 的极限，当 x 趋于 0 时，为 0。也许我会把它放得远一点，这样你就能读到它。好的，这些是非常有用的事实，我们稍后会需要它们。

In fact it’s equal to 1. So that’s a very important limit that we will work out either at the end of this lecture or the beginning of next lecture. And similarly, the limit of 1 cos x divided by x, as x goes to 0, is 0. Maybe I’ll put that a little farther away so you can read it. Okay, so these are very useful facts that we’re going to need later on.

他们说这些东西有可移除的奇点，对不起，在 x = 0 处有可移除的不连续性。好的，正如我所说，我们几分钟后就会讲到这个。好的，在我继续之前还有什么问题吗？是的？学生：教授：问题是：为什么这是真的？这就是你的问题吗？

And what they say is that these things have removable singularities, sorry removable discontinuity at x = 0. All right so as I say, we’ll get to that in a few minutes. Okay so are there any questions before I move on? Yeah? Student: Professor:. The question is: why is this true? Is that what your question is?

答案是，它非常非常不明显，我还没有向你展示它，如果你对此不感到惊讶，那确实很奇怪。所以我们还没有做到这一点。你必须继续关注，直到我们做到。好吗？我们还没有展示它。实际上，即使是这个可能看起来更奇怪的另一个说法，也还没有解释。

The answer is it’s very, very unobvious, I haven’t shown it to you yet, and if you were not surprised by it then that would be very strange indeed. So we haven’t done it yet. You have to stay tuned until we do. Okay? We haven’t shown it yet. And actually even this other statement, which maybe seems stranger still, is also not yet explained.

好的，正如我所说，我们将在本讲座结束或下一讲座开始时到达那里。还有其他问题吗？好的，那么让我继续参观不连续性动物园。而且，我想用右手极限和左手极限的便利性来说明一些事情，所以我将保留这个关于右手极限和左手极限的板块。

Okay, so we are going to get there, as I said, either at the end of this lecture or at the beginning of next. Other questions? All right, so let me just continue my tour of the zoo of discontinuities. And, I guess, I want to illustrate something with the convenience of right and left hand limits so I’ll save this board about right and left hand limits.

因此，第三种不连续性被称为无限不连续性。我们已经遇到过其中一种。我要在这里画出来。记住函数 y 是 1 / x。这就是这里的函数。但现在我想在这里画出双曲线的另一个分支，并允许我考虑 x 的负值。这是 1 / x 的图形。

So a third type of discontinuity is what’s known as an infinite discontinuity. And we’ve already encountered one of these. I’m going to draw them over here. Remember the function y is 1 / x. That’s this function here. But now I’d like to draw also the other branch of the hyperbola down here and allow myself to consider negative values of x. So here’s the graph of 1 / x.

这里区分左极限和右极限的方便性非常重要，因为在这里我可以写下当 x 趋向于 0+ 1/x 时的极限。好吧，那是从右边来的，而且是向上的。所以这个极限是无穷大。而另一个方向的极限，从左边来的，是向下的。所以它是完全不同的，它是负无穷大。

And the convenience here of distinguishing the left and the right hand limits is very important because here I can write down that the limit as x goes to 0+ of 1 / x. Well that’s coming from the right and it’s going up. So this limit is infinity. Whereas, the limit in the other direction, from the left, that one is going down. And so it’s quite different, it’s minus infinity.

现在有些人说这些极限是不确定的，但实际上它们朝着某个非常明确的方向发展。所以你应该尽可能地指定这些极限是什么。另一方面，当 x 趋向于 0 时，1/x 的极限是无穷大的说法是完全错误的。好吧，并不是人们不写这个。只是它是错的。并不是他们没有把它写下来。事实上，你可能会看到它。

Now some people say that these limits are undefined but actually they’re going in some very definite direction. So you should, whenever possible, specify what these limits are. On the other hand, the statement that the limit as x goes to 0 of 1 / x is infinity is simply wrong. Okay, it’s not that people don’t write this. It’s just that it’s wrong. It’s not that they don’t write it down. In fact you’ll probably see it.

这是因为人们只考虑右手边的分支。他们不一定犯错，但无论如何，这是马虎的。有些马虎我们可以忍受，有些我们会尽量避免。所以在这里，你想说的是，这确实有区别。你知道，正无穷是无限数量的美元，负无穷是无限数量的债务。它们实际上是不同的。它们不一样。

It’s because people are just thinking of the right hand branch. It’s not that they’re making a mistake necessarily, but anyway, it’s sloppy. And there’s some sloppiness that we’ll endure and others that we’ll try to avoid. So here, you want to say this, and it does make a difference. You know, plus infinity is an infinite number of dollars and minus infinity is and infinite amount of debt. They’re actually different. They’re not the same.

所以，你知道，这是草率的，而这实际上更正确。好的，现在另外，我只想指出一件事。记住，我们计算了导数，那是 1/x^2。但是，我想画出它的图形并对此做一些评论。所以我要直接在函数图形下方画出图形。注意这个图形是什么。

So, you know, this is sloppy and this is actually more correct. Okay, so now in addition, I just want to point out one more thing. Remember, we calculated the derivative, and that was 1/x^2. But, I want to draw the graph of that and make a few comments about it. So I’m going to draw the graph directly underneath the graph of the function. And notice what this graphs is.

就像这样，它总是负的，并且指向下方。所以现在这看起来可能有点奇怪，这个东西的导数是这个家伙，但这是因为一些非常重要的东西。你应该永远记住关于导数的这一点。导数函数看起来不一定像函数。所以你应该忘掉这个想法。有些人觉得如果一件事下降，另一件事也必须下降。

It goes like this, it’s always negative, and it points down. So now this may look a little strange, that the derivative of this thing is this guy, but that’s because of something very important. And you should always remember this about derivatives. The derivative function looks nothing like the function, necessarily. So you should just forget about that as being an idea. Some people feel like if one thing goes down, the other thing has to go down.

忘掉这种直觉吧。这是错的。如果你还记得的话，我们在这里处理的是斜率。所以如果你在这里有一个斜率，它只对应于这里的一个地方，随着斜率变得稍微平缓，这就是我们接近横轴的原因。随着我们越来越近，数字变得越来越小。现在在这里，斜率也是负的。

Just forget that intuition. It’s wrong. What we’re dealing with here, if you remember, is the slope. So if you have a slope here, that corresponds to just a place over here and as the slope gets a little bit less steep, that’s why we’re approaching the horizontal axis. The number is getting a little smaller as we close in. Now over here, the slope is also negative.

它正在下降，而且越往下，它的负值就越大。随着斜率的上升，这个函数正在上升，但它的斜率正在下降。好吧，所以斜率在两边都是下降的，我们使用的符号非常适合这种左右关系。

It is going down and as we get down here it’s getting more and more negative. As we go here the slope, this function is going up, but its slope is going down. All right, so the slope is down on both sides and the notation that we use for that is well suited to this left and right business.

也就是说，当 x 趋向于 0 时，1 / x^2 的极限等于负无穷大。这适用于 x 趋向于 0+ 和 x 趋向于 0，所以两者都具有此属性。最后，让我对这两个图做最后的评论。这里的这个函数是一个奇函数，当你对奇函数求导时，你总是得到一个偶函数。

Namely, the limit as x goes to 0 of 1 / x^2, that’s going to be equal to minus infinity. And that applies to x going to 0+ and x going to 0 So both have this property. Finally let me just make one last comment about these two graphs. This function here is an odd function and when you take the derivative of an odd function you always get an even function.

这与 1 / x 是奇数幂和 x^1 是奇数幂、x^2 是偶数幂的事实密切相关。所以，你的直觉应该会强化这些图片看起来正确的事实。好的，现在我想简要提一下最后一种不连续性，我将其称为其他丑陋的不连续性。而且有很多很多。

That’s closely related to the fact that this 1 / x is an odd power and. x^1 is an odd power and x^2 is an even power. So all of this your intuition should be reinforcing the fact that these pictures look right. Okay, now there’s one last kind of discontinuity that I want to mention briefly, which I will call other ugly discontinuities. And there are lots and lots of them.

一个例子是函数 y = sin 1 / x，当 x 趋向于 0 时。这看起来有点像这样。来来回回。当我们趋向于 0 时，它会无限地振荡。在这种情况下，没有左或右极限。所以有很多这样的事情。幸运的是，我们不会在本课程中处理它们。

So one example would be the function y = sin 1 / x, as x goes to 0. And that looks a little bit like this. Back and forth and back and forth. It oscillates infinitely often as we tend to 0. There’s no left or right limit in this case. So there is a very large quantity of things like that. Fortunately we’re not gonna deal with them in this course.

在现实生活中，很多时候，随着时间的流逝，事物都会发生振荡，但我们现在不担心这个问题。好的，这是我们最后一次提到不连续性，现在我需要为下一次的公式再做一点基础工作。也就是说，我想为你检查一个基本事实，一个限制工具。所以这将是一个定理。

A lot of times in real life there are things that oscillate as time goes to infinity, but we’re not going to worry about that right now. Okay, so that’s our final mention of a discontinuity, and now I need to do just one more piece of groundwork for our formulas next time. Namely, I want to check for you one basic fact, one limiting tool. So this is going to be a theorem.

幸运的是，这是一个非常短的定理，并且有一个非常短的证明。因此，该定理被称为可微分意味着连续。它说的是：如果 f 是可微分的，换句话说，它的导数在 x_0 处存在，那么 f 在 x_0 处是连续的。因此，我们需要这个工具，它是乘法和商法规则中的关键步骤。

Fortunately it’s a very short theorem and has a very short proof. So the theorem goes under the name differentiable implies continuous. And what it says is the following: it says that if f is differentiable, in other words its. the derivative exists at x_0, then f is continuous at x_0. So, we’re gonna need this is as a tool, it’s a key step in the product and quotient rules.

所以我现在想为你证明这一点。这是证明。幸运的是，证明只有一行。所以首先，我想以正确的方式写下我们必须检查的内容。所以我们要检查的是，当 x 趋向于 x_0 时，f(x) f(x_0) 的极限是否等于 0。这就是我们想知道的。

So I’d like to prove it right now for you. So here is the proof. Fortunately the proof is just one line. So first of all, I want to write in just the right way what it is that we have to check. So what we have to check is that the limit, as x goes to x_0, of f(x) f(x_0) is equal to 0. So this is what we want to know.

我们还不知道，但我们正在尝试检查这是否正确。所以这与函数连续的说法相同，因为 f(x) 的极限应该是 f(x_0)，所以这个差的极限应该是 0。现在，证明这一点的方法就是通过将其乘以和除以 (x x_0) 来重写。

We don’t know it yet, but we’re trying to check whether this is true or not. So that’s the same as the statement that the function is continuous because the limit of f(x) is supposed to be f(x_0) and so this difference should have limit 0. And now, the way this is proved is just by rewriting it by multiplying and dividing by (x x_0).

因此，我将极限重写为 x 趋向于 f(x) f(x_0) 的 x_0，除以 x x_0 乘以 x x_0。好的，我写下了与此处相同的表达式。这只是相同的极限，但我乘以并除以 (x x_0)。现在，当我取极限时，第一个因数的极限是 f'(x_0)。这就是我们根据假设知道存在的东西。

So I’ll rewrite the limit as x goes to x_0 of f(x) f(x_0) divided by x x_0 times x x_0. Okay, so I wrote down the same expression that I had here. This is just the same limit, but I multiplied and divided by (x x_0). And now when I take the limit what happens is the limit of the first factor is f’(x_0). That’s the thing we know exists by our assumption.

第二个因数的极限是 0，因为当 x 趋向于 x_0 时，(x x_0) 的极限显然是 0，所以就是这样。答案是 0，这正是我们想要的。这就是证明。现在这个证明看起来有些可疑，让我先指出这一点，然后再继续。

And the limit of the second factor is 0 because the limit as x goes to x_0 of (x x_0) is clearly 0 So that’s it. The answer is 0, which is what we wanted. So that’s the proof. Now there’s something exceedingly fishy looking about this proof and let me just point to it before we proceed.

也就是说，你习惯于将 x 设置为 0。这看起来就像我们在乘以或除以 0，这正是导致所有代数情况下的所有证明都错误的原因，等等。你被教导过这永远不会奏效。对吧？但不知何故，这些限制技巧找到了解决这个问题的方法，让我明确说明一下它是什么。

Namely, you’re used in limits to setting x equal to 0. And this looks like we’re multiplying, dividing by 0, exactly the thing which makes all proofs wrong in all kinds of algebraic situations and so on and so forth. You’ve been taught that never works. Right? But somehow these limiting tricks have found a way around this and let me just make explicit what it is.

在这个极限中，我们永远不会使用 x = x_0。这正是我们在这个极限中不考虑的一个 x 值。这就是极限的产生方式。这就是今天到目前为止的主题，我们不必考虑这一点，因此乘以和除以这个数字是合法的。这个数字可能很小，但它始终是非零的。

In this limit we never are using x = x_0. That’s exactly the one value of x that we don’t consider in this limit. That’s how limits are cooked up. And that’s sort of been the themes so far today, is that we don’t have to consider that and so this multiplication and division by this number is legal. It may be small, this number, but it’s always non zero.

所以这确实有效，而且确实如此，我们刚刚检查了可微函数是连续的。所以我下次要执行这些极限，它们非常有趣，是 0 / 0 极限。但在我们停下来之前，让我们等一下，看看是否还有问题。是的，有一个问题。学生：教授：在这里重复这个证明？再说一遍。

So this really works, and it’s really true, and we just checked that a differentiable function is continuous. So I’m gonna have to carry out these limits, which are very interesting 0 / 0 limits next time. But let’s hang on for one second to see if there any questions before we stop. Yeah, there is a question. Student: Professor: Repeat this proof right here? Just say again.

学生：教授：好的，所以证明有两个步骤，你问的步骤是第一步。对吧？我的意思是，如果你有一个数字，你把它乘以 10/10，它还是相同的数字。如果你把它乘以 3/3，它还是相同的数字。2/2、1/1，等等。所以可以把它改成这样，它们完全是一回事。

Student: Professor: Okay, so there are two steps to the proof and the step that you’re asking about is the first step. Right? And what I’m saying is if you have a number, and you multiply it by 10 / 10 it’s the same number. If you multiply it by 3 / 3 it’s the same number. 2 / 2,1 / 1, and so on. So it is okay to change this to this, it’s exactly the same thing.

这是第一步。对吧？学生：教授：嘘。问题是如何证明，这条线是如何证明的，是的，问号在哪里。所以我检查的是，左边的这个数字等于这个非常长的复杂数字，这个数字等于这个数字，这个数字等于这个数字。

That’s the first step. Yes? Student: Professor: Shhhh. The question was how does the proof, how does this line, yeah where the question mark is. So what I checked was that this number which is on the left hand side is equal to this very long complicated number which is equal to this number which is equal to this number.

所以我检查了这个数字是否等于 0，因为最后一个数字是 0。这等于那个等于那个等于 0。这就是证明。是吗？学生：教授：所以这是另一个问题。好的，我使用可微性假设，因为这个极限等于这个数字。那个极限存在。这就是我使用定理假设的方式。

And so I’ve checked that this number is equal to 0 because the last thing is 0. This is equal to that is equal to that is equal to 0. And that’s the proof. Yes? Student: Professor: So that’s a different question. Okay, so the hypothesis of differentiability I use because this limit is equal to this number. That that limit exits. That’s how I use the hypothesis of the theorem.

定理的结论与此相同，因为连续性与极限相同，当 x 趋向于 x_0 时，f(x) 等于 f(x_0)。这是连续性的定义。我从两边减去 f(x_0) 得到相同的结果。所以这个说法是连续性的，它与这个问题相同。最后一个问题。

The conclusion of the theorem is the same as this because being continuous is the same as limit as x goes to x_0 of f(x) is equal to f(x_0). That’s the definition of continuity. And I subtracted f(x_0) from both sides to get this as being the same thing. So this claim is continuity and it’s the same as this question here. Last question.

学生：你是怎么得到 0 的？教授：我们是怎么从中得到 0 的？所以，这个说法是，为什么这个趋向于那个。例如，我必须删除一些东西来解释这一点。所以这个说法是，当 x 趋向于 x_0 时，x 的极限等于 0。这就是我的说法。好的，这回答了你的问题吗？好的。好的。课后再问我其他问题。

Student: How did you get the 0 Professor: How did we get the 0 from this? So the claim that is being made, so the claim is why is this tending to that.
