And this is typically what’s done when you have an exponential, when you have an exponent. And what we found was that the limit here was 1 as k goes to infinity. So last time, this is what we did. And I just wanted to be careful and show you exactly what the next step is. If you exponentiate this fact; you take e to this power, that’s going to tend to e^1, which is just e.

然后，我们观察到这与 a_k 相同。所以这里的基本要素是 e^ln a = a。这是因为对数函数是指数函数的反函数。是的，问题？学生：教授：所以问题是，这个的对数不是 0 吗，因为 a_k 趋向于 1。但 a_k 并不趋向于 1。谁说的？

And then, we just observe that this is the same as a_k. So the basic ingredient here is that e^ln a = a. That’s because the log function is the inverse of the exponential function. Yes, question? STUDENT: PROFESSOR: So the question was, wouldn’t the log of this be 0 because a_k is tending to 1. But a_k isn’t tending to 1. Who said it was?

如果取对数，也就是我们上次所做的，a_k 的对数确实是 k * ln(1 + 1/k)。它不趋向于 0。这部分趋向于 0，这部分趋向于无穷大。它们相互平衡，0 乘以无穷大。从这个表达式中我们还不知道答案，事实上，我们巧妙地利用了极限和导数来找出这个极限。这是非常微妙的事情。

If you take the logarithm, which is what we did last time, logarithm of a_k is indeed k * ln(1 + 1/k). That does not tend to 0. This part of it tends to 0, and this part tends to infinity. And they balance each other, 0 times infinity. We don’t really know yet from this expression, in fact we did some cleverness with limits and derivatives, to figure out this limit. It was a very subtle thing.

结果是 1。好吗？现在，我想说的是，很抱歉，我要把这个抹掉，但你需要回到你的笔记，记住这是我们上次做的。因为我想在这块小黑板上留出空间写下我想说的下一条评论。

It turned out to be 1. All right? Now, the thing that I’d like to say I’m sorry I’m going to erase this aside here but you need to go back to your notes and remember that this is what we did last time. Because I want to have room for the next comment that I want to make on this little blackboard here.

我们刚刚推导出的是这个属性，但我昨天提出了一个主张，我只是想再次强调一下，以便我们意识到我们在做什么。我反向看待了这个问题。你可以这样想，我们正在评估这个极限并得到答案。但所有等式都可以双向解读。

What we just derived was this property here, but I made a claim yesterday, and I just want to emphasize it again so that we realized what it is that we’re doing. I looked at this backwards. One way you can think of this is we’re evaluating this limit and getting an answer. But all equalities can be read both directions.

我们也可以反过来写：当 k 趋向无穷大时，e 等于这个表达式的极限。所以这是一回事。如果我们反过来读，我们说的是这个极限是 e 的公式。所以这在数学中很典型。你总是想一直颠倒你的观点。方程式是双向的，在这种情况下，我们有两个不同的东西。

And we can write it the other way: e equals the limit, as k goes to infinity, of this expression here. So that’s just the same thing. And if we read it backwards, what we’re saying is that this limit is a formula for e. So this is very typical of mathematics. You want to always reverse your perspective all the time. Equations work both ways, and in this case, we have two different things here.

这个 e 就是我们定义的底数，当你绘制 e^x 的图形时，你会在 0 处得到斜率 1。然后它等于这个极限，我们可以用数字计算。如果你在计算器上这样做，你当然有办法对这个数字进行编程并为每个 k 求值。而且你会有另一个按钮来计算这个数字。

This e was what we defined as the base, which when you graph e^x, you get slope 1 at 0. And then it turns out to be equal to this limit, which we can calculate numerically. If you do this on your calculators, you, of course, will have a way of programming in this number and evaluating it for each k. And you’ll have another button available to evaluate this one.

换句话说，这两个事物之间存在某种关系。微积分的全部内容就是获得这些关系。因此，我们可以从几个不同的角度来看待这些事物。事实上，至少在今天结束时，我们在讨论衍生品时将要这样做。很多时候，当我们谈论衍生品时，我们会尝试同时从几个角度来看待它们。

So another way of saying it is it that there’s a relationship between these two things. And all of calculus is a matter of getting these relationships. So we can look at these things in several different ways. And indeed, that’s what we’re going to be doing at least at the end of today in talking about derivatives. A lot of times when we talk about derivatives, we’re trying to look at them from several perspectives at once.

好的，我必须继续讨论指数，因为我还有一件事情没有解决。我还没有讲到。还剩下一个非常重要的公式，那就是幂的导数。我们实际上做得不是很好，我们只是针对有理数 r 做了这个。所以这是这里的公式。但现在我们要对所有实数 r 进行检查。包括所有无理数。

Okay, so I have to keep on going with exponents, because I have one loose end. One loose end that I did not cover yet. There’s one very important formula that’s left, and it’s the derivative of the powers. We actually didn’t do this well we did it for rational numbers r. So this is the formula here. But now we’re going to check this for all real numbers, r. So including all the irrational ones as well.

这也是使用底数为 e 和对数微分的良好做法。因此，让我通过我们可以用来处理指数类型问题的两种方法来做到这一点。方法一是底数为 e。因此，如果我再次重写这个底数为 e，那就是这里的这个公式。x^r = (e^ln x)^r，即 e^r ln x。好的，现在我可以对其进行微分了。

This is also good practice for using base e and using logarithmic differentiation. So let me do this by our two methods that we can use to handle exponential type problems. So method one was base e. So if I just rewrite this base e again, that’s just this formula over here. x^r = (e^ln x)^r, which is e^r ln x. Okay, so now I can differentiate this.

所以我得到了 d/dx (x^r)，现在我要使用素数符号，因为我不想在这里一直写 d/dx；(e^(r ln x))'。现在，我能做的是使用链式法则。链式法则说它是这个函数的导数乘以函数的导数。所以指数的导数就是它本身。

So I get that d/dx (x^r), now I’m going to use prime notation, because I don’t want to keep on writing that d/dx here; (e^(r ln x))’. And now, what I can do is I can use the chain rule. The chain rule says that it’s the derivative of this times the derivative of the function. So the derivative of the exponential is just itself.

这里的这个导数，我先写出来，是 (r ln x)'。那么它等于什么呢？嗯，e^(r ln x) 就是 x^r。这里的导数是。嗯，r 的导数是 0。这是一个常数。它只是分解出来的。ln x 现在有导数。ln x 的导数是什么？1/x，所以这将是乘以 r/x。

And the derivative of this guy here, well I’ll write it out once, is (r ln x)’. So what’s that equal to? Well, e^(r ln x) is just x^r. And this derivative here is. Well the derivative of r is 0. This is a constant. It just factors out. And ln x now has derivative. What’s the derivative of ln x? 1/x, so this is going to be times r/x.

现在，我们将其重写为惯用形式，即 r，我们将 r 放在前面，x^(r 1)。好吗？我刚刚为您推导出了公式。无论 r 是有理数还是无理数，证明都是一样的。好的，现在我必须向您展示方法二的工作原理。让我们来做方法二，我们称之为对数微分。

And now, we rewrite it in the customary form, which is r, we put the r in front, x^(r 1). Okay? So I just derived the formula for you. And it didn’t matter whether r was rational or irrational, it’s the same proof. Okay so now I have to show you how method two works as well. So let’s do method two, which we call logarithmic differentiation.

因此，在这里我将使用一个符号，比如说 u，表示 x^r，然后取它的对数。即 r ln x。现在我对它进行微分。我将把它放在中间，因为我想记住对数微分的关键性质。但首先我要对它进行微分。稍后，我将使用它与 u'/u 相同。这是求对数导数的一种方法。

And so here I’ll use a symbol, say u, for x^r, and I’ll take its logarithm. That’s r ln x. And now I differentiate it. I’ll leave that in the middle, because I want to remember the key property of logarithmic differentiation. But first I’ll differentiate it. Later on, what I’m going to use is that this is the same as u’/u. This is one way of evaluating a logarithmic derivative.

然后另一个是区分我们这里的显式函数。这就是我们所说的 r/x。所以现在，我将其相乘，得到 u' = ur/x，也就是 x^r/x，这正是我们之前所做的。它是 rx^(r 1)。同样，通过比较这两个算术，你现在可以看到它们基本上是相同的。

And then the other is to differentiate the explicit function that we have over here. And that is just, as we said, r/x. So now, I multiply through, and I get u’ = ur/x which is just x^r/x, which is just what we did before. It’s r x^(r 1). Again, you can now see by comparing these two pieces of arithmetic that they’re basically the same.

几乎每次你转换为底数为 e 或进行对数微分时，只要你不搞混，结果都会是一样的。通常你必须在这里引入一个新符号。另一方面，你在那里处理的是指数。了解这两种观点是值得的。好的，现在我想在结束指数讨论之前做最后评论。

Pretty much every time you convert to base e or you do logarithmic differentiation, it’ll amount to the same thing, provided you don’t get mixed up. You generally have to introduce a new symbol here. On the other hand, you’re dealing with exponents there. It’s worth it to know both points of view. All right, so now I want to make one last remark before we finish with exponents.

随着课程的进行，我会尝试用多种方式向你推销这一点，但我想强调的一点是，自然对数确实是自然的。所以，我认为自然对数是自然的。我们将要用经济学来举例说明。好吗？让我来解释一下为什么自然对数是经济学的自然对数。

And, I’ll try to sell this to you in a lot of ways as the course goes on, but one thing that I want to try to emphasize is that the natural logarithm really is natural. So, I claim that the natural log is natural. And the example that we’re going to use for this illustration is economics. Okay? So let me explain to why the natural log is the one that’s natural for economics.

如果你想象自己持有的股票价格下跌一美元，那完全是毫无意义的。这取决于很多因素。特别是，这取决于原来的价格是一美元还是 100 美元。所以这些绝对数字没有多大意义。重要的永远是比率。

If you are imagining the price of a stock that you own goes down by a dollar, that’s a totally meaningless statement. It depends on a lot of things. In particular, it depends on whether the original price was a dollar or 100 dollars. So there’s not much meaning to these absolute numbers. It’s always the ratios that matter.

例如，我一小时前刚刚查过，伦敦证券交易所收盘时下跌了 27.9，正如我所说，除非你知道该指数的实际总点数，否则这个数字毫无意义。结果是 6,432。因此，价格变化除以价格，在本例中为 27.9/6,432，才是最重要的。在本例中，它恰好是 0.43%。好吗？这就是今天发生的事情。

So, for example, I just looked up an hour ago, the London Exchange closed, and it was down 27.9, which as I said, is pretty meaningless unless you know what the actual total of this index is. It turns out it was 6,432. So the change in the price, divided by the price, which in this case is 27.9 / 6,432, is what matters. And, in this case, it happens to be .43%. All right? That’s what happened today.

同样，如果你取无穷小值，人们认为天数是相对较小的增量，当你投资股票时，你会对无穷小值感兴趣，你会对 p'/p 感兴趣。p 除以 p 的导数。这只是 (ln p)'。所以这就是让我在它周围放一个小框的对数微分公式。

And similarly, if you take the infinitesimal of this, people think of days as being relatively small increments when you’re investing in a stock, you would be interested in the infinitesimal sense, you would be interested in p’/p. The derivative of p divided by p. That’s just (ln p)’. So this is the let me put a little box around it the formula of logarithmic differentiation.

但我要强调的是，它具有实际意义，经济学家和那些一直在为商品价格建模的人都使用它。当价格大幅波动时，他们从不使用绝对价格。他们总是使用价格的对数。使用以 10 为底的对数或以 2 为底的对数是没有意义的。这些都会让你得到垃圾数据。

But let me just emphasize that it has an actual significance, and it’s the one that’s used by economists and people who are modeling prices of things all the time. They never use absolute prices when there are large swings. They always use the log of the price. And there’s no point in using log base 10, or log base 2. Those give you junk.

它们会给你一个额外的 log 2 因子。显然，自然对数是可以使用的。这比使用以 10 为底的对数并在那里使用 10 的自然对数因子更简单，这完全是显而易见的，因为那样会把一切都搞乱。好吧，这只是一个例子。任何与比率有关的事情都会遇到对数。好吧，差不多就是这样。

They give you an extra factor of log 2. It’s the natural log that’s the obvious one to use. It’s completely straightforward that this is a simpler expression than using log base 10 and having a factor of natural log of 10 there, which would just mess everything up. All right, so this is just one illustration. Anything that has to do with ratios is going to encounter logarithms. All right, so that’s pretty much it.

无论如何，我现在想说的就这么多。还有很多话要说，但我们会在第二个单元讲到导数的应用时再说。现在，我想开始复习。我将介绍一下我们在这个单元中做了什么。我会大致告诉你我对你明天的考试有什么期望。好吧，让我们开始吧。

That’s all I want to say for now anyway. There’s lots more to say, but we’ll be saying it when we do applications of derivatives in the second unit. So now, what I’d like to do is to start a review. I’m just going to run through what we did in this unit. I’ll tell you approximately what I expect from you on the test that’s coming up tomorrow. And, well, so let’s get started with that.

这是对第一单元的复习。我会把所有你需要思考、记住的东西都写在黑板上。还有所谓的导数的通用公式。还有一些具体公式。让我提醒一下通用公式是什么。它们包括你用来区分和、函数倍数、乘法规则和商规则的方法。

So this is a review of Unit One. And I’m just going to put on the board all of the things that you need to think about, anyway, keep in your head. And there are what are called general formulas for derivatives. And then there are the specific ones. And let me just remind you what the general formulas are. There’s what you do to differentiate a sum, a multiple of a function, the product rule, the quotient rule.

这些都是几个通用公式。还有一个公式，即链式法则，我接下来会稍微讲一下。所以一个函数的导数等于该函数的导数乘以另一个函数的导数。所以这里我把 u 简写为 u(x)。对，这是两种写法之一。

Those are several general formulas. And then there’s one more, which is the chain rule, which I’m going to say just a little bit more about. So the derivative of a function of a function is the derivative of the function times the derivative of the other function. So here, I’ve abbreviated u is u(x). Right, so this is one of two ways of writing it.

另一种方法也是您可以记住的，而且您可能会发现更容易记住。记住这两个公式可能是一个好主意。然后我们做的最后一类通用公式是隐式微分。好吗？所以当你做隐式微分时，你有一个方程，你不必试图求解未知函数。你只需将其放在最简单的形式中，然后进行微分。

The other way is also one that you can keep in mind and you might find easier to remember. It’s probably a good idea to remember both formulas. And then the last type of general formula that we did was implicit differentiation. Okay? So when you do implicit differentiation, you have an equation and you don’t try to solve for the unknown function. You just put it in its simplest form and you differentiate.

所以，我们实际上这样做了，特别是对于逆函数。这是计算函数逆函数的一个非常关键的方法。对数微分也是这种类型。这是一种变换。我们对其他东西进行微分。我们通过取对数然后进行微分来变换方程。好的，所以有很多不同的应用方法。它也可以应用，无论如何，这是其中两种。所以也许在括号里。

So, we actually did this, in particular, for inverses. That was a very, very key method for calculating the inverses of functions. And it’s also true that logarithmic differentiation is of this type. This is a transformation. We’re differentiating something else. We’re transforming the equation by taking its logarithm and then differentiating. Okay, so there are a number of different ways this is applied. It can also be applied, anyway, these are two of them. So maybe in parenthesis.

这些只是例子。好吧。稍后我会尝试给出至少几个规则的例子。现在，您知道如何区分特定函数：好吧，您现在知道如何区分 x^r，这要感谢我刚才所做的。我们有正弦函数和余弦函数，您有责任知道它们的导数是什么。然后是其他三角函数，如正切和正割。

These are just examples. All right. I’ll try to give examples of at least a few of these rules later. So now, the specific functions that you know how to differentiate: well you know how to differentiate now x^r thanks to what I just did. We have the sine and the cosine functions, which you’re responsible for knowing what their derivatives are. And then other trig functions like tan and secant.

我们通常不考虑余割和余切，因为一切都可以用它们来表示。实际上，你可以用正弦和余弦来表示一切。但你会发现记住这些的导数也更方便。所以记住所有这些。好的，然后我们有了 e^x 和 ln x。我们有三角函数的逆。

We generally don’t bother with cosecants and cotangents, because everything can be expressed in terms of these anyway. Actually, you can really express everything in terms of sines and cosines. But what you’ll find is that it’s much more convenient to remember the derivatives of these as well. So memorize all of these. All right, and then we had e^x and ln x. And we had the inverses of the trig functions.

这是我们做的两个：反正切和反正弦。所以这些是你负责的。无论如何，如果你知道这些，你应该有足够的时间来计算其他任何东西。好吧，基本上这个想法是你有一堆特殊公式。你有一堆通用公式。你把它们放在一起，你几乎可以生成任何东西。

These were the two that we did: the arctangent and the arcsine. So those are the ones you’re responsible for. You should have enough time, anyway, to work out anything else, if you know these. All right, so basically the idea is you have a bunch of special formulas. You have a bunch of general formulas. You put them together, and you can generate pretty much anything.

好的，在继续复习之前，我们先来举几个例子。好的，我确实想举几个例子，难度逐渐增加，说明如何将这些东西组合在一起。首先，你应该记住，如果你区分割线函数，那只是哦，我刚刚意识到我之前想说点别的，所以忘了它吧。我们马上就做。

Okay, so let’s do a few examples before going on with the review. Okay, so I do want to do a few examples in sort of increasing level of difficulty in how you would combine these things together. So first of all, you should remember that if you differentiate the secant function, that’s just oh I just realized that I wanted to say something else before so forget that. We’ll do that in a second.

我想做一些一般性的评论。所以有一条规则在我不在的时候你们讨论了，那就是链式法则。现在我想对链式法则做几点评论，提醒你们它是什么，并介绍一些后果。所以，关于链式法则还有一点额外的内容。我想说的第一件事是，我们并没有真正完全解释为什么它是正确的。

I wanted to make some general remarks. So there’s one rule that you discussed in my absence, which is the chain rule. And I do want to make just a couple of remarks about the chain rule now to remind you of what it is, and also to present some consequences. So, a little bit of extra on the chain rule. The first thing that I want say is that we didn’t really fully explain why it’s true.

我确实想通过例子来解释一下，好吗？假设你有一个函数，比如说 10x + b。好吗？所以 y = 10x + b。那么显然，y 的变化速度是 b 的 10 倍，对吧？

And I do want to just explain it by example, okay? So imagine that you have a function which is, say, 10x + b. All right? So y = 10x + b. Then obviously, y is changing 10 times as fast as b, right?

问题是这里的数字 dy/dx 是 10。现在，如果 x 是某个东西（比如 t）的函数，在这里被其他常数移动，那么 dx/dt = 5。现在，链式法则表明，如果 y 的速度是 t 的 10 倍，对不起，是 x 的速度，而 x 的速度是 t 的 5 倍，那么 y 的速度就是 t 的 50 倍。

The issue is this number here, dy/dx, is 10. And now if x is a function of something, say t, shifted by some other constant here, then dx/dt = 5. Now all the chain rule is saying is that if y is going 10 times as fast as t, I’m sorry as x, and x is going 5 times as fast as t, then y is going 50 times as fast as t.

从代数上讲，这意味着如果我代入并代入，也就是两个函数的合成结果，10(5t + a) + b，然后将其相乘，得到 50t + 10a + b。现在这些项不重要了。常数项不重要。

And algebraically, all this means is if I plug in and substitute, which is what the composition of the two functions amounts to, 10(5t + a) + b and I multiply it out, I get 50t + 10a + b. Now these terms don’t matter. The constant terms don’t matter.

速率是 50。因此，如果我们把它们放在一起，结果是 dy/dt = 10*5，也就是 50。好吧，简而言之，这就是链式法则起作用的原因。以及这些速率相乘的原因。我想说的第二件事是，链式法则有一些后果，使其他一些规则更容易记住或避免。

The rate is 50. And so the consequence, if we put them together, is that dy/dt = 10*5, which is 50. All right, so this is in a nutshell why the chain rule works. And why these rates multiply. The second thing that I wanted to say about the chain rule is that it has a few consequences that make some of the other rules a little easier to remember or possibly to avoid.

在我看来，最复杂的规则是商法则，它有点难记。所以我提醒你一下，如果你只取一个函数的倒数，然后对其进行微分，还有另一种看待它的方式。这实际上是我使用的方式，所以我想鼓励你也这样思考。这与 (v^( 1))' 相同。

The messiest rule in my humble opinion is the quotient rule, which is kind of a nuisance to remember. So let me just remind you, if you take just the reciprocal of a function, and you differentiate it, there’s another way of looking at this. And it’s actually the way that I use, so I want to encourage you to think about it this way too. This is the same as (v^( 1))’.

现在，我们不用使用商法则（我们本来可以使用商法则），而是使用幂 1 的链式法则，它遵循幂律。那么这等于什么呢？这等于 v^( 2) v'。所以在这里，我应用了链式法则而不是商法则。同样，假设我想推导出完整的商法则。好吧，现在这可能更容易，也可能更难。

And now instead of using the quotient rule, which we could’ve used, we can use the chain rule here with the power 1, which works by the power law. So what is this equal to? This is equal to v^( 2) v’. So here, I’ve applied the chain rule rather than the quotient rule. And similarly, suppose I wanted to derive the full quotient rule. Well, now this may or may not be easier.

但这是记住发生了什么的一种方式。如果你将它转换为 uv^( 1) 并对其进行微分，现在我可以对此使用乘积规则。当然，我必须使用链式法则和此规则。那么我得到了什么？我得到 u' 逆，加上 u，然后我必须对 v 逆进行微分。这就是上面的公式。这是 v^( 2) v'。所以这是这样做的一种方法。

But this is one way of remembering what’s going on. If you convert it to uv^( 1) and you differentiate that, now I can use the product rule on this. Of course, I have to use the chain rule and this rule as well. So what do I get? I get u’the inverse, plus u, and then I have to differentiate the v inverse. That’s the formula right up here. That’s v^( 2) v’. So that’s one way of doing it.

这实际上解释了公式中对 v 求导时出现的奇怪的减号。另一个公式，我们采用的另一种方法是将其放在一个公分母上。公分母是 v^2。这来自这个 v^(2)。然后第二项是 uv'。第一项，我们必须乘以 v 的一个额外因子，因为分母中有 av^2。所以它是 u'v。

This actually explains the funny minus sign when you differentiate v in the formula. The other formula, the other way that we did it, was by putting this over a common denominator. The common denominator was v^2. This comes from this v^( 2). And then the second term is uv’. And the first term, we have to multiply by an extra factor of v, because we have a v^2 in the denominator. So it’s u’v.

好的，这就是我们在课堂上写下的商法则，这只是记住它或不记住它而推导它的另一种方法，只要你记住链式法则和乘法法则即可。好的，你会发现在许多情况下，做其中一种或另一种更容易。好的，现在我准备区分正割和一些这样的函数。所以我们在这里举几个例子。

All right, so this is the quotient rule as we wrote it down in lecture, and this is just another way of remembering it or deriving it without remembering it, if you just remember the chain rule and the product rule. Okay, so you’ll find that in many contexts, it’s easier to do one or the other. Okay, so now I’m ready to differentiate the secant and a few such functions. So we’ll do some examples here.

这是正割函数，我想用上面的公式来计算倒数。这是我的想法。这是 1 次方的余弦函数。所以，这里的公式是什么？它只是 (cos x)^( 2) 乘以 sin x。所以现在这通常以不同的方式写出来，所以实际上我这样做是有原因的。

So here’s the secant function, and I want to use that formula up there for the reciprocal. This is the way I think of it. This is the cosine function to the power 1. And so, the formula here is just what? It’s just (cos x)^( 2) times sin x. So now this is usually written in a different fashion, so that’s why I’m doing this for a reason actually.

也就是说，尽管有多种公式，但对于三角函数，通常有五种写法。所以我把这个写下来，这样你就知道标准的表示方法是什么。所以这里发生的事情是我们有两个减号抵消。我们得到 sin x / cos^2 x。这是一个完全可以接受的答案，但有一种习惯的写法。

Which is although there are several formulas for things, with trig functions, there are usually five ways of writing something. So I’m writing this one down so that you know what the standard way of presenting it is. So what happens here is that we have two minus signs cancelling. And we get sin x / cos^2 x. That’s a perfectly acceptable answer, but there’s a customary way in which is written.

它写成 (1 / cos x) (sin x / cos x)。然后我们通过用正割和正切的形式重写它来去掉分母，所以 sec x tan x。所以这是教科书中通常使用的公式形式。

It’s written (1 / cos x) (sin x / cos x). And then we get rid of the denominators by rewriting it in terms of secant and tangent, so sec x tan x. So this is the form that’s generally used when you see these formulas written in textbooks.

所以，你需要小心，因为如果你想使用这种微积分，你就不能被所有的正割和切线所吓倒。好吧，稍微复杂一点，如果我们微分 ln(sec x) 怎么样？如果你微分自然对数，那就是 (sec x)' / sec x。

And so you know, you need to watch out, because if you ever want to use this kind of calculus, you’ll have not be put off by all the secants and tangents. All right, so getting slightly more complicated, how about if we differentiate ln(sec x)? If you differentiate the natural log, that’s just going to be (sec x)’ / sec x.

代入我们之前的公式，就是 sec x tan x / sec x，也就是 tan x。所以这个公式也有一个非常好的形式。你可能会说这是一个丑陋的函数，但奇怪的是，自然对数是在指数函数之前由一个叫纳皮尔的人发明的，正是为了评估这样的函数。

And plugging in the formula that we had before, that’s sec x tan x / sec x, which is tan x. So this one also has a very nice form. And you might say that this is kind of an ugly function, but the strange thing is that the natural log was invented before the exponential by a guy named Napier, exactly in order to evaluate functions like this.

这些是人们非常关心的函数，因为它们用于导航。你需要将正弦和余弦相乘来进行导航。他使用对数对乘法进行编码。所以这些是在人们知道指数之前很久就发明的。令人惊讶的是，它与指数有关。所以自然对数是在以 10 为底的对数和其他一切之前发明的，正是出于这种目的。

These are the functions that people cared about a lot, because they were used in navigation. You wanted to multiply sines and cosines together to do navigation. And the multiplication he encoded using a logarithm. So these were invented long before people even knew about exponents. And it was a surprise, actually, that it was connected to exponents. So the natural log was invented before the log base 10 and everything else, exactly for this kind of purpose.

无论如何，这是一个很好的功能，非常重要，这样你的船就不会撞上珊瑚礁。好的，我们继续。还有另一种功能我想和你讨论。这些是可以选择应用哪些规则的类型。我只会举几个例子。通常有更好和更坏的方法，让我来举例说明。

Anyway, so this is a nice function, which was very important, so that your ships wouldn’t crash into the reef. Okay, let’s continue here. So there’s another kind of function that I want to discuss with you. And these are the kinds in which there’s a choice as to which of these rules to apply. And I’ll just give a couple of examples of that. There usually is a better and a worse way, so let me illustrate that.

好的，还有一个例子。我希望你以前见过这些例子。比如 (x^10 + 8x)^6。所以它比我们以前的例子要复杂一些，因为这里多了几个符号。那么现在我们该怎么做呢？我认为有一个选择是个坏主意，那就是将其展开到 6 次方。这是个坏主意，因为它很长。

Okay, yet another example. I hope you’ve seen some of these before. Say (x^10 + 8x)^6. So it’s a little bit more complicated than what we had before, because there were several more symbols here. So what should we do at this point? There’s one choice which I claim is a bad idea, and that is to expand this out to the 6th power. That’s a bad idea, because it’s very long.

然后你的答案也会很长。比如说，它会填满整个试卷。是吗？学生：你会用链式法则吗？教授：链式法则。就是这样。我们使用链式法则。幸运的是，使用链式法则相对容易。我们只需将这个框视为函数即可。

And then your answer will also be very long. It will fill the entire exam paper, for instance. Yeah? STUDENT: Can you use the chain rule? PROFESSOR: Chain rule. That’s it. We use the chain rule. So fortunately, this is relatively easy using the chain rule. We just think of this box as being the function.

我们用这个数的 6 倍乘以 5 倍，再乘以这个数的导数，也就是 10x^9 + 8。填上这个数，就是 x^10 + 8x。就是这样。这就是你对这类东西求导所需要做的。链式法则非常有效。学生：教授：这个问题问得好。所以我不太愿意回答太多关于考试内容的问题。

And we take 6 times this guy to the 5th, times the derivative of this guy, which is 10x^9 + 8. And this is, filling this in, it’s x^10 + 8x. And that’s it. That’s all you need to do differentiate things like this. The chain rule is very effective. STUDENT: PROFESSOR: That’s a good question. So I’m not really willing to answer too many questions about what’s going to be on the exam.

但刚才问的问题正是我非常乐意回答的那种问题。好的，问题是，以什么形式回答才是可接受的答案？在现实生活中，这是一个非常严肃的问题。当你问计算机一个问题，它给你 5 亿张打印输出时，这是无用的。

But the question that was just asked is exactly the kind of question I’m very happy to answer. Okay, the question was, in what form is. what form is an acceptable answer? Now in real life, that is a really serious question. When you ask a computer a question and it gives you 500 million sheets of printout, it’s useless.

你确实关心答案的形式，事实上，有人可能真的关心这个 6 次方是什么，然后你就不得不用另一种函数形式来讨论问题。就这次考试而言，这是可以接受的形式。事实上，任何正确的形式都是可以接受的形式。我强烈建议你不要试图简化事情，除非我们告诉你这样做。

And you really care what form answers are in, and indeed, somebody might really care what this thing to the 6th power is, and then you would be forced to discuss things in terms of that other functional form. For the purposes of this exam, this is okay form. And, in fact, any correct form is an okay form. I recommend strongly that you not try to simplify things unless we tell you to.

有时简化事情对你有利。有时我们会说简化。需要大量的经验才能知道什么时候简化表达式是真正值得的。是吗？学生：教授：好的，那么转到这个例子。问题是这个导数是什么？这是答案。这就是问题的结束。这是一种更习惯的形式。但这个答案没问题。同样的问题。这正是重点。是吗？学生：教授：。

Sometimes it will be to your advantage to simplify things. Sometimes we’ll say simplify. It takes a good deal of experience to know when it’s really worth it to simplify expressions. Yes? STUDENT: PROFESSOR: Right, so turning to this example. The question is what is this derivative? And here’s an answer. That’s the end of the problem. This is a more customary form. But this is answer is okay. Same issue. That’s exactly the point. Yes? STUDENT: PROFESSOR:.

问题是，你必须展示这项工作吗？你必须展示这项工作吗？如果我问你 d/dx of sec x 是多少，那么如果你写下这个答案，或者你写下这个答案而不显示任何工作，那么这是可以接受的。如果问题是从余弦导数的公式或类似的东西中推导出这个公式，那么这是不可接受的。

The question is, do you have to show the work? Do you have to show the work? Well if I ask you what is d/dx of sec x, then if you wrote down this answer or you wrote down this answer showing no work, that would be acceptable. If the question was derive the formula for this from the formula for the derivative of the cosine or something like that, then it would not be acceptable.

你必须进行这种算术运算。换句话说，通常这会在各种情况下出现。你基本上只需要遵循指示。是吗？学生：教授：下一个问题是，你是否应该能够证明正弦函数的导数是什么？简短的回答是肯定的。但我将在讨论其余材料时谈到这一点。我们快到了。

You’d have to carry out this arithmetic. So, in other words, typically this will come up, for instance, in various contexts. You just basically have to follow directions. Yes? STUDENT: PROFESSOR:. The next question is, are you expected to be able to prove what the derivative of the sine function is? The short answer to that is yes. But I will be getting to that when I discuss the rest of the material here. We’re almost there.

好的，让我用最后一个例子来结束这些例子。然后我们将讨论诸如正弦函数的导数以及它的推导之类的问题。我想写下的最后一个例子是我在第一堂课中向你们承诺的，即对 e^(x tan^( 1) x 进行微分。基本上你应该能够对任何函数进行微分。这就是我们在开始时提到的那个。

Okay, so let me just finish these examples with one last one. And then we’ll talk about this question of things like the derivative of the sine function, and deriving it. So the last example that I’d like to write down is the one that I promised you in the first lecture, namely to differentiate e^(x tan^( 1) x). Basically you’re supposed to be able to differentiate any function. So this is the one that we mentioned at the beginning.

这就是了。我们开始吧。那它是什么呢？嗯，它等于我必须求导。我必须使用链式法则，它等于指数乘以这个表达式的导数。这是链式法则。这是第一步。现在我必须在这里应用乘积法则。所以我有 e^(x tan^( 1) x)。我对第一个因式求导，所以我得到 tan^( 1) x。

So here it is. Let’s do it. So what is it? Well, it’s just equal to I have to differentiate. I have to use the chain rule it’s equal to the exponential times the derivative of this expression here. That’s the chain rule. That’s the first step. And now I have to apply the product rule here. So I have e^(x tan^( 1) x). And I differentiate the first factor, so I get tan^( 1) x.

加上我微分第二个因数时发生的情况，不考虑 x。所以这就是 x / (1+x^2)。就是这样。这就是问题的结尾。这并不难。当然，它要求你记住所有的规则，以及它们背后的大量公式。所以这和我刚才告诉你的一致。我告诉过你你想知道这个。

Add to it what happens when I differentiate the second factor, leaving alone the x. So that’s x / (1+x^2). And that’s it. That’s the end of the problem. It wasn’t that hard. Of course, it requires you to remember all of the rules, and a lot of formulas underlying them. So that’s consistent with what I just told you. I told you that you wanted to know this.

我告诉过你，你需要知道这个乘法规则，你需要知道链式法则。我想还有一件事，e^x 的导数在这里发挥作用。所以在这些公式中，我们在这次计算中使用了其中四个。好的，那么现在我们在第一单元还讨论了什么其他内容？所以我们讨论的另一个主要内容是导数的定义。

I told you that you needed to know this product rule, and that you needed to know the chain rule. And I guess there was one more thing, the derivative of e^x came into play there. So of these formulas, we used four of them in this one calculation. Okay, so now what other things did we talk about in Unit One? So the main other thing that we talked about was the definition of a derivative.

还有一个目标是要了解导数的含义。因此，我们有几种看待它的方法，或者至少我现在要强调的几种方法。但首先，让我提醒你公式是什么。导数是当 delta x 趋向于 0 时 (f(x + delta x) f(x)) / delta x 的极限。

And also there was sort of a goal which was to get to the meaning of the derivative. So these are things so we had a couple of ways of looking at it, or at least a couple that I’m going to emphasize right now. But first, let me remind you what the formula is. The derivative is the limit as delta x goes to 0 of (f(x + delta x) f(x)) / delta x.

就是这样，这当然是这里的核心焦点。您希望能够通过多种方式识别此公式。那么，我们如何使用它？我们所做的一件事就是计算出一堆变化率。事实上，它们或多或少就是写在这里的那些。这里有函数列表。

So that’s it, and this is certainly going to be a central focus here. And you want to be able to recognize this formula in a number of ways. So, how do we use this? Well one thing we did was we calculated a bunch of these rates of change. In fact, more or less, they’re the ones which are written right over here. This list of functions here.

现在，我们从这里的定义开始直接计算哪些呢？这些是哪些呢？有很多。所以我们从函数 1/x 开始。我们计算了 x^n。我们计算了正弦 x。我们计算了余弦 x。现在正弦 x 和余弦 x 有点微妙。我们使用其他东西来计算它们。我们并没有完全计算出来。

Now, which ones did we start out with just straight from the definition here? Which of these things? There were a whole bunch of them. So we started out with a function 1/x. We did x^n. We did sine x. We did cosine x. Now there was a little bit of subtlety with sine x and cosine x. We got them using something else. We didn’t quite get them all the way.

我们利用 x = 0 的情况得到了它们。我们从 x = 0 处的导数得到了它们，我们得到了正弦和余弦导数的公式。但这是一个涉及代入 sin (x + delta x) 并运行的参数。所以这是一个例子。我们还做了 a^x。可能就是这样。哦，是的，我想就是这样。可能就是这样。不。不是。

We got them using the case x = 0. We got them from the derivative at x = 0, we got the formulas for the derivatives of sine and cosine. But that was an argument which involved plugging in sin (x + delta x), and running through. So that’s one example. We also did a^x. And that may be it. Oh yeah, I think that’s about it. That may be about it. No. It isn’t.

好的，让我在这里做一个你可能还没有想到的联系，那就是我们对 (uv)' 做了同样的事。我们也对 (u / v)' 做了同样的事。很抱歉，我不应该写素数，因为这与那里的说法不一致。我对乘积进行了微分；我使用相同的 delta x 符号对商进行了微分。我想我忘记了，因为事情发生时我不在场。

Okay, so let me make a connection here which you probably haven’t yet made, which is that we did it for (u v)‘. And we also did it for (u / v)’. So sorry, I shouldn’t write primes, because that’s not consistent with the claim there. I differentiated the product; I differentiated the quotient using the same delta x notation. I guess I forgot that because I wasn’t there when it happened.

所以看，这些都是你通过这个做的。当然，你可能必须把它们简化成其他的东西。这些涉及使用其他东西。这一个涉及在 0 处使用此函数的斜率，就像正弦和余弦那样。这一个涉及单个函数 u 和 v 的斜率。这一个也涉及单个。

So look, these are the ones that you do by this. And, of course, you might have to reduce them to other things. These involve using something else. This one involves using the slope of this function at 0, just the way the sine and the cosine did. This one involves the slopes of the individual functions, u and v. And this one also involves the individual.

换句话说，它不会带你一路走到最后，但在每种情况下，它都以更简单的方式来表达。我还可以继续说下去。我们在课堂上没有做过这些，但你肯定。e^x 在一次考试中是完全没问题的。

So, in other words, it doesn’t get you all the way through to the end, but it’s expressed in terms of something simpler in each of these cases. And I could go on. We didn’t do these in class, but you’re certainly. e^x is a perfectly okay one on one of the exams.

我们要求您求 1/x^2。换句话说，我并不是说这个列表中一定会有一个，但它肯定可以是其中任何一个。但我们不会要求您从头到尾地学习这些公式。还有一些基本极限，我当然希望您知道。这些极限您可以反向推导。所以我现在就来描述一下。

We ask you for 1/x^2. In other words, I’m not claiming that it’s going to be one on this list, but it certainly can be any one of these. But we’re not going to ask you to go all the way through to the beginning in these formulas. There are also some fundamental limits that I certainly want you to know about. And these you can derive in reverse. So I will describe that now.

所以，我还要强调以下几点：我现在想倒着读。这是本讲座一开始的主题。也就是说，如果你给定函数 f，你可以通过这里的这个公式找出它的导数。这就是右边的公式。

So let me also emphasize the following thing: I want to read this backwards now. This is the theme from the very beginning of this lecture. Namely, if you’re given the function f, you can figure out its derivative by this formula here. That is the formula for this in terms of what’s on the right hand side.

另一方面，你也可以在那个方向上使用公式，如果你知道某个东西的斜率，你就可以算出极限是多少。例如，我在这里使用字母 x，尽管这是作弊。也许我会把它称为 delta x，这样对你来说更清楚。也许我会把它称为 u。假设你在这里看看这个极限。

On the other hand, you can also use the formula in that direction, and if you know the slope of something, you can figure out what the limit is. For example, I’ll use the letter x here, even though it’s cheating. Maybe I’ll call it delta x so it’s clearer to you. Maybe I’ll call it u. Suppose you look at this limit here.

好吧，我认为你应该认识到这是函数 e^u 在 u = 0 时对 u 的导数，当然我们知道它是 1。所以这是反向阅读这个公式。这是认识到这些极限之一，让我在这里重写一遍，这些所谓的差商极限之一是导数。因为我们知道这个导数的公式，所以我们可以求它。

Well, I claim that you should recognize that is the derivative with respect to u of the function e^u at u = 0, which of course we know to be 1. So this is reading this formula in reverse. It’s recognizing that one of these limits let me rewrite this again here one of these so called difference quotient limits is a derivative. And since we know a formula for that derivative, we can evaluate it.

最后，还有一种我认为你应该知道的东西。这些是你用差商做的。还有其他公式你希望能够推导出来的。你希望能够通过隐式微分推导公式。换句话说，基本思想是尽可能简化你得到的任何方程，而不是坚持要求你求解 y。

And lastly, there’s one other type of thing which I think you should know. These are the ones you do with difference quotients. There are also other formulas that you want to be able to derive. You want to be able to derive formulas by implicit differentiation. In other words, the basic idea is to take whatever equation you’ve got and simplify it as much as possible, without insisting that you solve for y.

这不一定是获得变化率的最合适方法。更简单的公式是 sin y = x。而且这个公式更容易隐式区分。所以我应该说，做这种事情。所以，如果你愿意的话，这就是你可能会看到的典型推导。然后你会面临最后一类问题，这也是我声称我们讨论过的另一件事。

That’s not necessarily the most appropriate way to get the rate of change. The much simpler formula is sin y = x. And that one is easier to differentiate implicitly. So I should say, do this kind of thing. So that’s, if you like, a typical derivation that you might see. And then there’s one last type of problem that you’ll face, and it’s the other thing that I claim we discussed.

这又回到了第一讲。我们最后要讨论的是切线。好吗？导数的几何观点。我们将在下一单元中做更多这方面的讨论。首先，你需要能够计算切线。这通常相当简单。第二件事是绘制函数导数 y' 的图形。

And it goes all the way back to the first lecture. So the last thing that we’ll be talking about is tangent lines. All right? The geometric point of view of a derivative. And we’ll be doing more of this in next the unit. So first of all, you’ll be expected to be able to compute the tangent line. That’s often fairly straightforward. And the second thing is to graph y’,the derivative of a function.

第三件事，我要在这里提出来，因为我认为它是一种几何学，尽管它有分析的一面。所以这是一幅图。这是一个计算。如果你把两者结合起来，你会得到其他的东西。这就是识别可微函数。好吧，那么你怎么做呢？嗯，我们真的只有一种方法可以做到。

And the third thing, which I’m going to throw in here, because I regard it in a sort of geometric vein, although it’s got an analytical aspect to it. So this is a picture. This is a computation. And if you combine the two together, you get something else. And so this is to recognize differentiable functions. Alright, so how do you do this? Well, we really only have one way of doing it.

我们要检查左切线和右切线。它们必须相等。同样，这是您应该从一些练习中熟悉的属性。其想法很简单，如果切线存在，则从右侧和左侧看它都是相同的。好的，现在我将从这种定性素描技巧中举一个例子，在这里给您举一个例子。

We’re going to check the left and right tangents. They must be equal. So again, this is a property that you should be familiar with from some of your exercises. And the idea is simply, that if the tangent line exists, it’s the same from the right and from the left. Okay, now I’m going to just do one example here from this sort of qualitative sketching skill to give you an example here.

我要做的是画出像这样的函数图。下面我要画出导数图。这是函数 y = f(x)，下面我要画出函数 y = f'(x) 的图。现在，让我们想想它应该是什么样子。

And what I’m going to do is I’m going to draw a graph of a function like this. And what I want to do underneath is draw the graph of the derivative. So this is the function y = f(x), and here I’m going to draw the graph of the function y = f’(x) right underneath it. So now, let’s think about what it’s supposed to look like.

要做到这一点，你需要做的一步是画几条切线。我在这里画一条。我在这里画一条。现在，这里的切线，注意这些切线的斜率都是正的。所以我在这里画的所有东西都会在 x 轴上方。此外，当我进一步向左移动时，它们会变得越来越陡峭。

And the one step that you need to make in order to do this, is to draw a few tangent lines. I’m just going to draw one down here. And I’m going to draw one up here. Now, the tangent lines here notice that the slope of these tangent lines are all positive. So everything I draw down here is going to be above the x axis. Furthermore, as I go further to the left, they get steeper and steeper.

所以它们越来越高。所以函数像这样下降。它从那里开始。也许我会用绿色画出来以说明这里的图形。这就是这里的函数。随着我们越走越远，它变得越来越平坦。所以它趋于平稳，但在轴上方就像这样。所以要强调的一件事是，你不应该期望导数看起来像函数。它完全不同。

So they’re getting higher and higher. So the function is coming down like this. It starts up there. Maybe I’ll draw it in green to illustrate the graph here. So that’s this function here. As we get farther out, it’s getting flatter and flatter. So it’s leveling off, but above the axis like that. So one of the things to emphasize is, you should not expect the derivative to look like the function. It’s totally different.

它跟踪切线的每个点。另一方面，你应该对它有某种物理上的感觉，我们将在下一个单元中更多地练习这一点。所以让我给你举一个函数的例子，它就是这样的。它是函数 y = ln x。如果你对它进行微分，你会得到 y' = 1/x。上面的这个图大致是对数。

It’s keeping track at each point of its tangent line. On the other hand, you should get some kind of physical feel for it, and we’ll be practicing this more in the next unit. So let me give you an example of a function which does exactly this. And it’s the function y = ln x. If you differentiate it, you get y’ = 1/x. And this plot above is, roughly speaking, the logarithm.

下面的这个图是函数 1/x。我们还有时间回答一个问题。所以，请开始提问。可以吗？学生：教授：问题是，你能展示如何推导 x 的反正切吗？这是在讲座中。我很乐意现在就做，但这要花我整整两分钟。所以，这是你的推导方法。y = tan^( 1) x。

And this plot underneath is the function 1/x. We still have time for one question. And so, fire away. Yes? STUDENT: PROFESSOR:. The question is, can you show how you derive the inverse tangent of x. So that’s in a lecture. I’m happy to do it right now, but it’s going to take me a whole two minutes. So, here’s how you do it. y = tan^( 1) x.

现在这个公式已经无法求导了，所以我把它改写成 tan y = x。现在我必须求导。所以当我求导时，我得到了 tan y 对 x 的导数。对 y 的导数。也就是 1 / (1 + y^2) 乘以 y'。所以这是很难的一步。这就是链式法则。

And now this is hopeless to differentiate, so I rewrite it as tan y = x. And now I have to differentiate that. So when I differentiate it, I get the derivative of tan y with respect to x. with respect to y. That’s 1 / (1 + y^2) times y’. So this is a hard step. That’s the chain rule.

在左边我得到 1。所以我做得非常快，因为我们还有三十秒。但这一步很难。你需要知道 d/dy tan y 等于一除以 1。哦，糟糕，割线平方。我太快了。所以这是恒等式。所以你需要提前知道这一点。这就是这个等式的输入。

And on the left side I get 1. So I’m doing this super fast because we have thirty seconds left. But this is the hard step right here. And it needs for you to know that d/dy tan y is equal to one over. Oh, bad, secant squared. I was ahead of myself so fast. So here’s the identity. So you need have known this in advance. And that’s the input into this equation.

所以现在，我们得到的是 y' = 1 / sec^2 y，它与 cos^2 y 是同一个东西。现在，问题的最后一部分是用 x 来重写它。而这需要用直角三角形来处理。如果这是 x，这是 1，那么角度就是 y，因为 y 的正切是 x。所以这表达了 y 的正切是 x 的事实。

So now, what we have is that y’ = 1 / sec^2 y, which is the same thing as cos^2 y. Now, the last bit of the problem is to rewrite this in terms of x. And that you have to do with a right triangle. If this is x and this is 1, then the angle is y, because the tangent of y is x. So this expresses the fact that the tangent of y is x.

然后斜边是 1 + x^2 的平方根。所以余弦是 1 除以它。所以这个数字是 1 除以 1 + x^2 的平方根，即平方量。所以，这里的最后一点，因为我在赶时间，它是 1 / (1 + x^2)，我在这里写错了。好的，祝你考试顺利。明天见。

And then the hypotenuse is the square root of 1 + x^2. And so the cosine is 1 divided by that. So this thing is 1 divided by the square root of 1 + x^2, the quantity squared. So, and then the last little bit here, since I’m racing along, is that it’s 1 / (1 + x^2), which I incorrectly wrote over here. Okay, so good luck on the test. See you tomorrow.

Lec 9 | MIT 18.01 单变量微积分，2007 年秋季

Lec 9 | MIT 18.01 Single Variable Calculus, Fall 2007

16 年前 (2009 年 2 月 20 日) — 46:48 https://youtube.com/watch?v=BSAA0akmPEU

16 years ago (Feb 20, 2009) — 46:48 https://youtube.com/watch?v=BSAA0akmPEU

The following content is provided under a Creative Commons license. Your support will help MIT OpenCourseWare continue to offer high quality educational resources for free. To make a donation, or to view additional materials from hundreds of MIT courses, visit MIT OpenCourseWare at ocw.mit.edu. PROF. JERISON: We’re starting a new unit today. And, so this is Unit 2, and it’s called Applications of Differentiation. OK.

因此，第一个应用，我们今天要做两个，就是所谓的线性近似。哎呀，里面应该有两个 p。近似。因此，这可以用一个公式来总结，但我们至少需要半个小时来解释如何使用这个公式。所以这是公式。它的 f(x) 约等于其在基点的值加上导数乘以 x x_0。对吗？

So, the first application, and we’re going to do two today, is what are known as linear approximations. Whoops, that should have two p’s in it. Approximations. So, that can be summarized with one formula, but it’s going to take us at least half an hour to explain how this formula is used. So here’s the formula. It’s f(x) is approximately equal to its value at a base point plus the derivative times x x_0. Right?

这是目前的主要公式。把它放在一个框里。首先，让我先描述一下它的含义。然后我会再次描述它的含义，并且还会多次描述。首先，它的意思是，如果你有一条曲线，即 y = f(x)，它与它的切线大致相同。所以另一边是切线方程。让我们举个例子。

So this is the main formula. For right now. Put it in a box. And let me just describe what it means, first. And then I’ll describe what it means again, and several other times. So, first of all, what it means is that if you have a curve, which is y = f(x), it’s approximately the same as its tangent line. So this other side is the equation of the tangent line. So let’s give an example.

我要取函数 f(x)，即 ln x，然后它的导数是 1/x。因此，我们取基点 x_0 = 1。这几乎是我们唯一可以确定对数的地方。因此，我们现在在这里插入的是值。

I’m going to take the function f(x), which is ln x, and then its derivative is 1/x. And, so let’s take the base point x_0 = 1. That’s pretty much the only place where we know the logarithm for sure. And so, what we plug in here now, are the values.

因此 f(1) 是 0 的对数。或者，抱歉，是 1 的对数，也就是 0。而 f'(1)，嗯，也就是 1/1，也就是 1。所以现在我们有一个近似公式，如果我把上面的公式抄下来，它就是 ln x 的近似值，所以 f(0) 是 0，对吧？加上 1 乘以 (x 1)。所以我在这里代入了 x_0 的三个位置。我计算了系数，这就是因变量。

So f(1) is the log of 0. Or, sorry, the log of 1, which is 0. And f’(1), well, that’s 1/1, which is 1. So now we have an approximation formula which, if I copy down what’s right up here, it’s going to be ln x is approximately, so f(0) is 0, right? Plus 1 times (x 1). So I plugged in here, for x_0, three places. I evaluated the coefficients and this is the dependent variable.

总而言之，如果你愿意的话，我这里给出的是 x 的对数大约为 x 1。让我画一张图。这是 ln x 的图。然后，我将在我们正在考虑的地方画一条切线，也就是 x = 1。这是切线。我把它分开了一点，但实际上我应该把它画得更近一点，以便向你展示。

So, all told, if you like, what I have here is that the logarithm of x is approximately x 1. And let me draw a picture of this. So here’s the graph of ln x. And then, I’ll draw in the tangent line at the place that we’re considering, which is x = 1. So here’s the tangent line. And I’ve separated a little bit, but really I probably should have drawn it a little closer there, to show you.

重点是这两个点很接近。但它们并不是到处都接近。所以这是 y = x 1 的直线。对，这是切线。只有当 x 接近 1 时，它们才接近。所以在这个小范围内。所以当 x 近似为 1 时，这是正确的。一旦你离得远一点，这条直线，这条直绿线就会与图形分离。但在这个地方附近，它们靠得很近。

The whole point is that these two are nearby. But they’re not nearby everywhere. So this is the line y = x 1. Right, that’s the tangent line. They’re nearby only when x is near 1. So say in this little realm here. So when x is approximately 1, this is true. Once you get a little farther away, this straight line, this straight green line will separate from the graph. But near this place they’re close together.

所以这个想法是，曲线，弯曲的线，近似于切线。这是一个例子。好的，我想再解释一下。然后我们要系统地讨论它。所以我要描述的第二种方式需要我提醒你导数的定义是什么。

So the idea, again, is that the curve, the curved line, is approximately the tangent line. And this is one example of it. All right, so I want to explain this in one more way. And then we want to discuss it systematically. So the second way that I want to describe this requires me to remind you what the definition of the derivative is.

因此，导数的定义是，当 delta x 趋于 0 时，delta f / delta x 的极限，这是一种写法，对吧？这是我们定义它的方式。我们在第一单元中做的一件事就是反向研究它。我们利用导数，知道函数的导数来求一些极限。所以你应该在你的课上这样做。

So, the definition of a derivative is that it’s the limit, as delta x goes to 0, of delta f / delta x, that’s one way of writing it, all right? And this is the way we defined it. And one of the things that we did in the first unit was we looked at this backwards. We used the derivative knowing the derivatives of functions to evaluate some limits. So you were supposed to do that on your.

在我们的测试中，有一些例子，至少有一个例子，这是解决问题的最简单方法。换句话说，你可以用两种方式解读这个方程。当然，这实际上是同一个方程写了两次。

In our test, there were some examples there, at least one example, where that was the easiest way to do the problem. So in other words, you can read this equation both ways. This is really, of course, the same equation written twice.

现在，我们要做的新颖之处在于，我们将采用这里的表达式 delta f / delta x，并且我们会说，当 delta x 非常接近 0 时，这个表达式将非常接近极限值。所以这大约是 f'(x_0)。因此，我认为，这与我这里粉红色框中的内容相同。

Now, what’s new about what we’re going to do now is that we’re going to take this expression here, delta f / delta x, and we’re going to say well, when delta x is fairly near 0, this expression is going to be fairly close to the limiting value. So this is approximately f’(x_0). So that, I claim, is the same as what’s in the box in pink that I have over here.

所以这里的近似公式与这个相同。这是平均变化率，这是无穷小变化率。它们几乎相同。这就是主张。所以你会有各种练习，其中这个近似值是有用的。正如我所说，我今天会稍微说明一下。现在，让我解释一下为什么方框中的这两个公式是相同的。

So this approximation formula here is the same as this one. This is an average rate of change, and this is an infinitesimal rate of change. And they’re nearly the same. That’s the claim. So you’ll have various exercises in which this approximation is the useful one to use. And I will, as I said, I’ll be illustrating this a little bit today. Now, let me just explain why those two formulas in the boxes are the same.

所以让我们从这里开始解释一下。如果我乘以 delta x，较小的框也是一样，因为 delta f 大约是 f'(x_0) delta x。现在，如果我写出它是什么，它是 f(x)，对，减去 f(x_0)，我会这样写。

So let’s just start over here and explain that. So the smaller box is the same thing if I multiply through by delta x, as delta f is approximately f’(x_0) delta x. And now if I just write out what this is, it’s f(x), right, minus f(x_0), I’m going to write it this way.

它近似于 f'(x_0)，这是 x x_0。所以这里我使用的符号 delta x 是 x x0。所以这是 f 的变化，这只是重写了 delta x。现在最后一步就是将常数放在另一边。所以 f(x) 近似于 f(x_0) + f'(x_0)(x x_0)。所以这正是我刚开始说的，对吧？所以这两个只是代数上的相同陈述。

Which is approximately f’(x_0), and this is x x_0. So here I’m using the notations delta x is x x0. And so this is the change in f, this is just rewriting what delta x is. And now the last step is just to put the constant on the other side. So f(x) is approximately f(x_0) + f’(x_0)(x x_0). So this is exactly what I had just to begin with, right? So these two are just algebraically the same statement.

这是另一种看待问题的方式。好的，现在，我想系统地讨论一下几个线性近似，你们会想要记住它们。记住这些并不难，反而会提醒你。这样你就会在记住各种导数时得到很多额外的强化。

That’s one another way of looking at it. All right, so now, I want to go through some systematic discussion here of several linear approximations, which you’re going to be wanting to memorize. And rather than it’s being hard to memorize these, it’s supposed to remind you. So that you’ll have a lot of extra reinforcement in remembering derivatives of all kinds.

因此，当我们进行这些系统性讨论时，我们希望让事情尽可能简单。所以我们所做的一件事就是始终使用 x_0 作为基点。因此，我将始终在要使用的这个标准公式列表中使用 x_0 = 0。如果我将 x_0 = 0，那么这个公式就变成了 f(x)，这样读起来会简单一些。

So, when we carry out these systematic discussions, we want to make things absolutely as simple as possible. And so one of the things that we do is we always use the base point to be x_0. So I’m always going to have x_0 = 0 in this standard list of formulas that I’m going to use. And if I put x_0 = 0, then this formula becomes f(x), a little bit simpler to read.

它变成 f(x) 等于 f(0) + f'(0) x。所以这可能是你最想记住的形式。这只是线性近似。但你必须记住，这非常重要，这个近似只在 x 为 1 附近有效。这里的近似实际上只在 x 接近 x_0 时有效。所以这是你需要加入的一点补充。

It becomes f(x) is f(0) + f’(0) x. So this is probably the form that you’ll want to remember most. That’s again, just the linear approximation. But one always has to remember, and this is a very important thing, this one only worked near x is 1. This approximation here really only works when x is near x_0. So that’s a little addition that you need to throw in.

所以当 x 接近 0 时，这个公式有效。你不能指望它在很远的地方也有效。当曲线远离切点时，它可以去任何它想要去的地方。所以，好吧，让我们来解决这个问题。让我们先对正弦函数、余弦函数和 e^x 进行计算。是的。问题。学生：教授。杰里森：是的。这个公式什么时候有效。好吧，问题是，这个公式什么时候有效。

So this one works when x is near 0. You can’t expect it to be true far away. The curve can go anywhere it wants, when it’s far away from the point of tangency. So, OK, so let’s work this out. Let’s do it for the sine function, for the cosine function, and for e^x, to begin with. Yeah. Question. STUDENT: PROF. JERISON: Yeah. When does this one work. Well, so the question was, when does this one work.

再次说明，这是当 x 近似为 x_0 时的情况。因为它实际上与这里的相同。好的。事实上，当我们取这个极限值时，情况就是这样。Delta x 趋向于 0 时也是一样。Delta x 很小。换句话说，delta x 很小。现在，我们将解释我们所说的“小”的确切含义。

Again, this is when x is approximately x_0. Because it’s actually the same as this one over here. OK. And indeed, that’s what’s going on when we take this limiting value. Delta x going to 0 is the same. Delta x small. So another way of saying it is, the delta x is small. Now, exactly what we mean by small will also be explained.

但在某种程度上，它有多大、有多好，是一个直觉问题。在实际情况下，人们会真正关心它有多小，然后近似才有用。这是一个严重的问题。好吧，让我对 x 进行这些近似。

But it is a matter to some extent of intuition as to how much, how good it is. In practical cases, people will really care about how small it is before the approximation is useful. And that’s a serious issue. All right, so let me carry out these approximations for x.

再次强调，这总是针对接近 0 的 x。所以所有这些都将针对接近 0 的 x。因此，为了进行此计算，我必须评估该函数。我需要在这里插入两个数字。为了得到这个表达式。我需要知道 f(0) 是什么，我需要知道 f'(0) 是什么。

Again, this is always for x near 0. So all of these are going to be for x near 0. So in order to make this computation, I have to evaluate the function. I need to plug in two numbers here. In order to get this expression. I need to know what f(0) is and I need to know what f’(0) is.

如果这是函数 f(x)，那么我将在右边用 f' 制作一个小表格，然后我将计算 f(0)，然后我将计算 f'(0)，然后读出答案。对，首先，如果函数是正弦 x，则导数是余弦 x。f(0) 的值，即 0 的正弦，是 0。导数是余弦。

If this is the function f(x), then I’m going to make a little table over to the right here with f’ and then I’m going to evaluate f(0), and then I’m going to evaluate f’(0), and then read off what the answers are. Right, so first of all if the function is sine x, the derivative is cosine x. The value of f(0), that’s sine of 0, is 0. The derivative is cosine.

0 的余弦是 1。所以就是这样。现在我们有系数 0 和 1。所以这个数字是 0。这个数字是 1。所以我们得到的是 0 + 1x，所以这大约是 x。这是 sin x 的线性近似值。同样，现在这是一个常规问题，只需将其读出到此表即可。我们将对余弦函数执行此操作。

Cosine of 0 is 1. So there we go. So now we have the coefficients 0 and 1. So this number is 0. And this number is 1. So what we get here is 0 + 1x, so this is approximately x. There’s the linear approximation to sin x. Similarly, so now this is a routine matter to just read this off for this table. We’ll do it for the cosine function.

如果对余弦求导，得到的是 sin x。0 处的值为 1，因此这是 1 处 0 的余弦。0 处的减正弦值为 0。因此，这又回到了这里，1 + 0x，因此近似为 1。这个线性函数恰好是常数。

If you differentiate the cosine, what you get is sin x. The value at 0 is 1, so that’s cosine of 0 at 1. The value of this minus sine at 0 is 0. So this is going back over here, 1 + 0x, so this is approximately 1. This linear function happens to be constant.

最后，如果我确实需要 e^x，它的导数也是 e^x，它在 0 处的值是 1，导数在 0 处的值也是 1。所以这里的两个项 f(0) 和 f'(0) 都是 1，我们得到 1 + x。所以这些是线性近似值。你可以记住这些。你可能会用这种方式或那种方式记住它们。

And finally, if I do need e^x, its derivative is again e^x, and its value at 0 is 1, the value of the derivative at 0 is also 1. So both of the terms here, f(0) and f’(0), they’re both 1 and we get 1 + x. So these are the linear approximations. You can memorize these. You’ll probably remember them either this way or that way.

此处的信息集合编码的信息集合与我们此处的信息集合相同。函数值及其导数在 0 处的值。因此，让我通过绘制这些结果的图像再次强调几何观点。首先，对于正弦函数，这是正弦，非常接近。所以，这真是个正弦，不是吗？

This collection of information here encodes the same collection of information as we have over here. For the values of the function and the values of their derivatives at 0. So let me just emphasize again the geometric point of view by drawing pictures of these results. So first of all, for the sine function, here’s the sine well, close enough. So that’s boy, now that is quite some sine, isn’t it?

大致来说，我应该尽量让两个凸起的高度相同。无论如何，我们讨论的切线在这里。这是 y = x。这是函数 sine x。在 0 附近，它们非常接近。余弦函数，我想把它放在下面。我想我可以把它放进去。在这里把它弄小一点。所以对于余弦函数，我们在这里。

I should try to make the two bumps be the same height, roughly speaking. Anyway the tangent line we’re talking about is here. And this is y = x. And this is the function sine x. And near 0, those things coincide pretty closely. The cosine function, I’ll put that underneath, I guess. I think I can fit it. Make it a little smaller here. So for the cosine function, we’re up here.

y = 1。好吧，难怪切线是常数。它是水平的。切线是水平的，所以对应的函数是常数。所以这是 y = cos x。最后，如果我画 y = e^x，它就会像这样下来。切线在这里。它是 y = 1 + x。值为 1，斜率为 1。所以如果你愿意的话，这就是用图形方式记住它的方法。

It’s y = 1. Well, no wonder the tangent line is constant. It’s horizontal. The tangent line is horizontal, so the function corresponding is constant. So this is y = cos x. And finally, if I draw y = e^x, that’s coming down like this. And the tangent line is here. And it’s y = 1 + x. The value is 1 and the slope is 1. So this is how to remember it graphically if you like.

这个解析图非常重要，它将帮助你处理正弦、余弦和指数。是的，问题。学生：杰里森教授：问题是你通常将线性近似用于什么。好问题。我们正要开始讨论。首先，我们得到一个小型的线性近似库，我会给你几个例子。好的，现在，我需要用另外两个例子来完成目录，这两个例子稍微有点挑战性。

The question is what do you normally use linear approximations for. Good question. We’re getting there. First, we’re getting a little library of them and I’ll give you a few examples. 还有一点不太明显。所以，接下来我们要做的就是 ln(1+x) 和 (1 + x)^r。好的，这是我们要写下的最后两个。你需要思考一下。现在，程序与这里的相同。也就是说，我必须写下 f'，我必须写下 f'(0)，我必须写下 f'(0)。

And a little bit less obvious. So, the next couple that we’re going to do are ln(1+x) and (1 + x)^r. OK, these are the last two that we’re going to write down. And that you need to think about. 然后我将得到系数，以便能够填写近似值。所以 f' = 1 / (1+x)，以对数为例。如果我代入 f(0)，那就是 1 的对数，也就是 0。如果我在这里代入 0，我会得到 1。同样，如果我对这个进行同样的操作，我会得到 r(1+x)^(r 1)。

And then I’ll have the coefficients to be able to fill in what the approximation is. So f’ = 1 / (1+x), in the case of the logarithm. And f(0), if I plug in, that’s log of 1, which is 0. And f’ if I plug in 0 here, I get 1. And similarly if I do it for this one, I get r(1+x)^(r 1).

当我代入 f(0) 时，我得到 1^r，也就是 1。这里我得到 r (1)^(r 1)，也就是 r。所以这里对应的陈述是 ln(1+x) 近似于 x。而 (1+x)^r 近似于 1 + rx。也就是 0 + 1x，这里我们有 1 + rx。现在，我确实想建立一种联系，向你们解释这里发生了什么以及与第一个例子的联系。我们已经做过一次对数了。

And when I plug in f(0), I get 1^r, which is 1. And here I get r (1)^(r 1), which is r. So the corresponding statement here is that ln(1+x) is approximately x. And (1+x)^r is approximately 1 + rx. That’s 0 + 1x and here we have 1 + rx. And now, I do want to make a connection, explain to you what’s going on here and the connection with the first example. We already did the logarithm once.

我们只需指出，这两个计算是相同的，或者说几乎是相同的。这里我使用基点 1，但由于我的形式有点方便，我声称，这种形式最终将对几乎所有用途都更加方便，我们希望在 x 近似为 0 时进行这些操作。您无法展开对数并理解 x 等于 0 时的切线，因为它下降到负无穷大。

And let’s just point out that these two computations are the same, or practically the same. Here I use the base point 1, but because of my, sort of, convenient form, which will end up, I claim, being much more convenient for pretty much every purpose, we want to do these things near x is approximately 0. You cannot expand the logarithm and understand a tangent line for it at x equals 0, because it goes down to minus infinity.

类似地，如果你尝试绘制 (1+x)^r, x^r 的图形，这里不加 1，你会发现斜率有时是无穷大的，等等。所以这是一个糟糕的点选择。1 是一个更好的扩展点选择。然后我们移动一些东西，让它看起来像是 x = 0，通过移动 1。所以与前面的例子的联系是。

Similarly, if you try to graph (1+x)^r, x^r without the 1 here, you’ll discover that sometimes the slope is infinite, and so forth. So this is a bad choice of point. 1 is a much better choice of a place to expand around. And then we shift things so that it looks like it’s x = 0, by shifting by the 1. So the connection with the previous example is that the.

之前我们写的内容我可以写成 ln u = u 1。没错，这只是重新复制我这里的内容。只不过用字母 u 代替字母 x。然后我代入，u = 1 + x。然后，如果我把它复制下来，你会看到我用 au 代替了 1+x，这与此相同。

What we wrote before I could write as ln u = u 1. Right, that’s just recopying what I have over here. Except with the letter u rather than the letter x. And then I plug in, u = 1 + x. And then that, if I copy it down, you see that I have a u in place of 1+x, that’s the same as this.

如果我把 u 写成 1，如果我从 u 中减去 1，这意味着它是 x。这就是右边的内容。所以这些是相同的计算，我只是改变了变量。所以现在我想尝试回答关于如何使用它的问题。以及它的重要性是什么。我要做的就是在这里给你举一个例子。然后试着强调。

And if I write out u 1, if I subtract 1 from u, that means that it’s x. So that’s what’s on the right hand side there. So these are the same computation, I’ve just changed the variable. So now I want to try to address the question that was asked about how this is used. And what the importance is. And what I’m going to do is just give you one example here. And then try to emphasize.

这是第一个有用的想法。或者，如果您愿意，这可能是第二个示例。因此，我们将其称为示例 2，也许。因此，我们只取 1.1 的对数。稍等一下。我们取 1.1 的对数。因此，我声称，根据我们的规则，我可以瞥一眼它，并立即看到它大约是 1/10。那么，我在这里使用了什么？

The first way in which this is a useful idea. So, or maybe this is the second example. If you like. So we’ll call this Example 2, maybe. So let’s just take the logarithm of 1.1. Just a second. 我使用 ln(1+x) 近似于 x，我使用的 x 值是 1/10。对吗？这就是公式，所以我应该在这两个公式周围放一个框。这就是这里的公式，应用 x = 1/10。我声称 1/10 是一个足够小的数字，足够接近 0，这是一个可以接受的陈述。

That’s this formula here, applied with x = 1/10. And I’m claiming that 1/10 is a sufficiently small number, sufficiently close to 0, that this is an OK statement.

所以我想问你的第一个问题是，你认为哪个更复杂。左边还是右边。我认为这是更复杂的事情，你必须用计算器来计算并算出这个数字是多少。这很容易。你知道十分之一是多少。所以我想指出的区分是，这一半，这一部分，这很难。

这很简单。现在，这看起来可能自相矛盾，但我也想在上面做。这很难。这很容易。好的。这看起来更丑，但实际上这是最难的。这为我们提供了有关它的信息。现在，让我告诉你为什么这是真的。看看这里的这一列。这些是困难的，困难的功能。这些是简单的功能。有什么比这更简单？没有。好的。
