这是示例 3。我想要找到 x = 0 附近的线性近似值。当我在 x = 0 附近写下这个表达式时，这与此相同。这与说 x 近似于函数 e^(3x) 除以平方根 1+x 的 0 相同。所以这是一个函数。好的。

So here’s Example 3. I want to, I’ll find the linear approximation near x = 0. I also when I write this expression near x = 0, that’s the same thing as this. That’s the same thing as saying x is approximately 0 of the function e^( 3x) divided by square root 1+x. So here’s a function. OK.

现在，我声称要用于这个近似的只是我们已经推导的近似公式的总和。并将它们代数地结合起来。所以我不会做任何微积分，我只会记住。所以对于 e^(3x)，很明显我应该使用这个公式来计算 e^x。对于另一个，可能不太明显，但我们这里有 1+x 的幂。

Now, what I claim I want to use for the purposes of this approximation, are just the sum of the approximation formulas that we’ve already derived. And just to combine them algebraically. So I’m not going to do any calculus, I’m just going to remember. So with e^( 3x), it’s pretty clear that I should be using this formula for e^x. For the other one, it may be slightly less obvious but we have powers of 1+x over here.

让我们把它们代入。我会把它贴出来，这样你就能记住了。我们将进行近似计算。首先，我要把它写得更直观一些。也就是说，我要把它写成乘积。现在你可以看到指数了。在本例中，r = 1/2，呃，1/2，我们将使用它。好的。

So let’s plug those in. I’ll put this up so that you can remember it. And we’re going to carry out this approximation. So, first of all, I’m going to write this so that it’s slightly more suggestive. Namely, I’m going to write it as a product. And there you can now see the exponent. In this case, r = 1/2, eh 1/2, that we’re going to use. OK.

所以现在我有 e^( 3x) (1+x)^( 1/2)，这将是近似值。好吧，我要使用这个公式。我必须正确使用它。x 被 3x 替换，所以这是 1 3x。然后在这里，我可以逐字复制另一个近似公式，其中 r = 1/2。所以这是乘以 1 1/2 x。现在我要进行乘法。所以这是 1 3x 1/2 x + 3/2 x^2。所以现在，这是我们的公式。

So now I have e^( 3x) (1+x)^( 1/2), and that’s going to be approximately. well I’m going to use this formula. I have to use it correctly. x is replaced by 3x, so this is 1 3x. And then over here, I can just copy verbatim the other approximation formula with r = 1/2. So this is times 1 1/2 x. And now I’m going to carry out the multiplication. So this is 1 3x 1/2 x + 3/2 x^2. So now, here’s our formula.

所以事情还没有结束。事实上，在我现在描述的这种算术中，事情比普通代数、算术要简单得多。原因是还有另一个步骤，我现在要执行。那就是我要在这里扔掉这个项。我要忽略它。事实上，我甚至不必去算它。因为我要把它扔掉。

So now this isn’t where things stop. And indeed, in this kind of arithmetic that I’m describing now, things are easier than they are in ordinary algebra, in arithmetic. The reason is that there’s another step, which I’m now going to perform. Which is that I’m going to throw away this term here. I’m going to ignore it. In fact, I didn’t even have to work it out. Because I’m going to throw it away.

原因是，当我从这个表达式转到这个表达式时，也就是从这种东西转到这种东西时，我已经抛弃了二次项和高阶项。所以这不是唯一的二次项。有很多。如果我要忽略其中一些，我必须忽略它们。事实上，我只想留下线性的东西。

So the reason is that already, when I passed from this expression to this one, that is from this type of thing to this thing, I was already throwing away quadratic and higher ordered terms. So this isn’t the only quadratic term. There are tons of them. I have to ignore all of them if I’m going to ignore some of them. And in fact, I only want to be left with the linear stuff.

因为这就是我真正得到的有效计算。所以，这大约是 1 减，让我们看看。总共是 7/2 x。这是答案。这是线性部分。所以 x^2 项可以忽略不计。所以我们放弃 x^2 项。项和更高。所有这些项都应该是低阶的。如果你想象 x 是 1/10，或者可能是 1/100，那么这些项最终会小得多。

Because that’s all I’m really getting a valid computation for. So, this is approximately 1 minus, so let’s see. It’s a total of 7/2 x. And this is the answer. This is the linear part. So the x^2 term is negligible. So we drop x^2 term. Terms, and higher. All of those terms should be lower order. If you imagine x is 1/10, or maybe 1/100, then these terms will end up being much smaller.

因此，我们采用一种相当粗略的方法。这确实很简单，而且可以节省开支。现在，由于这个单元被称为“应用”，而这些确实是数学应用，所以我还想给你一个实际应用。或者一个在实际生活中出现线性近似的地方。所以也许我们可以将其称为示例 4。这应该是一个实际示例。我会尽力说服你。

So we have a rather crude approach. And that’s really the simplicity, and that’s the savings. So now, since this unit is called Applications, and these are indeed applications to math, I also wanted to give you a real life application. Or a place where linear approximations come up in real life. So maybe we’ll call this Example 4. This is supposedly a real life example. I’ll try to persuade you that it is.

我喜欢这个例子，因为它包含很多数学和物理知识。我现在在地球表面。这里有一颗卫星在朝这个方向运行。速度是 v。这颗卫星上有时钟，因为这是一颗 GPS 卫星。它有时间 T，明白吗？但我有一块手表，它就在这里。我有时间，我会记住的。

So I like this example because it’s got a lot of math, as well as physics in it. So here I am, on the surface of the earth. And here is a satellite going this way. At some velocity, v. And this satellite has a clock on it because this is a GPS satellite. And it has a time, T, OK? But I have a watch, in fact it’s right here. And I have a time which I keep.

也就是 T'，T 和 T' 之间存在一种有趣的关系，称为时间膨胀。这是狭义相对论的结论。公式如下。T' = T 除以 1 的平方根 v 2/c 2，其中 v 是卫星的速度，c 是光速。现在我想大致了解一下我的手表和卫星上的时钟有何不同。

Which is T’And there’s an interesting relationship between T and T’which is called time dilation. And this is from special relativity. And it’s the following formula. T’ = T divided by the square root of 1 v2/c2, where v is the velocity of the satellite, and c is the speed of light. So now I’d like to get a rough idea of how different my watch is from the clock on the satellite.

所以我要使用同样的近似值，我们已经用过一次了。我要写 t。但现在让我提醒你一下。这里的情况是，我们有 (1 u)^( 1/2) 形式的值。这就是我在这里乘以时发生的情况。所以 u = v^2 / c^2。所以在现实生活中，当然，你要使用线性近似的表达式不一定是线性的。它可以是任何物理量。

So I’m going to use this same approximation, we’ve already used it once. I’m going to write t. But now let me just remind you. The situation here is, we have something of the form (1 u)^( 1/2). That’s what’s happening when I multiply through here. So with u = v^2 / c^2. So in real life, of course, the expression that you’re going to use the linear approximation on isn’t necessarily itself linear. It can be any physical quantity.

所以在这种情况下，它是 v 平方除以 c 平方。现在近似公式表明，如果这近似等于，那么同样是相同的规则。有一个 r，然后 x 是 u，所以这是。1/2，所以它是 1 + 1/2 u。所以这是近似的，根据相同的规则，这是 T，T' 近似为 t T(1 + 1/2 v 2/c 2) 现在，我向你保证这将是一个现实生活中的问题。

So in this case it’s v squared over c squared. And now the approximation formula says that if this is approximately equal to, well again it’s the same rule. There’s an r and then x is u, so this is. 1/2, so it’s 1 + 1/2 u. So this is approximately, by the same rule, this is T, T’ is approximately t T(1 + 1/2 v2/c2) Now, I promised you that this would be a real life problem.

所以问题是，当人们设计这些 GPS 系统时，他们会在卫星上运行时钟。你在那里，你正在测量，你正在通过卫星与卫星通话。或者你正在从它的无线电接收信号。问题是，这会导致传输问题吗？有几十个这样的问题需要你检查。所以在这种情况下，实际发生的情况是 v 大约是每秒 4 公里。

So the question is when people were designing these GPS systems, they run clocks in the satellites. You’re down there, you’re making your measurements, you’re talking to the satellite by. or you’re receiving its signals from its radio. The question is, is this going to cause problems in the transmission. And there are dozens of such problems that you have to check for. So in this case, what actually happened is that v is about 4 kilometers per second.

这就是 GPS 卫星的实际速度。事实上，他们必须决定将它们放置在某个高度，如果他们将它们放置在不同的地方，他们可以对此进行调整。无论如何，光速是每秒 3 * 10^5 公里。所以这个数字，v^2 / c^2 约为 10^(10)。

That’s how fast the GPS satellites actually go. In fact, they had to decide to put them at a certain altitude and they could’ve tweaked this if they had put them at different places. Anyway, the speed of light is 3 * 10^5 kilometers per second. So this number, v^2 / c^2 is approximately 10^( 10).

现在，如果你真的追踪一下 GPS 定位会产生多大误差，你会发现误差可能只有一毫米左右。所以实际上这并不重要。这很好。但事实上，设计这些系统的工程师确实使用了这种计算方法。就是这样。

Now, if you actually keep track of how much of an error that would make in a GPS location, what you would find is maybe it’s a millimeter or something like that. So in fact it doesn’t matter. So that’s nice. But in fact the engineers who were designing these systems actually did use this very computation. Exactly this.

他们使用的方式是，他们认为由于时钟不同，当卫星广播其无线电频率时，该频率会发生偏移。会产生偏移。他们认为保真度非常重要，因此他们会以这种偏移方式发射卫星。以补偿信号的方式。

And the way that they used it was, they decided that because the clocks were different, when the satellite broadcasts its radio frequency, that frequency would be shifted. Would be offset. And they decided that the fidelity was so important that they would send the satellites off with this kind of, exactly this, offset. To compensate for the way the signal is.

因此，从小型 GPS 设备良好接收的角度来看，他们正是根据这一规则改变了卫星发射器的频率。顺便说一句，他们没有这样做的原因是，他们忽略了高阶项，即二次项，因为如果取 u^2，其大小为 10^(20)。这实际上完全可以忽略不计。这对任何测量都无关紧要。

So from the point of view of good reception on your little GPS device, they changed the frequency at which the transmitter in the satellites, according to exactly this rule. And incidentally, the reason why they didn’t. they ignored higher order terms, the sort of quadratic terms, is that if you take u^2 that’s a size 10^( 20). And that really is totally negligible. That doesn’t matter to any measurement at all.

这是纳米级的，对于 GPS 的任何用途来说都不重要。好的，这是使用线性近似的一个真实例子。那么，让我们在这里稍作停顿。我要换个话题，谈谈二次近似。但在这之前，我们再问几个问题。是的。学生：教授。杰里森：好的，问题是，假设我用不同的方法做到这一点。

That’s on the order of nanometers, and it’s not important for any of the uses to which GPS is put. OK, so that’s a real example of a use of linear approximations. So. let’s take a little pause here. I’m going to switch gears and talk about quadratic approximations. But before I do that, let’s have some more questions. Yeah. STUDENT: PROF. JERISON: OK, so the question was asked, suppose I did this by different method.

假设我在这里应用了原始公式。也就是说，我定义了函数 f(x)，也就是这里的这个函数。然后我代入它在 x = 0 时的值以及它在 x = 0 时导数的值。所以答案是，是的，如果我称这个函数为 f(x)，那么线性近似一定是 f(x_0) 加上 f'，对不起，它在 0 处，所以它是 f(0)，f'(0) 乘以 x。

Suppose I applied the original formula here. Namely, I define the function f(x), which was this function here. And then I plugged in its value at x = 0 and the value of its derivative at x = 0. So the answer is, yes, it’s also true that if I call this function f(x), then it must be true that the linear approximation is f(x_0) plus f’ of I’m sorry, it’s at 0, so it’s f(0), f’(0) times x.

所以这应该是真的。这就是我们使用的公式。它也在上面的粉红色部分。所以这是公式。那么现在，f(0) 怎么样？好吧，如果我在这里代入 0，我得到 1 * 1。所以这个结果是 1。所以这并不奇怪。这就是我得到的。如果我用乘积规则计算 f'，这将是一个令人讨厌的、有点漫长的计算。

So that should be true. That’s the formula that we’re using. It’s up there in the pink also. So this is the formula. So now, what about f(0)? Well, if I plug in 0 here, I get 1 * 1. So this thing is 1. So that’s no surprise. And that’s what I got. If I computed f’by the product rule it would be an annoying, somewhat long, computation.

而根据我们刚才所做的，我们知道它应该是什么。它应该是-7/2。因为这是做这件事的捷径。这比做那个更快。但当然，那是一种合法的方法。当你得到二阶导数时，你很快就会发现我刚刚描述的这种方法很复杂，但比对这个表达式进行两次微分要好得多。学生：教授。

And because of what we just done, we know what it has to be. It has to be negative 7/2. Because this is a shortcut for doing it. This is faster than doing that. But of course, that’s a legal way of doing it. When you get to second derivatives, you’ll quickly discover that this method that I’ve just described is complicated, but far superior to differentiating this expression twice. STUDENT: PROF.

JERISON：如果你进行微分，是否必须舍弃 x^2 项？不。事实上，我们在这里真的不必这么做。如果你进行微分，然后代入 x = 0。因此，如果你对此进行微分并代入 x = 0，则得到 7/2。如果你对此进行微分并代入 x = 0，则该项仍然会消失，因为当你进行微分时，它只是一个 3x。

JERISON: Would you have to throw away an x^2 term if you differentiated? No. And in fact, we didn’t really have to do that here. If you differentiate and then plug in x = 0. So if you differentiate this and you plug in x = 0, you get 7/2. You differentiate this and you plug in x = 0, this term still drops out because it’s just a 3x when you differentiate.

然后代入 x = 0，它也会消失。同样，如果你在这里，它会消失，同样，在这里，它也会消失。所以高阶项永远不会影响这里的计算。这只是捕捉函数的线性特征。现在我想继续二次近似。现在我们要详细阐述这个公式。所以，线性近似。嗯，那应该是线性近似。线性。这很有趣。

And then you plug in x = 0, it’s gone too. And similarly, if you’re up here, it goes away and similarly over here it goes away. So the higher order terms never influence this computation here. This just captures the linear features of the function. So now I want to go on to quadratic approximation. And now we’re going to elaborate on this formula. So, linear approximation. Well, that should have been linear approximation. Liner. That’s interesting.

好吧，那是错的。但现在我们要把它改成二次。假设我们在这里讨论二次近似。现在，二次近似只是一种阐述，是细节的又一步。从线性近似开始。换句话说，它是线性近似的扩展。所以我们在这里又加了一个项。这个额外的项原来与二阶导数有关。

OK, so that was wrong. But now we’re going to change it to quadratic. So, suppose we talk about a quadratic approximation here. Now, the quadratic approximation is going to be just an elaboration, one more step of detail. From the linear. In other words, it’s an extension of the linear approximation. And so we’re adding one more term here. And the extra term turns out to be related to the second derivative.

但是有一个因子 2。所以这是二次近似的公式。当然，这部分是线性部分。这次我会正确拼写“线性”这个词。所以线性部分是第一部分。二次部分是第二部分。我想开发与以前相同的函数目录。换句话说，我想将我们的公式扩展到更高阶的项。

But there’s a factor of 2. So this is the formula for the quadratic approximation. And this chunk of it, of course, is the linear part. This time I’ll spell ‘linear’ correctly. So the linear part is the first piece. And the quadratic part is the second piece. I want to develop this same catalog of functions as I had before. In other words, I want to extend our formulas to the higher order terms.

如果你按照这个例子来做，也许我甚至会在继续之前用这个例子来说明，如果你按照这个例子来做，只是为了让你了解发生了什么，结果是什么。这是线性版本。现在我要把它和二次版本进行比较。二次版本是这样的。

And if you do that for this example here, maybe I’ll even illustrate with this example before I go on, if you do it with this example here, just to give you a flavor for what goes on, what turns out to be the case. So this is the linear version. And now I’m going to compare it to the quadratic version. So the quadratic version turns out to be this.

这就是二次近似值。当我使用这个例子时，结果是 1.1，它与 1 + 1/10 的 ln 相同，对吧？所以它大约是 1/10 1/2 (1/10)^2。也就是 1/200。所以结果不是 1/10，而是点，它是什么，0.095 或类似的数字。它稍微小一点。它不是 0.1，但非常接近。

That’s what turns out to be the quadratic approximation. And when I use this example here, so this is 1.1, which is the same as ln of 1 + 1/10, right? So that’s approximately 1/10 1/2 (1/10)^2. So 1/200. So that turns out, instead of being 1/10, that’s point, what is it, .095 or something like that. It’s a little bit less. It’s not .1, but it’s pretty close.

所以，如果您愿意，十进制扩展中的修正会更低。现在让我实际检查一下其中的几个。我会执行它们。我可能要留到下次再向您解释，这就是为什么这个因子是 1/2，我们稍后再做。下次再做。您当然可以坚持这个演示再讲一讲。这样我们可以看到这一点得到了加强。

So if you like, the correction is lower in the decimal expansion. Now let me actually check a few of these. I’ll carry them out. And what I’m going to probably save for next time is explaining to you, so this is why this factor of 1/2, and we’re going to do this later. Do this next time. You can certainly do well to stick with this presentation for one more lecture. So we can see this reinforced.

现在我要计算这些高阶项的导数。让我针对 x 近似为 0 的情况进行计算。首先，我要在这里添加额外的项。这是额外的项。对于二次部分。现在，为了弄清楚发生了什么，我还需要计算二阶导数。所以这里我需要一个二阶导数。

So now I’m going to work out these derivatives of the higher order terms. And let me do it for the x approximately 0 case. So first of all, I want to add in the extra term here. Here’s the extra term. For the quadratic part. And now in order to figure out what’s going on, I’m going to need to compute, also, second derivatives. So here I need a second derivative.

我需要将二阶导数的值代入 0 处。这就是我需要计算的。如果我这样做，例如，对于正弦函数，我已经有了线性部分。我需要最后一点。所以我对正弦函数进行两次微分，我得到，我声称减去正弦函数。一阶导数是余弦，余弦导数是减去正弦。

And I need to throw in the value of that second derivative at 0. So this is what I’m going to need to compute. So if I do it, for example, for the sine function, I already have the linear part. I need this last bit. So I differentiate the sine function twice and I get, I claim minus the sine function. The first derivative is the cosine and the cosine derivative is minus the sine.

当我在 0 处求值时，我得到了 0。0 的正弦是 0。所以实际上二次近似是相同的。0x^2。这里没有 x^2 项。这就是为什么这是一个如此出色的近似。它也是二次近似。对于余弦函数，如果你微分两次，你会得到导数减去符号，导数减去余弦。所以这就是 f''。

And when I evaluate it at 0, I get, lo and behold, 0. Sine of 0 is 0. So actually the quadratic approximation is the same. 0x^2. There’s no x^2 term here. So that’s why this is such a terrific approximation. It’s also the quadratic approximation. For the cosine function, if you differentiate twice, you get the derivative is minus the sign and derivative of that is minus the cosine. So that’s f’’.

现在，如果我在 0 处求值，我会得到 1。所以我必须在这里插入的项，这个 1 是出现在这里的系数。所以我需要一个额外的 1/2 x^2。如果你对 e^x 进行同样的操作，你会得到一个 e^x，然后得到一个 1，所以你在这里得到了 1/2 x^2。

And now, if I evaluate that at 0, I get 1. And so the term that I have to plug in here, this 1 is the coefficient that appears right here. So I need a 1/2 x^2 extra. And if you do it for the e^x, you get an e^x, and you got a 1 and so you get 1/2 x^2 here.

我马上就要讲完这两个了，但我首先想告诉你们这个二次项的几何意义。我们开始吧。（二次项的）几何意义。所以最好通过在这里画一幅图来描述几何意义。我要画出余弦函数的图。记住，我们已经有了切线。所以切线是这里的水平线。

I’m going to finish these two in just a second, but I first want to tell you about the geometric significance of this quadratic term. So here we go. Geometric significance (of the quadratic term). So the geometric significance is best to describe just by drawing a picture here. And I’m going to draw the picture of the cosine function. And remember we already had the tangent line. So the tangent line was this horizontal here.

那是 y = 1。但你可以直观地看到，这甚至没有告诉你这个函数是高于还是低于 1。没有告诉你太多。它有点乞求有更多信息来告诉我们函数在附近做什么。事实上，这就是第二个表达式为我们做的。它是下面的某种抛物线。

And that was y = 1. But you can see intuitively, that doesn’t even tell you whether this function is above or below 1 there. Doesn’t tell you much. It’s sort of begging for there to be a little more information to tell us what the function is doing nearby. And indeed, that’s what this second expression does for us. It’s some kind of parabola underneath here.

所以这是 y = 1 1/2 x^2。这比水平线更符合曲线。如果你愿意的话，这就是最符合抛物线。所以它将是最接近曲线的抛物线。这或多或少是很重要的。它非常非常接近曲线。

So this is y = 1 1/2 x^2. Which is a much better fit to the curve than the horizontal line. And this is, if you like, this is the best fit parabola. So it’s going to be the closest parabola to the curve. And that’s more or less the significance. It’s much, much closer.

好的，我想给你们，嗯，我想我们会把这些其他推导留到下次，因为我觉得现在时间不够了。所以我们下次再做这些。

All right, I want to give you, well, I think we’ll save these other derivations for next time because I think we’re out of time now. So we’ll do these next time.

Lec 10 | MIT 18.01 单变量微积分，2007 年秋季

Lec 10 | MIT 18.01 Single Variable Calculus, Fall 2007

16 年前 (2009 年 8 月 19 日) — 51:44 https://youtube.com/watch?v=eRCN3daFCmU

16 years ago (Aug 19, 2009) — 51:44 https://youtube.com/watch?v=eRCN3daFCmU

以下内容根据 Creative Commons 许可提供。您的支持将帮助 MIT OpenCourseWare 继续免费提供高质量的教育资源。要捐款或查看数百门 MIT 课程的其他材料，请访问 MIT OpenCourseWare，网址为 ocw.mit.edu。JERISON 教授：现在我们准备开始第 10 讲，我首先要完成上次讲的一些内容。

The following content is provided under a Creative Commons license. Your support will help MIT OpenCourseWare continue to offer high quality educational resources for free. To make a donation or to view additional materials from hundreds of MIT courses, visit MIT OpenCourseWare at ocw.mit.edu. PROF. JERISON: So, we’re ready to begin Lecture 10, and what I’m going to begin with is by finishing up some things from last time.

我们将讨论近似值，我想补充一些评论，让你们对我试图表达的关于近似值的观点有一点了解。所以，首先，我想提醒你们我上次写下的实际应用示例。这就是这里的业务。有些内容来自狭义相对论。

We’ll talk about approximations, and I want to fill in a number of comments and get you a little bit more oriented in the point of view that I’m trying to express about approximations. So, first of all, I want to remind you of the actual applied example that I wrote down last time. So that was this business here. There was something from special relativity.

我们使用的近似值是线性近似值，其 1/2 幂等于 t(1/2 v^2 / C^2)。我想重申一下为什么这是一种有用的思考方式。以及为什么它会在现实生活中出现。为什么这可能比我迄今为止在技术上教给你们的一切都更重要。

And the approximation that we used was the linear approximation, with a 1/2 power that comes out to be t( 1/2 v^2 / C^2). I want to reiterate why this is a useful way of thinking of things. And why this is that this comes up in real life. Why this is maybe more important than everything that I’ve taught you about technically so far.

首先，它告诉我们的是 t / t 的变化，如果你在这里做算术并减去 t，那么使用 t 的变化就是这里的 t't。如果你算出来，这大约等于 1/2 (v^2 / C^2)。那么这是什么意思呢？

So, first of all, what this is telling us is the change in t / t, if you do the arithmetic here and subtract t that’s using the change in t is t’t here. If you work that out, this is approximately the same as 1/2 (v^2 / C^2). So what is this saying?

也就是说，如果你有一颗卫星，它以速度 v 运行，而 c 是光速，那么地球上的手表相对于卫星上的时间的变化将与这里的这个比率成正比。所以，从物理上讲，这是有道理的。这是时间除以时间。这是速度平方除以速度平方。所以，在每种情况下，单位都是相除的。

This is saying that if you have this satellite, which is going at speed v, and little c is the speed of light, then the change in the watch down here on earth, relative to the time on the satellite, is going to be proportional to this ratio here. So, physically, this makes sense. This is time divided by time. And this is velocity squared divided by velocity squared. So, in each case, the units divide out.

所以这是一个无量纲量。这是一个无量纲量。我们在这里要表达的唯一观点就是比例的概念。所以我想写下来。总结一下。所以误差分数，如果你愿意的话，就是我们测量中的有效数字的数量，在这种情况下，与这个量成比例。它恰好与这里的这个量成比例。

So this is a dimensionless quantity. And this is a dimensionless quantity. And the only point here that we’re trying to make is just this notion of proportionality. So I want to write this down. Just, in summary. So the error fraction, if you like, which is sort of the number of significant digits that we have in our measurement, is proportional, in this case, to this quantity. It happens to be proportional to this quantity here.

而这个因子恰好是 1/2。所以这些比例因子就是我们要找的。它们的变化率。它们的变化率是某事物相对于其他事物的变化率。现在，在你的家庭作业中，你有一些与此非常相似的东西。所以在问题中，在第 2b 部分，第 II 部分，问题 1 中，有一个投球速度，对吧？投球速度会根据投球丘的高度而变化。

And the factor is, happens to be, 1/2. So these proportionality factors are what we’re looking for. Their rates of change. Their rates of change of something with respect to something else. Now, on your homework, you have something rather similar to this. So in Problem, on Part 2b, Part II, Problem 1, there’s the speed of a pitch, right? And the speed of the pitch is changing depending on how high the mound is.

这里的要点是，它与土丘高度的变化大致成正比。在那个问题中，我们有这个 delta h，即该问题中的 x 变量。你要弄清楚的是比例常数是什么。这就是你在这个问题中要寻找的。因此，两者大致呈线性关系，从所有意图和目的来看，这都是相等的。

And the point here is that’s approximately proportional to the change in the height of the mound. In that problem, we had this delta h, that was the x variable in that problem. And what you’re trying to figure out is what the constant of proportionality is. That’s what you’re aiming for in this problem. So there’s a linear relationship, approximately, to all intents and purposes this is an equality.

因为低阶项对于问题来说并不重要。就像这里一样，这个函数有点复杂。这个函数稍微简单一些。对于这个问题的目的而言，它们是相同的。因为对于我们正在处理的特定问题，误差可以忽略不计。所以我们不妨使用更简单的关系。

Because the lower order terms are unimportant for the problem. Just as over here, this function is a little bit complicated. This function is a little more simple. For the purposes of this problem, they are the same. Because the errors are negligible for the particular problem that we’re working on. So we might as well work with the simpler relationship.

同样，在这里，你可以用平方根来做这件事，用平方根的倒数来做这件事并不难。用数字来做这件事也不难。我们不用数字来做这件事的原因是，正如我所说，这是整个工程领域都会发生的事情。人们正在寻找某些输入的变化与输出的变化之间的线性关系。

And similarly, over here, so you could do this with, in this case with square roots, it’s not so hard here with reciprocals of square roots. It’s also not terribly hard to do it numerically. And the reason why we’re not doing it numerically is that, as I say, this is something that happens all across engineering. People are looking for these linear relationships between the change in some input and the change in the output.

如果不进行这些简化，那么当你把十几个简化放在一起时，你就无法弄清楚到底发生了什么。在这种情况下，卫星的设计非常重要。速度实际上不只是一个速度。因为它是你相对于卫星的相对速度。速度取决于你与卫星的视角。所以它变化很大。

And if you don’t make these simplifications, then when you get, say, a dozen of them together, you can’t figure out what’s going on. In this case the design of the satellite, it’s very important. The speed actually isn’t just one speed. Because it’s the relative speed of u to the satellite. And you might be, it depends on your angle of sight with the satellite what the speed is. So it varies quite a bit.

所以你确实需要这个经验法则。然后，这个问题中还有各种其他的考虑因素。例如，我们坐在地球上，所以我们在所谓的非惯性系中旋转。所以有加速度的问题。还有我在地球上感受到的重力与在卫星上感受到的重力不一样的问题。

So you really need this rule of thumb. Then there are all kinds of other considerations in this question. Like, for example, there’s the fact that we’re sitting on Earth and so we’re rotating around on what’s called a non inertial frame. So there’s the question of that acceleration. There’s the question that the gravity that I experience here on Earth is not the same as up at the satellite.

由于广义相对论，这也导致了时间上的差异。所以所有这些考虑都归结为公式，这些公式非常复杂，或者可能更复杂一点。其实并没有那么复杂。然后人们将它们大大简化为这些非常简单的规则。他们不跟踪正在发生的事情。所以为了设计系统，你必须进行这些简化，否则你甚至无法思考正在发生的事情。

And that also creates a difference in time, as a result of general relativity. So all of these considerations come down to formulas which are this complicated or maybe a tiny bit more. Not really that much. And then people simplify them enormously to these very simple minded rules. And they don’t keep track of what’s going on. So in order to design the system, you must make these simplifications, otherwise you can’t even think about what’s going on.

这在各行各业中都会出现。天气预报、经济预测。预测是否会有小行星撞击地球。每一件事都涉及数十种考虑因素。好的，我看到这里有一个问题。是的。学生：教授。杰里森：是的。基本上，任何有导数的问题，变化率也取决于基点。这就是问题所在。

This comes up in everything. In weather forecasting, economic forecasting. Figuring out whether there’s going to be an asteroid that’s going to hit the Earth. Every single one of these things involves dozens of these considerations. OK, there was a question that I saw, here. Yes. STUDENT: PROF. JERISON: Yeah. Basically, any problem where you have a derivative, the rate of change also depends upon what the base point is. That’s the question.

你说，这个 delta v 是否也取决于，我在这个问题中有一个基点。我碰巧决定投手投球的平均速度约为每小时 90 英里。而事实上，有些投手投球的速度是每小时 100 英里，有些投球的速度是每小时 80 英里，当然，他们的投球速度会有所不同。所以，这会有一点变化。事实上，这是一种二阶效应。

You’re saying, doesn’t this delta v also depend, I had a base point in that problem. I happened to decide that pitchers pitch on average about 90 miles an hour. Whereas, in fact, some pitchers pitch at 100 miles an hour, some pitch at 80 miles an hour, and of course they vary the speed of the pitch. And so, this varies a little bit. In fact, that’s sort of a second order effect.

它确实改变了比例常数。它是不同基点的变化率。我们认为它是固定的。事实上，这是一种二阶效应。当你真正进行计算时，你会发现它并没有太大的区别。对于 a。这是你从经验中得到的东西。事实证明，哪些事情很重要，哪些事情不重要。

It does change the constant of proportionality. It’s a rate of change at a different base point. Which we’re considering fixed. In fact, that’s sort of a second order effect. When you actually do the computations, what you discover is that it doesn’t make that much difference. To the a. And that’s something that you get from experience. That it turns out, which things matter and which things don’t.

再说一遍，这是完全相同的考虑，但我在这里要谈论的是下一个问题。你必须有足够的数字经验，才能知道如果你采取一些措施，如果你稍微改变一些事情，它不会对你想要的答案产生太大的影响。这正是我要说的重点。所以我不能一下子就说完所有这些要点。

And yet again, that’s exactly the same sort of consideration but at the next order of what I’m talking about here is. You have to have enough experience with numbers to know that if you take, if you vary something a little bit it’s not going to change the answer that you’re looking for very much. And that’s exactly the point that I’m making. So I can’t make them all at once, all such points.

这就是我从这个角度理解事物的观点。现在，我们继续讨论二次近似，这有点复杂。我们上次讨论过这个问题，但我没有讲完。所以我想把这个讲完。首先我要说的是，当线性近似不够时，你可以使用。

So that’s my pitch for understanding things from this point of view. Now, we’re going to go on, now, to quadratic approximations, which are a little more complicated. So, we talked a little bit about this last time but I didn’t finish. So I want to finish this up. And the first thing that I should say is that you use the when the linear approximation is not enough.

好的，所以，这确实是你需要积累一些经验的事情。在经济学中，我告诉过你他们使用对数。所以有时他们使用对数线性函数。有时当对数线性函数不起作用时，他们会使用对数二次函数。所以经济学中的大多数建模都是用对数二次函数。如果你把它弄得比这更复杂，那就没用了。而且很乱。人们不这么做。

OK, so, that’s something that you really need to get a little experience with. In economics, I told you they use logarithms. So sometimes they use log linear functions. Sometimes they use log quadratic functions when the log linear ones don’t work. So most modeling in economics is with log quadratic functions. And if you’ve made it any more complicated than that, it’s useless. And it’s a mess. And people don’t do it.

所以他们通常坚持使用二次函数。所以这里的基本公式，我将基点设为 0，是 f ( x ) 近似于 f ( 0 ) f' ( 0 )x。这是线性部分。加上这个额外的项。即 f'' ( 0 ) / 2x^2。这应该适用于 x 接近 0 的情况。所以它尽可能简单地显示基点。

So they stick with the quadratic ones, typically. So the basic formula here, and I’m going to take the base point to be 0, is that f ( x ) is approximately f ( 0 ) f’ ( 0 )x. That’s the linear part. Plus this extra term. Which is f’’ ( 0 ) / 2x^2. And this is supposed to work for x near 0. So it shows in the base point as simply as possible.

所以这里差不多就是我们上次停顿的地方。我说过要解释的一件事，现在就解释，那就是为什么它是 (1/2) f'' ( 0 )。所以我们需要知道这一点。所以让我们首先在这里解决这个问题。所以我将举例说明。所以如果你愿意，答案就是，好吧，当你有抛物线时会发生什么？抛物线是二次函数。

So here’s more or less where we left off last time. And one thing that I said I was going to explain, which I will now, is why it’s (1/2) f’’ ( 0 ). So we need to know that. So let’s work that out here first of all. So I’m just going to do it by example. So if you like, the answer is just, well, what happens when you have a parabola? A parabola’s a quadratic.

它的二次近似最好是它本身。它必须是最好的。所以它必须是它本身。所以这个公式，如果要起作用，必须完全起作用。对于二次函数。那么，让我们来看看。如果我微分，我得到 b 2cx。如果我第二次微分，我得到 2c。现在让我们把它代入。好吧，我们可以恢复，我们想要恢复的是什么？

It had better, its quadratic approximation had better be itself. It’s got to be the best one. So it’s got to be itself. So this formula, if it’s going to work, has to work on the nose. For quadratic functions. So, let’s take a look. If I differentiate, I get b 2cx. If I differentiate a second time, I get 2c. And now let’s plug it in. Well, we can recover, what is it that we want to recover?

我们想使用在 0 处求导的导数来恢复这些数字 a、b 和 c。让我们看看。实际上，这非常简单。f ( 0 ) = a。这很准确。如果您在这里代入 x = 0，这些项就会消失，您会得到 a。现在，f' ( 0 )，哎呀，错了。所以我写了 f'，但我的意思是 f。所以 f ( 0 ) 是 a。让我们回顾一下。

We want to recover these numbers a, b and c using the derivatives evaluated at 0. So let’s see. It’s pretty easy, actually. f ( 0 ) = a. That’s on the nose. If you plug in x = 0 here, these terms drop out and you get a. And now, f’ ( 0 ), whoops that was wrong. So I wrote f’ but what I meant was f. So f ( 0 ) is a. Let’s back up.

F ( 0 ) 是 a，所以如果我代入 x = 0，就会得到 a。现在，f' ( 0 )，也就是下一个公式，f' ( 0 )，我在这里代入 0，就会得到 b。这也很好。这正是线性近似应该得到的。但现在你注意到，f'' 是 2c。所以要恢复 c，我最好取一半。就是这样。这就是原因。

F ( 0 ) is a, so if I plug in x = 0 I get a. Now, f’ ( 0 ), that’s this next formula here, f’ ( 0 ), I plug in 0 here, and I get b. That’s also good. And that’s exactly what the linear approximation is supposed to be. But now you notice, f’’ is 2c. So to recover c, I better take half of it. And that’s it. That’s the reason.

任何其他公式都不可能奏效。但这个公式却奏效。这就是公式的解释。现在我提醒你们，我在黑板上写下了一系列基本公式。我只是想确保我们再次了解了它们。首先，正弦 x 近似于 x。

There’s no chance that any other formula could work. And this one does. So that’s the explanation for the formula. And now I remind you that I had a collection of basic formulas written on the board. And I want to just make sure we know all of them again. So, first of all, there was sine x is approximately x.

余弦 x 约为 1 1/2 x^2。而 e ^ x 约为 1 x 1/2 x^2。这就是我上次提到的三个。再次重申，这些都适用于接近 0 的 x。所有都仅适用于接近 0 的 x。这些都大错特错，虽然距离很远，但接近 0 时，它们是很好的二次近似值。现在，我想提到的另外两个近似值是对数，我们使用基点移位。

Cosine x is approximately 1 1/2 x^2. And e ^ x is approximately 1 x 1/2 x^2. So those were three that I mentioned last time. And, again, this is all for x near 0. All for x near 0 only. These are wildly wrong, Far away, but near 0 they’re nice, good, quadratic approximations. Now, the other two approximations that I want to mention are the logarithm and we use the base point shifted.

因此我们可以把它放在 x 接近 0 的位置。抱歉，这里是约等号。结果是 x 1/2 x^2。最后一个是 1 (1 x) ^ r，结果是 1 rx r ( r 1) / 2x^2。现在，最终，你的大脑会集中于所有这些，你会发现它们相对容易记住。但这需要一些时间来适应。

So we can put it at x near 0. And this one sorry, this is an approximately equals sign there. Turns out to be x 1/2 x^2. And the last one is one (1 x) ^ r, which turns out to be 1 rx r ( r 1) / 2x^2. Now, eventually, your mind will converge on all of these and you’ll find them relatively easy to memorize. But it’ll take some getting used to.

我并不是说你们现在应该认识并理解它们。但我要用一个巨大的方框来概括它们。学生：教授。杰里森：是的。所以问题是，如果你使用那个等式，你就会得到所有这些。这正是你要做的。所以上次我已经对这三个做了。但我还没有对这两个做。

现在，让我再多告诉你一点它的重要性。再说一遍，这只是为了强化我们已经做过的事情。但它与你正在处理的问题集密切相关。所以值得你回想一下。这就是我们处理的这个表达式。我们在讲座中讨论过它。我们证明了当 k 趋向于无穷大时，它趋向于 e。

So now, let me just tell you a little bit more about the significance. Again, this is just to reinforce something that we’ve already done. But it’s closely related to what you’re doing on your problem set. So it’s worth your while to recall this. So, there’s this expression that we were dealing with. And we talked about it in lecture. And we showed that this tends to e as k goes to infinity.

这就是我们在讲座中展示的内容。我们这样做的方法是，取对数，然后将其写为 k 乘以 1 的 ln（1 / k）。然后我们计算它的极限。我想再次使用线性近似来计算这个极限。向你们展示它是多么简单。如果你只记得线性近似的话。然后我们将解释二次近似的用武之地。

So that’s what we showed in lecture. And the way that we did that was, we took the logarithm and we wrote it as k times, sorry, the ln of 1 (1 / k). And then we evaluated the limit of this. And I want to do this limit again, using linear approximation. To show you how easy it is. If you just remember the linear approximation. And then we’ll explain where the quadratic approximation comes in.

所以我认为它近似等于 k（1/k）。那么，为什么呢？好吧，这只是线性近似。那么我在这里用了什么呢？我用 1 x 的 ln 近似等于 x。对于 x = 1/k。这就是我在这里的近似中使用的。这就是自然对数的线性近似。这个数字相对容易计算。我知道如何计算。

So I claim that this is approximately equal to k ( 1 / k). Now, why is that? Well, that’s just this linear approximation. So what did I use here? I used ln of 1 x is approximately x. For x = 1 / k. That’s what I used in this approximation here. And that’s the linear approximation to the natural logarithm. And this number is relatively easy to evaluate. I know how to do it.

它等于 1。这是一样的，那么它在哪里起作用呢？当这个东西接近 0 时，它起作用。也就是当 k 趋于无穷大时。只有当 k 趋于无穷大时，这个东西才会起作用。所以它真正的意思是，这个近似公式，它真正的意思是，当我们趋于无穷大时，在 k 中，这个东西会趋于 1。当 k 趋于无穷大时。所以这就是它所说的。这就是它的实质。

It’s equal to 1. That’s the same, well, so where does this work? This works where this thing is near 0. Which is when k is going to infinity. This thing is working only when k is going to infinity. So what it’s really saying, this approximation formula, it’s really saying that as we go to infinity, in k, this thing is going to 1. As k goes to infinity. So that’s what it’s saying. That’s the substance there.

在许多情况下，我们就是这样使用它的。只是为了评估极限。我们还希望意识到，当 k 很大时，比如 100 或类似的数字，它就在附近。现在，这就是线性近似的概念。现在，如果你想得到这里的收敛速度，那么所谓的收敛速度。所以收敛意味着这个向那个方向发展的速度有多快。

And that’s how we want to use it, in many instances. Just to evaluate limits. We also want to realize that it’s nearby when k is pretty large, like 100 or something like that. Now, so that’s the idea of the linear approximation. Now, if you want to get the rate of convergence here, so the rate of what’s called convergence. So convergence means how fast this is going towards that.

我要做的是取差值。我必须取 ln ak，然后从中减去 1。我知道这会变成 0，问题是这个值有多大。我们希望它非常小。我们会得到答案，所以答案只是使用二次近似。

What I have to do is take the difference. I have to take ln ak, and I have to subtract 1 from it. And I know that this is going to 0, and the question is how big is this. We want it to be very small. And the answer we’re going to get, so the answer just uses the quadratic approximation.

所以如果我再详细一点，那么这里的表达式，换句话说，我有下一个高阶项。这就像 1 / k，就像 1 / k^2。然后我就能理解我得到的表达式和它的极限之间的差异有多大。这就是你的家庭作业。这是你的问题集。

So if I just have a little bit more detail, then this expression here, in other words, I have the next higher order term. This is like 1 / k, this is like 1 / k^2. Then I can understand how big the difference is between the expression that I’ve got and its limit. And so that’s what’s on your homework. This is on your problem set.

好的，这或多或少解释了二次近似法的其中一个优点。我再举一个例子。再举一个例子。然后我们再检查一下这些公式。是的，还有一个问题。学生：教授。杰里森：这个问题问得非常好。

OK, so that is more or less an explanation for one of the things that quadratic approximations are good for. And I’m going to give you one more illustration. One more illustration. And then we’ll actually check these formulas. Yeah, another question. STUDENT: PROF. JERISON: That’s a very good question here.

当他们（在这种情况下可能意味着我）向您提问时，有人会指定您是要使用线性近似还是二次近似。答案是，在现实生活中，当您遇到这样的问题时，当某个卫星在轨道上运转并且您想知道重力的影响或类似的东西时，没有人会告诉您任何事情。

When they, which in this case means maybe, me, when I give you a question, does one specify whether you want to use a linear or a quadratic approximation. The answer is, in real life when you’re faced with a problem like this, where some satellite is orbiting and you want to know the effects of gravity or something like that, nobody is going to tell you anything.

他们甚至不会告诉你线性近似是否相关，二次近似或任何其他近似是否相关。所以你只能靠自己了。当我给你一个问题时，至少现在，我总是会告诉你。但随着时间的推移，我希望你能习惯什么时候用线性近似就足够了。而且，只有在有人强迫你使用二次近似时，你才应该使用。

They’re not even going to tell you whether a linear approximation is relevant, or a quadratic or anything. So you’re on your own. When I give you a question, at least for right now, I’m always going to tell you. But as time goes on I’d like you to get used to when it’s enough to get away with a linear approximation. And you should only use a quadratic approximation if somebody forces you to.

你应该总是从线性开始尝试。因为二次函数要复杂得多，正如你将在下一个例子中看到的那样。好的，我想使用的例子是，你会被它困住，因为我要求二次函数。所以我们要找到 x 接近 0 的二次近似值。到什么？好吧，这是我们在上节课中使用的相同函数。

You should always start trying with a linear one. Because the quadratic ones are much more complicated as you’ll see in this next example. OK, so the example that I want to use is, you’re going to be stuck with it because I’m asking for the quadratic. So we’re going to find the quadratic approximation near, for x near 0. To what? Well, this is the same function that we used in the last lecture.

我认为就是这个。e ^ 3x (1 x) ^ 1/2。好的。不幸的是，我把它放在了错误的地方，无法在这里放下这个很长的公式。所以我要换一下。我把它写在这里。我们只需要做近似值。所以我们要用括号表示二次。我们会说 x 接近 0。这就是我想要的。所以现在，我要这样做。

I think this was it. e ^ 3x (1 x) ^ 1/2. OK. So, unfortunately, I stuck it in the wrong place to be able to fit this very long formula here. So I’m going to switch it. I’m just going to write it here. And we’re going to just do the approximation. So we’re going to say quadratic, in parentheses. And we’ll say x near 0. So that’s what I want. So now, here’s what I have to do.

好吧，我必须写出 e ^ 3x 的二次近似值，我将使用这里的这个公式。这就是 (1 ( 3x) ( 3x)^2 / 2)。另一个因数，我必须使用下面的这个公式。因为 r 是 1/2。这就是 (1 1/2 x 1/2 ( 1/2)( 3/2)x^2)。这是 r 项，这是 r 1 项。

Well, I have to write in the quadratic approximation for e ^ 3x, and I’m going to use this formula right here. And so that’s (1 ( 3x) ( 3x)^2 / 2). And the other factor, I’m going to have to use this formula down here. because r is 1/2. And so that’s (1 1/2 x 1/2 ( 1/2)( 3/2)x^2). So this is the r term, and this is the r 1 term.

现在我要做一些关于二次近似的唯一好处。它们很乱，很长，没有什么特别好的地方。但是它们有一个好处。那就是你总是可以忽略高阶项。所以即使这看起来像一个非常丑陋的乘法，我也可以在我的脑海中完成它。只是看着它。因为我得到了 1 * 1，所以我在这里被迫使用这个项。

And now I’m going to do something which is the only good thing about quadratic approximations. They’re messy, they’re long, there’s nothing particularly good about them. But there is one good thing about them. Which is that you always get to ignore the higher order terms. So even though this looks like a very ugly multiplication, I can do it in my head. Just watching it. Because I get a 1 * 1, I’m forced with that term here.

然后我得到了线性的交叉项，即 3x 1/2 x。我们在计算线性近似值时已经这样做了，所以这是这个乘以 1，这个乘以那个 1。现在我有三个二次交叉项。其中一个是这两个线性项相乘。所以这是加上 3/2 x^2。也就是 ( 3)( 1/2)。

And then I get the cross terms which are linear, which is 3x 1/2 x. We already did that when we calculated the linear approximation, so that’s this times the 1 and this times that 1. And now I have three cross terms which are quadratic. So one of them is these two linear terms are multiplying. So that’s plus 3/2 x^2. That’s ( 3)( 1/2).

然后有一项，乘以 1，就是加上 9/2 x^2。然后还有最后一项，就是这里的这个怪物。乘以 1，就是 3/8。所以最棒的是，我们去掉 x^3、x^4 等项。是吗？学生：教授。杰里森：好的，那么就把它抄下来。然后你按照我现在的做法来算。所以我做的是，我将 1 乘以 1。我在这里使用分配律。

And then there’s this term, multiplying the 1, that’s plus 9/2 x^2. And then there’s one last term, which is this monster here. Multiplying 1, and that is 3/8. So the great thing is, we drop x^3, x ^ 4, etc., terms. Yeah? STUDENT: PROF. JERISON: OK, well so copy it down. And you work it out as I’m doing it now. So what I did is, I multiplied 1 by 1. I’m using the distributive law here.

就是这个。我把这个 3x 乘以这个，就是那个项。我把这个乘以这个，就是那个项。然后我把这个乘以这个。换句话说，2 x 项给了我一个 x^2 和一个 ( 3)( 1/2)。我要到那一点停下来。因为重点是它只是所有出现的其余项。

That was this one. I multiplied this 3x by this one, that was that term. I multiplied this by this, that’s that term. And then I multiplied this by this. In other words, 2 x terms that gave me an x^2 and a ( 3)( 1/2). And I’m going to stop at that point. Because the point is it’s just all the rest of the terms that come up.

现在，原因，唯一简单的原因是我只需要计算 x 平方项。我不需要计算更高阶的项。另一个问题，回到这里。是的，就在那里。学生：杰里森教授：好的。所以有人也可以检查我的算术。很好。学生：杰里森教授：为什么我要放弃所有高阶项。

Now, the reason, the only reason why it’s easy is that I only have to go up to x squared term. I don’t have to do the higher ones. Another question, way back here. Yeah, right there. STUDENT: PROF. JERISON: OK. So somebody can check my arithmetic, too. Good. STUDENT: PROF. JERISON: Why do I get to drop all the higher order terms.

这是因为我要应用这个的情况是 x 为 1/100 的情况。如果这里是 1/100，那么这个数就是 100 的量级。这个数就是 1/100 2.1/100 2 的量级，所有这些项。现在，这些三次和四次项的量级是 1/100^3。也就是 10 ^ 6。重点是我并没有声称我有一个确切的答案。

So, that’s because the situation where I’m going to apply this is the situation in which x is, say, 1/100. So if here’s about 1/100. Here’s something which is on the order of 100. This is on the order of 1/1002.1/1002, all of these terms. Now, these cubic and quartic terms are of the order of 1/100^3. That’s 10 ^ 6. And the point is that I’m not claiming that I have an exact answer.

我要删除该数量级的内容。所以我会保留小数点后 4 位以内的所有内容。我会丢弃小数点后 6 位以内的内容。这回答了你的问题吗？学生：教授。杰里森：所以。情况就是这样，现在你可以合并这些项了。我的意思是，这里的情况并不令人印象深刻。

And I’m going to drop things of that order of magnitude. So I’m saving everything up to 4 decimal places. I’m throwing away things which are 6 decimal places out. Does that answer your question? STUDENT: PROF. JERISON: So. That’s the situation, and now you can combine the terms. I mean, it’s not very impressive here.

这等于 1 7/2 x，也许是 51/8 x^2。如果我这样做了，如果那些减号没有被取消，我就会得到错误的答案。无论如何。所以，这里是 2，抱歉。7/2。这是我们上次得到的线性近似值，这是我们从这次计算中获得的额外信息。也就是这个 51/8 项。

This is equal to 1 7/2 x, maybe 51/8 x^2. If I’ve made that, if those minus signs hadn’t canceled, I would have gotten the wrong answer here. Anyway. So, this is a 2 here, sorry. 7/2. This is the linear approximation we got last time and here’s the extra information that we got from this calculation. Which is this 51/8 term.

是的，你必须承认这个问题有一定的复杂性，答案也足够复杂，所以它不可能不需要算术，因为我们得到了这个奇特的 51/8，对吧。所以要意识到的一件事是，这类问题，因为它们涉及很多很多项，所以总是会涉及一些复杂的算术。

Right, you have to accept that there’s a certain degree of complexity to this problem and the answer is sufficiently complicated so it can’t be less arithmetic because we get this peculiar 51/8 there, right. So one of the things to realize is that these kinds of problems, because they involve many, many terms are always going to involve a little bit of complicated arithmetic.

最后，我答应过你们，我会推导出这两个关系，就像我说的。左边一栏的就是推导出来的。让我们来推导一下。正如有人指出的那样，这一切都来自这里的这个公式。让我们来检查一下。所以我们从 ln 函数开始。这是函数 f，然后 f' 是 1/1 x。

Last little bit, I did promise you that I was going to derive these two relations, as I said. Did the ones in the left column. So let’s carry that out. And as someone just pointed out, it all comes from this formula here. So let’s just check it. So we’ll start with the ln function. This is the function, f, and then f’ is 1/1 x.

而 f''所以这是 f'这是 f''是 1/1 x^2。现在我必须代入 x = 0。所以在 x = 0 时这是 ln 1，也就是 0。所以这是在 x = 0 时。我在这里得到 0，我代入 0 得到 1。在这里，我代入 0 得到 1。所以现在我去查看那个公式，它就在那里的上角。

And f’‘so this is f’this is f’’is 1/1 x^2. And now I have to plug in x = 0. So at x = 0 this is ln 1, which is 0. So this is at x = 0. I’m getting 0 here, I plug in 0 and I get 1. And here, I plug in 0 and I get 1. So now I go and I look up at that formula, which is way in that upper corner there.

我看到常数项的系数是 0。x 项的系数是 1。然后另一个系数，也就是最后一个系数，是 1/2。所以这是这里的 1。然后在这个公式中，分母是 2。所以它是这个二阶导数在 0 处得到的值的一半。所以这是近似公式，它位于那个角落的上方。

And I see that the coefficient on the constant is 0. The coefficient on x is 1. And then the other coefficient, the very last one, is 1/2. So this is the 1 here. And then in the formula, there’s a 2 in the denominator. So it’s half of whatever I get for this second derivative, at 0. So this is the approximation formula, which is way up in that corner there.

类似地，如果我对 (1 x) ^ r 执行此操作，我必须区分我得到的 r( 1 x) ^ r 1，然后是 r ( r 1( x 1) ^ r 2。所以这里是导数。所以如果我在 x = 0 处对它们进行求值，我得到 1。那就是 1 ^ r = 1。这里我得到 r。(1 ^ r 1)r。在这里，我代入 x = 0 得到 r ( r 1)。

Similarly, if I do it for (1 x) ^ r, I have to differentiate that I get r( 1 x) ^ r 1, and then r ( r 1( x 1) ^ r 2. So here are the derivatives. And so if I evaluate them at x = 0, I get 1. That’s 1 ^ r = 1. And here I get r. (1 ^ r 1)r. And here, I plug in x = 0 and I get r ( r 1).

再次重申，模式就在它上面。1 在那里，r 在那里。然后，我用一半的公式代替 r (r 1)。这是系数。这些只是例子。显然，如果我们有一个更复杂的函数，我们可能会实现这一点。但实际上，我们尽量坚持使用粉色框中的公式，只使用代数来获得其他公式。

So again, the pattern is right above it here. The 1 is there, the r is there. And then instead of r ( r 1), I have half that. For the coefficient. So these are just examples. Obviously if we had a more complicated functional, we might carry this out. But as a practical matter, we try to stick with the ones in the pink box and just use algebra to get other formulas.

所以现在我想换个话题，讨论一下本该是本堂课的主题。我们还没有完全讲完，但我们会尽力在今天讲完。下一个主题是曲线绘制。让我们从这个开始吧。现在，幸运的是，这个主题有更多的图片，而且更几何化。计算相对较少。

So I want to shift gears now and treat the subject that was supposed to be this lecture. And we’re not quite caught up, but we will try to do our best to do as much as we can today. So the next topic is curve sketching. And so let’s get started with that. So now, happily in this subject, there are more pictures and it’s a little bit more geometric. And there’s relatively little computation.

希望我们能做到。我想，所以我们开始吧，我们从曲线草图开始。目标是学生：教授。杰里森：所以，这就像，liner，最后一次。这有点粗略的拼写，不是吗？是的，有些东西我拼写不了。但是，好吧。草图。好吧。这是我们的目标。我们的目标是用 f' 和 f'' 画出 f 的图形。无论它们是正数还是负数。

So let’s hope we can do this. So I want to, so here we go, we’ll start with curve sketching. And the goal here STUDENT: PROF. JERISON: So that’s like, liner, the last time. That’s kind of sketchy spelling, isn’t it? Yeah, there are certain kinds of things which I can’t spell. But, alright. Sketching. Alright. So here’s our goal. Our goal is to draw the graph of f, using f’ and f’’. Whether they’re positive or negative.

就是这样。这就是我的目标。但是，我要给你们一个很大的警告。不幸的是，我现在必须让你们忘记这一点，特别是那些之前学过一点微积分的人，我想让你们忘记你们培养的一些本能。所以这对你们中那些之前做过这件事的人来说会更难。

So that’s it. This is the goal here. However, there is a big warning that I want to give you. And this is one that unfortunately I now have to make you unlearn, especially those that you that have actually had a little bit of calculus before, I want to make you unlearn some of your instincts that you developed. So this will be harder for those of you who have actually done this before.

但对你们其他人来说，这相对容易。也就是说，不要放弃你的预科微积分技能。和常识。这里面有很多常识。它实际上胜过一些微积分。微积分只是填补了你还不太了解的部分。所以我会试着说明这一点。因为我们有点晚了，所以我要等到下一堂课才会讲到一些主要的妙语。

But for the rest of you, it will be relatively easy. Which is, don’t abandon your precalculus skills. And common sense. So there’s a great deal of common sense in this. And it actually trumps some of the calculus. The calculus just fills in what you didn’t quite know yet. So I will try to illustrate this. And because we’re running a bit late, I won’t get to the some of the main punchlines until next lecture.

但我希望你们能做到。所以现在，我只会告诉你们一般原则。在此过程中，我会介绍术语。只是，我们需要用这些词来描述我们正在做的事情。在你们将看到的许多治疗中，也存在一定程度的疏忽。而且有很多草率。所以请耐心一点，我们会做到这一点。

But I want you to do it. So for now, I’m just going to tell you about the general principles. And in the process I’m going to introduce the terminology. Just, the words that we need to use to describe what is that we’re doing. And there’s also a certain amount of carelessness with that in many of the treatments that you’ll see. And a lot of hastiness. So just be a little patient and we will do this.

因此，第一个原理如下。如果 f' 为正，则 f 增加。这是一个简单的想法，它与我刚才做的切线近似或线性近似密切相关。你可以想象一下。这是切线，这是函数。如果切线指向上方，则函数也会向上。所以这就是这里发生的一切。同样，如果 f' 为负，则 f 减少。

So, the first principle is the following. If f’ is positive, then f is increasing. That’s a straightforward idea, and it’s closely related to this tangent line approximation or the linear approximation that I just did. You can just imagine. Here’s the tangent line, here’s the function. And if the tangent line is pointing up, then the function is also going up, too. So that’s all that’s going on here. Similarly, if f’ is negative, then f is decreasing.

这就是基本思想。现在，第二步也相当简单。这只是同一类型的二阶效应。如果 f'' 为正，则意味着 f' 在增加。这是同一原理的进一步应用。对吗？因为如果 f'' 为正，则意味着它是 f' 的导数。所以这只是重复了同一原理。现在我只想画一张图。

And that’s the basic idea. Now, the second step is also fairly straightforward. It’s just a second order effect of the same type. If you have f’’ as positive, then that means that f’ is increasing. That’s the same principle applied one step up. Right? Because if f’’ is positive, that means it’s the derivative of f’. So it’s the same principle just repeated. And now I just want to draw a picture of this.

我声称，这是它的一张图片。看起来好像有什么东西在下降。我故意这样做的。但这里有一些东西在增加。也就是说，这里的斜率非常陡峭，为负。而这里的斜率则没那么陡峭。所以我们的斜率是某个负数，比如说 4。这里是 3。所以它在增加。它越来越不负，也许最终它会向另一个方向弯曲。

Here’s a picture of it, I claim. And it looks like something’s going down. And I did that on purpose. But there is something that’s increasing here. Which is, the slope is very steep negative here. And it’s less steep negative over here. So we have the slope which is some negative number, say, 4. And here it’s 3. So it’s increasing. It’s getting less negative, and maybe eventually it’ll curve up the other way.

这就是我在这里谈论的内容的图。这就是 f' 增加的意思。斜率越来越大。描述这种曲线的方式是它是凹的。所以 f 向上凹。同样，f'' 为负将与 f 凹相同，或意味着 f 向下凹。所以这些是导数帮助我们定性绘制图形的方式。

And this is a picture of what I’m talking about here. That’s what it means to say that f’ is increasing. The slope is getting larger. And the way to describe a curve like this is that it’s concave. So f is concave up. And similarly, f’’ negative is going to be the same thing as f concave, or implies f concave down. So those are the ways in which derivatives will help us qualitatively to draw graphs.

但正如我之前所说，我们在画图时仍然需要运用一些常识。这些只是微积分给我们提供的额外帮助。在画图时。所以我将通过一个例子来介绍所有的符号。

But as I said before, we still have to use a little bit of common sense when we draw the graphs. These are just the additional bits of help that we have from calculus. In drawing pictures. So I’m going to go through one example to introduce all the notations.

最后，可能在下次开始时，我会给你一个系统策略，当我现在描述的内容出错或出现一点错误时，这个策略就会起作用。让我们从一个简单的例子开始。我给你的第一个例子是函数 f (x) = 3x x^3。正如我所说，只是为了能够介绍所有的符号。

And then eventually, so probably at the beginning of next time, I’ll give you a systematic strategy that’s going to work when what I’m describing now goes wrong, or a little bit wrong. So let’s begin with a straightforward example. So, the first example that I’ll give you is the function f (x) = 3x x^3. Just, as I said, to be able to introduce all the notations.

现在，如果你对它进行微分，你会得到 3 3x^2。我可以对它进行因式分解。这是 3 ( 1 x)( 1 x)。好吗？这样，我就可以确定导数是正数还是负数。很简单。也就是说，只要盯着它看，我就可以看到当 1 < x < 1 时，在那个范围内，这两个数字，这两个因式分解都是正数。1 x 是正数，1 x 也是正数。

Now, if you differentiate it, you get 3 3x^2. And I can factor that. This is 3 ( 1 x)( 1 x). OK? And so, I can decide whether the derivative is positive or negative. Easily enough. Namely, just staring at this, I can see that when 1 < x < 1, in that range there, both these numbers, both these factors, are positive. 1 x is a positive number and 1 x is a positive number.

因此，在这个范围内，f' (x) 为正。所以 f 是增加的。同样，在其他范围内，如果 x 非常非常大，如果它超过 1，实际上，这个因子变为负数，而这个因子保持正数。所以当 x > 1 时，我们有 f ' (x) 为负数。所以 f 是减少的。另一边也是一样。

So, in this range, f’ ( x ) is positive. So this thing is, so f is increasing. And similarly, in the other ranges, if x is very, very large, this becomes, if it crosses 1, in fact, this becomes, this factor becomes negative and this one stays positive. So when x > 1, we have that f ’ (x) is negative. And so f is decreasing. And the same thing goes for the other side.

当它小于 1 时，也是这样。因为当它小于 1 时，这个数字的因数为正数。但另一个是负数。所以在这两种情况下，我们都得到它在减少。现在，这是这个函数的示意图。所以这是 1，这是 1。它会下降、上升、下降。这就是它正在做的事情。也许我会让它保持原样。这就是它的样子。

When it’s less than 1, that also works this way. Because when it’s less than 1, this number factors positive. But the other one is negative. So in both of these cases, we get that it’s decreasing. So now, here’s the schematic picture of this function. So here’s 1, here’s 1. It’s going to go down, up, down. That’s what it’s doing. Maybe I’ll just leave it alone like this. That’s what it looks like.

所以，这是我们可以立即获得的信息。你会立即注意到，从函数的特征来看，这两个位置非常重要，我们在这里看到的函数的关键特征就是这两个位置。也许我会像这样标记它们。这些都是转折点。那么它们是什么呢？嗯，它们只是导数改变符号的点。

So, this is the kind of information we can get right off the bat. And you notice immediately that it’s very important, from the features of the function, the sort of key features of the function that we see here, are these two places. Maybe I’ll even mark them in a, like this. And these things are turning points. So what are they? Well, they’re just the points where the derivative changes sign.

这里是负数，那里是正数，所以那里一定是 0。所以我们有一个定义，这是这个主题中最重要的定义，即如果 f' (x0) = 0，我们称 x0 为临界点。不使用“转折点”这个词只是因为事实上它不必在那些点转向。但可以肯定的是，如果它转向，那么就会发生这种情况。

Where it’s negative here and it’s positive there, so there it must be 0. So we have a definition, and this is the most important definition in this subject, which is that is if f’ (x0) = 0, we call x0 a critical point. The word ‘turning point’ is not used just because, in fact, it doesn’t have to turn around at those points. But certainly, if it turns around then this will happen.

我们还有另一种符号，即数值 y0，即 f ( x0 )，称为临界值。因此，这些是我们必须计算的关键数字，以便了解函数是什么样子。所以我要做的就是绘制它们。我们将绘制临界点和值。好吧，我们相对容易地找到了临界点。

And we also have another notation, which is the number y0 which is f ( x0 ) is called a critical value. So these are the key numbers that we’re going to have to work out in order to understand what the function looks like. So what I’m going to do is just plot them. We’re going to plot the critical points and the values. Well, we found the critical points relatively easily.

我没有在这里写下来，但这很明显。如果你设置 f(x) = 0，这意味着 (1 x)( 1 x) = 0，这意味着 x 为 或 1。所以这些被称为临界点。

I didn’t write it down here but it’s pretty obvious. If you set f(x) = 0, that implies that (1 x)( 1 x) = 0, which implies that x is or 1. So those are known as the critical points.

现在，为了得到这里的临界值，我必须代入 f (1)，例如，函数是 3x x^2，所以有 3 * 1 1^3，也就是 2。还有 f ( 1)，也就是 3 ( 1) ( 1)^3，也就是 2。这样我就可以在这里绘制函数了。所以这里是点 1，这里，上面是 2。所以这是，哎呀，是哪一个？是的。这是 1，所以它在下面。所以它是 ( 1, 2)。

And now, in order to get the critical values here, I have to plug in f (1), for instance, the function is 3x x^2, so there’s this 3 * 1 1^3, which is 2. And f ( 1), which is 3 ( 1) ( 1)^3, which is 2. And so I can plot the function here. So here’s the point 1 and here’s, up here, is 2. So this is whoops, which one is it? Yeah. This is 1, so it’s down here. So it’s ( 1, 2).

然后在这里，我有点 (1,2)。好了，现在，我从中得到了什么信息，所以我现在绘制了两个我认为非常有趣的点。我从中得到了什么信息？答案是，我知道附近有东西。因为我已经检查过，这个东西是从左边下来的，然后又上来。所以它的形状一定是这样的。在这里。切线是 0，它在那里是水平的。

And then over here, I have the point (1,2). Alright, now, what information do I get from so I’ve now plotted two, I claim, very interesting points. What information do I get from this? The answer is, I know something very nearby. Because I’ve already checked that the thing is coming down from the left, and coming back up. And so it must be shaped like this. Over here. The tangent line is 0, it’s going to be level there.

同样，在这里，它也会这样做。所以，根据我们的计算，这是我们目前所知道的。问题。学生：杰里森教授：问题是，如果有一个尖角会发生什么。答案是，微积分，它不被称为临界点。它是别的东西。而且它也是一个非常重要的点。我们将讨论这些点。有更戏剧性的例子。

And similarly over here, it’s going to do that. So this is what we know so far, based on what we’ve computed. Question. STUDENT: PROF. JERISON:. The question is, what happens if there’s a sharp corner. The answer is, calculus, it’s not called a critical point. It’s a something else. And it’s a very important point, too. And we will be discussing those kinds of points. There are much more dramatic instances of that.

这就是我们要讲的内容的一部分。但我只想保留这个，好吗？我们会讨论。是的。问题。学生：杰里森教授：。问题是，我怎么知道在临界点这里是凹的，这里是凸的。答案是，我实际上还没有使用二阶导数。我使用的是另一条信息。

That’s part of what we’re going to say. But I just want to save that, alright. We will be discussing. Yeah. Question. STUDENT: PROF. JERISON:. The question that was asked was, how did I know at the critical point that it’s concave down over here and concave up over here. The answer is that I actually did not use the second derivative yet. What I used is another piece of information.

我使用了我在这里得出的信息。f' 为正，f' 为正，f' 为负。所以我知道的是，图形在 1 的左侧向下。它在这里向右向上。它在这里向上，在那里向下。我没有使用二阶导数。我用的是一阶导数。好的，但我没有仅仅利用这里有一个转折点这一事实。

I used the information that I derived over here. That f’ is positive, where f’ is positive and where it’s negative. So what I know is that the graph is going down to the left of 1. It’s going up to the right, here. It’s going up here and it’s going down there. I did not use the second derivative. I used the first derivative. OK, but I didn’t just use the fact that there was a turning point here.

所以，实际上，我利用了它是一个转折点的事实。但我没有利用它有二阶导数的事实。好的。现在。你也可以通过二阶导数看到它。所以现在，我要做的下一件事是完成这个图表。我只是想在这里做得稍微仔细一点。按照合理的顺序。

So, actually, I was using the fact that it was a turning point. I wasn’t using the fact that it had the second derivative, though. OK. For now. You can also see it by the second derivative as well. So now, the next thing that I’d like to do, I need to finish off this graph. And I just want to do it a little bit carefully here. In the order that is reasonable.

现在，你可能会注意到，这并没有什么问题，所以让我们猜测一下。然而，为了猜测一下，并让它稍微正确一点，我必须注意到这个东西交叉了，这个函数交叉了原点。函数 f(x) = 3x x^3 恰好也具有 f ( 0 ) = 0 的性质。同样，这是常识。你可以使用你的常识。

Now, you might happen to notice, and there’s nothing wrong with this, so let’s even fill in a guess. In order to fill in a guess, though, and have it be even vaguely right, I do have to notice that this thing crosses, this function crosses the origin. The function f(x) = 3x x^3 happens also have the property that f ( 0 ) = 0. Again, common sense. You’re allowed to use your common sense.

你可以注意到函数的一个值，然后把它代入进去。所以这样做没有错。如果你碰巧有这样一个值。那么，现在我们可以猜一下我们的函数会是什么样子。它可能会像这样下降。像这样上升。然后像这样下降。它可能就是这个样子。

You’re allowed to notice a value of the function and put it in. So there’s nothing wrong with that. If you happen to have such a value. So, now we can guess what our function is going to look like. It’s going to maybe come down like this.come up like this. And come down like this. That could be what it looks like.

但是，你知道，另一种可能性是，它从这里出来，从那里出来。从这里出来，从那里出来，谁知道呢？顺便说一句，它恰好是一个奇函数。对吧？这些都是奇数幂。所以，实际上，它的右半部分和左半部分是对称的。并且在 0 处交叉。所以我们在右边所做的一切都将与在左边发生的相同。

But, you know, another possibility is it sort of comes along here and goes out that way.comes along here and goes out that way, who knows? It happens, by the way, that it’s an odd function. Right? Those are all odd powers. So, actually, it’s symmetric on the right half and the left half. And crosses at 0. So everything that we do on the right is going to be the same as what happens on the left.

这是另一条常识。无论何时绘制任何东西，你都希望尽可能多地利用这一点。不要丢掉信息。所以这个函数恰好是奇函数。奇数，并且 f ( 0 ) = 0。我认为这些是微积分预备技能，我希望你尽可能多地使用它们。所以现在，这是第一个特征，不幸的是，它在大多数函数讨论中都被忽略了。

That’s another piece of common sense. You want to make use of that as much as possible, whenever you’re drawing anything. Don’t want to throw out information. So this function happens to be odd. Odd, and f ( 0 ) = 0. I’m considering those to be kinds of precalculus skills that I want you to use as much as you can. So now, here’s the first feature which is unfortunately ignored in most discussions of functions.

这很奇怪，因为如今我们有了图形。这实际上是练习中唯一不能用图形计算器完成的部分，至少在这个相对简单的层面上是这样。这就是我所说的问题的结局。所以屏幕外发生的事情才是问题。这基本上是你必须解决的问题的理论部分。你可以对此进行编程。

And it’s strange, because nowadays we have graphing things. And it’s really the only part of the exercise that you couldn’t do, at least on this relatively simpleminded level, with a graphing calculator. And that is what I would call the ends of the problem. So what happens off the screen, is the question. And that basically is the theoretical part of the problem that you have to address. You can program this.

你可以画出你想要的所有图片。但你看不到屏幕外的东西。你需要知道一些东西才能弄清楚屏幕外的东西。所以，在这种情况下，我说的是屏幕外的东西向右或向左。所以让我们检查一下两端。所以在这里，我们来看看。

You can draw all the pictures that you want. But what you won’t see is what’s off the screen. You need to know something to figure out what’s off the screen. So, in this case, I’m talking about what’s off the screen going to the right, or going to the left. So let’s check the ends. So here, let’s just take a look.

我们有函数 f(x)，对不起，就是 3x x^3。这又是一种微积分预备知识。现在我们想象一下，让 x 趋向正无穷。那么这里会发生什么。当 x 很大时，这个项完全可以忽略不计。它的行为就像 x^3，当 x 趋向正无穷时，它趋向负无穷。同样，如果 x 趋向负无穷，f (x) 也趋向正无穷。

We have the function f(x), which is, sorry, 3x x^3. Again this is a precalculus sort of thing. And we’re imagining now, let’s just do x goes to plus infinity. So what happens here. When x is gigantic, this term is completely negligible. And it just behaves like x^3, which goes to minus infinity as x goes to plus infinity. And similarly, f (x) goes to plus infinity if x goes to minus infinity.

现在让我再次拉下这幅图，向你们展示我们得到的信息。我们现在知道它是朝这个方向向上的。它不是这样走的，而是朝那个方向向上的。我要给它画一个箭头，它是这样向下的。当 x 向右移动得更远时，它就朝负无穷方向移动。当 x 向左移动得更远时，它就朝正无穷方向移动。

Now let me pull down this picture again, and show you what piece of the information we’ve got. We now know that it is heading up this way. It doesn’t go like this, it goes up like that. And I’m going to put an arrow for it, And it’s going down like this. Heading down to minus infinity as x goes out farther to the right. And going out to plus infinity as x goes farther to the left.

现在这个函数几乎没什么可描述的了。除了装饰之外真的没什么可描述的了。我们有点喜欢这种装饰，所以我们会注意它。为此，我们必须检查二阶导数。所以如果我们第二次微分，一阶导数是，记住，3 3x^2。所以二阶导数是 6x。所以现在我们注意到，如果 x 为正，则 f'' (x) 为负。

So now there’s hardly anything left of this function to describe. There’s really nothing left except maybe decoration. And we kind of like that decoration, so we will pay attention to it. And to do that, we’ll have to check the second derivative. So if we differentiate a second time, the first derivative was, remember, 3 3x^2. So the second derivative is 6x. So now we notice that f’’ (x) is negative if x is positive.

如果 x 为负，则 f'' (x) 为正。所以这部分是向下凹的。这部分是向上凹的。现在我要换板子，这样你就可以画出来了。你看，它本来应该是这样的。所以我们将在这里填充其余部分。也许用漂亮的颜色。所以这是整个图表，这是正确的图表。

And f’’ ( x) is positive if x is negative. And so in this part it’s concave down. And in this part it’s concave up. And now I’m going to switch the boards so that you’ll, and draw it. And you see that it was begging to be this way. So we’ll fill in the rest of it here. Maybe in a nice color here. So this is the whole graph and this is the correct graph.

它一下子从这里下降，又从这里上升。然后它在原点处向下凹陷。所以这个点很有趣，不仅因为它是它与轴相交的地方，而且它也是所谓的拐点。

It comes down in one swoop down here, and comes up here. And then it changes to concave down right at the origin. So this point is of interest, not only because it’s the place where it crosses the axis, but it’s also what’s called an inflection point.

拐点，就是因为 f'' 在该位置等于 0 的点。所以它是二阶导数为 0 的地方。我们也认为这些是有趣的点。现在，让我在这里做一点总结。也就是说，所有这些信息都是相辅相成的。我们将有更多、更难的例子，你实际上必须思考发生了什么。但有很多东西在保护你。函数会表现良好并适当转向。无论如何，我们下次再讨论。

Inflection point, that’s a point where because f’’ at that place is equal to 0. So it’s a place where the second derivative is 0. We also consider those to be interesting points. Now, so let me just making one closing remark here. Which is that all of this information fits together. And we’re going to have much, much harder examples of this where you’ll actually have to think about what’s going on. But there’s a lot of stuff protecting you. And functions will behave themselves and turn around appropriately. Anyway, we’ll talk about it next time.

Lec 11 | MIT 18.01 单变量微积分，2007 年秋季

Lec 11 | MIT 18.01 Single Variable Calculus, Fall 2007
