And the second relationship that we have, we’ve already written down. Which is dx / dt oops, sorry. dD / dt = minus 80. Now, the idea here is relatively straightforward. We just want to use differentiation. Now, you could solve for x. Alright, x is the square root of D^2 30 squared.

这是一种可能性。但这基本上是在浪费时间。这是在浪费你的时间。所以，遵循这种隐式微分法会更容易，或者说最容易，我希望鼓励你习惯这种方法。也就是说，我们只是对时间微分这个方程。现在，当你这样做时，你必须记住，你不能代入一个常数。也就是 40，代表 t。

That’s one possibility. But this is basically a waste of time. It’s a waste of your time. So it’s easier, or easiest, to follow this method of implicit differentiation, which I want to encourage you to get used to. Namely, we just differentiate this equation with respect to time. Now, when you do that, you have to remember that you are not allowed to plug in a constant. Namely 40, for t.

你必须记住这个问题的真正含义，即 x 在移动，在变化。D 也在变化。所以你必须先求导，然后再代入数值。最简单的方法是使用隐式微分。如果我这样做，我会得到 2x dx / dt 等于 2D (dD / dt)。不再有 DDT 了。我们希望。除了这块黑板。

You have to keep in mind what’s really going on in this problem which is that x is moving, it’s changing. And D is also changing. So you have to differentiate first before you plug in the values. So the easiest thing is to use, in this case, implicit differentiation. And if I do that, I get 2x dx / dt is equal to 2D (dD / dt). No more DDT left. We hope. Except in this blackboard.

这就是我们的情况。现在，如果我代入，现在我可以代入。代入值。这是求导后的结果。实际上，我们这里有 2 乘以 x 的值，此时为 40。然后我们有 dx / dt。这等于 2 (D)，即 50。然后 dD / dt 为 80。所以 80 被抵消，我们看到 dv / dt = 100 英尺/秒。

So there’s our situation. Now, if I just plug in, now I can plug in. In values. so this is after taking the derivative. And, indeed, we have here 2 times the value for x which is 40 at this instant. And then we have dx / dt. And that’s equal to 2 (D), which is 50. And then dD / dt is 80. So the 80’s cancel and we see that dv / dt = 100 feet per second.

所以这个问题的答案是肯定的。尽管你可能不会因为这么严重的违规而被拦下。所以，没错，它的速度比每小时 65 英里高一点点。所以这就是这个问题的结尾。通常在这些变化率或相关费率问题中，如果你愿意的话，这被认为是问题的答案。所以这是一个例子。

And so the answer to the question is yes. Although you probably wouldn’t be pulled over for this much of a violation. So that’s, right, it’s more than 65 miles an hour, by a little bit. So that’s the end of this question. And usually in these rate of change or related rates questions, this is considered to be the answer to the question, if you like. So that’s one example.

在我们继续讨论隐式微分的其他应用之前，我将再举一个例子。我的第二个例子是，你有一个圆锥形水箱。假设顶部半径为 4 英尺。深度为 10 英尺。这就是我们的情况。然后它被灌满水。所以，被灌满水。以每分钟 2 立方英尺的速度。这就是我们的情况。

I’m going to give one more example before we go on to some other applications implicit differentiation. So my second example is going to be, you have a it is a conical tank. With top of radius 4 feet, let’s say. And depth 10 feet. So that’s our situation. And then it’s being filled with water. So, is being filled with water. At 2 cubic feet per minute. So there is our situation.

那么问题是，当水深 5 英尺时，水位上升的速度有多快？如果这个东西在某种意义上是半满的，那么不是总体积的半满。而是高度的半满，那么水位上升的速度是多少。那么，我们如何设置这样的问题呢？我们上次讨论过这个问题。第一步是设置图表和变量。

And then the question is, how fast is the water rising when it is at depth 5 feet? So if this thing is half full in the sense, well not half full in terms of total volume. But half full in terms of height, what’s the speed at which the water is rising. So, how do we set up problems like this? Well, we talked about this last time. The first step is to set up a diagram and variables.

我要画出这张图。实际上我要画两遍。这是圆锥形水箱。半径为 4。高度为 10。这只是为了让我思考这个问题。现在，结果是因为我们有变化的深度等等，而这只是顶部。

And I’m just going to draw the picture. And I’m actually going to draw the picture twice. So here’s the conical tank. And we have this radius, which is 4. And we have this height, which is 10. So that’s just to allow me to think about this problem. Now, it turns out because we have a varying depth and so on, and this is just the top.

我最好也描绘一下当前的水位。此外，最好以示意图的形式来描绘，正如你所看到的。所以这里的关键点是在这里画出这个三角形。它显示了 10，显示了 4。然后想象我正在填充它的一部分。所以也许我们可以把水位换成另一种颜色。这就是水位。

That I’d better depict also the level at which the water actually is at present. And furthermore, it’s better to do this schematically, as you’ll see. So the key point here is to draw this triangle here. Which shows me the 10 and shows me the 4, over here. And then imagine that I’m filling it partway. So maybe we’ll put that water level in another color here. So here’s the water level.

至于水位，我将在这里用 r 表示水平距离。这将是我的变量。这是水面的半径。所以我要截取它的横截面，因为从几何学上来说这是我唯一需要跟踪的东西。至少在最初是这样。所以这是我们的水位。它实际上是旋转的。但我只描绘了这幅图的一半。然后同样，我有高度。

And the water level, I’m going to depict that horizontal distance here, as r. That’s going to be my variable. That’s the radius of the top of the water. So I’m taking a cross section of this, because that geometrically the only thing I have to keep track of. At least initially. So this is our water level. And it’s really rotated around. But I’m depicting just this one half slice of the picture. And then similarly, I have the height.

那里的维度是多少。或者，如果你愿意的话，是水的深度。所以水已经充满了我们，直到这里的这个点。所以我这样设置它，这样我们就可以清楚地看到这里有两个三角形。我们可以从几何图形中获得的一条信息是相似三角形的信息。

Which is this dimension there. Or, if you like, the depth of the water. So the water has filled us up, up to this point here. So I set it up this way so that it’s clear that we have two triangles here. And that one piece of information we can get from the geometry is the similar triangles information.

即 r / h = 4 / 10。这是迄今为止最典型的几何事实，你必须从图片中收集。这是我们从这张图片中获得的一条信息。现在，我们要做的第二件事是建立水体积的公式，然后弄清楚这里发生了什么。所以水的体积是圆锥的体积。

Namely, that r / h = 4 / 10. So this is by far the most typical geometric fact that you’ll have to glean from a picture. So that’s one piece of information that we get from this picture. Now, the second thing we have to do is set up formulas for the volume of water, and then figure out what’s going on here. So the volume of water is, of a cone.

所以，再说一遍，你必须了解一些几何知识才能解决这些问题。所以你必须知道圆锥的体积是 1/3 底乘以高。现在，这个是倒置的。底在顶部，向下，但工作原理相同。这不会影响体积。所以它是 1/3，底是 pi r^2，这是底。乘以 h，即高。

So again, you have to know something about geometry to do many of these problems. So you have to know that the volume of a cone is 1/3 base times height. Now, this one is upside down. The base is on the top and it’s going down but it works the same way. That doesn’t affect volume. So it’s 1/3 and the base is pi r^2, that’s the base. And times h, which is the height.

这就是这个问题的设置。现在，有了关系，我们还需要记住一个关系。因为这个问题中还有一条信息。即体积变化的速度有多快。它以每分钟 2 立方英尺的速度变化。它在增加，这意味着 dv / dt = 2。所以我现在把所有的文字都删掉了，只剩下公式了。

So this is the setup for this problem. And now, having our relationship, we have one relationship left that we have to remember. Because we have one more piece of information in this problem. Namely, how fast the volume is changing. It’s going at 2 cubic feet per minute. It’s increasing, so that means that dv / dt = 2. So I’ve now gotten rid of all the words and I have only formulas left.

我从文字开始，画了一些图，推导出一些公式。实际上，还缺了一样东西。缺什么？是的。学生：教授：没错。你要找到什么。我漏掉了问题。所以问题是，当 h = 5 时，dh / dt 是多少？这就是这里的问题。现在，我们得到了整个问题，如果你愿意的话，我们再也不用看它了。

I started here with the words, I drew some pictures, and I derived some formulas. Actually, there’s one thing missing. What’s missing? Yeah. STUDENT: PROFESSOR: Exactly. What you want to find. What I left out is the question. So the question is, what is dh / dt when h = 5? So that’s the question here. Now, we’ve got the whole problem and we never have to look at it again if you like.

我们只需要注意这部分。让我们开始吧。这里会发生什么。你看，你可以通过隐式微分来实现这一点。但是将 r 表示为 h 的函数太容易了，这似乎有点愚蠢。所以我们将 r 写为 2/5 h。这是从这里的第一个方程得出的。然后我们将其代入。这意味着 v = 1/3 pi ( 2/5 h^2) h。

We just have to pay attention to this piece here. So let’s carry it out. So what happens here. So look, you could do this by implicit differentiation. But it’s so easy to express r as a function of h that seems kind of foolish. So let’s write r as 2/5 h. That’s coming from this first equation here. And then let’s substitute that in. That means that v = 1/3 pi ( 2/5 h^2) h.

现在我必须对其进行微分。因此，现在我将使用隐式微分。此时，用立方根来求解 h 是非常愚蠢的。你只会陷入一堆垃圾中。因此，在某个阶段，我们仍然使用隐式微分。我不会尝试求解 h 作为 v 的函数。相反，我只是直接从这个公式中进行微分，这相对容易区分。

And now I have to differentiate that. So now I will use implicit differentiation. It’s very foolish at this point to take cube roots to solve for h. You just get yourself into a bunch of junk. So there is a stage at which we’re still using implicit differentiation here. I’m not going to try to solve for h as a function of v. Instead I’m just differentiating straight out from this formula, which is relatively easy to differentiate.

所以这是 dv / dt，当然 = 2，如果我对它求导，我就会得到这个常数，pi / 3，另一个常数，(2/5)^2。然后我必须对 h^3 求导。(h^2)h。所以这是 3h^2 (dh / dt)。这就是链式法则。现在让我们代入所有数字。同样，另一个主题是，在一切都停止移动之前，不要代入数字，固定数字。

So this is dv / dt, which of course = 2 and if I differentiate it I just get this constant, pi / 3, this other constant, (2/5)^2. And then I have to differentiate h^3. (h^2)h. So that’s 3h^2 ( dh / dt). That’s the chain rule. So now let’s plug in all of our numbers. Again, the other theme is, you don’t plug in numbers, fixed numbers, until everything has stopped moving.

此时，我们已经计算了变化率。现在我可以输入数字了。所以，2 = pi 3 ( 2/5)^2.3)，然后 h 是 5，所以这是 5^2。然后我得到了 dh / dt。这个问题只剩下一个未知数，即 dh / dt。其他都是数字。如果你进行所有取消，你会发现这个会取消这个。

At this point, we’ve already calculated our rates of change. So now I can put in the numbers. So, 2 = pi 3 ( 2/5)^2.3), and then h was 5, so this is 5^2. And then I have dh / dt. There’s only one unknown thing left in this problem, which is dh / dt. Everything else is a number. And if you do all the cancellations, you see that this cancels this.

其中一个 2 抵消了，这个抵消了这个。然后，另一个 2 抵消了那个。所以，我们这里得到的是 dh / dt = 1 / 2 pi。所以，这正好是英尺每秒。这就是整个故事。问题，回到了那里。学生：教授：我从哪里得到这个问题，我从哪里得到 r = 2/5 h。

One of the 2’s cancels well, this cancels this. And then one of the 2’s cancels that. So all told what we have here is that dh / dt = 1 / 2 pi. And so that happens to be feet per second. This is the whole story. Questions, way back there. STUDENT: PROFESSOR: Where did I get the question is where did I get r = 2/5 h from.

答案是，它来自相似三角形，在这里。我做了这个相似三角形的事情。我得到了这个关系。r / h = 4/10，但后来我取消了它，得到了 2/5 并将 h 带过来。另一个问题，在这里。学生：教授：。问题如下。假设你处于这个阶段，你能从这里写出 dv / dh 吗？那么，假设你在这里。并找出这是什么。

The answer was, it came from similar triangles, which is over here. I did this similar triangle thing. And I got this relationship here. r / h = 4/10, but then I canceled it, got 2/5 and brought the h over. Another question, over here. STUDENT: PROFESSOR:. The question was the following. Suppose you’re at this stage, can you write from here dv / dh. So, suppose you’re here. And work out what this is.

最终会得到一些常数时间 h^2。然后还使用 dv / dt = dv / dh ( dh / dt )。这是链式法则。答案是肯定的。我们可以这样做，事实上这就是我的下一句话。这正是我要说的。所以当我说这个对不起，当你说这个时，我就是这么做的。这正是我所做的。这个块就是 dv / dh。

It’s going to end up being some constant times h^2. And then also use dv / dt = dv / dh ( dh / dt). Which the chain rule. And the answer is yes. We can do that, and indeed that is what my next sentence is. That’s exactly what I’m saying. So when I said this sorry, when you said this, I did that. That’s exactly what I did. This chunk is exactly dv / dh.

这正是我正在做的。好的。所以，这绝对是我的想法。是的，另一个问题。学生：教授：你问我的算术是否正确？学生：教授：π每秒。哦。这应该不是，好的，对。我猜是每分钟。因为另一个是每分钟。谢谢。是的。还有其他问题吗？可能还要将我的秒数修正为分钟。回到那里。学生：我不明白，你为什么要这么做。

That’s just what I’m doing. OK. So, definitely, that’s what I had in mind. Yeah, another question. STUDENT: PROFESSOR: You’re asking me whether my arithmetic is right or not? STUDENT: PROFESSOR: Pi per second. Oh. This should no, OK, right. I guess it’s per minute. Since the other one is per minute. Thank you. Yes. Was there another question? Probably also fixing my seconds to minutes. Way back there. STUDENT: I don’t understand, why did you have to do all that.

速度不是每分钟 2 立方英尺吗？教授：你灌水的速度是 2 立方英尺，但水位上升的速度不同，这取决于你是在低处还是在高处。这取决于池塘的宽度，水面有多大。所以事实上不是。事实上，答案不是 2 立方英尺。那里有一个速率。也就是说，这是增加的体积。

Isn’t the speed 2 cubic feet per minute? PROFESSOR:. The speed at which you’re filling it is 2 cubic feet, but the water level is rising at a different rate, depending on whether you’re low down or high up. It depends on how wide the pond, the surface, is. So in fact it’s not. In fact, the answer wasn’t 2 cubic it wasn’t. There’s a rate there. That is, that’s how much volume is being added.

但是，我们还要跟踪另一个数字，即高度。或者，如果你愿意的话，也可以叫它水的深度。好的。这就是相关速率的重点。你有一个变量，即 v，它是某种东西的体积。你还有另一个变量，即 h，它是水锥的高度。你用一个变量来跟踪另一个变量。

But then there’s another number that we’re keeping track of, which is the height. Or, if you like, the depth of the water. OK. So this is the whole point about related rates. Is you have one variable, which is v, which is volume of something. You have another variable, which is h, which is the height of the cone of water there. And you’re keeping track of one variable in terms of the other.

而且这种关系永远是链式法则类型的关系。因此，如果你知道一个，你就能找出另一个。只要你得到所有相关速率。这些就是所谓的相关速率。这是某物相对于某物的速率，等等。所以这真的都是关于链式法则的。然后把它应用到文字问题中。所以有几个例子。

And the relationship will always be a chain rule type of relationship. So, therefore, you’ll be able to if you know one you’ll be able to figure out the other. Provided you get all of the related rates. These are what are called related rates. This is a rate of something with respect to something, etc. etc. So it’s really all about the chain rule. And just fitting it to word problems. So there’s a couple of examples.

我会让你再做些练习。现在，我要做的下一件事是再给你一个最大最小问题。这与我随身携带的这个设备有关。这是一个环。恰好是一个餐巾环，这是一些降落伞绳，我去背包旅行时会用到。问题是，如果你认为这是一个重物，它是灵活的。

And I’ll let you work out some more. So now, the next thing that I want to do is to give you one more max min problem. Which has to do with this device, which I brought with me. So this is a ring. Happens to be a napkin ring, and this is some parachute string, which I use when I go backpacking. And the question is if you have a you think of this is a weight, it’s flexible.

它可以在这里移动。问题是，如果我把这两个端点固定在我的两只手的位置，我的右手在这里，我的左手在那里。问题是，这个环应该安放在哪里。现在，很明显，或者应该很明显，如果我的两只手处于相同的高度，它应该安放在中间。

It’s allowed to move along here. And the question is, if I fix these two ends where my two hands are, where my right hand is here and where my left hand is over there. And the question is, where does this ring settle down. Now, it’s obvious, or should be maybe obvious, is that if my two hands are at equal heights, it should settle in the middle.

我们试图解决的问题是，如果一只手比另一只手高一点，会发生什么情况，或者如果另一只手高一点，会发生什么情况。它会落在哪里？因此，为了正确描述这个问题，我需要两名志愿者来帮助我。我能得到一些帮助吗？好的。所以我需要你们中的一个人握住右侧，另一个人握住左侧。好的。

The question that we’re trying to resolve is what if one hand is a little higher than the other. What happens, or if the other way. Where does it settle down? So in order to depict this problem properly, I need two volunteers to help me out. Can I have some help? OK. So I need one of you to hold the right side, and one of you to hold the left side. OK.

把它靠在黑板上。我们要描一下。把它粘在这里，中间的某个地方。现在我们要确保这个稍微高一点，好吗？所以我们必须，是的，让我们再高一点。这可能就足够了。实验已经完成了。我们现在知道这个东西在哪里了。但是，现在抓紧。这个东西会伸展。

And just hold it against the blackboard. We’re going to trace. So stick it about here, in the middle somewhere. And now we want to make sure that this one is a little higher, alright? So we’ll have to yeah, let’s get a little higher up. That’s probably good enough. So the experiment has been done. We now see where this thing is. But, so now hold on tight. This thing stretches.

所以我们要把它拉长，这样我们才能看清楚它到底是什么。所以这个东西对于这个演示来说不够重。我应该在那里放一块十吨重的砖。但如果我这样做，那我就要考验我的，对吧，我要考验你的能力了。好吧，所以我们要试着找出这里的可能性。所以，粗略地说，这就是这个东西现在在哪里安顿下来。

So we want to get it stretched so that we can see what it is properly. So this thing isn’t heavy enough for this demonstration. I should’ve had a ten ton brick attached there. But if I did that, than I would tax my, right, I would tax your abilities to. Right, so we’re going to try to trace out what the possibilities are here. So this is, roughly speaking, where this thing and so now where does it settle.

嗯，它就在这里。所以我们要把它作为 x 标记点。好的，非常感谢。必须记住那些点的位置，好的，好吧。抱歉，我忘了标记这些点。好的，情况是这样的。我们遇到了问题。我们挂了一根绳子。它像这样下降，然后像那样下降。我们发现了它在哪里稳定下来。物理上。

Well, it settles about here. So we’re going to put that as x marks the spot. OK, thank you very much. Got to remember where those dots OK, all right. Sorry, I forgot to mark the spots. OK, so here’s the situation. We have a problem. And we’ve hung a string. And it went down like this and then it went like that. And we discovered where it settled. Physically.

因此，我们想用数学来解释这个问题，看看这个问题是怎么回事。所以这是一个现实生活中的问题。老实说，如果你想建一座桥，这就是你必须解决的问题。比如，一座悬索桥。这是众多问题之一。这是一个非常严肃和重要的问题。这是这类问题中最简单的一个。所以我们在这里得到了形状。

So we want to explain this mathematically, and see what’s going on with this problem. So this is a real life problem. It honestly is the problem you have to solve if you want to build a bridge. Like, a suspension bridge. This, among many problems. It’s a very serious and important problem. And this is the simplest one of this type. So we’ve got our shape here.

这应该是一条直线，也许没有那么倾斜。首先，我们已经画好了图表，我们或多或少已经把这里发生的事情形象化了。但画完图表后的第一步是给出字母。就是给事物贴上适当的标签。在这个阶段，我不指望你能做到这一点。因为这需要很多经验。但我会为你做这件事。

This should be a straight line, maybe not quite as angled as that. The first, we’ve already drawn the diagram and we’ve more or less visualized what’s going on here. But the first step after the diagram is to give letters. Is to label things appropriately. And I do not expect you to be able to do this, at this stage. Because it requires a lot of experience. But I’m going to do it for you.

我们就这样做了。最简单的做法是使用平面的坐标。如果你这样做，使用原点也是最简单的。我最喜欢的数字是 0，它也应该是你的。所以我们要把这个点设为 (0,0)。现在，这个问题中还有另一个固定点。就是这里的这个点。我们不知道它的坐标是什么。

We’re going to just do that. So the simplest thing to do is to use the coordinates of the plane. And if you do that, it’s also easiest to use the origin. My favorite number is 0 and it should be yours, too. So we’re going to make this point be (0,0). Now, there’s another fixed point in this problem. And it’s this point over here. And we don’t know what its coordinates are.

所以我们只需要给它们字母 a 和 b。但是这些字母在这个问题中是固定的数字。我们想要解决所有可能的 a 和 b。现在，记住，有趣的是，当 b 不为 0 时会发生什么。如果 b = 0，我们已经知道该点应该是中心点。

So we’re just going to give them letters, a and b. But those letters are going to be fixed numbers in this problem. And we want to solve it for all possible a’s and b’s. Now, the interesting thing, remember, is what happens when b Is not 0. If b = 0, we already have a clue that the point should be the center point.

它应该正好是 x，中间点，我马上就要标记它，它位于中间。所以现在我要使用的变量点就在这里。我要称这个点为 (x, y)。这是我的设置。到目前为止，我已经给图表上的所有东西都贴上了标签。图表上的大部分东西。那么现在，我还必须做什么呢？

It should be exactly that x, the middle point, which I’m going to label in a second, is halfway in between. So now the variable point that I’m going to use is down here. I’m going to call this point (x, y). So here’s my setup. I’ve now given labels to all the things on the diagram so far. Most of the things on the diagram. So now, what else do I have to do?

好吧，我必须向你解释，这是一个最小化问题。实际上，物理上发生的事情是重量稳定在最低点。这是具有最低势能的东西。所以我们最小化一个函数。它是这条曲线。约束是我们被限制在这条曲线上。所以这是一条约束曲线。我们想要这条曲线的最低点。

Well, I have to explain to you that this is a minimization problem. What happens, actually, physically is that the weight settles to the lowest point. That’s the thing that has the lowest potential energy. So we’re minimizing a function. And it’s this curve here. The constraint is that we’re restricted to this curve. So this is a constraint curve. And we want the lowest point of this curve.

所以现在，我们需要更多的语言来描述我们得到了什么。约束曲线，我们以一种特殊的方式得到它。也就是说，我们将一些绳子从这里拉到那里。在所有这些点上，绳子的总长度是相同的。所以表达约束的一种方式是，绳子的长度是恒定的。

So now, we need a little bit more language in order to describe what it is that we’ve got. And the constraint curve, we got it in a particular way. Namely, we strung some string from here to there. And what happens at all these points is that the total length of the string is the same. So one way of expressing the constraint is that the length of the string is constant.

因此，为了弄清楚约束是什么，这条曲线是什么，我必须对其进行分析描述。我将通过绘制一些辅助线来实现这一点。即，一些直角三角形来计算这个长度是多少。另一个长度是多少。如果我在这里画一个直角三角形，这个长度就很容易计算了。因为我们越过 x 并向下移动 y。

And so in order to figure out what the constraint is, what this curve is, I have to describe that analytically. And I’m going to do that by drawing in some helping lines. Namely, some right triangles to figure out what this length is. And what the other length is. So this length is pretty easy if I draw a right triangle here. Because we go over x and we go down y.

所以这个长度是 x^2 + y^2 的平方根。这就是勾股定理。同样，在这里，我将得到另一个长度。这有点混乱。它是垂直的。所以我只标记它的一半，这样你就能看出来。所以这个水平距离是 x。这个水平距离是从这个顶点到这个直角的距离，在那里。它从 x 开始，到 a 结束。

So this length is the square root of x^2 + y^2. That’s the Pythagorean theorem. Similarly, over here, I’m going to get another length. Which is a little bit of a mess. It’s the vertical. So I’m just going to label one half of it, so that you see. So this horizontal distance is x. And this horizontal distance from this top point with this right angle, over there. It starts at x and ends at a.

最右边的点是 x 坐标中的 a。所以整个距离是 a x。所以这是这个直角三角形的一条边。同样，垂直距离将是 b y。所以，这里的公式对于这个长度来说有点复杂，是 (ax)^2 + (b y)^2 的平方根。所以这两个公式现在可以帮助我解决我的问题。

The right most point is a in the x coordinate. So the whole distance is a x. So that’s this leg of this right triangle. And, similarly, the vertical distance will be b y. And so, the formula here, which is a little complicated for this length, is the square root of (a x)^2 + (b y)^2. So here are the two formulas that are going to allow me to set up my problem now.

因此，我的目标是像这里一样设置它，只使用公式。而不是使用图表和名称。这就是我想要做的。我声称，如果我沿着那条曲线，那么限制就是总长度是恒定的。这就是这里的陈述。x^2 + y^2 + 这个另一个平方根的平方根。这是两个字符串的长度。

So, my goal is to set it up the way I did here, just with formulas. And not with diagrams and not with names. So here’s what I’d like to do. I claim that what’s constrained, if I’m along that curve, is that the total length is constant. So that’s this statement here. The square root of x^2 + y^2 + this other square root. These are the two lengths of string.

等于某个常数 L。正如我所说，这就是我所说的约束。是的。学生：教授：那么问题是，它不应该是 b 加 y 吗？不，原因是 y 是负数。它小于 0。所以它实际上是总和，y 是正数。好的，这是公式。然后，我们想找到某个数的最小值。

Is equal to some number, L, which is constant. And this, as I said, is what I’m calling my constraint. Yeah. STUDENT: PROFESSOR: So the question is, shouldn’t it be b plus y. No, and the reason is that y is a negative number. It’s below 0. So it’s actually the sum, y is a positive number. Alright, so here’s the formula. And then, we want to find the minimum of something.

那么，我们要找到的最小值是什么呢？从概念上讲，这实际上是问题中最难的部分。我试着准备一下，但很难弄清楚。我们要找到的最小值是什么？它是 y。我们给它起了个名字。所以我们想找到最小的 y。现在，这看起来有点奇怪的原因是，你可能会认为 y 只是一个变量。

So what is it that we’re finding the minimum of? This is actually the hardest part of the problem, conceptually. I tried to prepare it, but it’s very hard to figure this out. We’re finding the least what? It’s y. We got a name for that. So we want to find the lowest y. Now, the reason why it seems a little weird is you might think of y as just being a variable.

但实际上，y 是一个函数。它实际上是 y = y ( x ) 由约束方程隐式定义。这就是那条曲线。请注意，底点恰好是切线水平的位置。这正是我们想要的。所以从图中可以看出，底点是 y' = 0 的位置。所以这是临界点。是吗？学生：教授：没错。

But really, y is a function. It’s really y = y ( x ) is defined implicitly by the constraint equation. That’s what that curve is. And notice the bottom point is exactly the place where the tangent line will be horizontal. Which is just what we want. So from the diagram, the bottom point is where y’ = 0. So this is the critical point. Yeah? STUDENT: PROFESSOR: Exactly.

所以我正在为你推导，所以问题是，我是否可以一开始就尝试找到 y' = 0。答案是肯定的，绝对可以。事实上，我正朝着这个方向前进。我只是向你展示，所以我试图提出以下非常微妙的观点。在最大最小问题中，我们总是必须跟踪两件事。通常有趣的点是临界点。

So I’m deriving for you, so the question is, could I have just tried to find y’ = 0 to begin with. The answer is yes, absolutely. And in fact I’m leading in that direction. I’m just showing you, so I’m trying to make the following, very subtle, point. Which is in maximum minimum problems, we always have to keep track of two things. Often the interesting point is the critical point.

事实证明确实如此。但我们总是要检查端点。因此，检查端点的方法有很多。一种是，我们做了这个物理问题。我们可以看到它从这里上升。我们可以看到它从这里上升。因此，底部一定位于这个临界点。所以没问题，这是检查方法之一。

And that indeed turns out to be the case here. But we always have to check the ends. And so there are several ways of checking the ends. One is, we did this physical problem. We can see that it’s coming up here. We can see that it’s coming up here. Therefore the bottom must be at this critical point. So that’s OK, so that’s one way of checking it.

另一种检查方法是我刚才给出的推理。但其实推理是一样的。我指着这个东西，向你展示底部在中间某处。因此，它是一个水平切点。这就是我使用的推理。所以，再说一次，这是为了避免必须评估端点的极限或使用二阶导数测试，这在这种情况下是一场彻底的灾难。

Another way of checking it is the reasoning that I just gave. But it’s really the same reasoning. I’m pointing to this thing and I’m showing you that the bottom is somewhere in the middle. So, therefore, it is a place of horizontal tangency. That’s the reasoning that I’m using. So, again, this is to avoid having to evaluate a limit of an end or to use the second derivative test, which is a total catastrophe in this case.

好了，现在。如果你以前见过这个几何构造，你也许会知道另一件事。用一根绳子和粉笔。那就是这条曲线是日食。事实证明，这是日食的一部分。这是一个巨大的椭圆。这两个点就是所谓的椭圆焦点。然而，这个几何事实对于解决这个问题完全没用。完全没用。

OK, now. There’s one other thing that you might know about this if you’ve seen this geometric construction before. With a string and chalk. Which is that this curve is an eclipse. It turns out, this is a piece of an eclipse. It’s a huge ellipse. These two points turn out to be the so called foci of the ellipse. However, that geometric fact is totally useless for solving this problem.completely useless.

如果你真的写出椭圆的公式，你会发现你手头上的问题要难得多。而且它会花费你两倍或十倍的时间，所以，它确实是椭圆，但这没有帮助。好的，所以我们要做的要简单得多。我们将保留这个表达式，我们只需隐式微分。所以再次，我们对约束方程使用隐式微分。

If you actually write out the formulas for the ellipse, you’ll discover that you have a much harder problem on your hands. And it will take you twice or ten times as long, so, it’s true that it’s an ellipse, but it doesn’t help. OK, so what we’re going to do instead is much simpler. We’re going to leave this expression along and we’re just going to differentiate implicitly. So again, we use implicit differentiation on the constraint equation.

这就是我上方上方的方程。我必须对 x 求导。这有点难看，但我们之前已经做过几次了。求平方根导数时，平方根会进入分母。有一个因数 1/2，所以有一个 2x 可以抵消。所以我声称它就是这个。现在，因为 y 取决于 x，所以这里还有一个 y'。

So that’s the equation which is directly above me there, at the top. And I have to differentiate it with respect to x. So that’s a little ugly, but we’ve done this a few times before. When you differentiate a square root, the square root goes into the denominator. And there’s a factor of 1/2, so there’s a 2x which cancels. So I claim it’s this. Now, because y depends on x, there’s also a y’ here.

所以从技术上讲，它是这个的两倍乘以一半。2/2 乘以那个。所以这是这个家伙第一部分的微分。现在我要做第二个，这也是链式法则。但你必须让我为你做。因为它太长了，你很难注意到。

So technically speaking, it’s twice this with a half. 2 / 2 times that. So that’s the differentiation of the first piece of this guy. Now I’m going to do this second one, and it’s also the chain rule. But you’re just going to have to let me do it for you. Because it’s just a little bit too long for you to pay attention to.

结果出现了一个减号，因为那里有 ax 和 ay。然后分子，分母是相同的大平方根。所以它是 (ax)^2 ( by)^2。分子是 ax，它取代了这里的 x。然后是另一项，即 (by)y'。我认为这与我在第一个项中所做的类似。你只需要自己检查一下。

It turns out there’s a minus sign that comes out, because there’s a x and a y there. And then the numerator, the denominator is the same massive square root. So it’s (a x)^2 ( b y)^2. And the numerator is a x, which is what replaces the x over here. And then another term, which is (b y)y’. I claim that’s analogous to what I did in the first term. And you’ll just have to check this on your own.

因为我算得太快了，你来不及自己检查。现在，这将等于右边的。L 对 x 的导数是多少？它是 0。它在问题中没有变化。虽然我的降落伞材料会伸展。我们试图将它拉伸到最大程度。这样我们就可以保持它固定，这就是这里的目标。所以现在，这看起来一团糟。但事实并非如此。

Because I did it too fast for you to be able to check yourself. Now, that’s going to be equal to what on the right hand side. What’s the derivative of L with respect to x? It’s 0. It’s not changing in the problem. Although my parachute stuff stretches. We tried to stretch it to its fullest extent. So that we kept it fixed, that was the goal here. So now, this looks like a total mess. But, it’s not.

让我来告诉你为什么。这大大简化了。让我来告诉你具体怎么做。首先，重点是我们要寻找 y' = 0 的位置。这意味着这些项消失了。y' = 0。所以它们消失了。现在我们有以下等式。

And let me show you why. It simplifies a great deal. And let me show you exactly how. So, first of all, the whole point is we’re looking for the place where y’ = 0. So that means that these terms go away. y’ = 0. So they’re gone. And now what we have is the following equation.

它的 x / x^2 的平方根 + y^2 的平方等于，如果我把它放在另一边，减号就会变成加号。ax 除以另一个大物体，(ax)^2 + (by)^2。所以它简化为这个。现在，这对你来说可能看起来也很复杂。

It’s x / square root of x^2 + y^2 squared is equal to, if I put it on the other side the minus sign is changed to a plus sign. a x divided by this other massive object, (a x)^2 + (b y)^2. So this is what it’s simplifies to. Now again, that also might look complicated to you.

但我认为，这是一种可以用几何学解释的平衡方程，其解释方式非常有意义且重要。首先，让我为您观察一下，这个 x 是我们图片上的某个东西。x^2 + y^2 的平方根也是我们图片上的某个东西。也就是说，如果我转到图片，这里是 x，这是一个直角三角形。

But I claim that this is something, this is a kind of equilibrium equation that can be interpreted geometrically, in a way that is very meaningful and important. So first of all, let me observe for you that this x is something on our picture. And the square root of x^2 + y^2 is something on our picture. Namely, if I go over to the picture, here was x and this was a right triangle.

斜边是 x^2 + y^2 的平方根。所以，如果我把这个角称为 alpha，那么这就是 alpha 的正弦。对吧？这是一个直角三角形，那是对边。所以这个就是 alpha 的正弦。同样，另一边对另一个直角三角形也有解释。如果这个角是 beta，那么对边就是 ax，斜边就是那边的分母。

And this hypotenuse was square root of x^2 + y^2. So, if I call this angle alpha, then this is the sine of alpha. Right? It’s a right triangle, that’s the opposite leg. So this guy is the sine of alpha. Similarly, the other side has an interpretation for the other right triangle. If this angle is beta, then the opposite side is a x, and the hypotenuse is what was in the denominator over there.

所以这一边是 beta 的正弦。所以这个条件告诉我们 alpha = beta。这是问题中隐藏的对称性。我不知道当我向你展示这个东西时你是否真的能看到它。但是，无论我如何倾斜它，实际上与水平的两个角度都是相同的。在中间，显然应该是这样的。

So this side is sine of beta. And so what this condition is telling us is that alpha = beta. Which is the hidden symmetry in the problem. I don’t know if you can actually see it when I show you this thing. But, no matter how I tilt it, actually the two angles from the horizontal are the same. In the middle it’s kind of obvious that should be the case.

但在侧面，情况并不明显。现在，这种情况是均匀的，所以如果你愿意的话，这是一种对称的情况。这两个角度相等。但还有更多要说的。如果你为此做一个强制图，你会发现两条线上的张力是相同的。这意味着当你建造像这样悬挂的东西时，它将承受最小的压力。

But on the sides it’s not obvious that’s what’s happening. Now, this has even, so that’s a symmetry, if you like, of the situation. These two angles are equal. But there’s something more to be said. If you do a forced diagram for this, what you’ll discover is that the tension on the two lines is the same. Which means that when you build something which is hanging like this, it will involve the least stress.

如果你挂着一个很重的东西，而且其中一侧的负载是另一侧的两倍，那么它掉落和断裂的几率也会是另一侧的两倍。如果它们各自的强度相同，那么你就可以以更平衡的方式分配负载。所以这是一种平衡条件，这是最小化问题的典型特征。幸运的是，有很好的解决方案可以合理地分配重量。

If you hang something very heavy, and one side carries twice as much load as the other, then you have twice as much chance of its falling and breaking. If they each hold the same strength, then you’ve distributed the load in a much more balanced way. So this is a kind of a balance condition, and it’s very typical of minimization problems. And fortunately, there are nice solutions which distribute the weight reasonably well.

这当然是悬索桥的原理。所以，是的，还有一个问题。学生：教授：好的，那么问题就是它悬挂在哪里，也就是说，x 的公式是什么，y 的公式是什么。还有其他的东西，比如椭圆的方程式和很多其他类似的东西。这些是我将在一组笔记中为您解答的，我将分发这些笔记。它们简直是一团糟。

That’s certainly the principal of suspension bridges. So yeah, one more question. STUDENT: PROFESSOR: OK, so the question where it hangs, that is, what the formula for x is and what the formula for y is. And other things, like the equation for the ellipse and lots of other stuff like that. Those are things that I will answer for you in a set of notes which I will hand out. And they’re just a mess.

你看，就像我们上次做的另一道题一样，你可以对这个问题给出一些启发性的东西，但也会有一些混乱的公式。你知道，你要试着找出你能说出来的简单的东西。事实上，这是数学的一个特性，你要把重点放在更容易理解的东西上。另一方面，这是可以做到的。只需要一点计算。

You see they’re, just as in that other problem that we did last time, there’s some illuminating things you can say about the problem and then there’s some messy formulas. You know, you want to try to pick out the simple things that you can say. In fact, that’s a property of math, you want to focus on the more comprehensible things. On the other hand, it can be done. It just takes a little bit of computation.

所以我没有回答最低 y 是多少的问题。但我会为你回答。也许我只想再提一下这个问题。我从一个完全不同的角度来看待问题。如果你把椭圆转一圈，你会从这里的每个地方得到相同的现象。所以 a 和 0 在哪里并不重要。你会得到相同的现象。也就是切线。

So I didn’t answer the question of what the lowest y was. But I’ll do that for you. Maybe I’ll just mention one more thing about this problem. I’m using problems from a completely different point of view. If you sort of roll the ellipse around, you get the same phenomenon from each place here. So it doesn’t matter where a and 0 are. You’ll get the same phenomenon. That is, the tangent line.

因此，这个角度和那个角度将相等。因此，您也可以将其理解为这里的角度和这里的角度相等。也就是说，β，即互补角也相等。如果您将其解释为光线，将其解释为镜子，那么这意味着如果您从一个焦点开始，每条光线都会反弹并到达另一个焦点。

So, this angle and that angle will be equal. So you can also read that as being the angle over here and the angle over here are equal. That is, beta, that is the complementary angles are also equal. And if you interpret this as a ray of light, and this as a mirror, then this would be saying that if you start at one focus, every ray of light will bounce and go to the other focus.

这就是椭圆所具有的属性。更准确地说，是这种曲线所具有的属性。事实上，几年前，在德科尔多瓦博物馆里有一件伟大的艺术品，我强烈建议你在四年期间去参观一下。那里有一系列迷你高尔夫球洞。所以他们有一堆迷你高尔夫艺术品。

So that’s a property that an ellipse has. More precisely, a property that this kind of curve has. And in fact, a few years ago there was this great piece of art at something called the DeCordova Museum, which I recommended very highly to you go sometime to visit in your four years here. There was a collection of miniature golf holes. So they had a bunch of mini golf pieces of art.

每一个都完全不同。其中一种叫做一杆进洞。球座位于椭圆的一个焦点上。球洞位于椭圆的另一个焦点上。所以，无论你如何击球，高尔夫球总会进洞。无论它弹到哪里，它只要弹一次就能进洞。

And every one was completely different from the other. And one of them was called hole in one. And the tee was at one focus of the ellipse. And the hole was at the other focus of the ellipse. So, no matter how you hit the golf ball, it always goes into the hole. No matter where it bounces, it just, one bounce and it’s in the hole.

这实际上是我们刚才计算的结果。该继续了。我们现在要讨论其​​他内容。我们的下一个主题是牛顿法。这是微积分最伟大的应用之一。我将在这里为您描述它。

So that’s actually a consequence of the computation that we just did. Time to go on. We’re going to now talk about something else. So our next topic is Newton’s method. Which is one of the greatest applications of calculus. And I’m going to describe it here for you.

我们将通过一个例子来说明这一点，即求解方程 x^2 = 5。我们要求 5 的平方根。现在，你实际上可以用这种方式求解任何方程。基本上，任何你理解的方程，你都可以用这种方式求解。

And we’ll illustrate it on an example, which is solving the equation x^2 = 5. We’re going to find the square root of 5. Now, you can actually solve any equation this way. Any equation that you understand, you can solve this way, essentially.

因此，尽管我计算的是 5 的平方根，这是可以用计算器算出来的，但事实上，这确实是计算器许多工作方式的核心。因此，首先要让这个问题更抽象一些。

So even though I’m doing it for the square root of 5, which is something that you can figure out on your calculator, in fact this is really at the heart of many of the ways in which calculators work. So, the first thing is to make this problem a little bit more abstract.

我们将设置 f ( x ) = x^2 5。然后我们将求解 f (x) = 0。因此，这是求解此类问题的标准形式。因此，您可以采用一些复杂或简单的 x 函数，线性函数很无聊，二次函数已经很有趣了。至于三次函数，正如我多次说过的，您甚至没有求解公式。

We’re going to set f ( x ) = x^2 5. And then we’re going to solve f (x) = 0. So this is the sort of standard form for solving such a. So you take some either complicated or simple function of x, linear functions are boring, quadratic functions are already interesting. And cubic functions, as I’ve said a few times, you don’t even have formulas for solving.

所以这是你用数字方法解决它们的唯一方法。这就是它的工作原理。我的想法是，我将绘制这个函数。这是函数，它是一个抛物线，y = x^2 5。它低于 0，对不起，它应该居中，但无论如何。现在这里的想法是从猜测开始。

So this would be the only method you have for solving them numerically. So here’s how it works. So the idea, I’ll plot this function. Here’s the function, it’s a parabola, y = x^2 5. It dips below 0, sorry, it should be centered, but anyway. And now the idea here is to start with a guess.

5 的平方根非常接近 4 的平方根，也就是 2。所以我的第一个猜测是 2。所以从初始猜测开始。这是我们的第一个猜测。现在，我们要做的就是假设该函数是线性的。这就是我们要做的。然后，如果该函数是线性的，我们将尝试找到 0 的位置。

And square root of 5 is pretty close to the square root of 4, which is 2. So my first guess is going to be 2, here. So start with initial guess. So that’s our first guess. And now, what we’re going to do is we’re going to pretend that the function is linear. That’s all we’re going to do. And then if the function were linear, we’re going to try to find where the 0 is.

如果函数是线性的，我们将使用绘制 2 所在的点，即点 (2, f ( 2 ))，然后我们将在这里绘制切线。这将是我们的新猜测。x = x，我将其称为 x1。所以这里的想法是，这个点可能离它相交的地方有点远，但这个点会更近一点。

So if the function is linear, what we’ll use is we’ll plot the point where 2 is on, that is, the point (2, f ( 2 )), and then we’re going to draw the tangent line here. And this is going to be our new guess. x = x, which I’ll call x1. So the idea here is that this point may be somewhat far from where it crosses, but this point will be a little closer.

现在我们要反复这样做。看看它能多快到达我们的目标。所以我们必须找出公式。这就是策略。现在，第一步是，我们有了猜测，我们有了切线。其公式为 y y0 = m(x x0)。所以这是切线的一般形式。现在，我必须告诉你 x1 是什么。

And now we’re going to do this over and over again. And see how fast it gets to the place we’re aiming for. So we have to work out what the formulas are. And that’s the strategy. So now, the first step here is, we have our guess, we have our tangent line. Which has the formula y y0 = m(x x0). So that’s the general form for a tangent line. And now, I have to tell you what x1 is.

就这条切线而言，x1 是 x 截距。如果您看一下图表，切线就是橙色线。它与轴的交点就是我想要放置 x1 的位置。所以这就是 x 截距。现在，您如何找到 x 截距？

In terms of this tangent line. x1 is the x intercept. The tangent line, if you look over here at the diagram, the tangent line is the orange line. Where that crosses the axis, that’s where I want to put x1. So that’s the x intercept. Now, how do you find the x intercept?

你可以通过设置 y = 0 来找到它。那条水平线是 y = 0。所以我设置 y = 0，得到 0 y0 = m (x1 x0)。所以我在这个等式中改变了两点。我在这里为 y 代入了 0。我说发生这种情况的地方将是 x 为 x1 的地方。现在让我们来解。

You find it by setting y = 0. That horizontal line is y = 0. So I set y = 0, and I get 0 y0 = m (x1 x0). So I changed two things in this equation. I plugged in 0 here, for y. And I said that the place where that happens is going to be where x is x1. So now let’s solve.

我们得到的结果是 y 除以 y0 / m = x1 x0。现在我可以得到 x1 的公式。所以 x1 = x0 (y0 / m)。我现在需要告诉你这个公式对于函数 f 的意义。首先，x0 就是 x0，无论 x0 是什么。而 y0，我认为，是 f (x0)。m 是同一位置的斜率。所以它是 f' (x0)。

And what we get here is y divided by sorry, y0 / m = x1 x0. And now I can get a formula for x1. So x1 = x0 (y0 / m). I now need to tell you what this formula means, in terms of the function f. So first of all, x0 is x0, whatever x0 is. And y0, I claim, is f (x0). And m is the slope at that same place. So it’s f’ (x0).

这就是整个故事。这个公式可以让我们计算任何根。我要重复这个公式，所以我要再告诉你们牛顿法是什么，并在它周围放一个多色的方框。牛顿法涉及以下公式。

And this is the whole story. This is the formula which will enable us to calculate basically any root. I’m going to repeat this formula, so I’m going to tell you again what Newton’s method is, and put a little more colorful box around it. So Newton’s method involves the following formula.

为了得到第 n + 1 个点，也就是我们越来越好的猜测，我要取第 n 个点，然后代入这个公式。所以是 f (xn) / f' (xn)。这是基本公式，如果你愿意，这只是重复我之前的想法。

In order to get the n + 1st point, that’s our better and better guess, I’m going to take the nth one and then I’m going to plug in this formula. So f ( xn ) / f’ ( xn ). So this is the basic formula, and if you like, this is the idea of just repeating what I had before.

现在，我们已经从几何学、从图片，转向了一个真正的公式，这个公式完全可以实现，而且在任何情况下都很容易实现。那么让我们看看在我们得到的情况下它是如何工作的。也就是 x0 = 2。f(x) = x^2 5。让我们看看如何实现这个公式。首先，我必须为你计算 f' (x)。也就是 2x。

Now, we’ve gone from geometry, from just pictures, to an honest to goodness formula which is completely implementable and very easy to implement in any case. So let’s see how it works in the case that we’ve got. Which is x0 = 2. f(x) = x^2 5. Let’s see how to implement this formula. So first of all, I have to calculate for you, f’ (x). That’s 2x.

因此，x1 = x0 ，所以 f'，对不起，f ( x ) 将是 x0^2 5。这就是分子。分母中我有导数，所以是 2 x0。总而言之，好吧，让我们在这里分两步来解决这个问题。第一项是 1/2 x0，然后第二项是 + (5/2 / x0)。

And so, x1 = x0 , so f’,sorry, f ( x ) would be x0^2 5. That’s what’s in the numerator. And in the denominator I have the derivative, so that’s 2 x0. And so all told, well, let’s work it out in two steps here. This is 1/2 x0 for the first term, and then + (5/2 / x0) for the second term.

这两个项合起来，所以我们得到 1/2 x0 + 5/2，分母为 x0。这是本例中 x1 的公式。现在我想向你们展示一下这个公式的效果。首先，如果我代入 x1，+ 5/4，得到 x1 = 1/2 ( 2)，也就是 9/4。然后代入 x2，得到 1/2 ( 9/4) + 5/2 ( 4/9)。这是下一个公式。

And these two terms combine, so we have here 1/2 x0 + 5/2 with an x0 in the denominator. So here’s the formula for x1. in this case. Now I’d like to show you how well this works. So first of all, we have x1 = 1/2 ( 2), if I plug in x1, + 5/4, which is 9/4. And x2, I have 1/2 ( 9/4) + 5/2 ( 4/9). That’s the next one.

如果你算出来，结果是 161/72。然后 x3 有点长。但我就把它写下来，这样你就能看到它是 1/2 (161/72) + 5/2，然后我计算它的倒数。所以是 72/161。让我们看看它们有多好。我仔细计算了它们有多远。在我的笔记上。所以我会看一下，看看我说了什么。

And if you work this out, it’s 161/72. And then x3 is kind of long. But I will just write down what it is, so that you can see it’s 1/2 ( 161/72) + 5/2 and then I do the reciprocal of that. So 72/161. So let’s see how good these are. I carefully calculated how far off they are. Somewhere on my notes. So I’ll just take a look and see what I said.

哦，是的，我做过。那么，5 的平方根减去 n 等于多少呢？如果你愿意的话，这是 5 的平方根 xn。或者反过来。这个的大小。你必须根据你的作业决定它是正数还是负数，是在答案的右边还是左边。但让我们这样做吧。

Oh yeah, I did do it. So, what’s the square root of 5 minus so here’s n, here’s the square root of 5 xn, if you like. Or the other way around. The size of this. You’ll have to decide on your homework whether it comes out positive or negative, to the right or to the left of the answer. But let’s do this.

因此，当 n = 0 时，猜测结果为 2。误差约为 2（10 ^ 1）。如果 n = 1，即 9/4，误差约为 10 ^ 2。然后 n = 2，即这个数字，对吗？误差约为 4（10 ^ 5）。这已经是您一生中所需要的 5 平方根的近似值。

So when n = 0, the guess was 2. And we’re off by about 2 ( 10 ^ 1). And if n = 1, so that’s this 9/4, that’s off by about 10 ^ 2. And then n = 2, that’s this number here, right? And that’s off by about 4 ( 10 ^ 5). That’s already as good an approximation to the square root of 5 as you’ll ever need in your life.

如果你计算 3，这个数字就会精确到 10^10 左右。这直接超出了我的计算器的范围，就是这里的这个。所以，通过第三次迭代，你已经远远超过了大多数事情所需的精度。是的，问题。学生：教授：x0 怎么消失了？学生：教授：所以，从这里到这里学生：教授：等等，伙计们，我们有一个问题。让我们回答它。

If you do 3, this number here turns out to be accurate to 10 ^ 10 or so. This goes right off to the edge of my calculator, this one here. So already, with the third iterate. you’re of way past the accuracy that you need for most things. Yep, question. STUDENT: PROFESSOR: How come the x0 disappears? STUDENT: PROFESSOR: So, from here to here STUDENT: PROFESSOR: Hang on, folks, we have a question. Let’s just answer it.

所以这里有一个 x0，这里有 1/2，有一个 x0^2 和一个 x，它们相互抵消。这里有一个减号，还有一个 5/2 x0。所以我把 1 1/2 合并起来，得到 + 1/2，就这样。好吗？好的，谢谢。下课后我们还要问其他问题。

So here we have an x0, and here we have 1/2, there’s an x0^2 and an x which cancel. And here we have a minus, and a 5/2 x0. So I combine the 1 1/2, I got + 1/2, that’s all. OK? Alright, thanks. We’ll have to ask other questions after class.

Lec 14 | MIT 18.01 单变量微积分，2007 年秋季

Lec 14 | MIT 18.01 Single Variable Calculus, Fall 2007

16 年前 (2009 年 4 月 15 日) — 49:42 https://youtube.com/watch?v=4Q37iOyBq44

16 years ago (Apr 15, 2009) — 49:42 https://youtube.com/watch?v=4Q37iOyBq44

以下内容根据 Creative Commons 许可提供。您的支持将帮助 MIT OpenCourseWare 继续免费提供高质量的教育资源。要捐款或查看数百门 MIT 课程的其他材料，请访问 MIT OpenCourseWare，网址为 ocw.mit.edu。教授：我们今天要讨论的内容是上一次的延续。我想回顾一下牛顿法，因为我想和你们谈谈它的准确性。

The following content is provided under a Creative Commons license. Your support will help MIT OpenCourseWare continue to offer high quality educational resources for free. To make a donation, or to view additional materials from hundreds of MIT courses, visit MIT OpenCourseWare at ocw.mit.edu. PROFESSOR: What we’re going to talk about today is a continuation of last time. I want to review Newton’s method because I want to talk to you about its accuracy.

如果你还记得的话，牛顿法的工作原理是这样的。如果你有一条曲线，你想知道它是否与轴相交。而你不知道这个点在哪里，这个点我在这里称之为 x，你要做的就是猜测。也许你在这里取一个点 x0。然后你往下到图上的这个点。然后画出切线。

So if you remember, the way Newton’s method works is this. If you have a curve and you want to know whether it crosses the axis. And you don’t know where this point is, this point which I’ll call x here, what you do is you take a guess. Maybe you take a point x0 here. And then you go down to this point on the graph. and you draw the tangent line.

我会用几种不同的颜色画出它们，这样你就能看出它们之间的区别。这是一条切线。它就是这样的。那条线会离我们的目标点更近一点。但现在的诀窍是，这很难看出来，因为尺度会迅速变小，如果你从那里开始向上走，然后重复同样的技巧。

I’ll draw these in a couple of different colors so that you can see the difference between them. So here’s a tangent line. It’s coming out like that. And that one is going to get a little closer to our target point. But now the trick is, and this is rather hard to see because the scale gets small incredibly fast, is that if you go right up from that, and you do this same trick over again.

也就是说，这是你的第二个猜测，x1，现在你画出第二条切线。这条切线会沿着这条线下来。它非常接近。你可以在黑板上看到，它实际上与 x 的点相同。所以这是下一个猜测。也就是 x2。现在我想分析一下它有多接近。并向你描述它的工作原理。所以让我也提醒你一下公式。

That is, this is your second guess, x1, and now you draw the second tangent line. Which is going to come down this way. That’s really close. You can see here on the chalkboard, it’s practically the same as the dot of x. So that’s the next guess. Which is x2. And I want to analyze, now, how close it gets. And just describe to you how it works. So let me just remind you of the formulas, too.

值得你记住它们。下一个公式是这样的。然后这个想法就是重复这个过程。它有一个花哨的名字，在算法中，如果你愿意的话，就是迭代。所以我们重复这个过程。这意味着，例如，我们用相同的公式从 x1 生成 x2。我们上次就是这样做的。

It’s worth having them in your head. So the formula for the next one is this. And then the idea is just to repeat this process. Which has a fancy name, which is in algorithms, which is to iterate, if you like. So we repeat the process. And that means, for example, we generate x2 from x1 by the same formula. And we did this last time.

更一般地，第 n + 1 个步骤是通过这个公式从第 n 个猜测中生成的。所以我想做的就是把一步的图画得更近一些。所以我想放大我上面的图片。那有点太高了。我的橡皮擦在哪里？必须把它画得比那低一点，因为我要把所有东西都画在这里的线以上。

And, more generally, the n + 1st is generated from the nth guess, by this formula here. So what I’d like to do is just draw the picture of one step a little bit more closely. So I want to blow up the picture, which is above me there. That’s a little too high. Where are my erasers? Got to get it a little lower than that, since I’m going to depict everything above the line here.

这是我的曲线。假设 x1 在此处，也就是它正上方的这个点。然后当我画出它时，这条绿色切线像这样向下。它稍微靠近一点，这是 x2 的位置，然后这里是 x，我们的目标，即曲线相交的地方，而不是直线切线相交的地方。这就是我希望你们记住的图。

So here’s my curve coming down. And suppose that x1 is here, so this is directly above it is this point here. And then as I drew it, this green tangent coming down like that. It’s a little bit closer, and this was the place, x2, and then here was x, our target, which is where the curve crosses as opposed to the straight tangent line crossing. So that’s the picture that I want you to keep in mind.

现在，我们要进行一种非常定性的误差分析。这就是我们的误差分析。首先，我们要测量 x1 和 x 之间的距离。换句话说，我们离目标有多近。我将其称为误差 1。这是 x x1。绝对值。然后，E2 将是 x x2，绝对值。等等。

And now, we’re just going to do a very qualitative kind of error analysis. So here’s our error analysis. And we’re starting out, the distance between x1 and x is what we want to measure. In other words, how close we are to where we’re heading. And so I’ve called that, I’m going to call that Error 1. That’s x x1. In absolute value. And then, E2 would be x x2, in absolute value. And so forth.

上次我估计这个的大小时，En 就是它的大小。上次，请记住，我们针对特定情况进行了估算。所以上次我实际上写下了这些数字。这些数字，也许你可以称它们为 En，即 5 xn 的平方根的绝对值。这些就是我上次写下的大小。

And, last time, when I was estimating the size of this, so En would be whatever it was. Last time, remember, we did it for a specific case. So last time, I actually wrote down the numbers. And they were these numbers, maybe you could call them En, which was the absolute value of square root of 5 xn. These are the sizes that I was writing down last time.

我只想谈谈一般情况下会发生什么。这种方法效果非常好，我想向你们展示这在一般情况下基本正确。所以，第一个距离，再次强调，是 E1，就是这里的这个距离。这是 E1。然后，这个较短的距离，这里，这一小段，我可能会用绿色标记，是 E2。那么，E1 比 E2 短多少？嗯，这个想法很简单。

And I just want to talk about in general what to expect. That worked amazingly well, and I want to show you that’s true pretty much in general. So the first distance, again, is E1, is this distance here. That’s the E1. And then this shorter distance, here, this little bit, which I’ll mark maybe in green, is E2. So how much shorter is E1 than E2? Well, the idea is pretty simple.

如果这个距离是垂直的，那么距离可能与垂直距离大致相同。这基本上是曲线与切线相切的情况。那么分离将是二次的。这基本上就是将要发生的事情。换句话说，距离 E2 将大约是距离 E1 的平方。这实际上是我想要指出的唯一特点。

It’s that if this distance in this vertical, distances are probably about the same as the perpendicular distance. And this is basically the situation of a curve touching a tangent line. Then the separation is going to be quadratic. And that’s basically what’s going to happen. So, in other words the distance E2 is going to be about the square of the distance E1. And that’s really the only feature of this that I want to point out.

因此，大致来说，这就是我们将要得到的情况。这意味着，也许从上次的经验来看，我们得到的情况大致如此。您有一个 E0，一个 E1，一个 E2，一个 E3，等等。也许我会在这里写下 E4。

So, approximately, this is the situation that we’re going to get. And so what that means is, and maybe thinking from last time, what we had was something roughly like this. You have an E0, you have an E1, you have an E2, you have an E3, and so forth. Maybe I’ll write down E4 here.

上次，这个数字大约是 10 ^ 1。因此，根据此规则，预期下一个误差是前一个误差的平方。所以是 10 ^ 2。下一个是前一个的平方。

And last time, this was about 10 ^ 1. So the expectation based on this rule is that the next error’s the square of the previous one. So that’s 10 ^ 2. The next one is the square of the previous one.

所以是 10 ^ 4。下一个是它的平方，即 10 ^ 8。这个是 10 ^ 16。所以这个数字列表令人印象深刻的是，你可以看到准确度的位数在每个阶段都会翻倍。准确度在每一步都会翻倍。准确度的位数在每一步都会翻倍。

So that’s 10 ^ 4. And the next one is the square of that, that’s 10 ^ 8. And this one is 10 ^ 16. So the thing that’s impressive about this list of numbers is you can see that the number of digits of accuracy doubles at each stage. Accuracy doubles at each step. The number of digits of accuracy doubles at each step.

因此，正如您在问题集上看到的那样，您很快就超出了计算器的精度范围。而且这个东西运行得非常好。所以，让我总结一下，牛顿法非常有效。我的意思是这种速率。我想稍微具体一点。如果真的有两个条件隐藏在里面，那么就会发生这种情况。一个是 f' 必须是，而不是。不能小。

So, very, very quickly you get past the accuracy of your calculator, as you saw on your problem set. And this thing works beautifully. So, let me just summarize by saying that Newton’s method works very well. By which I mean this kind of rate. And I want to be just slightly specific. If, there’s really two conditions disguised in this, that are going on. One is that f’ has to be, not to be. To be not small.

并且 f'' 不能太大。大致就是这样。我马上解释一下。x0 开始于附近。靠近目标值 x。这就是这里真正发生的事情。让我给你解释一下。所以我不打算解释这一点，只是说这个二阶导数之所以会涉及，是因为曲线有多弯曲，离目标值有多远。

And f’’ has to be not too big. That’s roughly speaking what’s going on. i’ll explain these in just a second. And x0 starts nearby. Nearby the target value x. So that’s really what’s going on here. So let me just illustrate to you. So I’m not going to explain this, except to say the reason why this second derivative gets involved is that it’s how curved the curve is, that how far away you get.

如果二阶导数为 0，那将是最好的情况。然后我们就能得到正确的结果。如果二阶导数不是太大，那就意味着二次部分不是太大。所以我们不会从绿线到曲线本身走得太远。另一件要说的是，正如我所说，x0 需要从附近开始。所以我会通过解释可能出错的地方来解释这一点。

If the second derivative were 0, that would be the best possible case. Then we would get it on the nose. If the second derivative is not too big, that means the quadratic part is not too big. So we don’t get away very far from the green line to the curve itself. The other thing to say is, as I said, that x0 needs to start nearby. So I’ll explain that by explaining what maybe could go wrong.

因此，该方法可能会失败，并且实际上会发生在我们上一个示例中的一个例子，即 y = x^2 5，假设我们从这里开始 x0。那么这个东西就会向左移动，我们得到的不是 5 的平方根，而是另一个根。所以如果它太远，那么我们就会得到错误的根。

So the ways the method can fail, and one example which actually would have happened in our example from last time, which was y = x^2 5, is suppose we’d started x0 over here. Then this thing would have gone off to the left, and we would have landed on not the square root of 5 but the other root. So if it’s too far away, then we get the wrong root.

这就是一个例子，解释了 x0 需要从我们讨论的根附近开始。否则，该方法不知道你要求哪个根。它只知道你从哪里开始。所以它可能会转到错误的地方。好吧，它无法读懂你的想法。是的，问题。学生：教授：哦，好问题。所以问题是，如果第一个错误大于 1，你会遇到麻烦吗？答案是，绝对是的。

So that’s an example, explaining that the x0 needs to start near the root that we’re talking about. Otherwise, the method doesn’t know which root you’re asking for. It only knows where you started. So it may go off to the wrong place. OK, it can’t read your mind. Yes, question. STUDENT: PROFESSOR: Oh, good question. So the question was, what if the first error is larger than 1. Are you in trouble? And the answer is, absolutely, yes.

如果你有二次行为，你可以看到。如果你附近有一个二次函数，它就非常接近直线。但远离它，抛物线离直线有几英里远。它离直线很远很远。所以如果你愚蠢到从这里开始，你可能会遇到一些困难。实际上，当我，那里的小摆动只是意味着成比例时，情况并非如此。

If you have quadratic behavior, you can see. If you have a quadratic nearby, it’s pretty close to the straight line. But far away, a parabola is miles from a straight line. It’s way, way, way far away. So if you’re foolish enough to start over here, you may have some trouble making progress. Actually, it isn’t when I, that little wiggle there just meant proportional to.

事实上，在抛物线这种特殊情况下，它会设法恢复。它会自我拯救。但这种事情并不能保证。你确实希望从相当接近的地方开始。是的。学生：教授：你必须要小心。也就是说，很难知道对 x0 做出什么假设。你把它插入机器，然后你会看到你得到了什么。它要么起作用，要么不起作用。

In fact, in the particular case of a parabola, it manages to get back. It saves itself. But there’s no guarantee of that sort of thing. You really do want to start reasonably close. Yep. STUDENT: PROFESSOR: What you have to do is you have to watch out. That is, it’s hard to know what assumptions to make about x0. You plug it into the machine and you see what you get. And either it works or it doesn’t.

你可以知道它正在向一个特定的地方行进，而且通常情况下，你可以知道那个地方可能是一个 0。但也许它不是你要找的那个。换句话说，你必须动动脑筋。你运行程序，然后看看它做了什么。如果你很幸运，问题是，如果你不知道 0 在哪里，你可能会一直徘徊。我们马上就会看到。

You can tell that it’s marching toward a specific place, and you can tell that place probably is a 0, usually. But maybe it’s not the one you were looking for. So in other words, you have to use your head. You run the program and then you see what it does. And if you’re lucky the problem is, if you have no idea where the 0 is, you may just wander around forever. As we’ll see in a second.

下一个例子如下。我说 f' 不能太小。这幅图里隐藏着一个真正的灾难。这是当你找到正根和负根之间的过渡。也就是说，如果你在这里。如果你愚蠢地得到 0，那么会发生什么？你的切线是水平的。它甚至不会与轴相交。

So the next example here is the following. I said that f’ has to be not too small. There’s a real catastrophe hiding just inside this picture. Which is the transition between when you find the positive root and when you find the negative root here. Which is, if you’re right down here. If you were foolish enough to get 0, then what’s going to happen is your tangent line is horizontal. It doesn’t even meet the axis.

因此，在公式中，您可以看到这是一场灾难。因为分母中有一个 f'。所以它是 0。它是未定义的。这并不奇怪，平行线不与轴相交是一致的。而且您没有 x1。所以，如果您愿意，这里的另一点是 f' = 0 是一场灾难。对于该方法来说，这是一场灾难。因为接下来，也就是说，如果 f (x0) = 0，那么 x1 是未定义的。

So in the formula, you can see that’s a catastrophe. Because there’s an f’ in the denominator. So that’s 0. That’s undefined. It’s not surprising, it’s consistent that the parallel line doesn’t meet the axis. And you have no x1. So you had, so if you like, another point here is that f’ = 0 is a disaster. A disaster for the method. Because the next, so say, if f (x0) = 0, then x1 is undefined.

最后，还有一件奇怪的事情可能发生。我先画一个示意图。你可以从摆动中得到它。这个摆动有三个根。我画的方式是这样的。

And finally, there’s one other weird thing that can happen. Which is, which I’ll just draw a picture of schematically. Which you can get from a wiggle. So this wiggle has three roots. The way I’ve drawn it.

你可以从 x0 开始。画一条切线，然后从这里到 x1。然后这条切线会带你回到 x0。我画得不太对，但差不多。所以它像这样。让我画两条切线，这样你就能看清楚了。抱歉，我搞砸了。

And it can be that you can start over here with your x0. And draw your tangent line and go over here to an x1. And then that tangent line will take you right back to the x0. I didn’t draw it quite right, but that’s about right. So it goes over like this. So let me draw the two tangent lines, so that you can see it properly. Sorry, I messed it up.

所以这里有两条切线。这条和那条。它只是来回移动。x0 循环到 x1，x1 又回到 x0。我们有一个循环。它永远不会去任何地方。也就是说，这边的草总是更绿。它在这里，它想，哦，我真的更愿意去这个 0，然后它想，哦，我想回去。

So here are the two tangent lines. This guy and this guy. And it just goes back and forth. x0 cycles to x1, and x1 goes back to x0. We have a cycle. And it never goes anywhere. This is, the grass is always greener. It’s over here, it thinks, oh, I really would prefer to go to this 0 and then it thinks oh, I want to go back.

就这样来来回回，反复推敲。篱笆那边的草总是更绿。永远没有结果。这些都是牛顿法可能出错的地方。不过，它还是很棒的。在很多情况下，它都很好用。它基本上可以用数字方式解出任何你能想到的方程。接下来我们继续。我们来讨论一些有点理论性的东西。

And it goes back and forth, and back and forth. Grass is always greener on the other side of the fence. Never, never gets anywhere. So those are the sorts of things that can go wrong with Newton’s method. Nevertheless, it’s fantastic. It works very well, in a lot of situations. And solves basically any equation that you can imagine, numerically. Next we’re going to move on. We’re going to move on to something which is a little theoretical.

这就是中值定理。这样我们就可以花一天左右的时间开始学习积分的概念，也就是整个课程的后半部分。让我们从这里开始吧。中值定理以后将缩写为 MVT。这样每次提到它时我就不用写那么多了。中值定理，通俗地说，就是以下内容。

Which is the mean value theorem. And that will allow us in just a day or so to launch into the ideas of integration, which is the whole second half of the course. So let’s get started with that. The mean value theorem will henceforth be abbreviated MVT. So I don’t have to write quite as much every time I refer to it. The mean values theorem, colloquially, says the following.

如果你从波士顿飞往洛杉矶，我想很多红袜队球迷很快就会想去那里，所以路程是 3,000 英里。6 小时内，在某个时间点，你会以某个速度行驶。这个速度的平均值。平均值，速度，在这个例子中是多少？所以我们以平均速度行驶。也就是 3,000 英里乘以 6 小时，也就是每小时 500 英里。没错。

If you go from Boston to LA, which I think a lot of Red Sox fans are going to want to do soon, so that’s 3,000 miles. In 6 hours, then at some time you are going at a certain speed. The average of this speed. Average, so speed, which in this case is what? So we’re going at the average speed. That’s 3,000 miles times 6 hours, so that’s 500 miles per hour. Exactly.

当然，在旅途中，有时你的速度会超过每小时 500 英里，有时速度会低于每小时 500 英里。有时你的速度一定正好是每小时 500 英里。这就是中值定理。之所以称之为中值定理，是因为“均值”这个词与“平均值”这个词相同。所以现在我要用数学符号来表达这个定理，这是一个公式。

So sometime on your journey, of course, some of the time you’re going more than 500 miles an hour, sometimes you are going less. And some time you must’ve been going 500 miles an hour exactly. That’s the mean value theorem. The reason why it’s called mean value theorem is that word mean is the same as the word average. So now I’m going to state it in math symbols, the same theorem. And it’s a formula.

它表示差商，也就是行进距离除以所用时间。这是平均速度，等于中间某个时间的无穷小速度。所以某个 c 介于 a 和 b 之间。我还没说完。这是一个真正的定理，它有假设。我先告诉你结论，但也有一些假设，它们是直截了当的假设。

It says that the difference quotient, so this is the distance traveled divided by the time elapsed. That’s the average speed, is equal to the infinitesimal speed for some time in between. So some c, which is in between a and b. I’m not quite done. It’s a real theorem, it has hypotheses. I’ve told you the conclusion first, but there are some hypotheses, they’re straightforward hypotheses.

假设 f 是可微的；也就是说，它在区间 a < x < b 内有一个导数。并且在 a < 或 = x，小于或等于 x 内是连续的。你必须能理解 f 在每个中间点的速度或变化率。为了使两端的值有意义，它必须是连续的。

Provided f is differentiable; that is, it has a derivative in the interval a < x < b. And continuous in a < or = x, less than or equal to. There has to be a sense that you can make out of the speed, or the rate of change of f at each intermediate point. And in order for the values at the ends to make sense, it has to be continuous.

两端的值和中间发生的事情之间必须存在联系。如果它是不连续的，那么左右值与函数的其余部分之间就没有关系。所以这是定理、结论和它的假设。它意味着我上面更通俗地说的话。现在，我要立即证明这个定理。

There has to be a link between the values at the ends and what’s going on in between. If it were discontinuous, there would be no relation between the left and right values and the rest of the function. So here’s the theorem, conclusion and its hypothesis. And it means what I said more colloquially up above. Now, I’m going to prove this theorem immediately.

至少，给出一个几何直观论证，它与非常系统的处理中给出的论证没有太大区别。这就是中值定理的证明。它实际上只是一幅图。所以这是图上的一个位置，这是另一个位置。假设该图是这样的。这条线是割线。所以这是 (a, f ( a ))。

At least, give a geometric intuitive argument, which is not very different from the one that’s given in a very systematic treatment. So here’s the proof of the mean value theorem. It’s really just a picture. So here’s a place, and here’s another place on the graph. And the graph is going along like this, let’s say. And this line here is the secant line. So this is (a, f ( a )) down here.

上面的这个是 (b, f ( b ))。这个线段是割线，它的斜率就是我们要找的斜率。这条线的斜率就是这个公式的左边。所以我们需要找到一个具有这个斜率的切线。我们需要找到一个具有这个斜率的切线，因为右边是切线的滑移。下面就是我们构造它的方法。

And this is (b, f ( b )) up there. And this segment is the secant, its slope is the slope that we’re aiming for. The slope of that line is the left hand side of this formula here. So we need to find something with that slope. And what we need to find is a tangent line with that slope, because what’s on the right hand side is the slip of a tangent line. So here’s how we construct it.

我们取一条平行线，就在这里。然后我们把它向上平移，让它保持平行，我们把它向上移动。朝着这个方向。直到它接触。在它接触的地方，在这个切点，在那里，我刚刚找到了我的 c 值。你可以看到，如果切线与这条线平行，那就是我们想要的方程。所以这个东西的斜率为 f' (c)。

We take a parallel line, down here. And then we just translate it up, leaving it parallel, we move it up. Towards this one. Until it touches. And where it touches, at this point of tangency, down there, I’ve just found my value of c. And you can see that if the tangent line is parallel to this line, that’s exactly the equation we want. So this thing has slope f’ (c).

另一个的斜率等于这个复杂的表达式，f ( b) f ( a ) / ( ba )。这几乎是证明的结束。还有一个问题。因此，我们再次向上移动一条平行线。将平行线向上移动直到它接触。这里有一点微妙之处，我只想强调一下。那就是虚线一直延伸到这里。但是当我们提起它时，我们将忽略 a 之外发生的事情。

And this other one has slope equal to this complicated expression, f ( b) f (a) / (b a). That is almost the end of the proof. There’s one problem. So, again, we move a parallel line up. Move up the parallel line until it touches. There’s a little subtlety here, which I just want to emphasize. Which is that dotted line keeps on going here. But when we bring it up, we’re going to ignore what’s happening outside of a.

并且超出 b 点，好吗？所以我们将忽略图形的其余部分。但有一件事可能会出错。因此，如果它不接触，那么图片看起来就像这样。这是相同的两个点。图形都在上面。我们提出了我们的东西。它就是这样。所以我们没有构造切线。如果发生这种情况。那么我们在这一点上就遇到麻烦了。

And beyond b, alright? So we’re just going to ignore the rest of the graph. But there is one thing that can go wrong. So if it does not touch, then the picture looks likes this. Here are the same two points. And the graph is all above. And we brought up our thing. And it went like that. So we didn’t construct a tangent line. If this happens. So we’re in trouble, in that point.

在这种情况下，抱歉。但有一个技巧，这是一个简单的技巧。然后从顶部向下拉切线。平行线，抱歉，不是切线。平行线。从上面。所以，这就是整个故事。这就是我们如何用正确的属性计算出这个点 c。我想再指出一个理论问题。然后剩下的，我们将得出结论。

In this situation, sorry. But there’s a trick, which is a straightforward trick. Then bring the tangent lines down from the top. So parallel lines, sorry, not tangent lines. Parallel lines. From above. So, that’s the whole story. That’s how we cook up this point c, with the right properties. I want to point out just one more theoretical thing. And then the rest, we’re going to be drawing conclusions.

因此，关于证明，还有一点理论上的评论，理解这一点非常重要。当你理解一个证明时，你应该总是思考为什么假设是必要的。我在哪里使用假设。我想给你举一个证明不起作用的例子，以向你展示假设是重要的。例子如下。

So there’s one more theoretical remark about the proof, which is something that is fairly important to understand. When you understand a proof, you should always be thinking about why the hypotheses are necessary. Where do I use the hypothesis. And I want to give you an example where the proof doesn’t work to show you that the hypothesis is an important one. So the example is the following.

我将取一个像这样的由两条直线组成的函数。如果你尝试用这些东西来执行这个技巧，那么它就会出现并触及这里。但问题是，这里没有定义切线。这里有很多切线，而这里没有导数。所以这里不存在导数。所以这就是一个坏点毁掉证明的说法。

I’ll just take a function which is two straight lines like this. And if you try to perform this trick with these things, then it’s going to come up and it’s going to touch here. But the problem is that the tangent line is not defined here. There are lots of tangents, and there’s no derivative at this point. So the derivative doesn’t exist here. So this is the claim that one bad point ruins the proof.

我们需要 f' 存在，因此 f' ( x ) 存在于介于两者之间的所有 x 处。即使只有一个缺陷点也不能逃脱。现在是时候得出一些结论了。主要结论将与图形应用有关。但我们明天以及本课程的其余部分将会看到，这更重要。这对微积分的所有其他部分都很重要。

We need f’ to exist at all so, f’ ( x ) to exist at all x in between. Can’t get away even with one defective point. Now it’s time to draw some consequences. And the main consequence is going to have to do with applications to graphing. But we’ll see tomorrow and for the rest of the course that this is even more significance. It’s significant to all the rest of Calculus.

我将列出三个你已经非常熟悉的推论。第一个推论是如果 f' 为正，则 f 增加。第二个推论是如果 f' 为负，则 f 减少。最后一个推论看起来最简单。但即使只有这一个推论也是一切的关键。如果 f' = 0，则 f 为常数。现在，这些就是中值定理的三个推论。

I’m going to list three consequences which you’re quite familiar with already. So, the first one is if f’ is positive, then f is increasing. And the second one is if f’ is negative, then f is decreasing. And the last one seems like the simplest. But even this one alone is the key to everything. If f’ = 0, then f is constant. These are three consequences, now, of the mean value theorem.

让我来告诉你们它们是如何被证明的。我刚刚告诉过你们它们是正确的，也许是前一段时间。当然，我提到了前两个。最后一个太简单了，我们可能只是把它扫到了地毯下。你确实在问题集上使用过它一次或两次。但事实证明，这实际上需要证明，我们现在就给出证明。

And let me show you how they’re proved. I just told you that they were true, maybe a while ago. And certainly I mentioned the first two. The last one was so simple that we maybe just swept it under the rug. You did use it on a problem set, once or twice. But it turns out that this actually requires proof, and we’re going to give the proof right now.

证明的方式很简单，就是写下来，重写星号。重写我们的公式。它表示 f (b) f (a) / (ba) = f' (c)。你看，我在这里从左到右写下来，表示导数的右侧信息将提供有关函数的信息。这就是我要读的方式。

The way that the proof goes is simply to write down, to rewrite star. Rewrite our formula. Which says that f (b) f (a) / (b a) = f’ (c). And you see I’ve written it from left to right here to say that the right hand side information about the derivative is going to be giving the information about the function. That’s the way I’m going to read it.

不过，为了表达这一点，我将在这里重写几次。所以这里是 f ( a )，乘以分母。现在我要用中值定理的另一种惯用形式来写它。即 f ( b ) = f ( a ) + f' (c) ( ba )。所以这是另一个版本。无论如何，我应该把这个放在盒子里。

In order to express this, though, I’m going to just rewrite it a couple of times here. So here’s f ( a ), multiplying through by the denominator. And now I’m going to write it in another customary form for the mean value theorem. Which is f ( b ) = f ( a ) + f’ (c) ( b a). So here’s another version. I should probably have put this one in the box to begin with anyway.

并且，只要代数变换一下，这就是这个事实。它们是同一个东西。现在有了以这种形式写出的公式，我声称我可以检查这三个事实。让我们从第一个开始。我将始终设置 a < b。这就是定理的设置。这意味着 ba 是正数。这意味着这里的这个因子是一个正数。

And, just changing it around algebraically, it’s this fact here. They’re the same thing. And now with the formula written in this form, I claim that I can check these three facts. Let’s start with the first one. I’m going to set things up always so that a < b. And that’s the setup of the theorem. And so that means that b a is positive. Which means that this factor over here is a positive number.

如果 f' 为正数（即第一种情况），这就是我们所做的假设，那么这就是一个正数。因此 f(b) > f(a)。这意味着它在增加。数值增加时，它也会增加。同样，如果 f' (c) 为负数，那么这就是一个正数乘以一个负数，结果为负数。f (b) < f(a)。因此，反之亦然。

If f’ is positive, which is what happens in the first case, that’s the assumption that we’re making, then this is a positive number. And so f( b ) > f( a ). Which means that it’s increasing. It goes up as the value goes up. Similarly, if f’ (c) is negative, then this is a positive times a negative number, this is negative. f ( b ) < f(a). So it goes the other way.

也许我会这样写。最后，如果 f' (c) = 0，则 f ( b ) = f(a)。如果你将它应用于所有可能的端点，这意味着如果你可以对每个间隔都这样做，但你不能，那么这意味着 f 是恒定的。它永远不会改变值。好吧，你可能已经相信这些事实了。

Maybe I’ll write this way. And finally, if f’ (c) = 0, then f ( b ) = f(a). Which if you apply it to all possible ends means if you can do it for every interval, which you can’t, then that means that f is constant. It never gets to change values. Well you might have believed these facts already.

但我只想向你们强调，这原来是无穷小、极限和这些实际差异之间的一个关键联系。之前，我们说差商近似等于导数。现在我们说它恰好等于导数。虽然我们不知道确切使用哪个点。它是介于两者之间的某个点。

But I just want to emphasize to you that this turns out to be the one key link between infinitesimals, between limits and these actual differences. Before, we were saying that the difference quotient was approximately equal to the derivative. Now we’re saying that it’s exactly equal to a derivative. Although we don’t know exactly which point to use. It’s some point in between.

我马上就要推论出其他一些后果，但让我先停下来，确保每个人都同意。特别是因为我已经完成了这里的黑板。在我们之前，每个人都满意吗？一个问题。学生：教授：我先重复一下你的问题。你说我有点困惑，什么保证了切点。这就是你说的。

I’m going to be deducing some other consequences in a second, but let me stop for second to make sure that everybody’s on board. Especially since I’ve finished the blackboards here. Before we, everybody happy? One question. STUDENT: PROFESSOR: I’m just going to repeat your question first. I’m a little bit confused, you said, about what guarantees that there’s a point of tangency. That’s what you said.

那么，你想详细说明一下吗，还是想就此打住？是什么让你感到困惑？学生：教授：是的。学生：教授：所以我并不是说只有一个点。这可能会摆动很多次，也许会触及十个地方。换句话说，如果它触及不止一次，我也没关系。那我就有更多，越多越好。

So do you want to elaborate, or do you want to want to stop with what you just send? What is it that confuses you? STUDENT: PROFESSOR: Yeah. STUDENT: PROFESSOR: So I’m not claiming that there’s only one point. This could wiggle a lot of times and it maybe touches at ten places. In other words, it’s OK with me if it touches more than once. Then I just have more, the more the merrier.

换句话说，我不希望一定只有一个。它可以像这样落下来。然后再次触摸。这就是你所担心的吗？所以在数学中，当我们声称这对于某个点是正确的时，我们并不一定意味着它对其他点不起作用。事实上，如果函数是常数，它就是 0，事实上这个等式对每个 c 都正确。这满足了你的问题吗？

In other words, I don’t want there necessarily only to be one. It could come down like this. And touch a second time. Is that what was concerning you? So in mathematics, when we claim that this is true for some point, we don’t necessarily mean that it doesn’t work for others. In fact, if the function is constant, this is 0 and in fact this equation is true for every c. That satisfies your question?

这个点存在的事实其实是一个棘手的问题。我只是用视觉说服了你。这是一个几何问题，无论你是否被允许这样做。事实上，这与切线的存在和我们在这堂课上做不到的更多分析有关。是的。另一个问题。学生：教授：对不起。学生：教授：问题是，这与线性近似有什么区别。

The fact that this point exists actually is a touchy point. I just convinced you of it visually. It’s a geometric issue, whether you’re allowed to do this. Indeed, it has to do with the existence of tangent lines and more analysis then we can do in this class. Yeah. Another question. STUDENT: PROFESSOR: Pardon me. STUDENT: PROFESSOR:. The question is, what’s the difference between this and the linear approximation.

我想，让我看看我能否描述一下。我会把定理留在黑板上。我要去掉定理的口语版本。我会试着向你们描述这与线性近似之间的区别。我打算过一会儿再做，但我们现在就做，因为这就是你要问的。没问题。情况是这样的。

And I think, let me see if I can describe that. I’ll leave the theorem on the board. I’m going to get rid of the colloquial version of the theorem. And I’ll try to describe to you the difference between this and the linear approximation. I was planning to do that in a while, but we’ll do it right now since that’s what you’re asking. That’s fine. So here’s the situation.

线性近似，我们将其与线性近似进行比较。它们非常密切相关。线性近似表示 f 的变化除以 x 的变化，即这个东西的左边，近似为 f' (a)。对于 b 接近 a，ba = delta x。这个语句位于框中，就在那里，表示 f 的变化实际上等于某个值。而不是近似等于它。

The linear approximation, so let’s say comparison with linear approximation. They’re very closely related. The linear approximation says the change in f over the change in x, that’s the left hand side of this thing, is approximately f’ (a). For b near a, and b a = delta x. This statement, which is in the box, which is sitting right up there, is the statement that this change in f is actually equal to something. Not approximately equal to it.

它等于某个 c 的 f'。这里的问题是我们不知道具体是哪个 c。这是某个 c 的 f'。介于 a 和 b 之间。对，所以。这就是两者之间的差异。让我详细说明一下。如果你想了解 f ( b ) f ( a ) / (ba) 是什么，中值定理会告诉你它肯定等于这个 f' (c)。

It’s equal to f’ of some c. And the problem here is that we don’t know exactly which c. This is for some c. Between a and b. Right, so. That’s the difference between the two. And let me elaborate a little bit. If you’re trying to understand what f ( b ) f ( a ) / (b a) is, the mean value theorem is telling you for sure that it’s equal to this f’ (c).

所以这意味着它肯定小于或等于你能得到的最大值。这是在整个区间上。我将包括两端，因为当你取最大值时，它有时会在两端实现。同样，因为它是 f' (c)，它肯定大于这里同一区间的最小值。这就是你根据均值定理所能说的全部内容。

So that means it’s less than or equal to the largest possible value on the largest value you can get, for sure. And this is on the whole interval. And I’m going to include the ends, because when you take a max it’s sometimes achieved at the ends. And similarly, because it’s f’ (c), it’s definitely bigger than the min on this same interval here. This is all you can say based on the mean value theorem.

你们只知道这些。通俗地说，这意味着平均速度介于最大值和最小值之间。这并不奇怪。中值定理应该非常直观。它说的是平均速度介于最大速度和最小速度之间。当然，这是有道理的，这就是为什么，顺便说一句，在牛顿和莱布尼茨在世的时候，这一点并没有真正得到证明。但是，让我们把它写下来，这样你就可以读懂了。

All you know is this. And colloquially, what that means is that the average speed is between the maximum and the minimum. Not very surprising. The mean value theorem is supposed to be very intuitively obvious. It’s saying the average speed is trapped between the maximum speed and the minimum speed. For sure, that’s something, that’s why, incidentally this wasn’t really proved when Newton and Leibniz were around. But, let’s write this so that you can read it.

平均速度介于最大值和最小值之间。但没有人对此感到困惑，他们并不怀疑，因为这是非常自然的事情。现在，例如，如果我采取任何类型的线性近似；例如，e ^ x 大约等于 1 + x。那么我就是在猜测，现在，我还不想这么说。这还不足以向您解释清楚。我们所说的是，这是这里的平均值。

Average speed is between the max and the min. But nobody had any trouble, they didn’t disbelieve it because it’s a very natural thing. Now if, for example, I take any kind of linear approximation; say, for instance, e ^ x is approximately 1 + x. Then I’m making the guess, now, don’t want to say this yet. That’s not going to explain it to you well enough. What we’re saying, so this is the mean value here.

这就是均值定理所说的。这是线性近似。线性近似表示平均速度近似为初速度，或可能是终速度。因此，如果 a 是左端点，那么它就是初速度。如果它恰好是右端点，如果 x 的值在左边，那么它就是终速度。所以这些就是，所以你可以看到它近似于右。

This is what the mean value theorem says. And here’s the linear approximation. The linear approximation is saying that the average speed is approximately the initial speed, or possibly the final speed. So if a is the left endpoint, then it’s the initial speed. If it happens to be the right endpoint, if the value of x is to the left then it’s the final speed. So those are the so you can see it’s approximately right.

因为在短间隔时，速度不应该变化太大。最大值和最小值应该非常接近。这就是为什么线性近似是合理的。这绝对告诉你，它不小于最小值，也不大于最大值。是的。学生：教授：。小扭结？学生：教授：如果你从顶部接近。如果它仍然低于这里，我可以再给你看一遍。

Because the speed, when you’re on a short interval, shouldn’t be varying very much. The max and the min should be pretty close together. So that’s why the linear approximation is reasonable. And this is telling you absolutely, it’s no less than the min and no more than the max. Yeah. STUDENT: PROFESSOR:. The little kink? STUDENT: PROFESSOR: If you approach from the top. So if it’s still under here I can show you it again.

哦，是的，它还在那儿。很好。学生：教授：哦，上面有摆动的那个？是的，这个你不能。因为没有东西可以触摸，而且从底部失败，因为有这个坏点。从顶部，它可以工作。它当然可以双向工作。所以，举个例子。看看如果你是一台机器，你可能没有办法做到这一点。但如果你是一个人，你就能发现所有的地方。

Oh yeah, it’s still there. Good. STUDENT: PROFESSOR: Oh, the one with the wiggle on top? Yeah, this one you can’t. Because there’s nothing to touch and it also fails from the bottom because there’s this bad point. From the top, it could work. It can certainly work both ways. So, for example. See if you’re a machine, you maybe don’t have a way of doing this. But if you’re a human being you can spot all the places.

有很多地方斜率是正确的。而且完全没问题。所有的地方都有效。学生：教授：并不是说 c 是一样的。只是我们现在已经找到了一个、两个、三个、四个、五个 c，它们都有效。学生：教授：如果你被要求找到 ac，那么首先这是一个假问题。你的问题集中有一些问题要求你找到一个 c。 

There are a bunch of spots where the slope is right. And it’s perfectly OK. All of them work. STUDENT: PROFESSOR: It’s not that the c is the same. It’s just we’ve now found one, two, three, four, five c’s for which it works. STUDENT: PROFESSOR: If you’re asked to find a c, so first of all that’s kind of a phony question. There are some questions on your problem set which ask you to find a c. 

这实际上很难让你理解中值定理的陈述，但你不应该太关注这些问题。它们并不令人印象深刻。但是，当然，你必须找到所有的，如果它要求你找到一个，你就找到一个。如果你能找到更多，那很好。你可以选择你想要的任何一个。中值定理并不关心。

That actually is struggling to get you to understand what the statement of the mean value theorem is, but you should not pay a lot of attention to those questions. They’re not very impressive. But, of course, you would have to find all the if it asked you to find one, you find one. If you can find some more, fine. You can pick whichever one you want. Mean value theorem just doesn’t care.

中值定理并不关心这个问题，因为实际上，中值定理除了在现实生活中，除了在这里的情况之外，从未使用过。你永远无法确定它是哪个 c，所以你唯一能说的是，你的速度比最大速度慢，比最小速度快。抱歉，再说一遍？学生：教授：如果有人问你一个具体的 c，你就必须找到一个具体的 c。 

The mean value theorem doesn’t care because actually, the mean value theorem is never used except in real life, except in this context here. You can never nail down which c it is, so the only thing you can say is that you’re going slower than the maximum speed and faster than the minimum speed. Sorry, say that again? STUDENT: PROFESSOR: If you’re asked for a specific c, you have to find a specific c. 

而且它必须在这个范围内。在中间，它必须在这里。所以现在我想告诉你另一种应用，这实际上只是我在这里描述的结果。顺便说一句，我应该强调一下，这可能应该这样做。我想我们从来没有在这里使用过这种颜色。这种流行。这是粉红色。所以这个很好。所以既然我们要这样做。

And it has to be in the range. In between, it has to be in here. So now I want to tell you about another kind of application, which is really just a consequence of what I’ve described here. I should emphasize, by the way, this, probably, should be doing this. I guess we’ve never used this color here. This popular. This is pink. So this one is so good. So since we’re going to do this.

所以感叹号是暂时的，这是一个显而易见的事实。但这就是你要使用中值定理的方式，也是你理解中值定理的唯一方式。在你的考试中，或者在你的一生中。所以这就是它被使用的方式。当我们复习考试时，我会说得很清楚。

So the reason why the exclamation points are temporary, this is such an obvious fact. But this is the way that you’re going to want to use the mean value theorem, and this is the only way you need to understand the mean value theorem. On your test, or ever in your whole life. So this is the way it will be used. As I will make very clear when we review for the exam.

实际上，你甚至会忘记中值定理，而你记住的只是这三个性质。它们本身就是中值定理的结果。所以这些就是我现在想要说明的。在下一次讨论中，我将只讨论不等式。不等式是函数之间的关系。

In practice what happens is you even forget about the mean value theorem, and what you remember is these three properties here. Which are themselves consequences of the mean value theorem. So these are the ones that I want to illustrate now. In my next discussion here. I’m just going to talk about inequalities. inequalities are relationships between functions.

我将用上面的性质来证明其中几个，即具有正导数的函数的性质是递增的。这是一个例子。e ^ x > 1 + x，其中 x > 0。证明如下。我考虑，所以这是证明。我考虑函数 f ( x )，它是差值。e ^ x (1 + x)。

And I’m going to prove a couple of them using the properties over there, the properties that functions with positive derivatives are increasing. Here’s an example. e ^ x > 1 + x, where x > 0. The proof is the following. I consider, so here’s a proof. I consider the function f ( x ), which is the difference. e ^ x (1 + x).

我观察到它从 f ( 0 ) 开始，等于 e ^ 0 (1 + 0)，也就是 0。然后，它继续下去。f' (x) = e ^ x。如果我在这里微分，1 就会消失。我得到 1。这是函数的导数。这个函数，因为 e ^ x > 1，对于 x 正数，就是正数。随着 x 越来越大，这个增长率是正数。

I observe that it starts at f ( 0 ) equal to, well, that’s e ^ 0 (1 + 0), which is 0. And, it keeps on going. f’ (x) = e ^ x. If I differentiate here, the 1 goes away. I get 1. That’s the derivative of the function. And this function, because e ^ x > 1, for x positive is positive. As x gets bigger and bigger, this rate of increase is positive.

因此，三个点，也就是 f ( x ) 大于其起始位置。对于 x > 0。如果它在增加，那么具体来说，它从 0 开始增加。所以这是正确的。现在，我要做的就是读出这个不等式的意思。它说的是 e ^ x，只需代入 f ( x ) 即可，它就在这里。（ 1 + x）大于起始值，即 0。现在，我将负数放在另一边。所以这与 e^x > 1 + x 相同。这是一个典型的不等式。现在，我们将再次使用这个原则。哦，天哪，我删错了。我删的是陈述，而不是证明。好吧，隐藏证明。

And therefore, three dots, that’s therefore, f ( x ) is bigger than its starting place. For x > 0. If it’s increasing, then that’s, in particular, it’s increasing starting from 0. So this is true. Now, all I have to do is read what this inequality says. And what it says is that e ^ x, just plug in for f ( x ), which is right here. ( 1 + x) is greater than the starting value, which was 0. Now, I put the thing that’s negative on the other side. So that’s the same thing as e^x > 1 + x. That’s a typical inequality. And now, we’ll use this principle again. Oh gee, I erased the wrong thing. I erased the statement and not the proof. Well, hide the proof.

接下来我想向你证明的是 e ^ x > 1 + x + (x^2 / 2)。那么，我该怎么做呢？我引入一个函数 g (x)，它是 e^x 减去这个。现在，我要做和以前完全相同的事情。也就是说，我从 g ( 0 ) 开始。
