The first place here, after 0, is b/n. So here’s b/n, that’s an x value. And the f(x) value is the height there. And that’s just, I evaluate f(x), f(x) is x^2. And that’s (b/n)^2. And similarly, the next one is 2b/n. 

这里的数值是 (2b/n)^2。就是这个。这里的高度是 2b/n。这是第二个矩形。我再记一个。3b/n，这是第三个。高度是 (3b/n)^2。等等。好吧，我的下一个工作是把这些面积加起来。

And the value here is (2b/n)^2. That’s this. This height here is 2b/n. That’s the second rectangle. And I’ll write down one more. 3b/n, that’s the third one. And the height is (3b/n)^2. And so forth. Well, my next job is to add up these areas.

总面积

Total Area

我已经准备好了，找出了底和高。所以总面积，或者说这些矩形的面积之和，是。

And I’ve already prepared that by finding out what the base and the height is. So the total area, or the sum of the areas, let’s say, of these rectangles, is.

嗯，第一个是 (b/n) (b/n)^2。第二个是 2b/n，对不起，是 (b/n) (2b/n)^2。它一直延续下去。最后一个是 (b/n) (nb / n)^2。因此，弄清楚通用公式非常重要。这里我们有一个底边。这里我们有一个高度，这里我们有相同类型的底边，但我们有一个新的高度。等等。

Well, the first one is (b/n) (b/n)^2. The second one is 2b/n I’m sorry, is (b/n) (2b/n)^2. And it just keeps on going. And the last one is (b/n) (nb / n)^2. So it’s very important to figure out what the general formula is. And here we have a base. And here we have a height, and here we have the same kind of base, but we have a new height. And so forth.

规律是这里的系数是 1，然后是 2，然后是 3，一直到 n。矩形越来越高，最后一个是最大的。

And the pattern is that the coefficient here is 1, then 2, then 3, all the way up to n. The rectangles are getting taller and taller, and this one, the last one is the biggest.

限制

Limit

好的，这是一个非常复杂的小工具。我要做的第一件事就是简化它，然后我实际上要评估它。但实际上我不会准确评估它。我只是要评估极限。

OK, this is a very complicated gadget. and the first thing I want to do is simplify it and then I’m actually going to evaluate it. But actually I’m not going to evaluate it exactly. I’m just going to evaluate the limit.

事实证明，极限总是更容易。这里关于微积分的要点是这些矩形很难。但极限值很容易计算。所以我们要找的是简单的公式，而不是复杂的公式。好吧，我要做的第一件事就是分解出所有这些 b/n 因子。这里有 ab/n，还有 (b/n)^2，所以总而言之，我们有一个 (b/n)^3。作为一个共同的因子。

Turns out, limits are always easier. The point about calculus here is that these rectangles are hard. But the limiting value is an easy value. So what we’re heading for is the simple formula, as opposed to the complicated one. Alright, so the first thing I’m going to do is factor out all these b/n factors. There’s a b/n, here, and there’s a (b/n)^2, So all told, we have a (b/n)^3. As a common factor.

然后第一项是 1，第二项，也就是剩下的，是 2 2.2 2。然后第三项是 3^2，虽然我还没有写出来。在最后一项中，有一个额外的因子 n^2。在分子中。好，大家都明白了吗？现在，我想要做的是最终取 n 趋于无穷时的极限。难以理解的数量是这里的巨大数量。

And then the first term is 1, and the second term, what’s left over, is 22.22. And then the third term would be 3^2, although I haven’t written it. In the last term, there’s an extra factor of n^2. In the numerator. OK, is everybody with me here? Now, what I’d like to do is to eventually take the limit as n goes to infinity here. And the quantity that’s hard to understand is this massive quantity here.

我想做一点改动，但改动很小。非常小。我要写 1，只是为了看看这里有一个一般模式。我要把 1 写成 1^2。我们在这里输入 3，为什么不呢。现在我想使用一个技巧。

And there’s one change that I’d like to make, but it’s a very modest one. Extremely minuscule. Which is that I’m going to write 1, just to see that there’s a general pattern here. Going to write 1 as 1^2. And let’s put in the 3 here, why not. And now I want to use a trick.

几何技巧

Geometric Trick

这个技巧并不完全推荐，但是当我们讲完时我会更多地谈论它。

This trick is not completely recommended, but I will say a lot more about that when we get through to the end.

我想了解这个量有多大。所以我要用几何技巧来画出这个量的图。也就是说，我要建造一座金字塔。金字塔的底部将是 n 乘 n 块。想象一下我们在埃及建造一座金字塔。

I want to understand how big this quantity is. So I’m going to use a geometric trick to draw a picture of this quantity. Namely, I’m going to build a pyramid. And the base of the pyramid is going to be n by n blocks. So imagine we’re in Egypt and we’re building a pyramid.

下一层将是 n 1 x n 1。所以下一层是 n 1 x n 1。所以底部的块总数是 n 平方。这是最右边的项。但是下一个项，我没有写进去，但也许我应该写，倒数第二个项是这个。这是我放上的第二层。现在，如果您愿意的话，这是顶视图。

And the next layer is going to be n 1 by n 1. So this next layer in is n 1 by n 1. So the total number of blocks on the bottom is n squared. That’s this rightmost term here. But the next term, which I didn’t write in but maybe I should, the next to the last term was this one. And that’s the second layer that I’ve put on. Now, this is, if you like, the top view.

但也许我们也应该从侧面来思考。这是同一张图片，我们从 n 开始，在这里建立这一层。现在我们要在它上面放一层，它要短一点。所以第一层的长度是 n。第二层的长度是 n 1，然后在它上面我们有长度为 n 2 的东西，等等。

But perhaps we should also think in terms of a side view. So here’s the same picture, we’re starting at n and we build up this layer here. And now we’re going to put a layer on top of it, which is a little shorter. So the first layer is of length n. And the second layers is of length n 1, and then on top of that we have something of length n 2, and so forth.

我们要把它们堆起来。我们把它们堆起来。一直堆到顶部，也就是一块巨大的石块。这就是最后一个，1^2。所以我们要倒着算。所以我必须把整个东西都堆起来。然后我沿着这个阶梯状的图案一直堆到顶部的石块上。

And we’re going to pile them up. So we pile them up. All the way to the top, which is just one giant block of stone. And that’s this last one, 1^2. So we’re going backwards in the sum. And so I have to build this whole thing up. And I get all the way up in this staircase pattern to this top block, up there.

所以这里有一个技巧，你可以用它来估计它的大小，当 n 趋向无穷大时，它在极限下是足够的。这个技巧是，我可以想象楼梯下面的固体，就像这样。那是一座普通的金字塔，而不是楼梯金字塔。它在里面。这个在里面。所以，但它是一座普通的金字塔，而不是楼梯金字塔。

So here’s the trick that you can use to estimate the size of this, and it’s sufficient in the limit as n goes to infinity. The trick is that I can imagine the solid thing underneath the staircase, like this. That’s an ordinary pyramid, not a staircase pyramid. Which is inside. And this one is inside. And so, but it’s an ordinary pyramid as opposed to a staircase pyramid.

所以，我们知道了它的体积公式。因为我们知道圆锥的体积公式。这个东西的体积公式，也就是内部的体积，是 1/3 底乘以高。在这种情况下，底边就是这里。所以是 1/3，底边是 n 乘以 n，对吧？所以底边是 n^2。这就是底边。而高，它一直延伸到顶点。

And so, we know the formula for the volume of that. Because we know the formula for volumes of cones. And the formula for the volume of this guy, of the inside, is 1/3 base times height. And in that case, the base here. so that’s 1/3, and the base is n by n, right? So the base is n^2. That’s the base. And the height, it goes all the way to the top point.

所以高度是 n。我们在这里发现，这个总和大于 1/3 n^3。顺便说一下，现在我声称这条线的斜率为 2。所以每次你上升 1，你就会超过 1/2。这就是你到达顶部的原因。另一方面，我也可以通过在这里画一条平行线将它困在外面。

So the height is n. And what we’ve discovered here is that this whole sum is bigger than 1/3 n^3. Now, I claimed that this line, by the way has slope 2. So you go 1/2 over each time you go up 1. And that’s why you get to the top. On the other hand, I can trap it on the outside, too, by drawing a parallel line out here.

这边会再往下 1/2，另一边再往下 1/2。所以底面是这个大金字塔的 n+1 乘以 n+1。它会向上增加 1。所以在另一端，我们得到它小于 1/3 (n+1)^3。同样，(n+1)^2 乘以 n+1，同样，这是底面乘以高度。这个大金字塔的。是的，问题。学生：然后将其等同于体积。教授：。

And this will go down 1/2 more on this side and 1/2 more on the other side. So the base will be n+1 by n+1 of this bigger pyramid. And it’ll go up 1 higher. So on the other end, we get that this is less than 1/3 (n+1)^3. Again, (n+1)^2 times n+1, again, this is a base times a height. Of this bigger pyramid. Yes, question. STUDENT: and then equating it to volume. PROFESSOR:.

问题是，我似乎在把面积相加，然后将其等同于体积。但实际上，我是通过在这里进行这些诚实的递增来创建体积的。也就是说，底数是 n，但高度是 1。谢谢您指出这一点。这里每个小楼梯的高度都恰好是 1。所以我确实在那里粘了块。它们是方形块，我将它们排成一行。

The question is, it seems as if I’m adding up areas and equating it to volume. But I’m actually creating volumes by making these honest increments here. That is, the base is n but the height is 1. Thank you for pointing that out. Each one of these little staircases here has exactly height 1. So I’m honestly sticking blocks there. They’re sort of square blocks, and I’m lining them up.

如果你愿意的话，我正在考虑 n 乘 n 立方体。真正的立方体。高是 1。底是 n^2。好吧，所以我声称我把这个家伙困在了两个量之间。现在我准备取极限。如果你看看我们的目标是什么，我们想要一个像这样的表达式。我要这样做。这是我们拥有的庞大表达式。

And I’m thinking of n by n cubes, if you like. Honest cubes, there. And the height is 1. And the base is n^2. Alright, so I claim that I’ve trapped this guy in between two quantities here. And now I’m ready to take the limit. If you look at what our goal is, we want to have an expression like this. And I’m going to. This was the massive expression that we had.

实际上，我要用不同的方式写。我会把它写成 b^3 乘以 1^2 加 2^2 加，再加 n^2，除以 n^3。我要把所有的 n 加在一起。好的，所以正确的做法是除以我上面得到的。在这组不等式中除以 n^3。我得到的结果是 1/3 小于 1 加 2^2 加 3^2 加。

And actually, I’m going to write it differently. I’ll write it as b^3 times 1^2 plus 2^2 plus. plus n^2, divided by n^3. I’m going to combine all the n’s together. Alright, so the right thing to do is to divide what I had up there. Divide by n^3 in this set of inequalities there. And what I get here is 1/3 is less than 1 plus 2^2 plus 3^2 plus.

加上 n^2 除以 n^3 小于 1/3 (n+1)^3 / n^3。这就是 1/3 + (1 + 1/n)^3。现在，我说我们完成了。因为这是 1/3，而当 n 趋于无穷大时，这个量的极限很容易看出，当 n 趋于无穷大时，它趋于 0。所以它也趋于 1/3。所以这里的总和，也就是 x^2 下的总面积，我们有时可能会将其写为从 0 到 bx^2 dx 的积分，将等于，这就是我得到的 1/3。

Plus n^2 divided by n^3 is less than 1/3 (n+1)^3 / n^3. And that’s 1/3 + (1 + 1/n)^3. And now, I claim we’re done. Because this is 1/3, and the limit, as n goes to infinity, of this quantity here, is easily seen to be, this is, as n goes to infinity, this goes to 0. So this also goes to 1/3. And so our total here, so our total area, under x^2, which we sometimes might write the integral from 0 to b x^2 dx, is going to be equal to well, it’s this 1/3 that I’ve got.

但那里还有 ab^3。所以这里多了一个 b 的立方。所以是 1/3 b^3。这就是整个计算的结果。是的，问题。学生：教授：所以这是一个非常好的问题。

But then there was also a b^3 there. So there’s this extra b cubed here. So it’s 1/3 b^3. That’s the result from this whole computation. Yes, question. STUDENT: PROFESSOR: So that was a very good question.

恶意预谋

Malicious Aforethought

问题是，为什么我们在这一步省略了 b/n^3。答案的一部分是蓄意为之。换句话说，我们知道我们要去哪里。我们知道、我们理解这个数量。这都是一回事。

The question is, why did we leave the b/n^3 out, for this step. And a part of the answer is malice aforethought. In other words, we know what we’re heading for. We know, we understand, this quantity. It’s all one thing.

这个东西是一个总和，而且越来越大。它不是所谓的封闭形式。所以，我们不知道或不太理解的是这个量到底有多大。1^2 + 2^2，平方和。然而，这个东西很容易理解。所以我们把它分解出来。我们仔细分析我们还不知道的部分，它有多大。

This thing is a sum, which is growing larger and larger. It’s not what’s called a closed form. So, the thing that’s not known, or not well understood, is how big is this quantity here. 1^2 + 2^2, the sum of the squares. Whereas, this is something that’s quite easy to understand. So we factor it out. And we analyze carefully the piece which we don’t know yet, how big it is.

我们发现它与 n^3 非常相似。但它更类似于 1/3 n^3。它几乎与 1/3 n^3 完全相同。这是这里的额外部分。这就是发生的事情。然后我们匹配它。由于这个东西与 1/3 n^3 非常相似，我们取消了 n^3 并得到了结果。

And we discovered that it’s very, very similar to n^3. But it’s more similar to 1/3 n^3. It’s almost identical to 1/3 n^3. This extra piece here. So that’s what’s going on. And then we match that. Since this thing is very similar to 1/3 n^3 we cancel the n^3’s and we have our result.

我只想说，虽然这看起来很奇怪，但事实上，如果你分析这类总和，你总是会这样做。你总是把你能分解的东西分解出来。然后你仍然会面临这样的总和。所以每次你面对这样的总和时，这种情况都会系统地发生。好的，现在我想再说一句关于符号的话。也就是说，这种符号在这里非常麻烦。

Let me just mention that although this may seem odd, in fact this is what you always do if you analyze these kinds of sum. You always factor out whatever you can. And then you still are faced with a sum like this. So this will happen systematically, every time you’re faced with such a sum. OK, now I want to say one more word about notation. Which is that this notation is an extreme nuisance here.

它确实太大了，我们无法处理。所以，数学家们对它有一个简写。不幸的是，当你真正进行计算时，你最终还是会得到这些东西的集合。但我想向你们展示这个求和符号，以便稍微压缩一下。求和符号的思想如下。所以这个东西趋向于。思想如下。

And it’s really sort of too large for us to deal with. And so, mathematicians have a shorthand for it. Unfortunately, when you actually do a computation, you’re going to end up with this collection of stuff anyway. But I want to just show you this summation notation in order to compress it a little bit. The idea of summation notation is the following. So this thing tends. The ideas are the following.

我先举个例子来说明。一般的表示法是 a_i 的总和，I = 1 到 n，等于 a_1 加 a_2 加点加 a_n。这就是缩写。这是大写的 sigma。例如，这里的这个量是 i^2 的总和，I = 1 到 n 的 1/n^3 倍。这就是这个东西的等价值。

I’ll illustrate it with an example first. So, the general notation is the sum of a_i, I = 1 to n, is a_1 plus a_2 plus dot plus a_n. So this is the abbreviation. And this is a capital sigma. And so, this quantity here, for instance, is 1/n^3 times the sum i^2, I = 1 to n. So that’s what this thing is equal to.

我们刚才展示的是，当 n 趋向于无穷大时，趋向于 1/3。这就是求和符号的使用方式。每个系数、这里的每个条目或被加数都有一个公式。这只是和的缩写。

And what we just showed is that tends to 1/3 as n goes to infinity. So this is the way the summation notation is used. There’s a formula for each of these coefficients, each of these entries here, or summands. And then this is just an abbreviation for what the sum is.

这就是我一开始就坚持使用 1^2 的原因，这样你就能看到这个模式一直到 I = 1 都有效。它不是规则的例外。它和所有其他的一样。现在，在这里，在这个板上，我们也有一个非常长的和。这个可以按以下方式写出来。

And this is the reason why I stuck in that 1^2 at the beginning, so that you could see that the pattern worked all the way down to I = 1. It isn’t an exception to the rule. It’s the same as all of the others. Now, over here, in this board, we also had one of these extremely long sums. And this one can be written in the following way.

我希望你们同意，这很难理解。但有一种写法是，它是从 I = 1 到 n 的总和，现在我必须写下通项的公式。即 b/n (ib/n)^2。所以这是一种将这个庞大的公式简化为一个更短的公式的方法。

And I hope you agree, this is rather hard to scan. But one way of writing it is, it’s the sum from I = 1 to n of now I have to write down the formula for the general term. Which is b/n (ib/n)^2. So that’s a way of abbreviating this massive formula into one which is just a lot shorter.

现在，我用它执行的操作，即分解出 (b/n)^3，我完全可以在这里执行。这是分配律。如果我分解出 b^3 / n^3，剩下的就是 i^2 的和，I = 1 到 n，对吗？所以这些符号使它更紧凑一些。我们正在处理的。概念现象仍然相同。

And now, the manipulation that I performed with it, which is to factor out this (b/n)^3, is something that I’m perfectly well allowed to do also over here. This is the distributive law. This, if I factor out b^3 / n^3, I’m left with the sum, I = 1 to n, of i^2, right? So these notations make it a little bit more compact. What we’re dealing with. The conceptual phenomenon is still the same.

而混乱仍然隐藏在地毯下。但符号至少可以用更少的符号表示。所以让我们继续。我给了你一个计算。现在我想把它融入一个模式。这是我想要计算的东西。所以，首先让我们尝试一下这个案例。我将再举两个例子。我将再举两个例子，但它们会容易得多。

And the mess is really still just hiding under the rug. But the notation is. at least fits with fewer symbols, anyway. So let’s continue here. I’ve given you one calculation. And now I want to fit it into a pattern. And here’s the thing that I’d like to calculate. So, first of all let’s try the case. S I’m going to do two more examples. I’ll do two more examples, but they’re going to be much, much easier.

从现在开始，事情会变得容易得多。第二个例子是函数 f(x) = x。如果我画出这个函数，那就是这个函数，它是斜率为 1 的直线。这是 b。所以这个面积等于底边为 b、高为 b 的三角形的面积。所以面积等于 1/2 b * b，所以这是底边。

And then things are going to get much easier from now on. So, the second example is going to be the function f(x) = x. If I draw that, that’s this function here, that’s the line with slope 1. And here’s b. And so this area here is the same as the area of the triangle with base b and height b. So the area is equal to 1/2 b * b, so this is the base.

这是高度。我们还知道如何求三角形的面积。所以，公式是 1/2 b^2。第三个例子。顺便说一句，请注意，我不需要做这个复杂的求和，因为我们恰好知道这个面积。第三个例子会更简单。f(x) = 1。这是迄今为止最重要的例子。值得注意的是，当你学到 18.02 多元微积分时，你会忘记这个计算。

And this is the height. We also know how to find the area of triangles. And so, the formula is 1/2 b^2. And the third example. Notice, by the way, I didn’t have to do this elaborate summing to do that, because we happen to know this area. The third example is going to be even easier. f(x) = 1. By far the most important example. Remarkably, when you get to 18.02, multivariable calculus, you will forget this calculation.

不知怎么的。我不知道为什么，但每个人都会这样。所以，函数是水平的，就像这样。对吧？它是常数 1。如果我们在 b 处停止，那么我们感兴趣的区域就是从 0 到 b。我们知道这是高度 1，所以这个面积是底面，是 b 乘以 1。所以它是 b。现在让我们看看这个模式。

Somehow. And I don’t know why, but it happens to everybody. So, the function is just horizontal, like this. Right? It’s the constant 1. And if we stop it at b, then the area we’re interested in is just this, from 0 to b. And we know that this is height 1, so this is area is base, which is b, times 1. So it’s b. Let’s look now at the pattern.

我们将研究函数的模式，它是曲线下的面积，也就是这个。有这个复杂的公式。所以这只是曲线下的面积。介于 0 和 b 之间。我们有 x^2，结果是 b^3 / 3。我们有 x，结果是。好吧，让我再写一点，给自己留点空间。

We’re going to look at the pattern of the function, and it’s the area under the curve, which is this. has this elaborate formula in terms of. so this is just the area under the curve. Between 0 and b. And we have x^2, which turned out to be b^3 / 3. And we have x, which turned out to be. well, let me write them over just a bit more to give myself some room.

X，结果是 b^2 / 2。然后我们有 1，结果是 b。所以我认为这是有启发性的。如果你能找出规律，一种让它更清楚的方法是看到 x 是 x^1。而 1 是 x^0。所以情况是这样的，0、1 和 2。而 b 是 b^1 / 1。所以，如果你想猜测当 f(x) 是 x^3 时会发生什么，那么如果它是 0，你做 b^1 / 1；如果它是 1，你做 b^2 / 2；如果它是 2，你做 b^3 / 3。所以可以合理地猜测这应该是 b^4 / 4。我想说这是一个合理的猜测。

X, which turns out to be b^2 / 2. And then we have 1, which turned out to be b. So this, I claim, is suggestive. If you can figure out the pattern, one way of making it a little clearer is to see that x is x^1. And 1 is x^0. So this is the case, 0,1 and 2. And b is b^1 / 1. So, if you want to guess what happens when f(x) is x^3, well if it’s 0, you do b^1 / 1; if it’s 1, you do b^2 / 2; if it’s 2, you do b^3 / 3. So it’s reasonable to guess that this should be b^4 / 4. That’s a reasonable guess, I would say.

现在，奇怪的是，在历史上，阿基米德计算出了抛物线下的面积。那是很久以前的事情了。那是在金字塔之后。他使用的方法实际上比我刚才描述的要复杂得多。他的方法非常神奇，非常出色，可能使数学倒退了 2000 年。因为当时人们太难了，以至于他们看不出这种模式。

Now, the strange thing is that in history, Archimedes figured out the area under a parabola. So that was a long time ago. It was after the pyramids. And he used, actually, a much more complicated method than I just described here. And his method, which is just fantastically amazing, was so brilliant that it may have set back mathematics by 2,000 years. Because people were so. it was so difficult that people couldn’t see this pattern.

他们没有意识到，其实这类计算很简单。所以他们无法计算立方。即使他们计算了立方，他们仍然在为其他事情而苦苦挣扎。直到微积分把所有东西都拼凑起来，人们才能够在计算这些面积方面取得重大进展。尽管他是当时计算面积和体积的专家。

And couldn’t see that, actually, these kinds of calculations are easy. So they couldn’t get to the cubic. And even when they got to the cubic, they were struggling with everything else. And it wasn’t until calculus fit everything together that people were able to make serious progress on calculating these areas. Even though he was the expert on calculating areas and volumes, for his time.

所以，我们现在有了简单的方法来做这件事，这真的是一件很棒的事情。我想告诉你们的主要事情是，我们不必费力地建造金字塔来计算所有这些量。我们将有一种更快的方式来做到这一点。这是缓慢而费力的方法。我们将能够如此轻松地做到这一点，以至于它会像你区分一样快。

So this is really a great thing that we now can have easy methods of doing it. And the main thing that I want to tell you is that’s we will not have to labor to build pyramids to calculate all of these quantities. We will have a way faster way of doing it. This is the slow, laborious way. And we will be able to do it so easily that it will happen as fast as you differentiate.

所以明天就要开始了。但我想让你们知道，事情会是这样的。不过，在开始之前，我们还要经历一点痛苦。我在这里再告诉你们一个符号。所以你们需要一点练习才能知道我们能节省多少钱。但你们再也不必面对像这样复杂的几何论证了。

So that’s coming up tomorrow. But I want you to know that it’s going to be. However, we’re going to go through just a little pain before we do it. And I’ll just tell you one more piece of notation here. So you need to have a little practice just to recognize how much savings we’re going to make. But never again will you have to face elaborate geometric arguments like this.

符号

Notation

让我添加一些定积分的符号。这就是黎曼和。以 19 世纪一位数学家的名字命名。

So let me just add a little bit of notation for definite integrals. And this goes under the name of Riemann sums. Named after a mathematician from the 1800s.

一般程序

General Procedure

这就是定积分的一般程序。我们把它分成几部分。我们怎么做呢？嗯，这是 a，这是 b。我们要做的就是把它分成小部分。

So this is the general procedure for definite integrals. We divide it up into pieces. And how do we do that? Well, so here’s our a and here’s our b. And what we’re going to do is break it up into little pieces.

我们将为增量命名。我们将其称为 delta x。因此，我们将其分成这些部分。那么有多少部分呢？如果有 n 个部分，那么通用公式始终是 delta x 是总长度的 1/n 倍。因此它必须是 (ba) / n。我们将始终使用这些相等的增量，尽管您不一定必须这样做。对于这些黎曼和，我们将这样做。

And we’re going to give a name to the increment. And we’re going to call that delta x. So we divide up into these. So how many pieces are there? If there are n pieces, then the general formula is always the delta x is 1/n times the total length. So it has to be (b a) / n. We will always use these equal increments, although you don’t absolutely have to do it. We will, for these Riemann sums.

现在我们只允许自己有一点灵活性。就是这个。我们将在区间内，在每个区间内选择任意高度 f。这意味着，让我在这里的图片上向你展示一下。我只需在区间内选择任意值，我将其称为 c_i，它就在那里。然后我到这里。我有级别，即 f(c_i)。

And now there’s only one bit of flexibility that we will allow ourselves. Which is this. We’re going to pick any height of f between. in the interval, in each interval. So what that means is, let me just show it to you on the picture here. Is, I just pick any value in between, I’ll call it c_i, which is in there. And then I go up here. And I have the level, which is f(c_i).

这就是我选择的矩形。在这种情况下，我们总是选择右手边，结果发现它是最大的。但我也可以选择中间的某个水平。或者甚至是左手边。这意味着楼梯会低很多。

And that’s the rectangle that I choose. In the case that we did, we always chose the right hand, which turned out to be the largest one. But I could’ve chosen some level in between. Or even the left hand end. Which would have meant that the staircase would’ve been quite a bit lower.

黎曼和

Riemann Sum

因此，这些楼梯中的任何一个都可以完美运行。这意味着我们选择 f(c_i)，这是一个高度。

So any of these staircases will work perfectly well. So that means were picking f(c_i), and that’s a height.

现在我们把它们全部加起来。这是矩形面积的总和，因为这是高度。这是底边。这个符号应该非常能让人联想到莱布尼茨使用的符号。也就是说，在极限中，这变成了从 a 到 b 的 f(x) dx 的积分。注意 delta x 被 a dx 替换了。

And now we’re just going to add them all up. And this is the sum of the areas of the rectangles, because this is the height. And this is the base. This notation is supposed to be, now, very suggestive of the notation that Leibniz used. Which is that in the limit, this becomes an integral from a to b of f(x) dx. And notice that the delta x gets replaced by a dx.

这就是极限下发生的事情。当矩形变薄时。这就是 delta x 变为 0 时的情况。这些小玩意被称为黎曼和。这被称为黎曼和。我们已经算出了一个例子。这个非常复杂的家伙就是黎曼和的一个例子。所以这是一个符号。当我们最后做一些数值工作时，我们会给你一个机会来更多地适应它。

So this is what happens in the limit. As the rectangles get thin. So that’s as delta x goes to 0. And these gadgets are called Riemann sums. This is called a Riemann sum. And we already worked out an example. This very complicated guy was an example of a Riemann sum. So that’s a notation. And we’ll give you a chance to get used to it a little more when we do some numerical work at the end.

今天最后要讲的是，我答应过你们举一个不是面积的例子。我想向你们展示积分可以解释为累积和。积分就是累积和。所以这只是一个例子。事情是这样的。

Now, the last thing for today is, I promised you an example which was not an area example. I want to be able to show you that integrals can be interpreted as cumulative sums. Integrals as cumulative sums. So this is just an example. And, so here’s the way it goes.

财务示例

Financial Example

因此，我们将考虑一个函数 f，我们将考虑一个变量 t，即时间，以年为单位。

So we’re going to consider a function f, we’re going to consider a variable t, which is time. In years.

我们将考虑一个函数 f(t)，单位是美元/年。没错，这是一个金融示例。这里的单位是美元/年。这将是借款利率。

And we’ll consider a function f(t), which is in dollars per year. Right, this is a financial example here. That’s the unit here, dollars per year. And this is going to be a borrowing rate.

为什么使用 Units

Why Units

现在，我之所以想在这里加上单位，是为了向你们展示这个奇怪的 dx 是有原因的，我们把它附加在这些积分上。这个符号。

Now, the reason why I want to put units in here is to show you that there’s a good reason for this strange dx, which we append on these integrals. This notation.

它允许我们改变变量，允许它与单位保持一致。并允许我们开发有意义的公式，这些公式在各个方面都是一致的。因此，当我在这里设置这个建模问题时，我想强调一下单位。现在，假设你每天都在借钱。这意味着 delta t = 1/365。从各种用途的角度来看，这几乎是 1/无穷大。

It allows us to change variables, it allows this to be consistent with units. And allows us to develop meaningful formulas, which are consistent across the board. And so I want to emphasize the units in this when I set up this modeling problem here. Now, you’re borrowing money, let’s say, every day. So that means delta t = 1/365. That’s almost 1 / infinity, from the point of view of various purposes.

这就是你借的钱数额。每次借款都是这样。假设你借了钱，利率一年内会变化。我的意思是，有时你需要更多钱，有时你需要更少钱。当然任何生意都是这样。所以你现在有钱了。你借了钱，但利率在变化。那么你借了多少钱？

So this is how much you’re borrowing. In each time increment you’re borrowing. And let’s say that you borrow. your rate varies over the year. I mean, sometimes you need more money sometimes you need less. Certainly any business would be that way. And so here you are, you’ve got your money. And you’re borrowing but the rate is varying. And so how much did you borrow?

好吧，在第 45 天，也就是 t 为 45/365，您借入了以下金额。这是您的借款利率乘以这个数量。所以，每年美元数。如果您愿意的话，这就是。我想强调一下这里的比例。您每年有美元数。这是这个年数。所以结果是美元。这是最终金额。这是您实际借入的金额。

Well, in day 45, which corresponds to t is 45/365, you borrowed the following amount. Here was your borrowing rate times this quantity. So, dollars per year. And so this is, if you like. I want to emphasize the scaling that comes about here. You have dollars per year. And this is this number of years. So that comes out to be in dollars. This final amount. This is the amount that you actually borrow.

所以你借了这么多钱。现在，如果我想算一下你全年借了多少钱。这就是这个总数。I = 1 到 365 的 f，嗯，就是 (i / 365) delta t。我在这里就把它保留为 delta t。这是借入的总金额。这是一个有点混乱的总数。事实上，你的银行可能会跟踪它，他们知道如何做到这一点。

So you borrow this amount. And now, if I want to add up how much you get. you’ve borrowed in the entire year. That’s this sum. I = 1 to 365 of f of, well, it’s (i / 365) delta t. Which I’ll just leave as delta t here. This is total amount borrowed. This is kind of a messy sum. In fact, your bank probably will keep track of it and they know how to do that.

但是当我们用策略建模时，您知道，当然，交易策略，您实际上是某种金融工程师，您想巧妙地优化借款金额。以及您花费多少，以及您投资多少。这将非常非常类似于 f(t) dt 从 0 到 1 的积分。在 1/35 的尺度上，它可能就是。365，对于许多目的来说，它可能已经足够了。

But when we’re modeling things with strategies, you know, trading strategies, of course, you’re really some kind of financial engineer and you want to cleverly optimize how much you borrow. And how much you spend, and how much you invest. This is going to be very, very similar to the integral from 0 to 1 of f(t) dt. At the scale of 1/35, it’s probably. 365, it’s probably enough for many purposes.

但是现在，还有另一件事需要建模。同样重要。这就是你借了多少钱，还有你年底欠银行多少钱。年底你欠银行的金额，我将用一种奇特的方式来表示。可以说，利息是连续复利的。

Now, however, there’s another thing that you would want to model. Which is equally important. This is how much you borrowed, but there’s also how much you owe the back at the end of the year. And the amount that you owe the bank at the end of the year, I’m going to do it in a fancy way. It’s, the interest, we’ll say, is compounded continuously.

因此，如果您以 P 作为本金，那么在时间 t 之后，您欠款。因此，借入 P，在时间 t 之后，您欠款 P e^(rt)，其中 r 是您的利率。假设每年 0.05 美元。这就是利率的一个例子。因此，如果您想了解年底您实际欠款多少钱。

So the interest rate, if you start out with P as your principal, then after time t you owe. So borrow P, after time t, you owe P e^(rt), where r is your interest rate. Say .05 per year. That would be an example of an interest rate. And so, if you want to understand how much money you actually owe at the end of the year.

到年底，您所欠的金额就是您在这里借的这些金额。但是现在，到年底，您所欠的金额更多了。您欠的金额是今年剩余时间的 e^r 倍。因此，今年剩余的时间是 1 i / 365。或者说是 365 i 天。因此，这是 1 i / 365。您必须将这些数字相加，才能知道您欠了多少钱。

At the end of the year what you owe is, well, you borrowed these amounts here. But now you owe more at the end of the year. You owe e^r times the amount of time left in the year. So the amount of time left in the year is 1 i / 365. Or 365 i days left. So this is 1 i / 365. And this is what you have to add up, to see how much you owe.

这本质上是从 0 到 1 的积分。delta t 出来了。这里有 e^(r(1 t))，所以 t 代替了这个 I / 365，f(t) dt。所以当你开始计算并思考什么是正确的策略时，你会面临这种类型的积分。这只是一个例子。下次见。记得考虑下次要问的问题。

And that is essentially the integral from 0 to 1. The delta t comes out. And you have here e^(r(1 t)), so the t is replacing this I / 365, f(t) dt. And so when you start computing and thinking about what’s the right strategy, you’re faced with integrals of this type. So that’s just an example. And see you next time. Remember to think about questions that you’ll ask next time.

Lec 19 | MIT 18.01 单变量微积分，2007 年秋季

Lec 19 | MIT 18.01 Single Variable Calculus, Fall 2007

16 年前 (2009 年 8 月 13 日) — 48:15 https://youtube.com/watch?v=1RLctDS2hUQ

16 years ago (Aug 13, 2009) — 48:15 https://youtube.com/watch?v=1RLctDS2hUQ

以下内容根据 Creative Commons 许可提供。您的支持将帮助 MIT OpenCourseWare 继续免费提供高质量的教育资源。要捐款或查看数百门 MIT 课程的其他材料，请访问 MIT OpenCourseWare，网址为 ocw.mit.edu。教授：今天我们将继续讨论积分。我们要做的可能是整个课程中最重要的事情。它的名字很贴切。它被称为微积分基本定理。

The following content is provided under a Creative Commons license. Your support will help MIT OpenCourseWare continue to offer high quality educational resources for free. To make a donation, or to view additional materials from hundreds of MIT courses, visit MIT OpenCourseWare at ocw.mit.edu. PROFESSOR: Today we’re going to continue with integration. And we get to do the. probably the most important thing of this entire course. Which is appropriately named. It’s called the fundamental theorem of calculus.

我们将缩写为 FTC，有时我会在这里输入 1，因为它有两个版本。但这是您在这门课上使用最多的版本。微积分基本定理是这样说的。它说如果 F' = f，那么 F'(x) = f(x)，有一个大写的 F 和一个小写的 f，那么 f(x) 从 a 到 b 的积分等于 F(b) F(a)。就是这样。

And we’ll be abbreviating it FTC and occasionally I’ll put in a 1 here, because there will be two versions of it. But this is the one that you’ll be using the most in this class. The fundamental theorem of calculus says the following. It says that if F’ = f, so F’(x) = f(x), there’s a capital F and a little f, then the integral from a to b of f(x) is equal to F(b) F(a). That’s it.

这就是整个定理。你可能已经认出了它。之前，我们用 F 表示不定积分，也就是说，大写的 F 是 f(x) 的积分。我们这样写。这是不定积分。现在我们代入确定值。我们在积分符号的两种用法之间建立了联系。但是有了确定值，我们得到的是实数，而不是函数。或者一个直到常数的函数。

That’s the whole theorem. And you may recognize it. Before, we had the notation that F was the antiderivative, that is, capital F was the integral of f(x). We wrote it this way. This is this indefinite integral. And now we’re putting in definite values. And we have a connection between the two uses of the integral sign. But with the definite values, we get real numbers out instead of a function. Or a function up to a constant.

就是这样。这是公式。它通常也用另一种符号表示。所以我也想向你们介绍一下那个符号。这里有一个新的符号。你会发现它很方便。因为我们并不总是需要给所涉及的函数加上字母 f。所以它是一个缩写。现在会有很多 f，但无论如何。这是缩写。

So this is it. This is the formula. And it’s usually also written with another notation. So I want to introduce that notation to you as well. So there’s a new notation here. Which you’ll find very convenient. Because we don’t always have to give a letter f to the functions involved. So it’s an abbreviation. For right now there’ll be a lot of f’s, but anyway. So here’s the abbreviation.

每当我有一个函数在两个值之间的差异时，我也可以将其写成 F(x)，a 在下面，ab 在上面。这就是我们使用的符号。你也可以为了强调，这有时很重要，当问题中有多个变量时。指定变量为 x。所以这与 x = a 相同。

Whenever I have a difference between a function at two values, I also can write this as F(x) with an a down here and a b up there. So that’s the notation that we use. And you can also, for emphasis, and this sometimes turns out to be important, when there’s more than one variable floating around in the problem. To specify that the variable is x. So this is the same thing as x = a.

x = b。它表示你想插入的位置，你想插入什么。现在你用上面的值减去下面的值。所以 F(b) F(a)。这只是一个符号，当然，在这个符号中，定理可以用这组符号来写。同样好。我们举几个例子。第一个例子是我们上次费力做的。

And x = b. It indicates where you want to plug in, what you want to plug in. And now you take the top value minus the bottom value. So F(b) F(a). So this is just a notation, and in that notation, of course, the theorem can be written with this set of symbols here. Equally well. So let’s just give a couple of examples. The first example is the one that we did last time very laboriously.

如果你取函数 F(x)，它恰好是 x^3 / 3，那么如果你对它进行微分，你就会得到，嗯，因子 3 被抵消了。所以你得到 x^2，这就是导数。所以根据基本定理，这意味着根据基本定理，从 a 到 b 的积分 x^3 除以 x^2 dx，这就是这里的导数。

If you take the function F(x), which happens to be x^3 / 3, then if you differentiate it, you get, well, the factor of 3 cancels. So you get x^2, that’s the derivative. And so by the fundamental theorem, so this implies by the fundamental theorem, that the integral from say, a to b of x^3 over sorry, x^2 dx, that’s the derivative here.

这是我们要使用的函数，因为这里的 f(x) 等于这里的函数 F(b) F(a)，就是这里。这个函数在这里。所以这是 F(b) F(a)，等于 b^3 / 3 a^3 / 3。现在，在这个新的符号中，我们通常不会使用所有这些字母。我们只写以下内容。

This is the function we’re going to use as f(x) here is equal to this function here, F(b) F(a), that’s here. This function here. So that’s F(b) F(a), and that’s equal to b^3 / 3 a^3 / 3. Now, in this new notation, we usually don’t have all of these letters. All we write is the following.

我们写出从 a 到 b 的积分，我要计算从 0 到 b 的情况，因为这是我们上次实际计算的。所以我要在这里设置 a = 0。然后，我们上次遇到的问题就是这样。正如我所说，我们做起来非常费力。但现在你可以看到，我们可以在 10 秒内完成。

We write the integral from a to b, and I’m going to do the case 0 to b, because that was the one that we actually did last time. So I’m going to set a = 0 here. And then, the problem we were faced last time as this. And as I said we did it very laboriously. But now you can see that we can do it in ten seconds, let’s say.

嗯，这个的反导数是 x^3 / 3。我要在 0 和 b 处求它的值，然后减去。所以结果是 b^3 / 3 0^3 / 3。当然是 b^3 / 3。这就是结果，这就是答案。所以这比昨天快多了。我希望你会同意。我们可以省去那些复杂的计算。

Well, the antiderivative of this is x^3 / 3. I’m going to evaluate it at 0 and at b and subtract. So that’s going to be b^3 / 3 0^3 / 3. Which of course is b^3 / 3. And that’s the end, that’s the answer. So this is a lot faster than yesterday. I hope you’ll agree. And we can dispense with those elaborate computations.

虽然有一个概念上的原因，一个非常重要的原因，可以理解我们所经历的过程。因为最终你将使用积分和这些快速的方法来解决诸如找到金字塔体积之类的问题。换句话说，我们将逆转这个过程。所以我们需要理解两者之间的联系。我将再举几个例子。然后我们继续。

Although there’s a conceptual reason, a very important one, for understanding the procedure that we went through. Because eventually you’re going to be using integrals and these quick ways of doing things, to solve problems like finding the volumes of pyramids. In other words, we’re going to reverse the process. And so we need to understand the connection between the two. I’m going to give a couple more examples. And then we’ll go on.

因此，第二个例子很难用我们昨天描述的黎曼和法来解决。虽然这是可行的。它需要用到更高级的数学知识。这就是正弦曲线 sin x 的一个峰下的面积。我来画一张图。曲线是这样的，我们讨论的是这里的面积。它从 0 开始，到 pi。

So the second example would be one that would be quite difficult to do by this Riemann sum technique that we described yesterday. Although it is possible. It uses much higher mathematics to do it. And that is the area under one hump of the sine curve, sin x. Let me just draw a picture of that. The curve goes like this, and we’re talking about this area here. It starts out at 0, it goes to pi.

那是一个驼峰。所以答案是，它是 sin x dx 从 0 到 pi 的积分。所以我需要对它求反导数。那就是 cos x。它的导数是 sin x。在 0 和 pi 处求它的值。现在，让我们仔细地做一下。因为这是我看到很多算术错误的地方。尽管这是问题中比较容易的部分。

That’s one hump. And so the answer is, it’s the integral from 0 to pi of sin x dx. And so I need to take the antiderivative of that. And that’s cos x. That’s the thing whose derivative is sin x. Evaluating it at 0 and pi. Now, let’s do this one carefully. Because this is where I see a lot of arithmetic mistakes. Even though this is the easy part of the problem.

很难集中注意力并输入正确的数字。所以，让我们非常仔细地观察。我输入的是 π。也就是 cos π。这是第一项。然后我减去底部的值，也就是 cos 0。在我刚才所做的过程中，您已经有五次机会犯抄写错误或算术错误。我已经看到了所有这五次。

It’s hard to pay attention and plug in the right numbers. And so, let’s just pay very close attention. I’m plugging in pi. That’s cos pi. That’s the first term. And then I’m subtracting the value at the bottom, which is cos 0. There are already five opportunities for you to make a transcription error or an arithmetic mistake in what I just did. And I’ve seen all five of them.

下一个是（1）。如果你愿意的话，可以减去负 1。然后这是负数，这是另一个 1。所以总共是 2。就是这样。这就是面积。这个面积很难猜，这是面积 2。第三个例子可能有些多余，但我还是要说。我们可以对 x^100 取从 0 到 1 的积分。现在，任何幂都在我们的能力范围之内。

So the next one is that this is ( 1). Minus negative 1, if you like. And then this is minus, and here’s another 1. So altogether we have 2. So that’s it. That’s the area. This area, which is hard to guess, this is area 2. The third example is maybe superfluous but I’m going to say it anyway. We can take the integral, say, from 0 to 1, of x^100. Any power, now, is within our power.

让我们开始吧。所以这里我们有 x^101 / 101，在 0 和 1 处求值。这就是 1 / 101。就是这样。这就是基本定理。现在，正如我所说，这利用了我们已经学到的很多关于不定理的知识。现在，我想给你一个直观的解释。让我们试试看。我们稍后会讨论基本定理的证明。

So let’s do it. So here we have the antiderivative is x^101 / 101, evaluated at 0 and 1. And that is just 1 / 101. That’s that. So that’s the fundamental theorem. Now this, as I say, harnesses a lot of what we’ve already learned, all about antiderivatives. Now, I want to give you an intuitive interpretation. So let’s try that. We’ll talk about a proof of the fundamental theorem a little bit later.

其实没那么难。但如果​​你愿意的话，我们可以给出一个直观的理由或解释。基本定理。所以这个定理与面积无关，而是与时间和距离有关。所以我们认为 x(t) 是你在时间 t 的位置。然后 x'(t)，也就是 dx/dt，就是我们所知的速度。然后这个定理告诉我们的是以下内容。

It’s not actually that hard. But we’ll give an intuitive reason, interpretation, if you like. Of the fundamental theorem. So this is going to be one which is not related to area, but rather to time and distance. So we’ll consider x(t) is your position at time t. And then x’(t), which is dx/dt, is going to be what we know as your speed. And then what the theorem is telling us is the following.

它告诉我们从 a 到 b 的 v(t) dt 的积分，因此，读取关系等于 x (b) x(a)。所以这是速度的某种累积和。让我们先解释一下右边。这是行驶的距离。这也是你在里程表上读到的。对，从旅程的开始到结束。这就是你在里程表上读到的。

It’s telling us the integral from a to b of v(t) dt so, reading the relationship is equal to x (b) x(a). And so this is some kind of cumulative sum of your velocities. So let’s interpret the right hand side first. This is the distance traveled. And it’s also what you would read on your odometer. Right, from the beginning to the end of the trip. That’s what you would read on your odometer.

而这正是你在车速表上读到的。所以这就是解释。现在，我想进一步深入解释一下，将其与我们昨天得到的黎曼和联系起来。因为那些很难理解。我希望你们从几个不同的层面上深刻理解它们。因为这样你才能更好地理解积分。

Whereas this is what you would read on your speedometer. So this is the interpretation. Now, I want to just go one step further into this interpretation, to make the connection with the Riemann sums that we had yesterday. Because those are very complicated to understand. And I want you to understand them viscerally on several different levels. Because that’s how you’ll understand integration better.

我想想象的第一件事，我们现在来做一个思想实验，假设你非常执着。你开车从时间 a 到时间 b，从地点 Q 到地点 R，等等。你每秒都会检查你的车速表。好的，你在第 i 秒读到了你的车速表，并且读到你以这个速度行驶。现在，你在那一秒钟行驶了多远？

The first thing that I want to imagine, so we’re going to do a thought experiment now, which is that you are extremely obsessive. And you’re driving your car from time a to time b, place Q to place R, whatever. And you check your speedometer every second. OK, so you’ve read your speedometer in the i th second, and you’ve read that you’re going at this speed. Now, how far do you go in that second?

嗯，答案是你以这个速度乘以时间间隔，在这个例子中我们假设为 1 秒。好吗？这就是你走了多远。但这是时间间隔。这是在第 i 秒内行进的距离。第 i 秒行进的距离，就是你行进的总距离。现在，如果你走完全程会发生什么？

Well, the answer is you go this speed times the time interval, which in this case we’re imagining as 1 second. All right? So this is how far you went. But this is the time interval. And this is the distance traveled in that. second number i, in the i th second. The distance traveled in the i th second, that’s a total distance you traveled. Now, what happens if you go the whole distance?

好吧，你要行驶所有这些距离的总和。所以这是一个巨大的总和，其中 n 是一个荒谬的秒数。3600 秒或类似的数字。不管它是多少。这将与你在里程表上读到的非常相似。因为在那一秒钟里，你的速度变化不大。

Well, you travel the sum of all these distances. So it’s some massive sum, where n is some ridiculous number of seconds. 3600 seconds or something like that. Whatever it is. And that’s going to turn out to be very similar to what you would read on your odometer. Because during that second, you didn’t change velocity very much.

因此，您测得的某一时刻的速度近似值与整秒内的速度非常相似。它不会发生太大变化。因此，这是对您行驶距离的相当好的近似值。因此，总和是对整个积分的非常现实的近似值。它是这样表示的。根据基本定理，它就是您行驶的距离。因此，这是 x(b) x(a) 完全正确。另一个是近似值。

So the approximation that the speed at one time that you spotted it is very similar to the speed during the whole second. It doesn’t change that much. So this is a pretty good approximation to how far you traveled. And so the sum is a very realistic approximation to the entire integral. Which is denoted this way. Which, by the fundamental theorem, is exactly how far you traveled. So this is x(b) x(a) Exactly. The other one is approximate.

好的，这又称为黎曼和。好的，这就是基本定理的介绍。现在我需要做的是稍微扩展一下。我将按照以下方式扩展它。我将首先在这个例子上进行扩展。然后我们将更正式地进行扩展。所以这是我们去过某个地方的例子。但现在我只想在这里给你画一张额外的图。

OK, again this is called a Riemann sum. All right, so that’s the intro to the fundamental theorem. And now what I need to do is extend it just a bit. And the way I’m going to extend it is the following. I’m going to do it on this example first. And then we’ll do it more formally. So here’s this example where we went someplace. But now I just want to draw you an additional picture here.

想象一下，我从这里出发，走到那里，然后又回来。也许我会来回一趟。我回到同一个地方。好吧，如果我回到同一个地方，那么位置从开始到结束都是不变的。换句话说，差异是 0。严格来说，是速度，而不是速率。

Imagine I start here and I go over to there and then I come back. And maybe even I do a round trip. I come back to the same place. Well, if I come back to the same place, then the position is unchanged from the beginning to the end. In other words, the difference is 0. And the velocity, technically rather than the speed.

向右的速度和向左的速度可能相同，但其中一个向正方向移动，另一个向负方向移动，它们相互抵消。所以如果你遇到这种情况，我们希望它能够得到反映。我们喜欢这种解释，我们希望即使在函数 v 为负的情况下也能保留它。

It’s the speed to the right and the speed to the left maybe are the same, but one of them is going in the positive direction and one of them is going in the negative direction, and they cancel each other. So if you have this kind of situation, we want that to be reflected. We like that interpretation and we want to preserve it even when. in the case when the function v is negative.

所以我现在要扩展我们的积分概念。所以我们将积分扩展到负数的情况。或者正数。换句话说，它可以是任何符号。实际上，没有变化。公式都是一样的。我们只是。如果这个 v 是正数，我们写一个正数。如果它是负数，我们写一个负数。我们就不管它了。还有实数。所以这里是。

And so I’m going to now extend our notion of integration. So we’ll extend integration to the case f negative. Or positive. In other words, it could be any sign. Actually, there’s no change. The formulas are all the same. We just. If this v is going to be positive, we write in a positive number. If it’s going to be negative, we write in a negative number. And we just leave it alone. And the real. So here’s.

让我举个例子来向你们展示它是如何工作的。我将在这块黑板上举这个例子。关于正弦函数。但我们将尝试两个峰。我们将尝试第一个峰和下面的那个峰。在那里。所以我们这里的例子是 sin x dx 从 0 到 2pi 的积分。

Let me carry out an example and show you how it works. I’ll carry out the example on this blackboard up here. Of the sine function. But we’re going to try two humps. We’re going to try the first hump and the one that goes underneath. There. So our example here is going to be the integral from 0 to 2pi of sin x dx.

现在，因为基本定理非常重要、非常有用且方便，所以我们假设它在这种情况下也是正确的。所以我们坚持认为这将是 cos x，在 0 和 2pi 处求值，并求差。现在，当我们执行该差分时，我们得到的是 cos 2pi ( cos 0)。也就是 1 ( 1)，也就是 0。对此的解释如下。

And now, because the fundamental theorem is so important, and so useful, and so convenient, we just assume that it be true in this case as well. So we insist that this is going to be cos x, evaluated at 0 and 2pi, with the difference. Now, when we carry out that difference, what we get here is cos 2pi ( cos 0). Which is 1 ( 1), which is 0. And the interpretation of this is the following.

这是我们的双峰，这是 pi，这是 2pi。而这一切的发生意味着，我们之前对曲线下面积的几何解释必须持怀疑态度。换句话说，当我说定积分是曲线下面积时，我骗了你。事实并非如此。

Here’s our double hump, here’s pi and here’s 2pi. And all that’s happening is that the geometric interpretation that we had before of the area under the curve has to be taken with a grain of salt. In other words, I lied to you before when I said that the definite integral was the area under the curve. It’s not.

定积分是当曲线在曲线上方时，曲线下方的面积，当曲线在曲线下方时，它计为负数。所以昨天，我的几何解释是不完整的。这真的是一个明显的谎言。所以定积分的真正几何解释是加上轴上方的面积，即 x 轴上方的面积，减去 x 轴下方的面积。如图所示。

The definite integral is the area under the curve when it’s above the curve, and it counts negatively when it’s below the curve. So yesterday, my geometric interpretation was incomplete. And really just a plain lie. So the true geometric interpretation of the definite integral is plus the area above the axis, above the x axis, minus the area below the x axis. As in the picture.

我只是用文字写下来，但你也应该形象地思考一下。这就是这里的设置。现在我们有了积分的完整定义。我需要为你列出它们的一系列属性以及我们如何处理积分。在我们继续之前还有什么问题吗？是的。学生：教授：对。所以问题是，速度函数的绝对值是否参与其中？答案是肯定的。

I’m just writing it down in words, but you should think of it visually also. So that’s the setup here. And now we have the complete definition of integrals. And I need to list for you a bunch of their properties and how we deal with integrals. So are there any questions before we go on? Yeah. STUDENT: PROFESSOR: Right. So the question was, wouldn’t the absolute value of the velocity function be involved? The answer is yes.

也就是说，这是你可以问的一个问题。你可以问的一个问题是总行进距离是多少。在这种情况下，你会像你说的那样，记录速度的绝对值，不管它是正数还是负数。然后你会得到这条曲线的总长度。然而，这不是定积分测量的。它测量的是净行进距离。所以这是另一回事。

That is, that’s one question that you could ask. One question you could ask is what’s the total distance traveled. And in that case, you would keep track of the absolute value of the velocity as you said, whether it’s positive or negative. And then you would get the total length of this curve here. That’s, however, not what the definite integral measures. It measures the net distance traveled. So it’s another thing.

换句话说，我们可以做到这一点。我们现在有工具可以同时完成这两件事。我们也可以。所以如果你愿意的话，总距离等于这个的积分。从 a 到 b。但净距离是没有绝对值符号的距离。所以这是正确的。还有其他问题吗？好的。现在，我们来谈谈积分的性质。我想向你们提到的积分性质是这些。

In other words, we can do that. We now have the tools to do both. We could also. So if you like, the total distance is equal to the integral of this. From a to b. But the net distance is the one without the absolute value signs. So that’s correct. Other questions? All right. So now, let’s talk about properties of integrals. So the properties of integrals that I want to mention to you are these.

第一个不需要过多评论。如果你取和的累积积分，你只是试图得到这里各个积分的总和。我不会对此多说。这是因为总和出来了，因为积分就是总和。顺便说一句，你知道这里的这个奇怪的符号，从历史上看，它实际上是有原因的。

The first one doesn’t bear too much comment. If you take the cumulative integral of a sum, you’re just trying to get the sum of the separate integrals here. And I won’t say much about that. That’s because sums come out, the because the integral is a sum. Incidentally, you know this strange symbol here, there’s actually a reason for it historically.

如果你回头看看旧书，你会发现它实际上看起来更像一个 S。这个大写字母 sigma 是一个总和。S 代表总和，因为当时每个人都懂拉丁文和希腊文。这个也是 S，但渐渐地它变得如此重要，他们把它做得更大。然后他们把它拉长，让它变细一点，因为它不适合一个排版空间。

If you go back to old books, you’ll see that it actually looks a little bit more like an S. This capital sigma is a sum. S for sum, because everybody in those days knew Latin and Greek. And this one is also an S, but gradually it was such an important S that they made a bigger. And then they stretched it out and made it a little thinner, because it didn’t fit into one typesetting space.

因此，出于排版原因，它被拉长了。变得有点瘦了。无论如何，它实际上是一个 S。事实上，在法语中，他们称它为 sum。尽管我们称它为integral。所以它是一个和。所以它与和是一致的。同样，我们可以从和中分解出常数。所以如果你有一个像这样的积分，常数就会被分解出来。

And so just for typesetting reasons it got stretched. And got a little bit skinny. Anyway, so it’s really an S. And in fact, in French they call it sum. Even though we call it integral. So it’s a sum. So it’s consistent with sums in this way. And similarly, similarly we can factor constants out of sums. So if you have an integral like this, the constant factors out.

但绝对不要试图从中得到一个函数。那是不可能的。好的，换句话说，c 必须是一个常数。不依赖于 x。第三个属性。我想把这里的第三个属性称为什么？是的，我这里有一个初步属性。如下所示。我会画一张图。我假设你沿着一条线有三个点。

But definitely don’t try to get a function out of this. That won’t happen. OK, in other words, c has to be a constant. Doesn’t depend on x. The third property. What do I want to call the third property here? I have sort of a preliminary property, yes, here. Which is the following. And I’ll draw a picture of it. I suppose you have three points along a line.

那么我要画一张图。我将使用曲线上方的解释，尽管这不是全部。所以这是 a，这是 b，这是 c。你可以看到，这部分的面积，也就是前两部分的面积，加在一起就是整体的面积。这就是我想告诉你的规则。

So then I’m going to draw a picture of that. And I’m going to use the interpretation above the curve, even though that’s not the whole thing. So here’s a, here’s b and here’s c. And you can see that the area of this piece, of the first two pieces here, when added together, gives you the area of the whole. And that’s the rule that I’d like to tell you.

因此，如果你从 a 到 b 积分，并将从 b 到 c 的积分添加到该积分中，你将得到从 a 到 c 的积分。这只是初步的，因为规则比这要好一点。但我稍后会解释。第四条规则非常简单。

So if you integrate from a to b, and you add to that the integral from b to c, you’ll get the integral from a to c. This is going to be just a little preliminary, because the rule is a little better than this. But I will explain that in a minute. The fourth rule is a very simple one.

也就是说，f(x) dx 从 a 到 a 的积分等于 0。现在，你可以非常明显地看到这一点，因为那里没有面积。那里没有水平运动。矩形无限薄，那里什么都没有。所以情况就是这样。你也可以将它解释为 F(a) F(a)。所以这也与我们的解释一致。就微积分基本定理而言。这种情况是完全合理的。

Which is that the integral from a to a of f(x) dx is equal to 0. Now, that you can see very obviously because there’s no area. No horizontal movement there. The rectangle is infinitely thin, and there’s nothing there. So this is the case. You can also interpret it a F(a) F(a). So that’s also consistent with our interpretation. In terms of the fundamental theorem of calculus. And it’s perfectly reasonable that this is the case.

现在，第五个属性是一个定义。它实际上不是一个属性。但它非常重要。f(x) dx 从 a 到 b 的积分等于 f(x) dx 从 b 到 a 的积分减去。现在，实际上，这里的右边到目前为止是一个未定义的量。我们从来没有说过你可以在 a 小于 b 的情况下做到这一点。因为这是反向操作。

Now, the fifth property is a definition. It’s not really a property. But it’s very important. The integral from a to b of f(x) dx equal to minus the integral from b to a, of f( x) dx. Now, really, the right hand side here is an undefined quantity so far. We never said you could ever do this where the a is less than the b. Because this is working backwards here.

但我们只是有一个惯例，那就是定义。每当我们写下这个数字时，它就等于减去那个数字。所有这些的原因再次是我们希望它们与微积分基本定理一致。这就是使所有这些工作正常的原因。所以如果你注意到左边是 F(b) F(a)，大写 F，小写 f 的反导数。 

But we just have a convention that’s the definition. Whenever we write down this number, it’s the same as minus what that number is. And the reason for all of these is again that we want them to be consistent with the fundamental theorem of calculus. Which is the thing that makes all of this work. So if you notice the left hand side here is F(b) F(a), capital F, the antiderivative of little f. 

另一方面，另一边是减号，如果我们忽略这一点，我们说这些是字母，如果我们是一台机器，我们不知道哪个比哪个大，我们只是把它们代入，我们会得到 F(a) F(b)，在这里。为了让这两个东西相等，我们需要把那个减号放进去。现在它是一致的。所以再说一次，这些规则的设置是为了让一切都保持一致。

On the other hand, the other side is minus, and if we just ignore that, we say these are letters, if we were a machine, we didn’t know which one was bigger than which, we just plugged them in, we would get here F(a) F(b), over here. And to make these two things equal, what we want is to put that minus sign in. Now it’s consistent. So again, these rules are set up so that everything is consistent.

现在我想改进规则 3。我要指出的是，让我先回到规则 3，现在我们可以不考虑顺序来计算积分，我们不必满足 a < b、b < c 才能理解这一点。实际上，我们可以考虑 a、b 和 c 的任意顺序的积分。

And now I want to improve on rule 3 here. And point out to you so let me just go back to rule 3 for a second that now that we can evaluate integrals regardless of the order, we don’t have to have a < b, b < c in order to make sense out of this. We actually have the possibility of considering integrals where the a’s and the b’s and the c’s are in any order you want.

事实上，有了这个定义，有了这个定义，无论数字是多少，5,3 都可以正常工作。所以这更方便。我们不需要，这不是必要的。没有必要。它只需使用约定 5 即可。好的，使用 5。再次强调，在我继续之前，让我强调一下：我们确实要尊重这个速度的符号。我们确实想要位置的净变化。我们不想要这里的绝对值。

And in fact, with this definition, with this definition 5,3 works no matter what the numbers are. So this is much more convenient. We don’t, this is not necessary. Not necessary. It just works using convention 5. OK, with 5. Again, before I go on, let me emphasize: we really want to respect the sign of this velocity. We really want the net change in the position. And we don’t want this absolute value here.

因为否则，我们所有的公式都会出错。我们无法始终进行检查。有时，这里显示的是字母而不是实际数字，您不知道 a 是否大于 b。因此，您需要知道这些公式在所有情况下都有效且一致。好的，我要再次交易这些。

Because otherwise, all of our formulas are going to mess up. We won’t always be able to check. Sometimes you have letters rather than actual numbers here, and you won’t know whether a is bigger than b. So you’ll want to know that these formulas work and are consistent in all situations. OK, I’m going to trade these again.

为了保持 1 到 5 的顺序。现在我要谈谈第六个属性。这个属性称为估计。它表示以下内容。如果 f(x) <= g(x)，则 f(x) dx 从 a 到 b 的积分小于或等于 g(x) dx 从 a 到 b 的积分。

In order to preserve the ordering 1 through 5. And now I have a sixth property that I want to talk about. This one is called estimation. And it says the following. If f(x) <= g(x), then the integral from a to b of f(x) dx is less than or equal to the integral from a to b of g(x) dx.

现在，这个公式表示，如果我走得比你慢，那么你走得比我远。好的。这就是它的全部含义。对于这个公式，你最好有一个 < b。你需要它。因为我们在翻转 a 和 b 的顺序时会翻转符号。所以这个公式，下限必须小于上限。但让我强调一下，因为我们正在处理这个公式的一般性问题。

Now, this one says that if I’m going more slowly than you, then you go farther than I do. OK. That’s all it’s saying. For this one, you’d better have a < b. You need it. Because we flip the signs when we flip the order of a and b. So this one, it’s essential that the lower limit be smaller than the upper limit. But let me just emphasize, because we’re dealing with the generalities of this.

实际上，如果其中一个是负数，另一个也是负数，那么它也会起作用。最终结果是，如果 f 比 g 更负，那么这个加起来的值就比那个更负。同样，假设 a 小于 b。所以正如我所写的，这是完全普遍的。让我们来说明这一点。然后我们还有一个属性要学习。

Actually if one of these is negative and the other one is negative, then it also works. This one ends up being, if f is more negative than g, then this added up thing is more negative than that one. Again, under the assumption that a is less than b. So as I wrote it’s in full generality. Let’s illustrate this one. And then we have one more property to learn after that.

让我给你举一个估算的例子。这个例子和我已经给你的例子一样。但这次，因为我们有积分工具，我们可以跟着感觉走，它就起作用了。我从不等式开始，所以我试图说明估算，所以我想从一个不等式开始，这就是这里的假设。我将对不等式进行积分以得出这个结论。

So let me give you an example of estimation. The example is the same as one that I already gave you. But this time, because we have the tool of integration, we can just follow our noses and it works. I start with the inequality, so I’m trying to illustrate estimation, so I want to start with an inequality which is what the hypothesis is here. And I’m going to integrate the inequality to get this conclusion.

看看结论是什么。我要取的不等式是，当 x >= 0 时，e^x >= 1。这就是我们的起点。现在我要对它进行积分。也就是说，我要使用估算来查看结果。好吧，我要对从 0 到 b 进行积分。

And see what conclusion it is. The inequality that I want to take is that e^x >= 1, for x >= 0. That’s going to be our starting place. And now I’m going to integrate it. That is, I’m going to use estimation to see what that gives. Well, I’m going to integrate, say, from 0 to b.

我无法在 0 以下积分，因为它只在 0 以上成立。这是 e^x dx 大于或等于从 0 到 b 的 1 dx 的积分。好吧，让我们算出它们各自是什么。第一个，e^x dx，是反导数是 e^x，在 0 和 b 处求值。所以这是 e^be^0。也就是 e^b 1。另一个，你应该能够通过矩形定律得到。

I can’t integrate below 0 because it’s only true above 0. This is e^x dx greater than or equal to the integral from 0 to b of 1 dx. Alright, let’s work out what each of these is. The first one, e^x dx, is, the antiderivative is e^x, evaluated at 0 and b. So that’s e^b e^0. Which is e^b 1. The other one, you’re supposed to be able to get by the rectangle law.

这是一个底边为 b、高为 1 的矩形。所以答案是 b。或者你也可以用不定积分来计算，但答案是 b。这意味着我们的不等式表明，如果我将这两个东西组合在一起，那么 e^b 1 >= b。这与 e^b >= 1 + b 是一样的。同样，这只适用于 b >= 0。注意，如果 b 为负数，这将是一个定义明确的量。

This is one rectangle of base b and height 1. So the answer is b. Or you can do it by antiderivatives, but it’s b. That means that our inequality says if I just combine these two things together, that e^b 1 >= b. And that’s the same thing as e^b >= 1 + b. Again, this only works for b >= 0. Notice that if b were negative, this would be a well defined quantity.

但这个估计是错误的。我们需要 b > 0 才能使它有意义。所以使用了它。这是一件好事，因为这个不等式是可疑的。实际上，当 b 为负时，它被证明是正确的。但我们当然没有证明它。我只会重复这个过程。所以让我们重复一下。从不等式开始，结论就在这里。

But this estimation would be false. We need that the b > 0 in order for this to make sense. So this was used. And that’s a good thing, because this inequality is suspect. Actually, it turns out to be true when b is negative. But we certainly didn’t prove it. I’m going to just repeat this process. So let’s repeat it. Starting from the inequality, the conclusion, which is sitting right here.

但是我会把它写成 e^x >= 1 + x 的形式，其中 x >= 0。现在，如果我对这个进行积分，我会得到从 0 到 b 的积分，e^x dx 大于或等于从 0 到 b 的积分，(1 + x) dx，我提醒你，我们已经计算过这个了。这是 e^b 1。另一个并不难计算。

But I’ll write it in a form e^x >= 1 + x, for x >= 0. And now, if I integrate this one, I get the integral from 0 to b, e^x dx is greater than or equal to the integral from 0 to b, (1 + x) dx, and I remind you that we’ve already calculated this one. This is e^b 1. And the other one is not hard to calculate.

不定积分是 x + x^2 / 2。我们在 0 和 b 处对其进行求值。因此结果是 b + b^2 / 2。所以我们的结论是左边，即 e^b 1 >= b + b^2 / 2。这是针对 b >= 0 的情况。这与 e^b >= 1 + b + b^2 / 2 是一样的。对于 b 负数，这个结论实际上是假的，因此你必须小心这里的 b 正数。

The antiderivative is x + x^2 / 2. We’re evaluating that at 0 and b. So that comes out to be b + b^2 / 2. And so our conclusion is that the left side, which is e^b 1 >= b + b^2 / 2. And this is for b >= 0. And that’s the same thing as e^b >= 1 + b + b^2 / 2. This one actually is false for b negative, so that’s something that you have to be careful with the b positive’s here.

所以你可以继续这样做，你不必思考。你会得到一个非常有趣的多项式，它很好地近似于 e^b。这就是基本属性。现在我需要告诉你一个棘手的属性。它不是那么棘手，但有点棘手。这就是变量变换。积分中的变量变换，我们实际上已经做过了。

So you can keep on going with this, and you didn’t have to think. And you’ll produce a very interesting polynomial, which is a good approximation to e^b. So that’s it for the basic properties. Now there’s one tricky property that I need to tell you about. It’s not that tricky, but it’s a little tricky. And this is change of variables. Change of variables in integration, we’ve actually already done.

我们上次讨论时称之为代换。如果你还记得的话，这里的想法是，如果你面对这样的积分，你可以将其改为，如果你代入 u = u(x)，你得到一个 du，它等于 u'(x) du. dx，对不起。那么你可以按如下方式更改积分。这与 g(u(x)) u'(x) dx 相同。

We called that, the last time we talked about it, we called it substitution. And the idea here, if you may remember, was that if you’re faced with an integral like this, you can change it to, if you put in u = u(x) and you have a du, which is equal to u’(x) du. dx, sorry. Then you can change the integral as follows. This is the same as g(u(x)) u’(x) dx.

这是代换的一般程序。今天的新内容是，我们要代入极限。如果这里有一个极限，u_1，还有一个极限，u_2，你想知道这里的极限和将变量更改为新变量时的极限之间的关系。这是最简单的事情。也就是说，这里的两个极限与 u(x) 与此处的符号 u 的关系相同。

This was the general procedure for substitution. What’s new today is that we’re going to put in the limits. If you have a limit here, u_1, and a limit here, u_2, you want to know what the relationship is between the limits here and the limits when you change variables to the new variables. And it’s the simplest possible thing. Namely the two limits over here are in the same relationship as u(x) is to this symbol u here.

换句话说，u_1 = u(x_1)，u_2 = u(x_2)。这样就行得通了。现在这里只有一个危险，有一个微妙之处，那就是，只有当 u' 不改变符号时，这才有效。我一直有点担心来回走动，我允许自己反转并做各种各样的事情，对吧，用这些积分。所以我们可以自由地去做。

In other words, u_1 = u(x_1), and u_2 = u(x_2). That’s what works. Now there’s only one danger here, there’s one subtlety which is, this only works if u’ does not change sign. I’ve been worrying a little bit about going backwards and forwards, and I allowed myself to reverse and do all kinds of stuff, right, with these integrals. So we’re sort of free to do it.

好吧，这是您要避免的一种情况，好吗？别这么做。实际上，有可能理解它，但也有可能让您无限困惑。所以只要确保这一点就行了。现在，如果您总是负数，或者总是朝一个方向，那就没问题，所以如果您总是正数，您总是朝另一个方向，但如果您将它们混淆，您就会陷入混乱。

Well, this is one case where you want to avoid it, OK? Just don’t do it. It is possible, actually, to make sense out of it, but it’s also possible to get yourself infinitely confused. So just make sure that. Now, it’s OK if u’ is always negative, or always going one way, so OK if u’ is always positive, you’re always going the other way, but if you mix them up you’ll get yourself mixed up.

我来举个例子。这个例子可能和我们上次做的差不多。我的意思是，当我们第一次做代换时。所以从 1 到 2 的积分，这次我会把 x^2 加上明确的极限放进去。抱歉，也许我把它叫做 x^3。x^3 + 2，比如说，我不知道，5 次方，x^2 dx。

Let me give you an example. The example will be maybe close to what we did last time. When we first did substitution, I mean. So the integral from 1 to 2, this time I’ll put in definite limits, of x^2 plus. sorry, maybe I call this x^3. x^3 + 2, let’s say, I don’t know, to the 5th power, x^2 dx.

所以这是一个积分的例子，我们之前会尝试用代换法来处理它。我们使用的代换法是 u = x^3 + 2。这正是我们在这里要做的。但我们也会考虑极限。第一步，就像任何代换或变量变化一样，就是这样。这样我们就可以填写我们之前做过的事情。

So this is an example of an integral that we would have tried to handle by substitution before. And the substitution we would have used is u = x^3 + 2. And that’s exactly what we’re going to do here. But we’re just going to also take into account the limits. The first step, as in any substitution or change of variables, is this. And so we can fill in the things that we would have done previously.

也就是说，这是积分，这是 u^5。然后因为这是 3x^2，我们看到这是 3。抱歉，让我们换一种写法。1/3 du = x^2 dx。这就是我要在这里代入的因数。所以这是 1/3 du，它取代了那个。但现在有一个额外的特征。额外的特征是极限。所以这里，实际上是伪装的，因为，现在这非常重要。

Which is that this is the integral and this is u^5. And then because this is 3x^2, we see that this is 3. Sorry, let’s write it the other way. 1/3 du = x^2 dx. So that’s what I’m going to plug in for this factor here. So here’s 1/3 du, which replaces that. But now there’s the extra feature. The extra feature is the limits. So here, really in disguise, because, and now this is incredibly important.

这就是我们使用 dx 和 du 符号的原因之一。我们想提醒自己积分涉及哪个变量。尤其是如果你是命名变量的人，你可能会在这方面感到困惑。

This is one of the reasons why we use this notation dx and du. We want to remind ourselves which variable is involved in the integration. And especially if you’re the one naming the variables, you may get mixed up in this respect.

所以你必须知道哪个变量在 1 和 2 之间变化。答案是，x 是在 1 和 2 之间变化的变量。所以，虽然我没有写出它，但它隐藏在了这个小符号中。这提醒我们哪个变量。当你学习多变量微积分时，你会发现这一点非常重要。当有许多变量在周围浮动时。所以这是一个非常重要的区别。

So you must know which variable is varying between 1 and 2. And the answer is, it’s x is the one that’s varying between 1 and 2. So in disguise, even though I didn’t write it, it was contained in this little symbol here. This reminded us which variable. You’ll find this amazingly important when you get to multivariable calculus. When there are many variables floating around. So this is an incredibly important distinction to make.

现在，我们这里有一个极限。但当然，它现在应该是相对于 u 而言的。所以我们需要计算那些相应的极限。事实上，我在这里代入 u_1 将等于我代入 x = 1 的值，即 1^3 + 2，也就是 3。然后 u_2 是 2^3 + 2，等于 10，对吧？

So now, over here we have a limit. But of course it’s supposed to be with respect to u, now. So we need to calculate what those corresponding limits are. And indeed it’s just, I plug in here u_1 is going to be equal to what I plug in for x = 1, that’s going to be 1^3 + 2, which is 3. And then u_2 is 2^3 + 2, which is equal to 10, right?

8 + 2 = 10。所以这是 u^5 1/3 du 从 3 到 10 的积分。现在我可以完成这个问题了。这是 1/18 u^6，从 3 到 10。这是此类代换中最常见的错误。

8 + 2 = 10. So this is the integral from 3 to 10, of u^5 1/3 du. And now I can finish the problem. This is 1/18 u^6, from 3 to 10. And this is where the most common mistake occurs in substitutions of this type.

也就是说，如果你忽略这一点，在这里插入 1 和 2，你会想，哦，我应该把它放在 1 和 2 上。但实际上，它应该是我们感兴趣的 u 值，下限是 u = 3，上限是 u = 10。所以这些在这里被抑制了。但这些是我们想要的。所以，我们开始吧。

Which is that if you ignore this, and you plug in these 1 and 2 here, you think, oh I should just be putting it at 1 and 2. But actually, it should be, the u value that we’re interested in, and the lower limit is u = 3 and u = 10 is the upper limit. So those are suppressed here. But those are the ones that we want. And so, here we go.

这是 1/18 倍，这是一个荒谬的数字，我不会计算。10^6。3^6。是的，问题。学生：教授：所以，如果你想做一些你担心符号变化的事情，正确的策略是，你建议的方法是有效的。事实上，我现在要举一个例子。但正确的策略是把它分成几部分。u' 有一个符号或另一个符号，好吗？让我给你举个例子。

It’s 1/18 times some ridiculous number which I won’t calculate. 10^6. 3^6. Yes, question. STUDENT: PROFESSOR: So, if you want to do things with where you’re worrying about the sign change, the right strategy is, what you suggested works. And in fact I’m going to do an example right now on this subject. But, the right strategy is to break it up into pieces. Where u’ has one sign or the other, OK? Let me show you an example.

哪里出错了。我会告诉你如何处理，大致来说。以下是我们的警告。假设你正在从 1 到 1 积分，x^2 dx。这是一个例子。你很想代入 u = x^2。现在，当然，我们知道如何积分。但让我们假装我们很固执，想使用代换。然后我们有 du = 2x dx。

Where things go wrong. And I’ll tell you how to handle it, roughly. So here’s our warning. Suppose you’re integrating from 1 to 1, x^2 dx. Here’s an example. And you have the temptation to plug in u = x^2. Now, of course, we know how to integrate this. But let’s just pretend we were stubborn and wanted to use substitution. Then we have du = 2x dx.

现在，如果我尝试建立对应关系，请注意极限是 u_1 = ( 1)^2，这是下限。而 u_2 是上限。那是 1^2，也等于 1。两个极限都是 1。所以这是从 1 到 1。无论它是什么，我们都知道它会是 0。但我们知道这不是 0。这是正量的积分。

And now if I try to make the correspondence, notice that the limits are u_1 = ( 1)^2, that’s the bottom limit. And u_2 is the upper limit. That’s 1^2, that’s also equal to 1. Both limits are 1. So this is going from 1 to 1. And no matter what it is, we know it’s going to be 0. But we know this is not 0. This is the integral of a positive quantity.

曲线下的面积将为正面积。所以这是一个正量。它不能为 0。如果你真的把它代入，它看起来同样奇怪。你把这个 u 代入这里，然后，这就是 u^2。然后代入 dx，你会写成 dx = 1/(2x) du。然后你可以把它写成这样。

And the area under a curve is going to be a positive area. So this is a positive quantity. It can’t be 0. If you actually plug it in, it looks equally strange. You put in here this u and then, so that would be for the u^2. And then to plug in for dx, you would write dx = 1/(2x) du. And then you might write that as this.

所以我应该在这里输入这个量。这是一个完全没问题的积分。它有一个值，我的意思是，它就是它。它是 0。所以这当然不是真的。原因是 u 等于 x^2，而 u'(x) 等于 2x，如果 x 为正，则为正，如果 x 为负，则为负。这就是给我们带来麻烦的符号变化。

And so what I should put in here is this quantity here. Which is a perfectly OK integral. And it has a value, I mean, it’s what it is. It’s 0. So of course this is not true. And the reason is that u was equal to x^2, and u’(x) was equal to 2x, which was positive for x positive, and negative for x negative. And this was the sign change which causes us trouble.

如果我们把它分成两半，那么就没问题了，你就可以使用它了。现在，有一个错误。这基本上就是你所说的。也就是说，如果你非常小心，在做这件事时就有可能看到这种情况发生。这个过程有一个错误，错误发生在过渡中。这是一个错误。

If we break it off into its two halves, then it’ll be OK and you’ll be able to use this. Now, there was a mistake. And this was essentially what you were saying. That is, it’s possible to see this happening as you’re doing it if you’re very careful. There’s a mistake in this process, and the mistake is in the transition. This is a mistake here.

也许我今天还没有用过红色，所以我得在这里用点红色。天哪。这里不对。这一步不对。那么为什么不对呢？它不正确的原因是标准原因。也就是说，x = u 的正负平方根。如果你坚持一边或另一边，你就会得到一个连贯的公式。

Maybe I haven’t used any red yet today, so I get to use some red here. Oh boy. This is not true, here. This step here. So why isn’t it true? It’s not true for the standard reason. Which is that really, x = plus or minus square root of u. And if you stick to one side or the other, you’ll have a coherent formula for it.

其中一个是正数，另一个是负数，当你把它分成几部分时，它就会起作用。所以你可以这样做。但这很麻烦。所以我避免这样做。只在逆函数定义明确的地方这样做。函数要么稳步上升，要么稳步下降。

One of them will be the plus and one of them will be the minus and it will work out when you separate it into its pieces. So you could do that. But this is a can of worms. So I avoid this. And just do it in a place where the inverse is well defined. And where the function either moves steadily up or steadily down.

Lec 20 | MIT 18.01 单变量微积分，2007 年秋季

Lec 20 | MIT 18.01 Single Variable Calculus, Fall 2007

16 年前 (2009 年 8 月 13 日) — 49:30 https://youtube.com/watch?v=Pd2xP5zDsRw

16 years ago (Aug 13, 2009) — 49:30 https://youtube.com/watch?v=Pd2xP5zDsRw

以下内容根据 Creative Commons 许可提供。您的支持将帮助 MIT OpenCourseWare 继续免费提供高质量的教育资源。要捐款或查看数百门 MIT 课程的其他材料，请访问 MIT OpenCourseWare，网址为 ocw.mit.edu。教授：今天开始之前，我想提醒您，我需要在黑板上至少写两遍微积分基本定理。

The following content is provided under a Creative Commons license. Your support will help MIT OpenCourseWare continue to offer high quality educational resources for free. To make a donation, or to view additional materials from hundreds of MIT courses, visit MIT OpenCourseWare at ocw.mit.edu. PROFESSOR: To begin today I want to remind you, I need to write it down on the board at least twice, of the fundamental theorem of calculus.

我们称其为 FTC 1，因为它是基本定理的第一个版本。今天我们将讨论另一个版本，即第二个版本。它的内容是：如果 F' = f，则 f (x) dx = F ( b) F ( a) 从 a 到 b 的积分。这就是微积分基本定理。我们上次使用它的方式是，它用于求积分。

We called it FTC 1 because it’s the first version of the fundamental theorem. We’ll be talking about another version, called the second version, today. And what it says is this: If F’ = f, then the integral from a to b of f (x) dx = F ( b) F ( a). So that’s the fundamental theorem of calculus. And the way we used it last time was, this was used to evaluate integrals.

毫不奇怪，我们就是这样使用的。但今天，我想反转一下这个观点。我们将反向阅读这个等式，并以这种方式写出它。我们将使用 f 来理解大写 F。或者换句话说，导数。理解函数。这就是我想提出的反转观点。我们将以各种方式来阐述这一点。

Not surprisingly, that’s how we used it. But today, I want to reverse that point of view. We’re going to read the equation backwards, and we’re going to write it this way. And we’re going to use f to understand capital F. Or in other words, the derivative. To understand the function. So that’s the reversal of point of view that I’d like to make. And we’ll make this point in various ways.

因此，关于 F 的信息，关于 F' 的信息为我们提供了关于 F 的信息。现在，由于存在关于中值定理的问题，我将首先通过比较微积分基本定理和中值定理来说明这一点。因此，我们将把微积分基本定理与我们所说的中值定理进行比较。为了做到这一点，我将介绍几个符号。

So information about F, about F’gives us information about F. Now, since there were questions about the mean value theorem, I’m going to illustrate this first by making a comparison between the fundamental theorem of calculus and the mean value theorem. So we’re going to compare this fundamental theorem of calculus with what we call the mean value theorem. And in order to do that, I’m going to introduce a couple of notations.

我将 delta F 写为 F ( b ) F ( a)。另一个极富想象力的符号是 delta x = b a。这是 f 的变化，这是 x 的变化。然后，这个基本定理可以写成，当然，就在上面那个公式。这是 delta F 的公式。这就是我们所说的微积分基本定理。我现在要除以 delta x。

I’ll write delta F as F ( b ) F ( a). And another highly imaginative notation, delta x = b a. So here’s the change in f, there’s the change in x. And then, this fundamental theorem can be written, of course, right up above there is the formula. And it’s the formula for delta F. So this is what we call the fundamental theorem of calculus. I’m going to divide by delta x, now.

如果我除以 delta x，结果就等于 1 / ba 乘以 f ( x) dx 从 a 到 b 的积分。所以我刚刚重写了这里的公式。右边的这个表达式相当重要。这是 f 的平均值。这是 f 的平均值。 

And If I divide by delta x, that’s the same thing as 1 / b a times the integral from a to b of f ( x) dx. So I’ve just rewritten the formula here. And this expression here, on the right hand side, is a fairly important one. This is the average of f. That’s the average value of f. 

现在，这将允许我比较均值定理（我们尚未在此说明）和基本定理。我将以不等式的形式进行。因此，我将在中间位置放置基本定理。它表示，此符号中的 delta F 等于，如果我再次乘以 delta x，我可以将其写为 F 的平均值。

Now, so this is going to permit me to make the comparison between the mean value theorem, which we don’t have stated yet here. And the fundamental theorem. And I’ll do it in the form of inequalities. So right in the middle here, I’m going to put the fundamental theorem. It says that delta F in this notation is equal to, well if I multiply by delta x again, I can write it as the average of F.

所以我在这里把它写成 F' 的平均值。乘以 delta x。所以我们这里有一个因子，它是 F' 的平均值或小 f 的平均值，它们是同一个东西。然后我再次乘以它。所以我把它放在红框里。这里。这不是大 F 的平均值。所以问题是，为什么这是小 f 的平均值而不是大 F 的平均值。

So I’m going to write it as the average of F’ here. Times delta x. So we have this factor here, which is the average of F’or the average of little f, it’s the same thing. And then I multiplied through again. So I put the thing in the red box. Here. Isn’t what the average of big F. So the question is, why is this the average of little f rather than the average of big F.

因此，函数的平均值是典型值。例如，如果小 f 是常数，小 f 是常数，那么这个积分将是，所以问题是为什么这是平均值。我会花一点时间来解释这一点。但我想我会在这里解释。因为我要把它擦掉。所以平均值的概念如下。

So the average of a function is the typical value. If, for example, little f were constant, little f were constant, then this integral would be, so the question is why is this the average. And I’ll take a little second to explain that. But I think I’ll explain it over here. Because I’m going to erase it. So the idea of an average is the following.

例如，假设 a = 0 且 b = n。因此，我们可以对从 1 到 n 的函数求和。现在，这将是从 1 到 n 的值的总和。但平均值是，我们在这里除以 n。所以这是平均值。这是一种黎曼和，表示 f (x) dx 从 0 到 n 的积分。

For example, imagine that a = 0 and b = n, let’s say for example. And so we might sum the function from 1 to n. Now, that would be the sum of the values from 1 to n. But the average is, we divide by n here. So this is the average. And this is a kind of Riemann sum, representing the integral from 0 to n, of f (x) dx.

其中增量 delta x 为 1。所以这是平均值的概念。但这是连续设置而不是离散设置。而左边是 f 的变化。大写 F。这是小写 f 的平均值。所以平均值是一个总和。它就像一个积分。

Where the increment, delta x, is 1. So this is the notion of an average value here. But in the continuum setting as opposed to the discrete setting. Whereas what’s on the left hand side is the change in f. The capital F. And this is the average of the little f. So an average is a sum. And it’s like an integral.

换句话说，我在这里说的是，f 的变化是其无穷小变化乘以时间流逝量的平均值，如果你愿意的话。所以这是基本定理的陈述。只是重写了一下。完全符合我在那里写的内容。但我乘以了 delta x。现在，让我将其与均值定理进行比较。均值定理也是一个方程。

So, in other words what I have here is that the change in f is the average of its infinitesimal change times the amount of time elapsed, if you like. So this is the statement of the fundamental theorem. Just rewritten. Exactly what I wrote there. But I multiplied back by delta x. Now, let me compare this with the mean value theorem. The mean values theorem also is an equation.

均值定理说这等于 F' (c) delta x。现在，我骗了你。我在这里用大写字母 F 来使类比更清楚。但字母的作用对于过渡到这种比较很重要。我们在这里讨论的是函数大写字母 F。以及它的导数。现在，这是真的。所以现在我说这个东西相当具体。

The mean value theorem says that this is equal to F’ (c) delta x. Now, I pulled a fast one on you. I used capital F’s here to make the analogy clear. But the role of the letter is important to make the transition to this comparison. We’re talking about the function capital F here. And its derivative. Now, this is true. So now I claim that this thing is fairly specific.

而不幸的是，这个有点模糊。模糊的原因在于 c 只是在区间的某个地方。所以某个 c，抱歉，这是某个 c，在 a 和 b 之间。所以实际上，由于我们不知道这个东西在哪里，我们不知道它是哪个值，所以我们不能说它是什么。我们能做的就是肯定地说它小于最大值。

Whereas this, unfortunately, is a little bit vague. And the reason why it’s vague is that c is just somewhere in the interval. So some c sorry, this is some c, in between a and b. So really, since we don’t know where this thing is, we don’t know which of the values it is, we can’t say what it is. All we can do is say well for sure it’s less than the largest value.

假设，（F' 的最大值）delta x。而我们唯一可以肯定的是，另一端它小于或等于，对不起，它大于或等于，（F' 的最小值）delta x。在相同的间隔内。这比 0 小于，对不起，a < x < b。所以这意味着微积分基本定理是一个更具体的东西。事实上，它给出了相同的结论。

Say, (the maximum of F’ ) delta x. And the only thing we can say for sure on the other end is that it’s less than or equal to sorry, it’s greater than or equal to, (the minimum of F’ ) delta x. Over that same interval. This is over 0 less than sorry, a < x < b. So that means that the fundamental theorem of calculus is a much more specific thing. And indeed it gives the same conclusion.

它比中值定理强得多。它比中值定理好得多。事实上，一旦我们有了积分，我们就可以抛弃中值定理。我们不想要它。它太简单了。而我们拥有的是更复杂的东西，我们可以使用它。就是这个。所以很明显，如果这是平均值，平均值小于最大值。

It’s much stronger than the mean value theorem. It’s way better than the mean value theorem. In fact, as soon as we have integrals, we can abandon the mean value theorem. We don’t want it. It’s too simple minded. And what we have is something much more sophisticated, which we can use. Which is this. So it’s obvious that if this is the average, the average is less than the maximum.

所以很明显，得出这个结论也同样有效。这里最小值也是一样。好吧，平均值总是大于最小值，小于最大值。所以这就是联系，如果你愿意的话。我将通过讨论你在考试中遇到的问题来进一步阐述。所以有一道考试 2 的问题。

So it’s obvious that it works just as well to draw this conclusion. And similarly over here with the minimum. OK, the average is always bigger than the minimum and smaller than the max. So this is the connection, if you like. And I’m going to elaborate just one step further by talking about the problem that you had on the exam. So there was an Exam 2 problem.

我将向你们展示如何使用均值定理以及如何使用积分。但我必须使用大写 F 这个符号。大写 F'与小写 f 相对，小写 f 就是你们考试时的符号。所以我们遇到了这种情况。这些是问题的给定条件。

And I’ll show you how it works using the mean value theorem and how it works using integrals. But I’m going to have to use this notation capital F. So capital F’as opposed to the little f, which was what was the notation that was on your exam. So we had this situation here. These were the givens of the problem.

那么问题是，中值定理说，或者说暗示，如果你愿意的话，它没有说出来，但它暗示了这一点。暗示 a < 大写 F ( 4) < b，其中 a 和 b 是多少？让我们看看它说了什么。嗯，中值定理说 F( 4) F (0) = F' ( c)( 4 0)。这是 (F') delta x，这是 x 的变化。

And then the question was, the mean value theorem says, or implies, if you like, it doesn’t say it, but it implies it. Implies a < capital F ( 4) < b, for which a and b? So let’s take a look at what it says. Well, the mean value theorem says that F( 4) F (0) = F’ ( c)( 4 0). This is this (F’) delta x, this is the change in x.

这与 (1 / 1 + c )( 4) 相同。因此，这个数的值域是从 (1 / 1 加 0)( 4)，也就是 4。到，这是最大值，到它得到的最小值，也就是 (1 / 1 + 4)( 4)。这就是范围。因此结论是 F (4) f ( 0 ) 介于，让我们看看。

And that’s the same thing as (1 / 1 + c )( 4). And so the range of values of this number here is from (1 / 1 plus 0)( 4), that’s 4. To, that’s the largest value, to the smallest that it gets, which is (1 / 1 + 4)( 4). That’s the range. And so the conclusion is that F (4) f ( 0 ) is between, well, let’s see.

它介于 4 和 4/5 之间。下面这两个数字是什么？如果你还记得 F (0) 是 1，那么它与 F (4) 相同，介于 5 和 9/5 之间。这就是你在考试中应该解决的问题。另一方面，让我们与你使用微积分基本定理的方法进行比较。使用微积分基本定理，我们有以下公式。

It’s between 4 and 4/5. Which are those two numbers down there. And if you remember that F ( 0) was 1, this is the same as F ( 4), is between 5 and 9/5. So that’s the way that you were supposed to solve the problem on the exam. On the other hand, let’s compare to what you would do with the fundamental theorem of calculus. With the fundamentals theorem of calculus, we have the following formula.

F(4) F(0) = dx/1+x 从 0 到 4 的积分。这就是基本定理所说的。现在我声称我们可以通过一个非常基本的观察得到这些相同类型的结果。这实际上与我在这里得出的观察结果相同，即平均值小于或等于最大值。也就是说，这个最大值是多少，让我们看看。

F( 4) F ( 0) = the integral from 0 to 4 of dx / 1 + x. That’s what the fundamental theorem says. And now I claim that we can get these same types of results by a very elementary observation. It’s really the same observation that I made up here, that the average is less than or equal to the maximum. Which is that the biggest this can ever be is, let’s see.

当 x 为 0 时，它的最大值是 1。所以它能达到的最大值是这个。它等于 4。对吧？另一方面，它能达到的最小值是这个。它能达到的最小值是 1/5 dx 从 0 到 4 的积分。因为这是被积函数取的最小值。

The biggest it is when x is 0, that’s 1. So the biggest it ever gets is this. And that’s equal to 4. Right? On the other hand, the smallest it ever gets to be, it’s equal to this. The smallest it ever gets to be is the integral from 0 to 4 of 1/5 dx. Because that’s the lowest value that the integrand takes.

当 x = 4 时，它是 1/5。这等于 4/5。现在，有一个小细节，那就是我们实际上知道这是某个矩形的面积，而这个严格小于这个。我们知道这些不等式实际上是严格的。但这是一个次要问题。当然我们不会密切关注。但现在，让我向你们展示这在几何上是什么样子。

When x = 4, it’s 1/5. And that’s equal to 4/5. Now, there’s a little tiny detail which is that really we know that this is the area of some rectangle and this is strictly smaller. And we know that these inequalities are actually strict. But that’s a minor point. And certainly not one that we’ll pay close attention to. But now, let me show you what this looks like geometrically.

因此，从几何学上讲，我们将其解释为曲线下的面积。这是曲线 y = 1/1 + x 的一部分。它从这里的 0 开始，一直上升到 4。我们做出的第一个估计值，也就是上限，是通过将其限制在这里的大矩形中。我们将它与常数函数进行比较，常数函数始终为 1。

So geometrically, we interpret this as the area under a curve. Here’s a piece of the curve y = 1/1 + x. And it’s going up to 4 and starting at 0 here. And the first estimate that we made; that is, the upper bound, was by trapping this in this big rectangle here. We compared it to the constant function, which was 1 all the way across.

这是 y = 1。然后我们还用位于底部的函数从下方捕获它。这就是 y = 1/5。这实际上是，这些东西是最简单的黎曼和。有点傻乎乎的黎曼和。这是一个带有一个矩形的黎曼和。这是最简单的一个。所以这是一个非常非常粗略的估计。你可以看到它差得很远。

This is y = 1. And then we also trapped it from underneath by the function which was at the bottom. And this was y = 1/5. And so what this really is, these things are the simplest possible Riemann sum. Sort of a silly Riemann sum. This is a Riemann sum with one rectangle. This is the simplest possible one. And so this is a very, very crude estimate. You can see it misses by a mile.

较大值和较小值相差 5 倍。但这个叫做，这个是下黎曼和。这个小于我们的实际积分。小于上黎曼和。现在你应该已经在家庭作业中看过那些上和和和了。所以它只是下面的矩形和上面的矩形。

The larger and the smaller values are off by a factor of 5. But this one is called the, this one is the lower Riemann sum. And that one is less than our actual integral. Which is less than the upper Riemann sum. And you should, by now, have looked at those upper and lower sums on your homework. So it’s just the rectangles underneath and the rectangles on top.

因此，此时，我们可以完全放弃中值定理。因为我们有更好的方法来处理事物。如果我们将事物分成更多的矩形，我们将获得更好的数值近似值。如果我们使用简单的积分表达式，我们将能够找出使用中值定理可以得到的任何界限。所以这不是中值定理的相关性。

So at this point, we can literally abandon the mean value theorem. Because we have a much better way of getting at things.
